{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"10 Projects to Get You to Your First Dev Job in 2020","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175442","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/first-dev-job-projects/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"10 Projects to Get You to Your First Dev Job in 2020\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583794075dev-job.png\" alt=\"10 Projects to Get You to Your First Dev Job in 2020\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583794075dev-job-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583794075dev-job.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>For those of you looking to break into the world of web development with your first dev job, the amount of <a href=\"https://roadmap.sh/frontend\">things you are expected to know</a> can be overwhelming: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, version control, build tools, frameworks, the command line. The list goes on …</strong></p> \n<p>But never fear! In this post I’d like to offer you a little guidance by outlining ten skills that will help you land your first dev job in 2020. For each skill, I’ll suggest a hands-on project to get you started and point you to appropriate resources on <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/library?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">SitePoint Premium</a> for further reading.</p> \n<p>Let’s dive in.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1gettoknowyourcodeeditor\">1. Get to Know Your Code Editor</h2> \n<p>As a coder, you’re going to be spending a lot of time in your editor of choice. That’s why you should make the effort to learn what it can do and how to configure it properly. The subject of which editor to use can quickly become controversial, but if you’re just starting out, I would encourage you to check out <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">VS Code</a> (or <a href=\"https://vscodium.com/\">VSCodium</a> if you care about privacy).</p> \n<p>VS Code ships with a lot of cool features, such as <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/tips-and-tricks#_emmet-syntax\">Emmet abbreviations</a>, <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/tips-and-tricks#_intellisense\">intellisense</a>, <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/tips-and-tricks#_default-keyboard-shortcuts\">various keyboard shortcuts</a> and <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/tips-and-tricks#_git-integration\">Git integration</a>. There are also <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/tips-and-tricks#_extensions\">hundreds (if not thousands) of extensions</a> that you can install to customize your workflow.</p> \n<h3 id=\"projectidea\">Project Idea</h3> \n<p>Install VS Code on your machine and commit to using it. Spend some time researching popular extensions for your language of choice and install at least three of these. You should also install <a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=esbenp.prettier-vscode\">Prettier</a> and configure it to format your code on save, as well as <a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=dbaeumer.vscode-eslint\">ESLint</a>, which will display JavaScript linting errors in VS Code’s console. For bonus points, you can print out the <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/tips-and-tricks#_keyboard-reference-sheets\">keyboard shortcut reference sheet for your platform</a> and attempt to memorize two or three shortcuts per week.</p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading\">Further Reading</h3> \n<p>By way of a reference, I would recommend <em><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/visual-studio-code-end-to-end-editing-and-debugging-tools-for-web-developers?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Visual Studio Code: End-to-End Editing and Debugging Tools for Web Developers</a></em>. This up-to-date guide covers all of the essential VS Code components, including the editing features of the workspace, advanced functionality such as code refactoring and key binding, and integration with Grunt, Gulp, npm, and other external tools. <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/visual-studio-code-end-to-end-editing-and-debugging-tools-for-web-developers/read/2?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Chapter Two</a>, which introduces you to the user interface, and <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/visual-studio-code-end-to-end-editing-and-debugging-tools-for-web-developers/read/9?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Chapter Nine</a>, on working with extensions, should be of particular interest.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2buildacontactform\">2. Build a Contact Form</h2> \n<p>If you’re building a web application, it’s only a matter of time until you encounter HTML forms. They’re a big part of the web experience, and they can be complicated. For example, you need to make them accessible, and you need to make sure they render well on different browsers and on smaller screens. It can also be a challenge to style them consistently without breaking their usability.</p> \n<p>Forms are a critical part of a visitor’s journey on your site. Even if your visitor is sold on what you have to offer, a broken or even a badly laid out form could be enough for them to abandon ship. That means you lose the conversion.</p> \n<h3 id=\"projectidea-1\">Project Idea</h3> \n<p>Build and style a contact form. Concentrate on the alignment of the form fields, a prominent <a href=\"https://11web.com/what-is-call-to-action/\">CTA</a>, and make sure the form previews well across browsers and devices. Try to include various form controls, such as <code>&lt;select&gt;</code> elements and check boxes, while keeping the layout simple and elegant.</p> \n<p>You might also like to upload your finished form to <a href=\"https://codepen.io/\">CodePen</a>, an online community for testing and showcasing user-created HTML, CSS and JavaScript code snippets. When applying for a job, a well-curated CodePen account could potentially serve as a mini portfolio.</p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-1\">Further Reading</h3> \n<p><em><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/form-design-patterns?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Form Design Patterns</a></em> offers ten recipes for different kinds of forms — registration forms, booking forms, login forms and more. Learn from the pros and find out how to make your forms both engaging and accessible to all. If you’re looking for a quick start with this project, I recommend reading the first part of the <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/form-design-patterns/read/1?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">first chapter</a>, which covers things such as labels, placeholders, styling and input types.</p> \n<h2 id=\"3becomeacquaintedwithclientsidevalidation\">3. Become Acquainted with Client-side Validation</h2> \n<p>You won’t get far as a web developer in 2020 without knowing JavaScript: it’s one of the most popular programming languages in the world and, frankly, a must-have skill.</p> \n<p>On the front end it’s used for a wide variety of tasks, such as making interactive elements for web pages (sliders, maps, charts, menus, chat widgets, etc.) and generally enhancing the user experience. One rather nice feature of the language is that it can manipulate the <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document_Object_Model\">DOM</a>, so as to offer users instant feedback on an action without needing to reload the page. This makes web pages feel snappier and more responsive.</p> \n<h3 id=\"projectidea-2\">Project Idea</h3> \n<p>In this project, you should take the contact form you built in step two and augment it with client-side validation.</p> \n<p>Using the <a href=\"https://www.w3schools.com/html/html_form_input_types.asp\">correct input types</a> will get you a lot of the way there, but also try to add some custom validation. You should display error messages in an intuitive way and avoid using alert boxes. And if all that sounds a bit too easy, why not add a field which asks a question to ensure that the user isn’t a bot.</p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-2\">Further Reading</h3> \n<p>If you’re new to the world of JavaScript programming, or would just like a quick and easy desk reference, then check out <em><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/javascript-novice-to-ninja-2nd-edition?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">JavaScript: Novice to Ninja, 2nd Edition</a></em>. This step-by-step introduction to coding in JavaScript will show you how to to solve real-world problems and develop richer web applications. You’ll want to pay particular attention to <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/javascript-novice-to-ninja-2nd-edition/read/8?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Chapter Eight</a>, which shows you how to use JavaScript to interact with an HTML form.</p> \n<h2 id=\"4makeacurrencyconverterusingthefixerapi\">4. Make a Currency Converter Using the Fixer API</h2> \n<p>In the past, JavaScript had a reputation as being a toy language — good for menus and animations, but not a lot else. And while that might have been the case in the early 2000s, in 2020 nothing could be further from the truth.</p> \n<p>Nowadays, entire apps are written in JavaScript. New tools and frameworks are introduced and developed at a rapid rate, and the language itself has undergone big changes since the arrival of ES2015 (aka ES6). It’s important you stay abreast of these changes, and have a good idea of what JavaScript is capable of and where it fits into the web development picture as a whole.</p> \n<h3 id=\"projectidea-3\">Project Idea</h3> \n<p>Make an app that allows users to convert one currency to another. Users should enter an amount, select the actual currency, select the desired currency and then the app should fetch the exchange rate from the <a href=\"https://fixer.io/\">Fixer API</a>. The user interface should be updated dynamically without any kind of page refresh.</p> \n<p>Use modern JavaScript features where you can. Complete the project using either vanilla JavaScript, or a library like <a href=\"https://reactjs.org/\">React</a> to handle the UI updates.</p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-3\">Further Reading</h3> \n<p><em><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/javascript-best-practice?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">JavaScript: Best Practice</a></em> is a collection of articles which take a look at modern JavaScript and how the language has evolved to allow you to write clean, maintainable, and reusable code. I would recommend reading the “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/javascript-best-practice/read/1?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Anatomy of a Modern JavaScript Application</a>”, “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/javascript-best-practice/read/6?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Using Modern JavaScript Syntax</a>” and “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/javascript-best-practice/read/7?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Flow Control in Modern JavaScript</a>”.</p> \n<h2 id=\"5designyourownportfoliowebsite\">5. Design Your Own Portfolio Website</h2> \n<p>In your career as a web developer, you’ll likely find yourself working alongside a designer on the same project. And while design and development can be considered separate disciplines, having a firm grasp of the design process will ease that relationship and stand you in good stead with your colleagues.</p> \n<p>Or perhaps you want to go it alone as a freelancer, taking projects from design to deployment. In this case, a generic-looking website won’t cut it. You’ll need to offer the client an eye-catching but also highly functional design that helps them achieve their business goals.</p> \n<h3 id=\"projectidea-4\">Project Idea</h3> \n<p>Design your own portfolio website — your place on the internet to present yourself and showcase your skills. Spend some time researching what makes a good portfolio design, then mock up a design of your own either with pencil and paper, or using a <a href=\"https://thedigitalprojectmanager.com/wireframe-tools/\">wireframing tool</a> of your choice.</p> \n<p>Design-wise, pay attention to the layout, the colors you’ll use, and the typography. Content-wise, consider which pages you’ll need (hint: you could include a contact form) and how to present both yourself and your work. There are <a href=\"https://undsgn.com/creating-a-portfolio-website-tips-on-how-to-do-it-right/\">lots of sites</a> around the Internet that will give you tips on what to include.</p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-4\">Further Reading</h3> \n<p>Ok, I get it. Design is hard. But it doesn’t need to be …</p> \n<p><em><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/the-principles-of-beautiful-web-design-3rd-edition/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">The Principles of Beautiful Web Design</a></em> is a fantastic book if you’re struggling with the design process. It will walk you through an example design, from concept to completion, teaching you a host of practical skills along the way.</p> \n<p>Start in Chapter One by reading about <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/the-principles-of-beautiful-web-design-3rd-edition/read/1/jz96kwyx?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">what makes good design</a> and take it from there. Personally, I read the book from cover to cover in the course of a week, but you could also dip into the other chapters and learn about layout, color, texture, typography and imagery at your leisure.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/first-dev-job-projects/?utm_source=rss\">10 Projects to Get You to Your First Dev Job in 2020</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/q9DR2dCHhU8\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 23 Mar 2020 23:00:37 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583794075dev-job.png","linkMd5":"f8a08f1ea36b75360076fe4f17d3a33c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn26@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-28-560_49ed378677d5bf9b.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":6694,"destBytes":6694,"author":"James Hibbard","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583794075dev-job.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn26@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-28-560_49ed378677d5bf9b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=q9DR2dCHhU8:BKzrmbsOQY8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn2@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-37-789_b89564bd2f185490.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/q9DR2dCHhU8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn11@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-39-951_6525cc75e30ecf39.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483290},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"An Introduction to MongoDB","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=162926","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/an-introduction-to-mongodb/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"An Introduction to MongoDB\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1581897968mongodb.png\" alt=\"Introduction to MongoDB\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1581897968mongodb-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1581897968mongodb.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>MongoDB is a cross-platform, open-source, NoSQL database, used by many modern Node-based web applications to persist data.</strong></p> \n<p>In this beginner-friendly tutorial, I’ll demonstrate how to install Mongo, then start using it to store and query data. I’ll also look at how to interact with a Mongo database from within a Node program, and also highlight some of the differences between Mongo and a traditional relational database (such as MySQL) along the way.</p> \n<h2 id=\"terminologyandbasicconcepts\">Terminology and Basic Concepts</h2> \n<p>MongoDB is a document-oriented database. This means that it doesn’t use tables and rows to store its data, but instead <em>collections</em> of JSON-like <em>documents</em>. These documents support embedded fields, so related data can be stored within them.</p> \n<p>MongoDB is also a schema-less database, so we don’t need to specify the number or type of columns before inserting our data.</p> \n<p>Here’s an example of what a MongoDB document might look like:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  _id: ObjectId(3da252d3902a),\n  type: \"Tutorial\",\n  title: \"An Introduction to MongoDB\",\n  author: \"Manjunath M\",\n  tags: [ \"mongodb\", \"compass\", \"crud\" ],\n  categories: [\n    {\n      name: \"javascript\",\n      description: \"Tutorialss on client-side and server-side JavaScript programming\"\n    },\n    {\n      name: \"databases\",\n      description: \"Tutorialss on different kinds of databases and their management\"\n    },\n  ],\n  content: \"MongoDB is a cross-platform, open-source, NoSQL database...\"\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>As you can see, the document has a number of <em>fields</em> (<code>type</code>, <code>title</code> etc.), which store <em>values</em> (“Tutorial”, “An Introduction to MongoDB” etc.). These values can contain strings, numbers, arrays, arrays of sub-documents (for example, the <code>categories</code> field), geo-coordinates and more.</p> \n<p>The <code>_id</code> field name is reserved for use as a primary key. Its value must be unique in the collection, it’s immutable, and it may be of any type other than an array.</p> \n<p><em>Tip: for those wondering what “JSON-like” means, internally Mongo uses something called <a href=\"http://bsonspec.org/\">BSON</a> (short for Bin­ary JSON). In practice, you don’t really need to know much about BSON when working with MongoDB.</em></p> \n<p>As you might guess, a <strong>document</strong> in a NoSQL database corresponds to a <strong>row</strong> in an SQL database. A group of documents together is known as a <strong>collection</strong>, which is roughly synonymous with a <strong>table</strong> in a relational database.</p> \n<p>Here’s a table summarizing the different terms:</p> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th>SQL Server</th> \n   <th>MongoDB</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td>Database</td> \n   <td>Database</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>Table</td> \n   <td>Collection</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>Row</td> \n   <td>Document</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>Column</td> \n   <td>Field</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>Index</td> \n   <td>Index</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p>If you’re starting a new project and are unsure whether to choose Mongo or a relational database such as MySQL, now might be a good time to read our tutorial <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/sql-vs-nosql-choose/\">SQL vs NoSQL: How to Choose</a>.</p> \n<p>With that said, let’s go ahead and install MongoDB.</p> \n<h2 id=\"installingmongodb\">Installing MongoDB</h2> \n<p><em>Note: if you’d just like to follow along with this tutorial without installing any software on your PC, there are a couple of online services you can use. <a href=\"https://mongoplayground.net/\">Mongo playground</a>, for example, is a simple sandbox to test and share MongoDB queries online.</em></p> \n<p>MongoDB comes in various editions. The one we’re interested in is the MongoDB Community Edition.</p> \n<p>The project’s home page has excellent documentation on installing Mongo, and I won’t try to replicate that here. Rather, I’ll offer you links to instructions for each of the main operating systems:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/install-mongodb-on-windows/\">Install MongoDB Community Edition on Windows</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/install-mongodb-on-os-x/\">Install MongoDB Community Edition on macOS</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/install-mongodb-on-ubuntu/\">Install MongoDB Community Edition on Ubuntu</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you use a non-Ubuntu-based version of Linux, you can check out <a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/installation/#mongodb-community-edition-installation-tutorials\">this page</a> for installation instructions for other distros. MongoDB is also normally available through the official Linux software channels, but sometimes this will pull in an outdated version.</p> \n<h3 id=\"postinstallationconfiguration\">Post Installation Configuration</h3> \n<p>Once you have MongoDB installed for your system, you might encounter this error:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">dbpath (/data/db) does not exist.\n Create this directory or give existing directory in --dbpath.\n See http://dochub.mongodb.org/core/startingandstoppingmongo\n</code></pre> \n<p>This means that Mongo can’t find (or access) the directory it uses to store its databases. This is pretty easy to remedy:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo mkdir -p /data/db\nsudo chown -R `id -un` /data/db\n</code></pre> \n<p>The first command creates the <code>data/db</code> directory. The second sets permissions so that Mongo can write to that directory.</p> \n<h3 id=\"installthecompassgui\">Install the Compass GUI</h3> \n<p>We’ll be using the command line in this tutorial, but MongoDB also offers a tool called Compass to connect to and manage your databases using a GUI.</p> \n<p>If you’re on Windows, Compass can be installed as part of the main Mongo installation (just select the appropriate option from the wizard). Otherwise, you can <a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/compass/master/install/\">download Compass for your respective OS here</a>.</p> \n<p>This is what it looks like:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1579526415MongoDB-Compass.png\" alt=\"Mongo DB Compass GUI\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"themongoshell\">The Mongo Shell</h3> \n<p>We can test our installation by opening the Mongo shell. You can do this by opening a terminal window and typing <code>mongo</code>.</p> \n<p><em>Note: this assumes that <code>&lt;mongodb installation dir&gt;/bin</code> is in your path. If for any reason this isn’t the case, change into the <code>&lt;mongodb installation dir&gt;/bin</code> directory and rerun the command.</em></p> \n<p>If you get an <code>Error: couldn't connect to server</code> error, you’ll need to start the Mongo server (in a second terminal window) with the command <code>mongod</code>.</p> \n<p>Once you’re in the Mongo shell, type in <code>db.version()</code> to see the version of MongoDB you’re running. At the time of writing, this should output <code>4.2.2</code>.</p> \n<p>Please note that you can exit the Mongo shell by running <code>quit()</code> and the Mongo daemon by pressing <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>C</kbd> at any time.</p> \n<p>Now let’s get acquainted with some MongoDB basics.</p> \n<h2 id=\"basicdatabaseoperations\">Basic Database Operations</h2> \n<p>Enter the Mongo shell if you haven’t already (by typing <code>mongo</code> into a terminal):</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">[mj@localhost ~]$ mongo\nMongoDB shell version v4.2.2\nconnecting to: mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017/?compressors=disabled&amp;gssapiServiceName=mongodb\nImplicit session: session { \"id\" : UUID(\"08a624a0-b330-4233-b56b-1d5b15a48fea\") }\nMongoDB server version: 4.2.2\n</code></pre> \n<p>Let’s start off by creating a database to work with. To create a database, MongoDB has a <code>use DATABASE_NAME</code> command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">&gt; use exampledb\nswitched to db exampledb\n</code></pre> \n<p>To display all the existing databases, try <code>show dbs</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">&gt; show dbs\n\nadmin          0.000GB\nconfig         0.000GB\nlocal          0.000GB\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <code>exampledb</code> isn’t in the list because we need to insert at least one document into the database. To insert a document, you can use <code>db.COLLECTION_NAME.insertOne({\"key\":\"value\"})</code>. Here’s an example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">&gt; db.users.insertOne({name: \"Bob\"})\n{\n   \"acknowledged\" : true,\n   \"insertedId\" : ObjectId(\"5a52c53b223039ee9c2daaec\")\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>MongoDB automatically creates a new <code>users</code> collection and inserts a document with the key–value pair <code>'name':'Bob'</code>. The ObjectId returned is the ID of the document inserted. MongoDB creates a unique ObjectId for each document on creation, and it becomes the default value of the <code>_id</code> field.</p> \n<p>Now we should be able to see our database:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">&gt;show dbs\nadmin          0.000GB\nconfig         0.000GB\nexampledb      0.000GB\nlocal          0.000GB\n</code></pre> \n<p>Similarly, you can confirm that the collection was created using the <code>show collections</code> command:</p> \n<pre><code>&gt; show collections\nusers\n</code></pre> \n<p>We’ve created a database, added a collection named <code>users</code> and inserted a document into it. Now let’s try dropping it. To drop an existing database, use the <code>dropDatabase()</code> command, as exemplified below:</p> \n<pre><code>&gt;db.dropDatabase()\n{ \"dropped\" : \"exampledb\", \"ok\" : 1 }\n</code></pre> \n<p><code>show dbs</code> confirms that the database was indeed dropped:</p> \n<pre><code>&gt; show dbs\nadmin          0.000GB\nconfig         0.000GB\nlocal          0.000GB\n</code></pre> \n<p>For more database operations, please consult the MongoDB reference page on <a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/command/\">database commands</a>.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/an-introduction-to-mongodb/?utm_source=rss\">An Introduction to MongoDB</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=_WbfHU3L3kk:Pb5QiEbuc_E:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=_WbfHU3L3kk:Pb5QiEbuc_E:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1581897968mongodb.png","linkMd5":"f070e28f116e1ac183ddc7ff115ae69b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn21@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-25-093_dbbee966c0ebd4d9.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":7684,"destBytes":7684,"author":"Manjunath M","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1581897968mongodb.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn21@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-25-093_dbbee966c0ebd4d9.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1579526415MongoDB-Compass.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn83@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-41-671_2ea8740132f434a8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=_WbfHU3L3kk:Pb5QiEbuc_E:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn8@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-39-234_d45dc1030bcfe370.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/_WbfHU3L3kk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn67@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-42-896_74d33e9d62c05120.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483300},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"30 Web Development Checklists Every Team Should Keep Handy","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175724","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/web-development-checklists/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"30 Web Development Checklists Every Team Should Keep Handy\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585614006web-dev-resources.png\" alt=\"30 Web Development Resources Every Team Should Keep Handy\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585614006web-dev-resources-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585614006web-dev-resources.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Building a website or app and making it available for the world is a complex business. A number of factors must come together to ensure the final product is successful. That means attracting and keeping visitors, meeting business goals, and minimizing problems. You can deliver a better product with the help of web development checklists.</strong></p> \n<p>As in everyday life, checklists can be a great organizational tool. They keep web development teams on track. They also ensure important tasks aren’t overlooked in the rush to complete a project.</p> \n<p>We searched the web for the most useful web development checklists. They cover everything from front-end and performance to SEO and marketing.</p> \n<h2 id=\"launchprelaunchpostlaunch\">Launch (Pre-launch/Post-launch)</h2> \n<h3 id=\"1theessentialprelaunchchecklistforyourwebsitehttpswebflowcomblogtheessentialprelaunchchecklistforyourwebsite\">#1 <a href=\"https://webflow.com/blog/the-essential-pre-launch-checklist-for-your-website\">The Essential Pre-launch Checklist for Your Website</a></h3> \n<p>A practical checklist that includes:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>design elements to look out for before launch</li> \n <li>functionality</li> \n <li>cross-browser testing</li> \n <li>SEO and content editing</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"2websitelaunchchecklisthttpswebsitelaunchchecklistcom\">#2 <a href=\"https://websitelaunchchecklist.com/\">Website Launch Checklist</a></h3> \n<p>This is a nice checklist tool built by Glasgow developer <a href=\"https://boag.online/\">Fraser Boag</a>.</p> \n<p>This tools lets you:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>check items as you complete each task</li> \n <li>grey out an item if it’s not applicable</li> \n <li>reset the checklist to get it ready for the next project.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Changes will be saved using cookies, so you can easily use the checklist throughout the duration of your project.</p> \n<p>The checklist covers content, benchmarks and performance, compatibility, accessibility, analytics, and more.&nbsp;Items in the list include, among other things:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>content editing</li> \n <li>navigation usability</li> \n <li>links testing</li> \n <li>GDPR compliance</li> \n <li>HTML and CSS validity</li> \n <li>styles and scripts minification</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>#3 <a href=\"https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/the-essential-launch-checklist-for-web-apps-and-mobile-apps-a0d52c6014b5/\">The Essential Launch Checklist for Web Apps and Mobile Apps</a></h3> \n<p>Ben Cheng presents “… a simple launch checklist for web and mobile apps … for product managers to quickly test performance of their apps.”</p> \n<p>Not only does the author include important tasks to complete before launching, he also explains the <em>why</em> behind his choices.</p> \n<p>The list presents items belonging to the following areas:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>performance</li> \n <li>security</li> \n <li>broken links</li> \n <li>compatibility</li> \n <li>SEO/social</li> \n <li>nice to haves, such as a 404 page, print stylesheets, and more.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"backenddatabaseandserverandsecurity\">Back-end (Database and Server) and Security</h2> \n<h3 id=\"4databasetestingchecklisthttpwwwprofessionalqacomdatabasetestingchecklist\">#4 <a href=\"http://www.professionalqa.com/database-testing-checklist\">Database Testing Checklist</a></h3> \n<p>For data persistence, you most likely need a database. The smooth running and integrity of the database are crucial to a fast and secure website or app. In this checklist, you’ll find items relating to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>database integrity</li> \n <li>stored procedures</li> \n <li>field validation</li> \n <li>constraints</li> \n <li>security</li> \n <li>transactions and more.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"5backendbestpracticeshttpsgithubcomfuturicebackendbestpractices\">#5 <a href=\"https://github.com/futurice/backend-best-practices\">Back-end Best Practices</a></h3> \n<p>These are stack-agnostic guidelines for best practices that encompass various back-end architectures. It’s comprehensive, including best practices on:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>data storage solutions</li> \n <li>security</li> \n <li>server environments</li> \n <li>application monitoring, and much more.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Towards the end of the document, you’ll find a responsibility checklist to organize your team’s work. You’ll also find a release checklist for the launch of your website or app.</p> \n<h2 id=\"frontend\">Front-end</h2> \n<h3 id=\"6afrontenddeploymentchecklisthttpsmediumcomjohn_fishermanafrontenddeploymentchecklist620574250a35\">#6 <a href=\"https://medium.com/@john_fisherman/a-front-end-deployment-checklist-620574250a35\">A Front-end Deployment Checklist</a></h3> \n<p>If you code landing pages, Fred Rocha’s deployment checklist is what you need. It’s succinct and to the point. It includes technical front-end items such as:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>checking performance</li> \n <li>validating the markup</li> \n <li>checking the console for JavaScript errors, and more.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"7thefrontendchecklistbydaviddiashttpsfrontendchecklistio\">#7 <a href=\"https://frontendchecklist.io/\">The Front-end Checklist by David Dias</a></h3> \n<p>It describes itself as “perfect for modern websites and meticulous developers”. This is an online interactive tool that allows you to enter the project’s URL and get a complete report on the following areas:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>head</li> \n <li>HTML</li> \n <li>webfonts</li> \n <li>CSS</li> \n <li>JavaScript</li> \n <li>images</li> \n <li>accessibility</li> \n <li>performance</li> \n <li>SEO</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The check is thorough and reveals which items in the various areas deserve high, medium or low priority.</p> \n<h2 id=\"reactappdeploymentandperformance\">React App Deployment and Performance</h2> \n<h3 id=\"8livereadinesschecklistofareactapphttpsmediumcomsouvikbasulivereadinesschecklistofareactappa5b1caeeda5a\">#8 <a href=\"https://medium.com/@souvikbasu/live-readiness-checklist-of-a-react-app-a5b1caeeda5a\">Live Readiness Checklist of a React App</a></h3> \n<p>This is a list of tasks you need to complete before your React app is ready for production.</p> \n<h3 id=\"9deathbyathousandcutsachecklistforeliminatingcommonreactperformanceissueshttpsbloglogrocketcomdeathbyathousandcutsachecklistforeliminatingcommonreactperformanceissues\">#9 <a href=\"https://blog.logrocket.com/death-by-a-thousand-cuts-a-checklist-for-eliminating-common-react-performance-issues/\">Death by a Thousand Cuts: A Checklist for Eliminating Common React Performance Issues</a></h3> \n<p>This is a six-item checklist with fun and clear explanations of how to go about implementing each of the tasks on the list for a blazing fast React app.</p> \n<h2 id=\"crossbrowsertesting\">Cross-browser Testing</h2> \n<h3 id=\"10crossbrowsertestingchecklistbeforegoinglivehttpswwwsitepointcomcrossbrowsertestingchecklist\">#10 <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/cross-browser-testing-checklist/\">Cross-browser Testing Checklist Before Going Live</a></h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/author/deeksha-agarwal/\">Deeksha Agarwal</a> offers a top-notch checklist to ensure your website or app works and looks as intended in all browsers and platforms on your local dev environment before the launch.&nbsp;Among the items you’ll find in this list are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>element alignment, and other HTML and CSS cross-browser issues</li> \n <li>font rendering</li> \n <li>API connections, and much more.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"11crossbrowsertestingchecklisthttpswwwsoftwaretestingmaterialcomcrossbrowsertestingchecklist\">#11 <a href=\"https://www.softwaretestingmaterial.com/cross-browser-testing-checklist/\">Cross-browser Testing Checklist</a></h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.softwaretestingmaterial.com/author/smrajkumar27gmail-com/\">Rajkumar</a> offers this handy checklist where he mentions all the items you need to test on multiple operating systems and browsers.</p> \n<h2 id=\"accessibility\">Accessibility</h2> \n<h3 id=\"12checklistofcheckpointsforwebcontentaccessibilityguidelines10httpswwww3orgtrwaiwebcontentfullchecklisthtml\">#12 <a href=\"https://www.w3.org/TR/WAI-WEBCONTENT/full-checklist.html\">Checklist of Checkpoints for Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 1.0</a></h3> \n<p>This W3C checklist includes all the items you need to consider so that more people can access and use your site. The items are grouped according to a priority number from one to three.</p> \n<p>It covers:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>providing text for non-text elements</li> \n <li>organizing documents so they can be read without stylesheets</li> \n <li>color contrast</li> \n <li>appropriate structure and elements for HTML documents</li> \n <li>expanding acronyms and abbreviations the first time they appear</li> \n <li>logical tab navigation, and more.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"13webaimswcag2checklisthttpswebaimorgstandardswcagchecklist\">#13 <a href=\"https://webaim.org/standards/wcag/checklist\">WebAIM’s WCAG 2 Checklist</a></h3> \n<p>This checklist presents WebAIM’s (Web Accessibility in Mind) accessibility recommendations for those seeking WCAG conformance.</p> \n<h3 id=\"14thea11yprojectchecklisthttpsa11yprojectcomchecklist\">#14 <a href=\"https://a11yproject.com/checklist/\">The A11Y Project Checklist</a></h3> \n<p>This A11Y Project checklist organizes items under the following headings:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>content</li> \n <li>global code</li> \n <li>keyboard</li> \n <li>images</li> \n <li>headings</li> \n <li>lists</li> \n <li>controls</li> \n <li>tables</li> \n <li>forms</li> \n <li>media</li> \n <li>appearance</li> \n <li>animation</li> \n <li>color contrast</li> \n <li>mobile/touch.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"15thedefinitivewebsiteaccessibilitychecklisthttpswwwwebfxcomblogwebdesignwebsiteaccessibilitychecklist\">#15 <a href=\"https://www.webfx.com/blog/web-design/website-accessibility-checklist/\">The Definitive Website Accessibility Checklist</a></h3> \n<p>This checklist is presented in a great, user-friendly table where items are grouped on the basis of their accessibility priority level in accordance with WCAG 2.0 guidelines:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Level A makes your website or app accessible to <strong>some</strong> users</li> \n <li>Level AA makes it available to <strong>almost all</strong> users</li> \n <li>Level AAA makes it available to <strong>all</strong> users.</li> \n</ul> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/web-development-checklists/?utm_source=rss\">30 Web Development Checklists Every Team Should Keep Handy</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/5-features-to-make-your-web-developer-portfolio-stand-out/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"5 Features to Make Your Web Developer Portfolio Stand Out\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\"
