Media</a>. Thank you for supporting the partners who make SitePoint possible.</em></p> \n<p>It’s not always easy to find and get new clients as a web developer.</p> \n<p>First, there’s the obstacle of how to translate what you do into a language that clients will understand. If you start talking about things like PHP, APIs, and wireframes, your prospects’ eyes will glaze over. They want to see for their own eyes what you can do.</p> \n<p>Secondly, how do you stand out from the crowd when most developers use the same tools and programming languages to build websites?</p> \n<p><strong>A well-crafted web developer portfolio site will solve both of these problems.</strong></p> \n<p>Below, I’m going to show you some web developer portfolios that are true standouts in the space. If you’re interested in building something as attractive and innovative as the sites below, I’ve also suggested some <a href=\"https://themes.muffingroup.com/?utm_source=sitepoint.com&amp;utm_medium=content&amp;utm_campaign=apr20\" rel=\"sponsored\">BeTheme pre-built sites</a> you can use to easily create your own.</p> \n<p>Let’s take a look.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/5-features-to-make-your-web-developer-portfolio-stand-out/?utm_source=rss\">5 Features to Make Your Web Developer Portfolio Stand Out</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=9Vy8S28g3kk:fdlY45wZOJU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=9Vy8S28g3kk:fdlY45wZOJU:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=9Vy8S28g3kk:fdlY45wZOJU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=9Vy8S28g3kk:fdlY45wZOJU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/9Vy8S28g3kk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Apr 2020 23:00:39 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15869985137.jpg","linkMd5":"04378c042dc04f40a83fa983c25837ac","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn89@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-27-407_c3b6e7821ac4c8b6.webp","destWidth":1666,"destHeight":1250,"sourceBytes":39656,"destBytes":39656,"author":"SitePoint Sponsors","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15869985137.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn89@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-27-407_c3b6e7821ac4c8b6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=9Vy8S28g3kk:fdlY45wZOJU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn71@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-42-286_a7f5b48580d1f88e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/9Vy8S28g3kk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn29@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-35-073_f166134eac1ad6a3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483275},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Host Static Sites for Free with an Automated Pipeline","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176736","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-host-static-sites-for-free-with-an-automated-pipeline/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Host Static Sites for Free with an Automated Pipeline\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595820731free-static-web-hosting.png\" alt=\"Hosting Static Jamstack Sites for Free with an Automated Pipeline\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595820731free-static-web-hosting-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595820731free-static-web-hosting.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Did you know that you can host static sites for free on a number of high-grade services? This doesn’t just save money, but also means you’re deploying to globally distributed CDNs and automating processes.</strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595294384Jamstack_Logo_Original.png\" /></p> \n<p><small><em>Provided: Netlify</em></small></p> \n<p>In a previous article, we <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/jamstack-tools-services-apis/\">reviewed 100 Jamstack tools, APIs and services to power your sites</a>, which included a lot of hosting services.</p> \n<p>In this article, we’ll get hands-on and show you how to host static sites with an automated pipeline for deployment.</p> \n<p>Does this sound complicated? It’s easier than you’d think.</p> \n<h2 id=\"freecloudhostingbutwithstringsattached\">Free Cloud Hosting, but with Strings Attached</h2> \n<p>You can actually host websites for free — even dynamic ones — with the <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/free/\">AWS Free Tier</a> (Amazon Web Services), the <a href=\"https://cloud.google.com/free\">GCP Free Tier</a> (Google Cloud Platform) and Windows Azure (with <a href=\"https://www.reddit.com/r/AZURE/comments/a66q63/how_to_get_150_azure_credits_for_free/\">some workarounds</a>).</p> \n<p>But when you go to give that a try, you’ll come across a number of conditions, fine print considerations, and implementation constraints:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>how much computing power do you need?</li> \n <li>your credit card number, please?</li> \n <li>where do you want to deploy to?</li> \n <li>is your account brand new?</li> \n <li>and not older than 1 year?</li> \n <li>actually, what services?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Often this is more a tryout than an actual freebie (hence the reason why <a href=\"https://docs.amplify.aws/lib/storage/getting-started/q/platform/js\">AWS Amplify Storage</a> is not included in this list). And while some power users might take advantage of the goodies, if you aren’t well acquainted with these platforms beforehand, you’ll find out that the learning curve to start using these services is very steep, and that for every cloud service you intend to use you’ll need to find out first in which way each provider reinvented the wheel before you can actually spin it into any free deployment.</p> \n<p>Let’s see now how a handful of smaller players rose to prominence with free hosting services that aren’t a hassle to implement and have fewer strings attached.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-host-static-sites-for-free-with-an-automated-pipeline/?utm_source=rss\">How to Host Static Sites for Free with an Automated Pipeline</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=7-Hx4dh2RiY:Ow0De2cxZw0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=7-Hx4dh2RiY:Ow0De2cxZw0:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=7-Hx4dh2RiY:Ow0De2cxZw0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=7-Hx4dh2RiY:Ow0De2cxZw0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/7-Hx4dh2RiY\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Jul 2020 18:23:40 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595820731free-static-web-hosting.png","linkMd5":"7b507d14614482649f98a2d100ba2b41","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn30@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-25-627_c4a14dc1cab2c93b.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":12416,"destBytes":12416,"author":"Lucero del Alba","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595820731free-static-web-hosting.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn30@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-25-627_c4a14dc1cab2c93b.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595294384Jamstack_Logo_Original.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn95@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-43-041_adbddd8db48491dd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=7-Hx4dh2RiY:Ow0De2cxZw0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn84@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-38-972_6a474c7823a79c19.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/7-Hx4dh2RiY":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn83@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-44-579_028efb975457ec3a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483250},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Make a Career Transition Into Web Development","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176339","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-make-a-career-transition-into-web-development/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Make a Career Transition Into Web Development\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592379114web-dev-job.png\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592379114web-dev-job-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592379114web-dev-job.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Over the past ten years, there has been an explosion of interest in web development.</strong></p> \n<p>The 2008–09 financial crisis caused millions of young adult workers to lose their jobs and rethink their entire careers from scratch. From the ashes of this crisis, web development has become the darling of the job market.</p> \n<p>An increased number of companies, small and large, have turned to the wonders of web development to disrupt or adapt to the new “web 2.0” environment. These companies know that without a web presence, their businesses are doomed to be ignored.</p> \n<p>The spike in interest in web development has led to millions of young adults thinking of it not just as a skill to learn, but as a career to adopt. But for those who have already gone through college and spent a life worth of savings to get their degree, switching their careers to web development seems like a tough proposition.</p> \n<p>If you’re in this position, the questions are hard. Do you have to start all over again, taking expensive and lengthy classes to learn the skills? Or can you jump ship from a traditional career to web development and still make it until you get a well-paying job?</p> \n<p>The answer is, no, you don’t have to go back to college to <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/21-steps-to-becoming-a-successful-web-developer/\">become a web developer</a>. And yes, you can transition to web development if you prepare yourself for it.</p> \n<p>People from all backgrounds have been able to switch to a career in web development. Their advice will shine a light for those who want to do the same without having to sacrifice everything in the way.</p> \n<h2 id=\"choosetherightselfeducationpath\">Choose the Right Self-education Path</h2> \n<p>To say that it is possible to become a web developer through self-education may have seemed like alchemy 20 years ago. In 2020, self-education appears to be the rule rather than the exception.</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://insights.stackoverflow.com/survey/2016#work\">2016 StackOverflow annual survey</a> found that almost 70% of its respondents considered themselves as “self-taught.” Whether they learned to code entirely on their own or partially is something the survey left out. However, it still shows the relevance self-education has for professional web developers.</p> \n<p>For someone who wants to become a developer, learning on their own is more of a pragmatic obligation than a moral one. Without a formal degree, self-education is the only path to acquire the skills necessary to launch a web development career.</p> \n<p>The question, however, shouldn’t be focused on whether self-education is a good idea or not. What truly matters, according to several developers, is to pick the right language and put all energies available into mastering it before focusing on a specific framework. It seems, unlike what the business saying goes, that it’s better to put all the eggs in one basket than to spread them out.</p> \n<p>For Lexis Hanson, a former finance professional turned developer, mastering a programming language first — one based on her needs — and focusing on frameworks and libraries second <a href=\"https://code.likeagirl.io/thoughts-on-becoming-a-self-taught-software-engineer-c8d8e7bde704?gi=d29f1405520b\">was critical</a> to her self education.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>[Mastering a programming language first] forced me to stay focused on getting extremely comfortable with vanilla JavaScript before diving into frameworks, which made that next step significantly easier.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Putting language over frameworks may be the smart decision, but it still doesn’t help to pick the right one. One solution that can shine a light on the issue is to <em>pick a personal project</em>. The specific technical needs required to fulfill your project will guide your choices better.</p> \n<p>One self-taught developer who’s in favor of this approach is Avi Flombaum. Instead of picking the first language that pops into a Google search, he <a href=\"https://medium.com/learn-love-code/what-i-wish-i-knew-before-teaching-myself-how-to-code-402cc31d566a\">explains</a>:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Beginners shouldn’t care about the languages they’re using. They should care that their chosen language matches their goals, if they’re getting expertise and depth and in it — and, of course, if they love using it.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>A personal project will foster your passion for programming, and it will help you decide on the language you should consider to build it. Some common ideas include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>a static website</li> \n <li>a basic app, like a to-do list</li> \n <li>an automation script</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you’re short of ideas, you can check the <a href=\"https://www.reddit.com/r/dailyprogrammer/\">r/DailyProgrammer</a> subreddit, which posts daily projects with a detailed background, challenges, and inputs to use.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923787101-reddit-1024x643.jpg\" alt=\"Reddit\" width=\"1024\" height=\"643\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176344\" /></p> \n<p>Another vital aspect to consider before settling on a specific language is to think about your natural problem-solving methodologies. How do you break down problems? How do you think about their solutions?</p> \n<p>In the case of Hanson, she wasn’t sure whether to choose a language based on object-oriented programming or functional programming. But instead of going with the wisdom of the crowds and picking a popular language, she thought about the way she solved problems in general. Based on that introspection, she chose the programming paradigm that best suited her (which happened to be JavaScript).</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Functional programming resonated with me (you might have other preferences), and I challenged myself to approach problems from a “functional-first” perspective. In my opinion, this forced me to think more flexibly about programming and how functions and components should “compose” with one another.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>As you learn the basics of a language, consider reading its documentation, especially if you’re already toying with a specific framework. At first, this may seem hard, but the more you practice your skills, and the more you read the documentation, the more sense it will all make.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923787382-angular-1024x425.jpg\" alt=\"Angular\" width=\"1024\" height=\"425\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176345\" /></p> \n<p>Vinicius Brasil <a href=\"https://hackernoon.com/how-to-learn-a-new-programming-language-faster-dc31ec8367cb\">recommends</a> using GitHub to find and read production code in the language you’re learning. He adds, “If you are confident to contribute, that’s even better.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923787693-angular-1024x773.jpg\" alt=\"Angular\" width=\"1024\" height=\"773\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176346\" /></p> \n<p>Whenever you get stuck, don’t panic. Web development is a friendly skill whose practitioners share solutions to common problems. Stack Overflow is the most popular place developers go to ask questions and share advice. And when you can’t seem to find a solution, remember: “<a href=\"https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=Google%20is%20your%20friend\">Google is your friend</a>.”</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923788004-stack-overflow-1024x603.jpg\" alt=\"Stack Overflow\" width=\"1024\" height=\"603\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176347\" /></p> \n<p>Among the many challenges self-educated developers often face is getting accustomed to the rather strange way of writing code. Many experienced developers will tell you that the way you write a string of code is as important as what that code is meant to do. The truthfulness of such a statement is a discussion of its own, and it has its merits, but for a beginner developer who’s learning on the side and with their own resources, writing perfect code is more of a luxury than a necessity, at least in the beginning.</p> \n<p>Such is the case of <a href=\"https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/google-not-learn-not-why-searching-can-be-better-than-knowing-79838f7a0f06/\">Jeremy Gunter</a>, whose “learn first, clean later” mentality became the greatest boon to his confidence during the early days of his self-education. His methodology consisted of using pseudo-code to make his code work and then Googling how they are supposed to be written.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Instead of going mental trying to remember method names, I focused on what action I needed to perform. When I wanted to add an item to the beginning of an array, I found it easier to google the phrase “add item to beginning of array JavaScript” than to try and use my own memory to differentiate between shift(), unshift(), and pop().</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Any experienced developer will probably grind their teeth at the idea of using pseudo-code over syntax. Still, for the self-educated folk, Gunter’s approach resembles more to Mark Zuckerberg’s “learn fast and break things” mantra than to Tim Peters’ “beautiful is better than ugly.”</p> \n<p>All in its time, Mr. Peters, all in its time.</p> \n<h2 id=\"buildanetwork\">Build a Network</h2> \n<p>College education is often seen as a mechanical process where a student acquires all the required knowledge to become a professional in their chosen field. Under this mentality, anything that doesn’t imply studying and memorizing technical concepts is secondary.</p> \n<p>This simplistic idea leaves a significant advantage that college-educated developers have over self-taught ones, and on which the latter must work if they want to be in an equal position to the former. That is, the <em>professional network</em> college provides to its students.</p> \n<p>A professional network is built upon a web of mentors, professors, job seekers, and classmates. Some of these people will eventually become colleagues, and some will act as referrals and references for job prospects, both critical elements to succeed in any professional career.</p> \n<p>To dismiss the importance that a network like this has over web developers is to undervalue one of the most prominent advantages colleges bring to their students. Thus, anyone who is considering switching to a career in web development must prioritize building this network while they develop their skillset.</p> \n<p>As a self-educated developer, you may not have professors or job seekers around you. The work, then, should be focused on building strong relationships with those developers who may help you in your journey.</p> \n<p>To start, you need to consider participating in local development events and meetups. Whether these meetings are general or language-specific isn’t important. What matters is that you proactively meet other people and become a part of the community.</p> \n<p>Nnena Ndukwe, a college dropout and former tanning consultant, <a href=\"https://codeburst.io/how-i-went-from-mopping-floors-at-a-tanning-salon-to-becoming-a-software-developer-7dc4d2e8d21a\">explains</a> the usefulness of attending meetups throughout her self-education journey:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Having these conversations about tech with people in the field helped me gain more knowledge about opportunities for work, organizations to volunteer for, and tech or social events to attend that would be fulfilling. One opportunity always leads to the next via networking.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>To prove her point, Nnenna says she got her first development job through a bootcamp she heard about in one of the meetups she participated in. Whether meetups generate jobs directly or indirectly isn’t relevant. The point is that they compound the opportunities available for switching to a web development career.</p> \n<p>The most popular site to find local meetups is Meetup.com, but you can also use Facebook events and Eventbrite. A quick search in any of these sites will bring you dozens of meetups in your area.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923788295-meetup-1024x529.jpg\" alt=\"MeetUp\" width=\"1024\" height=\"529\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176348\" /></p> \n<p>Just like Google is your friend when it comes to learning to code, you can also use it to find events in your area. You can use a general search query like “web development” plus your city, or a more specific one like “Python” (or any other language or framework you want) plus your city, and you’ll get many events close to you.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923788546-google-1024x928.jpg\" alt=\"Google\" width=\"1024\" height=\"928\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176349\" /></p> \n<p>You can both participate as an attendee and use the networking available to meet others who can help you, or you can give a talk on your self-taught process.</p> \n<p>Most attendees will be surprised and glad to meet someone who’s trying to make the switch without a degree. You may even meet others who happened to achieve your career switching goal and who can give you feedback and support on your journey.</p> \n<p>Another option to build a network is to participate in online communities. There are dozens of <a href=\"https://techbeacon.com/app-dev-testing/46-slack-groups-developers\">Slack chats for developers</a>, and these will provide you with a great deal of information about the latest news, ideas, and people to connect with. You can even search for developers in your area you can meet for a coffee.</p> \n<p>These events and meetups aren’t just useful for meeting colleagues. As Nnenna Ndukwe attests, they are also effective for meeting potential clients or employers as well.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-make-a-career-transition-into-web-development/?utm_source=rss\">How to Make a Career Transition Into Web Development</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Thh9E_7so9k:b-cDw2K8kd4:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Thh9E_7so9k:b-cDw2K8kd4:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Thh9E_7so9k:b-cDw2K8kd4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Thh9E_7so9k:b-cDw2K8kd4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/Thh9E_7so9k\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 16 Jun 2020 22:00:31 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592379114web-dev-job.png","linkMd5":"ca98f621de472d2541b4bd02a6ec334d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn45@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-27-222_74dd0377fa707c6a.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":6174,"destBytes":6174,"author":"Ivan Kreimer","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592379114web-dev-job.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn45@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-27-222_74dd0377fa707c6a.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923787101-reddit-1024x643.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923787382-angular-1024x425.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923787693-angular-1024x773.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923788004-stack-overflow-1024x603.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923788295-meetup-1024x529.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15923788546-google-1024x928.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Thh9E_7so9k:b-cDw2K8kd4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn76@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-44-554_de9b2a643806a7b3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/Thh9E_7so9k":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn32@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-37-737_9efdb43460ef3dca.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483262},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"The Complete Developer&#8217;s Guide to Windows Subsystem for Linux 2","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=173424","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wsl2-windows-terminal/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"The Complete Developer’s Guide to Windows Subsystem for Linux 2\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596512234windows-subsystem-linux-2.png\" alt=\"The Complete Guide to the Windows Subsystem for Linux 2\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596512234windows-subsystem-linux-2-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596512234windows-subsystem-linux-2.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>This tutorial demonstrates how to install, manage, and use a full Linux environment on your Windows 10 PC with WSL2. You’ll be running a Linux kernel and executing native applications while seamlessly sharing files and services with Windows code editors and browsers.</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"whyuselinux\">Why Use Linux?</h2> \n<p>Your host almost certainly uses Linux. It’s fast, open source, and runs the majority of web software including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>servers (Apache, NGINX, LiteSpeed, etc.)</li> \n <li>language runtimes (PHP, Python, Node.js, Ruby, etc.)</li> \n <li>utility libraries (image manipulation, ZIP creation, emailers, etc.)</li> \n <li>databases (MySQL, MongoDB, Redis, etc.)</li> \n <li>other dependencies (Elastic Search, RabbitMQ, proxies, etc.)</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Some of these dependencies may be available on Windows and macOS, but installing and maintaining identical versions is difficult. They’re often slower and you may encounter subtle differences which will not become apparent until you deploy.</p> \n<p>Some developers install Linux on their desktop, but that may not be viable if you regularly require non-Linux software such as Microsoft or Adobe products. Alternative options:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Use two PCs or dual boot on a single device. Switching between systems can be cumbersome.</li> \n <li>Run a Linux virtual machine (VM) using Hyper-V, VirtualBox, Parallels, WMware, or Vagrant. This requires considerable OS resources and reasonable IT knowledge. Sharing files between systems can be awkward.</li> \n <li>Run web applications in Docker containers. It’s another topic to learn and Docker itself runs natively on Linux. Both the Windows and macOS editions use Linux below the surface.</li> \n</ol> \n<h2 id=\"whatisthewindowssubsystemforlinux\">What is the Windows Subsystem for Linux?</h2> \n<p>The Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) lets developers run a Linux environment directly on Windows 10. It’s an unmodified OS, but highly integrated into Windows and without the overhead of a virtual machine.</p> \n<p>WSL1 was groundbreaking and translated Linux system calls to Windows equivalents. This could be slow and several features weren’t available. WSL2 uses Hyper-V virtual machine technology so Linux compatibility is excellent and file access is up to 20x faster than before.</p> \n<h2 id=\"windows10requirements\">Windows 10 Requirements</h2> \n<p>WSL2 is compatible with the Home, Pro, or Server editions of Windows but <em>not</em> Windows 10 S (although you can often upgrade to the Home edition for free).</p> \n<p>The Windows May 2020 update is essential — that’s version 2004 or above. Choose the <strong>Settings</strong> cog from the Start menu, then select <strong>System</strong> followed by <strong>About</strong>. The <strong>Windows specifications</strong> are shown at the bottom of the panel:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596503684windows-requirements.png\" alt=\"Windows specifications\" width=\"249\" height=\"155\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176895\" /></p> \n<p>The update has been slowly rolling out since the end of May 2020. If you have a version below 2004, you may be able to trigger the update by clicking the <strong>Check for updates</strong> button in <strong>Settings</strong>, then <strong>Update &amp; Security</strong>.</p> \n<p>If 2004 remains stubbornly unavailable, you may be able to download and install it manually from <a href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/software-download/windows10\">microsoft.com/software-download/windows10</a></p> \n<p>However, be aware some PCs report that version 2004 is currently unavailable in the <strong>Windows Update</strong> panel. You won’t be able to upgrade until Microsoft has released a fix for your device.</p> \n<h2 id=\"pcrequirements\">PC Requirements</h2> \n<p>WSL2 (and Hyper-V) require hardware virtualization support to be enabled in your BIOS.</p> \n<p><em>WARNING: <strong>fiddling with your BIOS settings can trash your PC!</strong> Be careful when making changes. Consult your manufacturer’s help pages or search for online advice about your specific make and model.</em></p> \n<p>Hardware virtualization will be active on most devices, but you can check by rebooting, and opening the BIOS panels — typically by hitting the <kbd>DEL</kbd>, <kbd>F2</kbd>, or <kbd>F10</kbd> key as the system starts. Look for <strong>Virtualization Technology</strong>, <strong>VTx</strong> or similar options. Ensure they are enabled, save, and reboot the device.</p> \n<p>Finally, ensure your <code>C:</code> drive has at least 1GB of spare disk space — ideally more. You may be able to free up some space in <strong>Settings</strong>, <strong>System</strong>, <strong>Storage</strong> or using the <strong>Disk clean-up</strong> tool in <strong>Windows Administrative Tools</strong>.</p> \n<p>At the time of writing, WSL2 will install Linux to your <code>C:</code> drive, although it’s possible to <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=173424#move-your-linux-disk-image\">move it elsewhere</a> after installation.</p> \n<h2 id=\"enablewsl2\">Enable WSL2</h2> \n<p>The <strong>Virtual Machine Platform</strong> and <strong>Windows Subsystem for Linux</strong> features must be enabled in <strong>Turn Windows features on or off</strong>. The panel can be accessed by hitting Start and typing <em>“features”</em> or from the <strong>Programs and Features</strong> icon in the classic Control Panel.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596503725windows-features.png\" alt=\"enable WSL2\" width=\"415\" height=\"368\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176896\" /></p> \n<p>Alternatively, you can execute the following commands in a Windows Powershell terminal run as an Administrator:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">dism.exe /online /enable-feature /featurename:Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux /all /norestart\ndism.exe /online /enable-feature /featurename:VirtualMachinePlatform /all /norestart\n</code></pre> \n<p>Reboot Windows 10, then enable WSL2 as the default by entering the following command in a Windows Powershell or command prompt:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">wsl --set-default-version 2\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"downloadlinux\">Download Linux</h2> \n<p>You can install any number of Linux distros from the <strong>Microsoft Store</strong> accessed in the Start menu. This includes Ubuntu, Debian, SUSE, Kali, and Alpine. Enter <em>“Linux”</em> in the search box:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596503767store.png\" alt=\"Microsoft Store\" width=\"1013\" height=\"611\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176897\" /></p> \n<p><strong>Ubuntu</strong> is a good choice unless you have specific requirements. The latest edition will be installed if you click the <strong>Ubuntu</strong> icon followed the <strong>Get</strong> button.</p> \n<p>The download could take a while depending on your network speed.</p> \n<h2 id=\"launchlinux\">Launch Linux</h2> \n<p>Following download, click the <strong>Launch</strong> button on the <strong>Microsoft Store</strong> app, or the new <strong>Ubuntu</strong> icon in the Start menu. This will complete the installation process and can take several minutes.</p> \n<p><em>Note: the first time you launch a WSL2 distro, you <strong>may</strong> see a message in the terminal about a kernel update. Copy the link into your browser, then download and install the update. You will need to launch Ubuntu again to continue with the installation.</em></p> \n<p>You’ll be prompted to enter a username and password. These are the credentials for Linux administration: <em>they are completely separate from your Windows username and password</em> (although choosing the same ones may be practical).</p> \n<p>Linux will eventually be ready and your terminal will show content similar to this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">Installing, this may take a few minutes...\nPlease create a default UNIX user account. The username does not need to match your Windows username.\nFor more information visit: https://aka.ms/wslusers\nEnter new UNIX username: ******\nNew password:\nRetype new password:\npasswd: password updated successfully\nInstallation successful!\nTo run a command as administrator (user \"root\"), use \"sudo &lt;command&gt;\".\nSee \"man sudo_root\" for details.\n\nWelcome to Ubuntu 20.04 LTS (GNU/Linux 4.19.104-microsoft-standard x86_64)\n\n * Documentation:  https://help.ubuntu.com\n * Management:     https://landscape.canonical.com\n * Support:        https://ubuntu.com/advantage\n\n  System information as of Mon Jul 6 12:07:38 BST 2020\n\n  System load:  0.27               Processes:             8\n  Usage of /:   0.4% of 250.98GB   Users logged in:       0\n  Memory usage: 0%                 IPv4 address for eth0: 172.21.232.173\n  Swap usage:   0%\n\n0 updates can be installed immediately.\n0 of these updates are security updates.\n\nThe list of available updates is more than a week old.\nTo check for new updates run: sudo apt update\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"updatelinux\">Update Linux</h2> \n<p>There are likely to be several Linux updates. To update Ubuntu, enter the following commands in the Linux terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo apt-get update\nsudo apt-get upgrade\nsudo apt-get dist-upgrade\nsudo apt-get autoremove\n</code></pre> \n<p>Other Linux distros will have a similar process, but check the documentation for assistance.</p> \n<h2 id=\"switchbetweenwsl1andwsl2\">Switch Between WSL1 and WSL2</h2> \n<p>Existing WSL1 distros can be converted to WSL2. Entering the following command in a Windows Powershell terminal to display the installed Linux distros and their WSL version:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">PS C:\\&gt; wsl --list --verbose\n\n  NAME    STATE    VERSION\n* Ubuntu  Running  1\n</code></pre> \n<p>(The * asterisk highlights the default Linux installation.)</p> \n<p>To switch <code>Ubuntu</code> to WSL2, enter:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">wsl --set-version Ubuntu 2\n</code></pre> \n<p>Similarly, to switch back to WSL1, enter:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">wsl --set-version Ubuntu 1\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"setadefaultlinuxdistribution\">Set a Default Linux Distribution</h2> \n<p>When you have multiple Linux distributions installed, one must be set as the default. It will be used when <code>wsl</code> is entered in a Windows Powershell terminal.</p> \n<p>To set the default distro, list your installations:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">wsl --list\n</code></pre> \n<p>and set a default with:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">wsl --setdefault &lt;DistributionName&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Ubuntu example: <code>wsl --setdefault Ubuntu</code>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"runlinuxasaspecificuser\">Run Linux as a Specific User</h2> \n<p>To run your default distribution as a specific user, enter the following command in a Windows Powershell terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">wsl --user &lt;username&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>A default user is defined <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=173424#launch-linux\">during installation</a> and you can create others. A <code>root</code> user is also created, but you should avoid using it under normal circumstances. <em>It’s too easy to enter a dangerous command!</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"moveyourlinuxdiskimage\">Move Your Linux Disk Image</h2> \n<p>The Linux disk image is installed on your <code>C:</code> drive. Optionally, you can move it to another drive to free up space. The following instructions presume you’ll move it to <code>D:\\wsl</code>.</p> \n<p>In a Windows Powershell terminal (<strong>not</strong> the Ubuntu terminal), enter <code>wsl --list</code> to view your Linux distributions, then export one by name to a back-up <code>.tar</code> file, e.g. <code>D:\\backup\\ubuntu.tar</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mkdir D:\\backup\nwsl --export Ubuntu D:\\backup\\ubuntu.tar\n</code></pre> \n<p>Unregister the same distribution to remove it from the <code>C:</code> drive:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">wsl --unregister Ubuntu\n</code></pre> \n<p>Enter <code>wsl --list</code> to verify the distribution has been removed.</p> \n<p>Import the backup into a new WSL2 distribution at another location, such as <code>D:\\wsl</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mkdir D:\\wsl\nwsl --import Ubuntu D:\\wsl\\ D:\\backup\\ubuntu.tar\n</code></pre> \n<p>Verify it has been successfully created by entering <code>wsl --list</code> and launching the <strong>Ubuntu</strong> app from the Start menu.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, Ubuntu will now use <code>root</code> as the default user. To use your own account, enter the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">ubuntu config --default-user &lt;yourname&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>where <code>&lt;yourname&gt;</code> is the username you defined <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=173424#launch-linux\">during installation</a>.</p> \n<p>Presuming all has gone well, you can safely delete the backup file (<code>D:\\backup\\ubuntu.tar</code>).</p> \n<h2 id=\"installwindowsterminal\">Install Windows Terminal</h2> \n<p>To launch the Linux terminal, you can use the Ubuntu icon, enter <code>wsl</code> or <code>bash</code> in Powershell, or use any third-party option such as <a href=\"https://github.com/cmderdev/cmder/\">Cmder</a>, <a href=\"https://www.fosshub.com/ConEmu.html\">ConEmu</a>, or <a href=\"https://hyper.is/\">Hyper</a>. Profiles can be defined to launch <code>%windir%\\system32\\bash.exe ~</code>.</p> \n<p>Another option is <strong>Windows Terminal</strong>, which is also available from the <strong>Microsoft Store</strong> or its repository at <a href=\"https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/\">github.com/microsoft/terminal/</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596503803terminal-1024x574.jpg\" alt=\"Windows Terminal\" width=\"1024\" height=\"574\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176898\" /></p> \n<p>Windows Terminal will automatically add your WSL2 Linux distros and offers a highly configurable range of options including tabs, split views, themes, transparency, and key bindings.</p> \n<p>Options are defined in the <code>settings.json</code> file accessed from the <strong>Settings</strong> menu or <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>,</kbd> (comma). Default values and theme settings can be viewed in <code>defaults.json</code>, accessed by holding down <kbd>Alt</kbd> while clicking the <strong>Settings</strong> menu.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wsl2-windows-terminal/?utm_source=rss\">The Complete Developer’s Guide to Windows Subsystem for Linux 2</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p> \n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=NE8lYvqkQEk:tJjOdCUuG_Y:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=NE8lYvqkQEk:tJjOdCUuG_Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div> \n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/NE8lYvqkQEk\" +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596512234windows-subsystem-linux-2.png","linkMd5":"253faeb8f0cb4bd16275b56afe8006e4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn73@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-27-183_59175b6e4830b217.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":20696,"destBytes":20696,"author":"Craig Buckler","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596512234windows-subsystem-linux-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn73@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-27-183_59175b6e4830b217.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596503684windows-requirements.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn69@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-38-280_3117756fc3d3d27a.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596503725windows-features.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn14@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-38-116_27032b9c99f1ee09.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596503767store.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn23@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-41-232_86ebfddd7b50e9f9.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/1596503803terminal-1024x574.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn93@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-37-083_be949589d4ab92f2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=NE8lYvqkQEk:tJjOdCUuG_Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn25@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-45-844_c943a13d90f46243.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/NE8lYvqkQEk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn50@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-42-744_ebb365690a8e90ad.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483249},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Build a Countdown Timer in Just 18 Lines of JavaScript","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=113448","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-javascript-countdown-timer-no-dependencies/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Build a Countdown Timer in Just 18 Lines of JavaScript\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1591024583m0021-12.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1591024583m0021-12-300x185.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1591024583m0021-12-768x473.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1591024583m0021-12-1024x631.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p>Sometimes, you’re going to need to build a JavaScript countdown clock. You may have an event, a sale, a promotion, or a game. You can build a clock in raw JavaScript rather than reaching for the nearest plugin. While there are many great clock plugins, here are the benefits you’ll get from using raw JavaScript:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Your code will be lightweight because it will have zero dependencies.</li> \n <li>Your website will perform better. You won’t need to load external scripts and stylesheets.</li> \n <li>You’ll have more control. You will have built the clock to behave exactly the way you want it to (rather than trying to bend a plugin to your will).</li> \n</ul> \n<p>So, without further ado, here’s how to make your own countdown clock in a mere 18 lines of JavaScript.</p> \n<p><em>For in-depth JavaScript knowledge, read our book, <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/javascript-novice-to-ninja-2nd-edition?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">JavaScript: Novice to Ninja, 2nd Edition</a>.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"basicclockcountdowntoaspecificdateortime\">Basic Clock: Count down to a Specific Date or Time</h2> \n<p>Here’s a quick outline of the steps involved in creating a basic clock:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Set a valid end date.</li> \n <li>Calculate the time remaining.</li> \n <li>Convert the time to a usable format.</li> \n <li>Output the clock data as a reusable object.</li> \n <li>Display the clock on the page, and stop the clock when it reaches zero.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"setavalidenddate\">Set a Valid End Date</h3> \n<p>First, you’ll need to set a valid end date. This should be a string in any of the formats understood by JavaScript’s <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/parse\">Date.parse()</a> method. For example:</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601\">ISO 8601</a> format:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const deadline = '2015-12-31';\n</code></pre> \n<p>The short format:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const deadline = '31/12/2015';\n</code></pre> \n<p>Or, the long format:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const deadline = 'December 31 2015';\n</code></pre> \n<p>Each of these formats allows you to specify an exact time and a time zone (or an offset from UTC in the case of ISO dates). For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const deadline = 'December 31 2015 23:59:59 GMT+0200';\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can read more about date formatting in JavaScript in <a href=\"https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff743760\">this article</a>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"calculatethetimeremaining\">Calculate the Time Remaining</h3> \n<p>The next step is to calculate the time remaining. We need to write a function that takes a string representing a given end time (as outlined above). We then calculate the difference between that time and the current time. Here’s what that looks like:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">function getTimeRemaining(endtime){\n  const total = Date.parse(endtime) - Date.parse(new Date());\n  const seconds = Math.floor( (total/1000) % 60 );\n  const minutes = Math.floor( (total/1000/60) % 60 );\n  const hours = Math.floor( (total/(1000*60*60)) % 24 );\n  const days = Math.floor( total/(1000*60*60*24) );\n\n  return {\n    total,\n    days,\n    hours,\n    minutes,\n    seconds\n  };\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>First, we’re creating a variable <code>total</code>, to hold the remaining time until the deadline. The <code>Date.parse()</code> function converts a time string into a value in milliseconds. This allows us to subtract two times from each other and get the amount of time in between.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const total = Date.parse(endtime) - Date.parse(new Date());\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"convertthetimetoausableformat\">Convert the Time to a Usable Format</h3> \n<p>Now we want to convert the milliseconds to days, hours, minutes, and seconds. Let’s use seconds as an example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const seconds = Math.floor( (t/1000) % 60 );\n</code></pre> \n<p>Let’s break down what’s going on here.</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Divide milliseconds by 1000 to convert to seconds: <code>(t/1000)</code></li> \n <li>Divide the total seconds by 60 and grab the remainder. You don’t want all of the seconds, just those remaining after the minutes have been counted: <code>(t/1000) % 60</code></li> \n <li>Round this down to the nearest whole number. This is because you want complete seconds, not fractions of seconds: <code>Math.floor( (t/1000) % 60 )</code></li> \n</ol> \n<p>Repeat this logic to convert the milliseconds to minutes, hours, and days.</p> \n<h3 id=\"outputtheclockdataasareusableobject\">Output the Clock Data as a Reusable Object</h3> \n<p>With the days, hours, minutes, and seconds prepared, we’re now ready to return the data as a reusable object:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">return {\n  total,\n  days,\n  hours,\n  minutes,\n  seconds\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>This object allows you to call your function and get any of the calculated values. Here’s an example of how you’d get the remaining minutes:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">getTimeRemaining(deadline).minutes\n</code></pre> \n<p>Convenient, right?</p> \n<h3 id=\"displaytheclockandstopitwhenitreacheszero\">Display the Clock and Stop It When It Reaches Zero</h3> \n<p>Now that we have a function that spits out the days, hours, minutes, and seconds remaining, we can build our clock. First we’ll create the following HTML element to hold our clock:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;div id=\"clockdiv\"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Then we’ll write a function that outputs the clock data inside our new div:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">function initializeClock(id, endtime) {\n  const clock = document.getElementById(id);\n  const timeinterval = setInterval(() =&gt; {\n    const t = getTimeRemaining(endtime);\n    clock.innerHTML = 'days: ' + t.days + '&lt;br&gt;' +\n                      'hours: '+ t.hours + '&lt;br&gt;' +\n                      'minutes: ' + t.minutes + '&lt;br&gt;' +\n                      'seconds: ' + t.seconds;\n    if (t.total &lt;= 0) {\n      clearInterval(timeinterval);\n    }\n  },1000);\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>This function takes two parameters. These are the id of the element that contains our clock, and the countdown’s end time. Inside the function, we’ll declare a <code>clock</code> variable and use it to store a reference to our clock container div. This means we don’t have to keep querying the DOM.</p> \n<p>Next, we’ll use <code>setInterval</code> to execute an anonymous function every second. This function will do the following:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-javascript-countdown-timer-no-dependencies/?utm_source=rss\">Build a Countdown Timer in Just 18 Lines of JavaScript</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=3cLR3rZXmIw:QCfcY_RDyIY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=3cLR3rZXmIw:QCfcY_RDyIY:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=3cLR3rZXmIw:QCfcY_RDyIY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=3cLR3rZXmIw:QCfcY_RDyIY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/3cLR3rZXmIw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 31 May 2020 22:10:07 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1591024583m0021-12.jpg","linkMd5":"00133b9c6b170f49190d459fee16da49","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn29@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-26-677_74558cef1d0b84fd.webp","destWidth":1800,"destHeight":1109,"sourceBytes":33406,"destBytes":33406,"author":"Yaphi Berhanu","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1591024583m0021-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn29@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-26-677_74558cef1d0b84fd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=3cLR3rZXmIw:QCfcY_RDyIY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn30@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-43-719_02db2dcd44d3ba26.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/3cLR3rZXmIw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-39-019_daa2e4279c49dd4f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483269},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Use Deno&#8217;s Built-in Tools","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=177668","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-built-in-tools/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Use Deno’s Built-in Tools\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1598232667deno-dev-tools.png\" alt=\"How to Use Deno’s Built-in Tools\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1598232667deno-dev-tools-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1598232667deno-dev-tools.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>One surprising difference between Deno and Node.js is the number of tools built into the runtime. Other than a Read-Eval-Print Loop (REPL) console, Node.js requires third-party modules to handle most <em>indirect</em> coding activities such as testing and linting. Deno provides almost everything you need out of the box.</strong></p> \n<p><em>Before we begin, a note. <strong>Deno is new!</strong> Use these tools with caution. Some may be unstable. Few have configuration options. Others may have undesirable side effects such as recursively processing every file in every subdirectory. It’s best to test tools from a dedicated project directory.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"installdeno\">Install Deno</h2> \n<p>Install Deno on macOS or Linux using the following terminal command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">curl -fsSL https://deno.land/x/install/install.sh | sh\n</code></pre> \n<p>Or from Windows Powershell:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">iwr https://deno.land/x/install/install.ps1 -useb | iex\n</code></pre> \n<p>Further installation options are provided in the <a href=\"https://deno.land/manual/getting_started/installation\">Deno manual</a>.</p> \n<p>Enter <code>deno --version</code> to check installation has been successful. The version numbers for the V8 JavaScript engine, TypeScript compiler, and Deno itself are displayed.</p> \n<h2 id=\"upgradedeno\">Upgrade Deno</h2> \n<p>Upgrade Deno to the latest version with:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">deno upgrade\n</code></pre> \n<p>Or upgrade to <a href=\"https://github.com/denoland/deno/releases\">specific release</a> such as v1.3.0:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">deno upgrade --version 1.30.0\n</code></pre> \n<p>Most of the tools below are available in all versions, but later editions may have more features and bug fixes.</p> \n<h2 id=\"denohelp\">Deno Help</h2> \n<p>A list of tools and options can be viewed by entering:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">deno help\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"readevalprintlooprepl\">Read-Eval-Print Loop (REPL)</h2> \n<p>Like Node.js, a REPL expression evaluation console can be accessed by entering <code>deno</code> in your terminal. Each expression you enter returns a result or <code>undefined</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ deno\n\nDeno 1.3.0\nexit using ctrl+d or close()\n&gt; const w = 'World';\nundefined\n&gt; w\nWorld\n&gt; console.log(`Hello ${w}!`);\nHello World!\nundefined\n&gt; close()\n\n$\n</code></pre> \n<p>Previously entered expressions can be re-entered by using the cursor keys to navigate through the expression history.</p> \n<h2 id=\"dependencyinspector\">Dependency Inspector</h2> \n<p>A tree of all module dependencies can be viewed by entering <code>deno info &lt;module&gt;</code> where <code>&lt;module&gt;</code> is the path/URL to an entry script.</p> \n<p>Consider the following <code>lib.js</code> library code with exported <code>hello</code> and <code>sum</code> functions:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// general library: lib.js\n\n/**\n * return \"Hello &lt;name&gt;!\" string\n * @module lib\n * @param {string} name\n * @returns {string} Hello &lt;name&gt;!\n */\nexport function hello(name = 'Anonymous') {\n\n  return `Hello ${ name.trim() }!`;\n\n};\n\n/**\n * Returns total of all arguments\n * @module lib\n * @param {...*} args\n * @returns {*} total\n */\nexport function sum(...args) {\n\n  return [...args].reduce((a, b) =&gt; a + b);\n\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>These can be used from a main entry script, <code>index.js</code>, in the same directory:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// main entry script: index.js\n\n// import lib.js modules\nimport { hello, sum } from './lib.js';\n\nconst\n  spr = sum('Site', 'Point', '.com', ' ', 'reader'),\n  add = sum(1, 2, 3);\n\n// output\nconsole.log( hello(spr) );\nconsole.log( 'total:', add );\n</code></pre> \n<p>The result of running <code>deno run ./index.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ deno run ./index.js\n\nHello SitePoint.com reader!\ntotal: 6\n</code></pre> \n<p>The dependencies used by <code>index.js</code> can be examined with <code>deno info ./index.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ deno info ./index.js\n\nlocal: /home/deno/testing/index.js\ntype: JavaScript\ndeps:\nfile:///home/deno/testing/index.js\n  └── file:///home/deno/testing/lib.js\n</code></pre> \n<p>Similarly, the dependencies required by any module URL can be examined, although be aware the module will be downloaded and cached locally on first use. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ deno info https://deno.land/std/hash/mod.ts\n\nDownload https://deno.land/std/hash/mod.ts\nDownload https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/hash/mod.ts\nDownload https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/hash/_wasm/hash.ts\nDownload https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/hash/hasher.ts\nDownload https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/hash/_wasm/wasm.js\nDownload https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/encoding/hex.ts\nDownload https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/encoding/base64.ts\ndeps:\nhttps://deno.land/std/hash/mod.ts\n  └─┬ https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/hash/_wasm/hash.ts\n    ├─┬ https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/hash/_wasm/wasm.js\n    │ └── https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/encoding/base64.ts\n    ├── https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/encoding/hex.ts\n    └── https://deno.land/std@0.65.0/encoding/base64.ts\n</code></pre> \n<p>For further information, see the <a href=\"https://deno.land/manual/tools/dependency_inspector\">Deno Manual: Dependency Inspector</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"lintersyntaxchecker\">Linter (Syntax Checker)</h2> \n<p>Deno provides a linter to validate JavaScript and TypeScript code. This is an unstable feature which requires the <code>--unstable</code> flag, but no files will be altered when it’s used.</p> \n<p>Linting is useful to spot less obvious syntax errors and ensure code adheres with your team’s standards. You may already be using a linter such as <a href=\"https://eslint.org/\">ESLint</a> in your editor or from the command line, but Deno provides another option in any environment where it’s installed.</p> \n<p>To recursively lint all <code>.js</code> and <code>.ts</code> files in the current and child directories, enter <code>deno lint --unstable</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ deno lint --unstable\n\n(no-extra-semi) Unnecessary semicolon.\n};\n ^\n    at /home/deno/testing/lib.js:13:1\n\nFound 1 problem\n</code></pre> \n<p>Alternatively, you can specify one or more files to limit linting. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ deno lint --unstable ./index.js\n$\n</code></pre> \n<p>For further information, see the <a href=\"https://deno.land/manual/tools/linter\">Deno Manual: Linter</a>. It includes a list of rules you can add to code comments to ignore or enforce specific syntaxes.</p> \n<h2 id=\"testrunner\">Test Runner</h2> \n<p>Deno has a built-in test runner for unit-testing JavaScript or TypeScript functions.</p> \n<p>Tests are defined in any file named <code>&lt;something&gt;test</code> with a <code>.js</code>, <code>.mjs</code>, <code>.ts</code>, <code>.jsx</code>, or <code>.tsx</code> extension. It must make one or more calls to <a href=\"https://doc.deno.land/builtin/stable#Deno.test\"><code>Deno.test</code></a> and pass a test name string and a testing function. The function can be synchronous or asynchronous and use a variety of <a href=\"https://deno.land/std/testing\">assertion utilities</a> to evaluate results.</p> \n<p>Create a new <code>test</code> subdirectory with a file named <code>lib.test.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// test lib.js library\n\n// assertions\nimport { assertEquals } from 'https://deno.land/std/testing/asserts.ts';\n\n// lib.js modules\nimport { hello, sum } from '../lib.js';\n\n// hello function\nDeno.test('lib/hello tests', () =&gt; {\n\n  assertEquals( hello('Someone'), 'Hello Someone!');\n  assertEquals( hello(), 'Hello Anonymous!' );\n\n});\n\n// sum integers\nDeno.test('lib/sum integer tests', () =&gt; {\n\n  assertEquals( sum(1, 2, 3), 6 );\n  assertEquals( sum(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), 21 );\n\n});\n\n// sum strings\nDeno.test('lib/sum string tests', () =&gt; {\n\n  assertEquals( sum('a', 'b', 'c'), 'abc' );\n  assertEquals( sum('A', 'b', 'C'), 'AbC' );\n\n});\n\n// sum mixed values\nDeno.test('lib/sum mixed tests', () =&gt; {\n\n  assertEquals( sum('a', 1, 2), 'a12' );\n  assertEquals( sum(1, 2, 'a'), '3a' );\n  assertEquals( sum('an', null, [], 'ed'), 'annulled' );\n\n});\n</code></pre> \n<p>To run all tests from all directories, enter <code>deno test</code>. Or run tests stored in a specific directory with <code>deno test &lt;dir&gt;</code>. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ deno test ./test\n\nrunning 4 tests\ntest lib/hello tests ... ok (4ms)\ntest lib/sum integer tests ... ok (2ms)\ntest lib/sum string tests ... ok (2ms)\ntest lib/sum mixed tests ... ok (2ms)\n\ntest result: ok. 4 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out (11ms)\n\n$\n</code></pre> \n<p>A <code>--filter</code> string or regular expression can also be specified to limit tests by name. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ deno test --filter \"hello\" ./test\n\nrunning 1 tests\ntest lib/hello tests ... ok (4ms)\n\ntest result: ok. 1 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 3 filtered out (5ms)\n</code></pre> \n<p>Longer-running tests can be stopped on the first failure by passing a <code>--failfast</code> option.</p> \n<p>For further information, see the <a href=\"https://deno.land/manual/testing\">Deno Manual: Testing</a>. A few third-party test modules are also available, including <a href=\"https://github.com/crewdevio/merlin\">Merlin</a> and <a href=\"https://github.com/drashland/rhum\">Ruhm</a>, but these still use <code>Deno.test</code> beneath the surface.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-built-in-tools/?utm_source=rss\">How to Use Deno’s Built-in Tools</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a 2020 21:25:00
