06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Local Authentication Using Passport in Node.js","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=78440","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/local-authentication-using-passport-node-js/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Local Authentication Using Passport in Node.js\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/1585544614local-auth.png\" alt=\"Local Authentication Using Passport in Node.js\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/1585544614local-auth-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/1585544614local-auth.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>A common requirement when building a web app is to implement a login system, so that users can authenticate themselves before gaining access to protected views or resources. Luckily for those building Node apps, there’s a middleware called <a href=\"http://www.passportjs.org/\">Passport</a> that can be dropped into any <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://expressjs.com/\">Express</a>-based web application to provide authentication mechanisms in only a few commands.</strong></p> \n<p>In this tutorial, I’ll demonstrate how to use Passport to implement local authentication (that is, logging in with a username and password) with a MongoDB back end. If you’re looking to implement authentication via the likes of Facebook or GitHub, please refer to <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/passport-authentication-for-nodejs-applications/\">this tutorial</a>.</p> \n<p>As ever, all of the code for this article is available for download on <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/LocalPassportAuth\">GitHub</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"prerequisites\">Prerequisites</h2> \n<p>To follow along with this tutorial, you’ll need to have Node and MongoDB installed on your machine.</p> \n<p>You can install <strong>Node</strong> by heading to <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/download/\">the official Node download page</a> and grabbing the correct binaries for your system. Alternatively, you can use a version manager — a program that allows you to install multiple versions of Node and switch between them at will. If you fancy going this route, please consult our quick tip, “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">Install Multiple Versions of Node.js Using nvm</a>”.</p> \n<p><strong>MongoDB</strong> comes in various editions. The one we’re interested in is the MongoDB Community Edition.</p> \n<p>The project’s home page has excellent documentation and I won’t try to replicate that here. Rather, I’ll offer you links to instructions for each of the main operating systems:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/install-mongodb-on-windows/\">Install MongoDB Community Edition on Windows</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/install-mongodb-on-os-x/\">Install MongoDB Community Edition on macOS</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/install-mongodb-on-ubuntu/\">Install MongoDB Community Edition on Ubuntu</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you use a non-Ubuntu–based version of Linux, you can check out <a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/installation/#mongodb-community-edition-installation-tutorials\">this page</a> for installation instructions for other distros. MongoDB is also normally available through the official Linux software channels, but sometimes this will pull in an outdated version.</p> \n<p><em>Note: You don’t need to enter your name and address to download MongoDB. If prompted, you can normally dismiss the dialog.</em></p> \n<p>If you’d like a quick refresher on using MongoDB, check out our beginner’s guide, “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/an-introduction-to-mongodb/\">An Introduction to MongoDB</a>”.</p> \n<h2 id=\"authenticationstrategiessessionvsjwt\">Authentication Strategies: Session vs JWT</h2> \n<p>Before we begin, let’s talk briefly about authentication choices.</p> \n<p>Many of the tutorials online today will opt for token-based authentication using <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/using-json-web-tokens-node-js/\">JSON Web Tokens</a> (JWTs). This approach is probably the simplest and most popular one nowadays. It relegates part of the authentication responsibility to the client and makes them sign a token that’s sent with every request, to keep the user authenticated.</p> \n<p>Session-based authentication has been around longer. This method relegates the weight of the authentication to the server. It uses cookies and sees the Node application and database work together to keep track of a user’s authentication state.</p> \n<p>In this tutorial, we’ll be using session-based authentication, which is at the heart of the <a href=\"http://www.passportjs.org/packages/passport-local/\">passport-local strategy</a>.</p> \n<p>Both methods have their advantages and drawbacks. If you’d like to read more into the difference between the two, <a href=\"https://stackoverflow.com/q/43452896\">this Stack Overflow thread</a> might be a good place to start.</p> \n<h2 id=\"creatingtheproject\">Creating the Project</h2> \n<p>Once all of the prerequisite software is set up, we can get started.</p> \n<p>We’ll begin by creating the folder for our app and then accessing that folder on the terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mkdir AuthApp\ncd AuthApp\n</code></pre> \n<p>To create the node app, we’ll use the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm init\n</code></pre> \n<p>You’ll be prompted to provide some information for Node’s <code>package.json</code>. Just keep hitting <kbd>Return</kbd> to accept the default configuration (or use the <code>-y</code> flag).</p> \n<h2 id=\"settingupexpress\">Setting up Express</h2> \n<p>Now we need to install <a href=\"http://expressjs.com/\">Express</a>. Go to the terminal and enter this command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install express\n</code></pre> \n<p>We’ll also need to install the <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/body-parser\">body-parser</a> middleware which is used to parse the request body that Passport uses to authenticate the user. And we’ll need to install the <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/express-session\">express-session </a> middleware.</p> \n<p>Let’s do that. Run the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install body-parser express-session\n</code></pre> \n<p>When that’s done, create an <code>index.js</code> file in the root folder of your app and add the following content to it:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">/*  EXPRESS SETUP  */\n\nconst express = require('express');\nconst app = express();\n\napp.use(express.static(__dirname));\n\nconst bodyParser = require('body-parser');\nconst expressSession = require('express-session')({\n  secret: 'secret',\n  resave: false,\n  saveUninitialized: false\n});\n\napp.use(bodyParser.json());\napp.use(bodyParser.urlencoded({ extended: true }));\napp.use(expressSession);\n\nconst port = process.env.PORT || 3000;\napp.listen(port, () =&gt; console.log('App listening on port ' + port));\n</code></pre> \n<p>First, we <code>require</code> Express and create our Express app by calling <a href=\"http://expressjs.com/en/api.html#express\">express()</a>. Then we define the directory from which to serve our static files.</p> \n<p>The next line sees us <code>require</code> the body-parser middleware, which will help us parse the body of our requests. We’re also adding the express-session middleware to help us save the session cookie.</p> \n<p>As you can, see we’re configuring express-session with a <code>secret</code> to sign the session ID cookie (you should choose a unique value here), and two other fields, <a href=\"https://github.com/expressjs/session#resave\">resave</a> and <a href=\"https://github.com/expressjs/session#saveuninitialized\">saveUninitialized</a>. The <code>resave</code> field forces the session to be saved back to the session store, and the <code>saveUninitialized</code> field forces a session that is “uninitialized” to be saved to the store. To learn more about them, check out their documentation, but for now it’s enough to know that for our case we want to keep them <code>false</code>.</p> \n<p>Then, we use <code>process.env.PORT</code> to set the port to the environment port variable if it exists. Otherwise, we’ll default to <code>3000</code>, which is the port we’ll be using locally. This gives you enough flexibility to switch from development, directly to a production environment where the port might be set by a service provider like, for instance, <a href=\"https://www.heroku.com/\">Heroku</a>. Right below that, we called <a href=\"http://expressjs.com/en/api.html#app.listen\">app.listen()</a> with the port variable we set up and a simple log to let us know that it’s all working fine and on which port is the app listening.</p> \n<p>That’s all for the Express setup. Now it’s on to setting up <code>Passport</code>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"settinguppassport\">Setting up Passport</h2> \n<p>First, we install Passport with the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install passport\n</code></pre> \n<p>Then we need to add the following lines to the bottom of the <code>index.js</code> file:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">/*  PASSPORT SETUP  */\n\nconst passport = require('passport');\n\napp.use(passport.initialize());\napp.use(passport.session());\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here, we require <code>passport</code> and initialize it along with its session authentication middleware, directly inside our Express app.</p> \n<h2 id=\"creatingamongodbdatastore\">Creating a MongoDB Data Store</h2> \n<p>Since we’re assuming you’ve already installed Mongo, you should be able to start the Mongo shell using the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mongo\n</code></pre> \n<p>Within the shell, issue the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">use MyDatabase;\n</code></pre> \n<p>This simply creates a datastore named <code>MyDatabase</code>.</p> \n<p>Leave the terminal there; we’ll come back to it later.</p> \n<h2 id=\"connectingmongotonodewithmongoose\">Connecting Mongo to Node with Mongoose</h2> \n<p>Now that we have a database with records in it, we need a way to communicate with it from our application. We’ll be using <a href=\"http://mongoosejs.com/\">Mongoose</a> to achieve this. Why don’t we just use plain Mongo? Well, as the Mongoose devs like to say on their website:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>writing MongoDB validation, casting and business logic boilerplate is a drag.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Mongoose will simply make our lives easier and our code more elegant.</p> \n<p>Let’s go ahead and install it with the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install mongoose\n</code></pre> \n<p>We’ll also be using<a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/passport-local-mongoose\"> passport-local-mongoose</a>, which will simplify the integration between Mongoose and Passport for local authentication. It will add a <code>hash</code> and <code>salt</code> field to our Schema in order to store the hashed password and the salt value. This is great, as <a href=\"https://security.stackexchange.com/a/120541\">passwords should never be stored as plain text in a database</a>.</p> \n<p>Let’s install the package:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install passport-local-mongoose\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now we have to configure Mongoose. Hopefully you know the drill by now: add the following code to the bottom of your <code>index.js</code> file:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">/* MONGOOSE SETUP */\n\nconst mongoose = require('mongoose');\nconst passportLocalMongoose = require('passport-local-mongoose');\n\nmongoose.connect('mongodb://localhost/MyDatabase',\n  { useNewUrlParser: true, useUnifiedTopology: true });\n\nconst Schema = mongoose.Schema;\nconst UserDetail = new Schema({\n  username: String,\n  password: String\n});\n\nUserDetail.plugin(passportLocalMongoose);\nconst UserDetails = mongoose.model('userInfo', UserDetail, 'userInfo');\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here we require the previously installed packages. Then we connect to our database using <code>mongoose.connect</code> and give it the path to our database. Next, we’re making use of a <a href=\"http://mongoosejs.com/docs/guide.html\">Schema</a> to define our data structure. In this case, we’re creating a <code>UserDetail</code> schema with <code>username</code> and <code>password</code> fields.</p> \n<p>Finally, we add <code>passportLocalMongoose</code> as a plugin to our Schema. This will work part of the magic we talked about earlier. Then, we create a <a href=\"http://mongoosejs.com/docs/models.html\">model</a> from that schema. The first parameter is the name of the collection in the database. The second one is the reference to our Schema, and the third one is the name we’re assigning to the collection inside Mongoose.</p> \n<p>That’s all for the Mongoose setup. We can now move on to implementing our Passport strategy.</p> \n<h2 id=\"implementinglocalauthentication\">Implementing Local Authentication</h2> \n<p>And finally, this is what we came here to do! Let’s set up the local authentication. As you’ll see below, we’ll just write the code that will set it up for us:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">/* PASSPORT LOCAL AUTHENTICATION */\n\npassport.use(UserDetails.createStrategy());\n\npassport.serializeUser(UserDetails.serializeUser());\npassport.deserializeUser(UserDetails.deserializeUser());\n</code></pre> \n<p>There’s quite some magic going on here. First, we make <code>passport</code> use the local strategy by calling <code>createStrategy()</code> on our <code>UserDetails</code> model — courtesy of <code>passport-local-mongoose</code> — which takes care of everything so that we don’t have to set up the strategy. Pretty handy.</p> \n<p>Then we’re using <code>serializeUser</code> and <code>deserializeUser</code> callbacks. The first one will be invoked on authentication, and its job is to serialize the user instance with the information we pass on to it and store it in the session via a cookie. The second one will be invoked every subsequent request to deserialize the instance, providing it the unique cookie identifier as a “credential”. You can read more about that in the <a href=\"http://www.passportjs.org/docs/configure/#sessions\">Passport documentation</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"routes\">Routes</h2> \n<p>Now let’s add some routes to tie everything together. First, we’ll add a final package. Go to the terminal and run the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install connect-ensure-login\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/connect-ensure-login\">connect-ensure-login</a> package is middleware that ensures a user is logged in. If a request is received that is unauthenticated, the request will be redirected to a login page. We’ll use this to guard our routes.</p> \n<p>Now, add the following to the bottom of <code>index.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">/* ROUTES */\n\nconst connectEnsureLogin = require('connect-ensure-login');\n\napp.post('/login', (req, res, next) =&gt; {\n  passport.authenticate('local',\n  (err, user, info) =&gt; {\n    if (err) {\n      return next(err);\n    }\n\n    if (!user) {\n      return res.redirect('/login?info=' + info);\n    }\n\n    req.logIn(user, function(err) {\n      if (err) {\n        return next(err);\n      }\n\n      return res.redirect('/');\n    });\n\n  })(req, res, next);\n});\n\napp.get('/login',\n  (req, res) =&gt; res.sendFile('html/login.html',\n  { root: __dirname })\n);\n\napp.get('/',\n  connectEnsureLogin.ensureLoggedIn(),\n  (req, res) =&gt; res.sendFile('html/index.html', {root: __dirname})\n);\n\napp.get('/private',\n  connectEnsureLogin.ensureLoggedIn(),\n  (req, res) =&gt; res.sendFile('html/private.html', {root: __dirname})\n);\n\napp.get('/user',\n  connectEnsureLogin.ensureLoggedIn(),\n  (req, res) =&gt; res.send({user: req.user})\n);\n</code></pre> \n<p>At the top, we’re requiring <code>connect-ensure-login</code>. We’ll come back to this later.</p> \n<p>Next, we set up a route to handle a POST request to the <code>/login</code> path. Inside the handler, we use the <a href=\"http://www.passportjs.org/docs/authenticate/\">passport.authenticate</a> method, which attempts to authenticate with the strategy it receives as its first parameter — in this case <code>local</code>. If authentication fails, it will redirect us to <code>/login</code>, but it will add a query parameter — <code>info</code> — that will contain an error message. Otherwise, if authentication is successful, it will redirect us to the <code>'/'</code> route.</p> \n<p>Then we set up the <code>/login</code> route, which will send the login page. For this, we’re using <a href=\"http://expressjs.com/en/api.html#res.sendFile\">res.sendFile()</a> and passing in the file path and our root directory, which is the one we’re working on — hence the <code>__dirname</code>.</p> \n<p>The <code>/login</code> route will be accessible to anyone, but our next ones won’t. In the <code>/</code> and <code>/private</code> routes we’ll send their respective HTML pages, and you’ll notice something different here. Before the callback, we’re adding the <code>connectEnsureLogin.ensureLoggedIn()</code> call. This is our route guard. Its job is validating the session to make sure you’re allowed to look at that route. Do you see now what I meant earlier by “letting the server do the heavy lifting”? We’re authenticating the user every single time.</p> \n<p>Finally, we’ll need a <code>/user</code> route, which will return an object with our user information. This is just to show you how you can go about getting information from the server. We’ll request this route from the client and display the result.</p> \n<p>Talking about the client, let’s do that now.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/local-authentication-using-passport-node-js/?utm_source=rss\">Local Authentication Using Passport in Node.js</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Z8-wbd_Js6k:yQv4e6Wzv38:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Z8-wbd_Js6k:yQv4e6Wzv38:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/Z8-wbd_Js6k\" Orac","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/1585544614local-auth.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn13@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-29-287_2eeb93fe376553c6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Z8-wbd_Js6k:yQv4e6Wzv38:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-46-919_40621cf5ee8b3540.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/Z8-wbd_Js6k":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn60@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-38-070_6cb2955b3722010c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483279},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"CSS Viewport Units: A Quick Start","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=151506","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/css-viewport-units-quick-start/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"CSS Viewport Units: A Quick Start\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/1490784120Viewport_Units.png\" alt=\"CSS Viewport Units\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/1490784120Viewport_Units-300x167.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/1490784120Viewport_Units-768x427.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/1490784120Viewport_Units.png 900w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>It’s been a few years since viewport units were first introduced in CSS. They’re truly “responsive length units” in the sense that their value changes every time the browser resizes. If you’ve heard about these units before but never learned about them in detail, this article can help you out.</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"theunitsandtheirmeaning\">The Units and Their Meaning</h2> \n<p>There are four viewport-based units in CSS. These are <code>vh</code>, <code>vw</code>, <code>vmin</code> and <code>vmax</code>.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Viewport Height</strong> (vh). This unit is based on the height of the viewport. A value of <code>1vh</code> is equal to 1% of the viewport height.</li> \n <li><strong>Viewport Width</strong> (vw). This unit is based on the width of the viewport. A value of <code>1vw</code> is equal to 1% of the viewport width.</li> \n <li><strong>Viewport Minimum</strong> (vmin). This unit is based on the <strong>smaller dimension of the viewport</strong>. If the <em>viewport height is smaller</em> than the width, the value of <code>1vmin</code> will be equal to 1% of the viewport height. Similarly, if the <em>viewport width is smaller</em> than the height, the value of <code>1vmin</code> will be equal to 1% of the viewport width.</li> \n <li><strong>Viewport Maximum</strong> (vmax). This unit is based on the <strong>larger dimension of the viewport</strong>. If the <em>viewport height is larger</em> than the width, the value of <code>1vmax</code> will be equal to 1% of viewport height. Similarly, if the <em>viewport width is larger</em> than the height, the value of <code>1vmax</code> will be equal to 1% of hte viewport width.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Let’s see what the value of these units will be in different situations:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>If the viewport is 1200px wide and 1000px high, the value of <code>10vw</code> will be 120px and the value of <code>10vh</code> will be 100px. Since the width of the viewport is greater than its height, the value of <code>10vmax</code> will be 120px and the value of <code>10vmin</code> will be 100px.</li> \n <li>If the device is now rotated so that the viewport becomes 1000px wide and 1200px high, the value of <code>10vh</code> will be 120px and the value of <code>10vw</code> will be 100px. Interestingly, the value of <code>10vmax</code> will still be 120px because it will now be determined based on the height of the viewport. Similarly, the value of <code>10vmin</code> will still be 100px.</li> \n <li>If you resize the browser window so that the viewport becomes 1000px wide and 800px high, the value of <code>10vh</code> will become 80px and the value of <code>10vw</code> will become 100px. Similarly, the value of <code>10vmax</code> will become 100px and the value of <code>10vmin</code> will become 80px.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>At this point, viewport units may sound similar to percentages. However, they’re very different. In the case of percentages, the width or height of the child element is determined with respect to its parent. Here’s an example:</p> \n<div style=\"margin-bottom:1em;\"> \n <p data-height=\"885\" data-theme-id=\"6441\" data-slug-hash=\"xqadex\" data-default-tab=\"result\" data-user=\"SitePoint\" data-embed-version=\"2\" data-pen-title=\"Viewport Units and Percentage\" class=\"codepen\">See the Pen <a href=\"http://codepen.io/SitePoint/pen/xqadex/\">Viewport Units and Percentage</a> by SitePoint (<a href=\"http://codepen.io/SitePoint\">@SitePoint</a>) on <a href=\"http://codepen.io\">CodePen</a>.</p> \n <p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://production-assets.codepen.io/assets/embed/ei.js\"></script></p> \n</div> \n<p>As you can see, the width of the first child element is set to be equal to 80% of its parent’s width. However, the second child element has a width of 80vw, which makes it wider than its parent.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/css-viewport-units-quick-start/?utm_source=rss\">CSS Viewport Units: A Quick Start</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=HDXuMOfIjjU:Kye8I2RwHrE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=HDXuMOfIjjU:Kye8I2RwHrE:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=HDXuMOfIjjU:Kye8I2RwHrE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=HDXuMOfIjjU:Kye8I2RwHrE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/HDXuMOfIjjU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 08 Jun 2020 16:00:10 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/1490784120Viewport_Units.png","linkMd5":"3f7e502dd184ddb0c8b83a12c1a12208","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn49@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-24-661_50df401814882fa6.webp","destWidth":900,"destHeight":500,"sourceBytes":22186,"destBytes":22186,"author":"Asha Laxmi","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/1490784120Viewport_Units.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn49@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-24-661_50df401814882fa6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=HDXuMOfIjjU:Kye8I2RwHrE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn75@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-46-979_902502630d8404eb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/HDXuMOfIjjU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn43@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-46-665_ccbb966366b730d1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483268},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Create an Ecommerce Site with React","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176295","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-create-an-ecommerce-site-with-react/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Create an Ecommerce Site with React\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1591621031ecommerce-app.png\" alt=\"How to Create an Ecommerce Site with React\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1591621031ecommerce-app-300x169.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1591621031ecommerce-app.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Since most of the performance optimizations for ecommerce web applications are front-end related, the prominent, front-end centric framework React — often preferred for its simplicity and elegance — will be used in this tutorial.</strong></p> \n<p>In creating a basic ecommerce site, we’ll also make use of React Context as an alternative to state management frameworks such as Redux and MobX.</p> \n<p>Also, a basic method for handling authentication and cart management will be shown in this application. Below is a screenshot of what we’ll be building:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15916199571-our-products-1024x503.gif\" alt=\"The finished app\" width=\"1024\" height=\"503\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176297\" /></p> \n<p>This tutorial assumes you have a basic knowledge of JavaScript and JSX.</p> \n<h2 id=\"prerequisites\">Prerequisites</h2> \n<p>In the course of building this application, we’ll be using React Context to manage our application data, because it “provides a way to pass data through the component tree without having to pass props down manually at every level”, as outlines in <a href=\"https://reactjs.org/docs/context.html\">the docs</a>.</p> \n<p>To build the application, you’ll also need a computer with the required applications for starting and running a React application — <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/\">Node &gt;= 8.10 and npm &gt;= 5.6</a> on your machine.</p> \n<p>Create a React project like so:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npx create-react-app e-commerce\n</code></pre> \n<p>In this application, we also use React Router to handle the routing. To install this module, run this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install react-router-dom\n</code></pre> \n<p>Finally, we’ll use the Bulma open-source CSS framework to style this application. To install this, run the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install bulma\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"gettingstarted\">Getting Started</h2> \n<p>First, we need to add the stylesheet to our application. To achieve that, we’ll add an import statement to include this file in the <code>index.js</code> file in the <code>src</code> folder of the application. This will apply the stylesheet across all the components in the application. Below is a snippet of the import statement:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// ./index.js\n...\nimport \"bulma/css/bulma.css\";\n...\n</code></pre> \n<p>In this application, we define a dataset for the application, since we aren’t working with a back-end API. The dataset contains the application’s users and the initial products list:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// ./Data.js\nexport default {\n  users: [\n    { username: \"regular\", accessLevel: 1, password: \"password\" },\n    { username: \"admin\", accessLevel: 0, password: \"password\" }\n  ],\n  initProducts: [\n    {\n      name: \"shoes\",\n      stock: 10,\n      price: 399.99,\n      shortDesc: \"Nulla facilisi. Curabitur at lacus ac velit ornare lobortis.\",\n      description:\n        \"Cras sagittis. Praesent nec nisl a purus blandit viverra. Ut leo. Donec quam          elis, ultricies nec, pellentesque eu, pretium quis, sem. Fusce a quam.\"\n    },\n    ...moreProducts\n  ]\n};\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"contextsetup\">Context Setup</h2> \n<p>In complex applications where the need for Context is usually necessary, there can be multiple contexts, with each having its data and methods relating to the set of components that requires the data and methods. For example, there can be a <code>ProductContext</code> for handling the components which use products related data, and another <code>ProfileContext</code> for handling data relating to authentication and user data. However, for the sake of keeping things as simple as possible, we’ll use just one context instance.</p> \n<p>In order to create the context, we create a file <code>Context.js</code> in the root of our application:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// ./Context.js\n\nimport React from \"react\";\nconst Context = React.createContext({});\nexport default Context;\n</code></pre> \n<p>This creates the Context and initializes the context data to an empty object. Next, we need to create a component wrapper, which we’ll use to wrap components that use the Context data and methods:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">    // ./withContext.js\n\nimport React from \"react\";\nimport Context from \"./Context\";\nconst withContext = WrappedComponent =&gt; {\n  const WithHOC = props =&gt; {\n    return (\n      &lt;Context.Consumer&gt;\n        {context =&gt; &lt;WrappedComponent {...props} context={context} /&gt;}\n      &lt;/Context.Consumer&gt;\n    );\n  };\n  WithHOC.WrappedComponent = WrappedComponent;\n  return WithHOC;\n};\nexport default withContext;\n</code></pre> \n<p>The code above exports a function <code>withContext</code>, which uses the Consumer Component property of the previously created Context. The Consumer component transmits data associated with the Context to its child component.</p> \n<h2 id=\"appdevelopment\">App Development</h2> \n<p>Next, we need to set up up the <code>App.js</code> file. Here, we’ll be handling the application’s navigation as well as defining its data and methods to manage them.</p> \n<p>First, let’s set up up the application navigation:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">//./src/App.js\n\nimport React, { Component } from \"react\";\nimport { Switch, Route, Link, BrowserRouter as Router } from \"react-router-dom\";\nimport data from \"./Data\";\nimport Context from \"./Context\";\nexport default class App extends Component {\n  constructor(props) {\n    super(props);\n    this.state = {};\n    this.routerRef = React.createRef();\n  }\n  ...\n  ...\n  ...\n\n  render() {\n    return (\n      &lt;Context.Provider\n        value={{\n          ...this.state,\n          removeFromCart: this.removeFromCart,\n          addToCart: this.addToCart,\n          login: this.login,\n          addProduct: this.addProduct,\n          clearCart: this.clearCart,\n          checkout: this.checkout\n        }}\n      &gt;\n        &lt;Router ref={this.routerRef}&gt;\n          &lt;div className=\"App\"&gt;\n            &lt;nav\n              className=\"navbar container\"\n              role=\"navigation\"\n              aria-label=\"main navigation\"\n            &gt;\n              &lt;div className=\"navbar-brand\"&gt;\n                &lt;b className=\"navbar-item is-size-4 \"&gt;ecommerce&lt;/b&gt;\n                &lt;a\n                  role=\"button\"\n                  class=\"navbar-burger burger\"\n                  aria-label=\"menu\"\n                  aria-expanded=\"false\"\n                  data-target=\"navbarBasicExample\"\n                  onClick={e =&gt; {\n                    e.preventDefault();\n                    this.setState({ showMenu: !this.state.showMenu });\n                  }}\n                &gt;\n                  &lt;span aria-hidden=\"true\"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;\n                  &lt;span aria-hidden=\"true\"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;\n                  &lt;span aria-hidden=\"true\"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;\n                &lt;/a&gt;\n              &lt;/div&gt;\n              &lt;div className={`navbar-menu ${\n                  this.state.showMenu ? \"is-active\" : \"\"\n                }`}&gt;\n                &lt;Link to=\"/products\" className=\"navbar-item\"&gt;\n                  Products\n                &lt;/Link&gt;\n                {this.state.user &amp;&amp; this.state.user.accessLevel &lt; 1 &amp;&amp; (\n                  &lt;Link to=\"/add-product\" className=\"navbar-item\"&gt;\n                    Add Product\n                  &lt;/Link&gt;\n                )}\n                &lt;Link to=\"/cart\" className=\"navbar-item\"&gt;\n                  Cart\n                  &lt;span\n                    className=\"tag is-primary\"\n                    style={{ marginLeft: \"5px\" }}\n                  &gt;\n                    {Object.keys(this.state.cart).length}\n                  &lt;/span&gt;\n                &lt;/Link&gt;\n                {!this.state.user ? (\n                  &lt;Link to=\"/login\" className=\"navbar-item\"&gt;\n                    Login\n                  &lt;/Link&gt;\n                ) : (\n                  &lt;a className=\"navbar-item\" onClick={this.logout}&gt;\n                    Logout\n                  &lt;/a&gt;\n                )}\n              &lt;/div&gt;\n            &lt;/nav&gt;\n            &lt;Switch&gt;\n              &lt;Route exact path=\"/\" component={Component} /&gt;\n              &lt;Route exact path=\"/login\" component={Component} /&gt;\n              &lt;Route exact path=\"/cart\" component={Component} /&gt;\n              &lt;Route exact path=\"/add-product\" component={Component} /&gt;\n              &lt;Route exact path=\"/products\" component={Component} /&gt;\n            &lt;/Switch&gt;\n          &lt;/div&gt;\n        &lt;/Router&gt;\n      &lt;/Context.Provider&gt;\n    );\n  }\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Our <code>App</code> component will be responsible for initializing the application data and will also define methods to manipulate these data. Here, we define the context data and methods using the context Provider component. The data and methods are passed as a property, <code>value</code>, on the Provider component to replace the object given on the context creation. (Note that the value can be of any data type.) We pass the state value and some methods, which we’ll define soon.</p> \n<p>Next, we build our application navigation. To achieve this, we need to wrap our app with a Router component, which can either be <code>BrowserRouter</code> (like in our case) or <code>HashRouter</code>. Next, we define our application’s routes using the Switch and Route component. We also create the app’s navigation menu, with each link using the Link component provided in the React Router module. We also add a reference, <code>routerRef</code>, to the Router component to enable us to access the router from the <code>App</code> component.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15916200132-app-component-1024x45.gif\" alt=\"App component\" width=\"1024\" height=\"45\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176298\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"userauthentication\">User Authentication</h2> \n<p>In the next step, we’ll handle the user authentication. First we need to initialize the user in the <code>App</code> component constructor. This is shown below:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">//./src/App.js\n...  \n  constructor(props) {\n    super(props);\n    this.state = {\n      user: null\n    };\n  }\n...\n</code></pre> \n<p>Next, we make sure the user is loaded when the application starts up by setting the user on component mount, as shown below:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">//.src/App/.js\n...\ncomponentDidMount() {\n    let user = localStorage.getItem(\"user\");\n    user = user ? JSON.parse(user) : null;\n    this.setState({ user });\n  }\n...\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here, we load the last user session from the local storage to the state if it exists. Next, we define the login and logout methods attached to the Context:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">//./src/App.js\n...\n  login = (usn, pwd) =&gt; {\n    let user = data.users.find(u =&gt; u.username === usn &amp;&amp; u.password === pwd);\n    if (user) {\n      this.setState({ user });\n      localStorage.setItem(\"user\", JSON.stringify(user));\n      return true;\n    }\n    return false;\n  };\n  logout = e =&gt; {\n    e.preventDefault();\n    this.setState({ user: null });\n    localStorage.removeItem(\"user\");\n  };\n...\n</code></pre> \n<p>The login method checks if the user and password combination match any user in the array and sets the state user if found. It also adds the user to local storage for persistency. The logout clears the user from both state and local storage. </p> \n<p>Next, we create the login component. First, we create a <code>components</code> folder where we’ll put all our components, then create a <code>Login.js</code> file. This component makes use of the context data. For it to have access to these data and methods, it has to be wrapped using the <code>withContext</code> method we created earlier.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// ./src/components/Login.js\n\nimport React, { Component, Fragment } from \"react\";\nimport withContext from \"../withContext\";\nimport { Redirect } from \"react-router-dom\";\nclass Login extends Component {\n  constructor(props) {\n    super(props);\n    this.state = {\n      username: \"\",\n      password: \"\"\n    };\n  }\n  handleChange = e =&gt;\n    this.setState({ [e.target.name]: e.target.value, error: \"\" });\n\n  login = () =&gt; {\n    const { username, password } = this.state;\n    if (!username || !password) {\n      return this.setState({ error: \"Fill all fields!\" });\n    }\n    let loggedIn = this.props.context.login(username, password);\n    if (!loggedIn) {\n      this.setState({ error: \"Invalid Credentails\" });\n    }\n  };\n  render() {\n    return !this.props.context.user ? (\n      &lt;Fragment&gt;\n        &lt;div className=\"hero is-primary \"&gt;\n          &lt;div className=\"hero-body container\"&gt;\n            &lt;h4 className=\"title\"&gt;Login&lt;/h4&gt;\n          &lt;/div&gt;\n        &lt;/div&gt;\n        &lt;br /&gt;\n        &lt;br /&gt;\n        &lt;div className=\"columns is-mobile is-centered\"&gt;\n          &lt;div className=\"column is-one-third\"&gt;\n            &lt;div className=\"field\"&gt;\n              &lt;label className=\"label\"&gt;User Name: &lt;/label&gt;\n              &lt;input\n                className=\"input\"\n                type=\"text\"\n                name=\"username\"\n                onChange={this.handleChange}\n              /&gt;\n            &lt;/div&gt;\n            &lt;div className=\"field\"&gt;\n              &lt;label className=\"label\"&gt;Password: &lt;/label&gt;\n              &lt;input\n                className=\"input\"\n                type=\"password\"\n                name=\"password\"\n                onChange={this.handleChange}\n              /&gt;\n            &lt;/div&gt;\n            {this.state.error &amp;&amp; (\n              &lt;div className=\"has-text-danger\"&gt;{this.state.error}&lt;/div&gt;\n            )}\n            &lt;div className=\"field is-clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;button\n                className=\"button is-primary is-outlined is-pulled-right\"\n                onClick={this.login}\n              &gt;\n                Submit\n              &lt;/button&gt;\n            &lt;/div&gt;\n          &lt;/div&gt;\n        &lt;/div&gt;\n      &lt;/Fragment&gt;\n    ) : (\n      &lt;Redirect to=\"/products\" /&gt;\n    );\n  }\n}\nexport default withContext(Login);\n</code></pre> \n<p>This component renders a form with two inputs to collect the user login credentials. On submit of the input the component calls the login method, which is passed through the context. This Module also makes sure to redirect to the products page if the user is already logged in. We need to update the <code>App.js</code> component to use the Login component:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// ./src/App.js\n...\nimport Login from \"./components/Login\";\n...\n...\n    &lt;Route exact path=\"/login\" component={Login} /&gt;\n...\n</code></pre> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15916200543-login-1024x503.gif\" alt=\"Login\" width=\"1024\" height=\"503\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176299\" /></p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-create-an-ecommerce-site-with-react/?utm_source=rss\">How to Create an Ecommerce Site with React</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=H3P9xWxgdeo:jWHNMTG1hhw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=H3P9xWxgdeo:jWHNMTG1hhw:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=H3P9xWxgdeo:jWHNMTG1hhw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=H3P9xWxgdeo:jWHNMTG1hhw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/H3P9xWxgdeo\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 10 Jun 2020 16:01:23 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1591621031ecommerce-app.png","linkMd5":"c683fc211657abe788e66a0a350ff5a7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn82@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-26-260_c792a6b7a0b56552.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":337,"sourceBytes":10554,"destBytes":10554,"author":"Deven Rathore","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1591621031ecommerce-app.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn82@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-26-260_c792a6b7a0b56552.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15916199571-our-products-1024x503.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15916200132-app-component-1024x45.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/15916200543-login-1024x503.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=H3P9xWxgdeo:jWHNMTG1hhw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn62@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-43-800_00697c373c1aaf8e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/H3P9xWxgdeo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn26@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-43-342_0e4757c32045fba9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483268},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Why We Moved a 20-Year-Old Site to Gatsby","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176571","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/our-gatsby-redesign/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Why We Moved a 20-Year-Old Site to Gatsby\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594114523gatsby-redesign.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594114523gatsby-redesign-300x225.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594114523gatsby-redesign-768x576.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594114523gatsby-redesign-1024x768.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p>We knew we had a problem.</p> \n<p>In 2019, SitePoint was getting Lighthouse Speed scores under 10 on mobile, and between 20 and 30 on desktop.</p> \n<p>Our efforts to control UX bloat were failing in the wake of a publishing business environment that sprang new leaks just as we’d finished temporarily plugging the last one. Our reliance on advertising, controlled by external parties, was a major obstacle to improved site performance. Our traffic growth had turned into decline.</p> \n<p>On a site that provided people with a place to come and learn to code with best practices, this was not a good look. And it wasn’t a site we could feel proud of, either.</p> \n<p>To make matters worse, operational bottlenecks had arisen that made adaptation a tricky logistical business. Our team was struggling to make changes to the site: having focused on our Premium experience for several years, we were down to one developer with WordPress and PHP experience. To test out code changes, the team would have to wait in a queue to access our staging server.</p> \n<p>It wasn’t energizing work for anyone, and it certainly wasn’t efficient.</p> \n<p>It was time to make some changes, and we set out to look for a solution. After a lot of research, we decided that <a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.com/\">Gatsby</a> would be a great fit for our team. It would play to our talent strengths, help us solve all of the issues we had identified, and allow us to keep using WordPress for the backend so the editorial process wouldn’t need to change.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whywemovedtogatsby\">Why We Moved to Gatsby</h2> [caption id=\"attachment_176594\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"1522\"]\n<img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594113779Visual_Studio_Code_A_Power_User_s_Guide_—_SitePoint.png\" alt=\"SitePoint 2020 Redesign\" width=\"1522\" height=\"914\" class=\"size-full wp-image-176594\" /> The end result.[/caption] \n<p>Early in the research process, Gatsby started to look like a serious frontrunner. SitePoint isn’t a small site, so we knew that the tech we chose had to be able to handle some pretty intense demands. Gatsby checked all of our boxes:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>We could code everything in <a href=\"https://reactjs.org/\">React</a>, a tech that every member of the front-end team knows and uses daily.</li> \n <li>Gatsby is super fast at its core — performance was at the heart of this project, and we could start from a good footing.</li> \n <li>The entire site is rendered as static, which would be great for SEO.</li> \n <li>We could build it as a new project, which meant no worrying about the existing codebase, which brought a huge amount of legacy code with it.</li> \n <li>We could use Gatsby Cloud, allowing the team to get feedback on the build at any time just by pushing the branch to GitHub.</li> \n <li>DDoS attacks on WordPress wouldn’t cause us issues, as the front-end is completely stand-alone.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"moremaintainablecsswithstyledcomponents\">More Maintainable CSS with <code>styled-components</code></h2> \n<p>Since we were going to rebuild the site from scratch, we planned to make some design changes at the same time. To help with this work we decided to use <a href=\"https://styled-components.com/\">styled-components</a>.</p> \n<p>styled-components keeps the site’s styling easy to maintain, and we know where to look when we want to change the style of something — the style is always with the component.</p> \n<h2 id=\"howwemadethebuildhappen\">How We Made the Build Happen</h2> \n<p>We started by following Gatsby’s basic docs and pulling in our posts with the <code>gatsby-source-wordpress</code> plugin.</p> \n<p>This was a big initial test for us: we had to see if it was even <em>possible</em> to use Gatsby for our site.</p> \n<p>After 20 years of blogging, we have over 17,000 posts published. We knew the builds would take a long time, but we had to find out if Gatsby could deal with such a massive amount of content. As you’ve probably figured, the test delivered good news: Gatsby works.</p> \n<p>A quick tip for other teams working with large sites: to make development a better experience, we used environment vars to prevent Gatsby from fetching <em>all</em> of the site’s posts in development. There’s nothing quite like a 60 minute hot reload to slow progress.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">if (hasNextPage &amp;&amp; process.env.NODE_ENV != \"development\") {\n  return fetchPosts({ first: 100, after: endCursor });\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>From this point, we ran into some limitations with the WordPress source plugin. We couldn’t get all the data we needed, so we moved to the <a href=\"https://github.com/wp-graphql/wp-graphql\">WordPress GraphQL plugin</a>.</p> \n<p>We use Yoast to set our metadata for SEO, and had to ensure we were pulling in the correct information. We were able to do this with WordPress GraphQL. By doing it this way, the content team could still edit metadata the same way, and the data would still be dynamic and fetched on each build.</p> \n<p>During the build, we would have three or four people in the team working on parts of the new blog. In the past, if they wanted to get feedback they’d have to push to our staging server and make sure nobody was already using it.</p> \n<p>We found that Gatsby Cloud was a great solution to this issue. Now when someone pushes to a branch in GitHub, it creates a build in Gatsby Cloud along with a preview link. Our developers could share this link and get immediate testing and feedback much more effectively than before.</p> \n<p>This faster feedback cycle made it easy to have multiple people on the team working on the build and put an end to a major bottleneck.</p> \n<h2 id=\"launchdayfun\">Launch Day Fun</h2> \n<p>On the big day, we launched the new site and ran through our initial tests. The new blog was <em>flying</em> — every page load felt instant.</p> \n<p>We ran into some problems on SitePoint Premium, which started running into slows and even crashes. The culprit was a new element on blog pages that pulled in the popular books people were currently reading. It would do this via a client-side API call, and it was too much for Premium to handle due to the amount of traffic we get on the blog side.</p> \n<p>We quickly added some page caching to the API to temporarily solve the issues. We realized we were doing this wrong — we should have been sourcing this data at build time, so that the popular books are already loaded when we serve the page to the user.</p> \n<p>This is the main mindset shift you need to make when using Gatsby: any data that you can get at build time should be fetched at build time. You should only use client-side API calls when you need live data.</p> \n<p>Once we’d re-written the API call to happen during the build, the first load of a blog page was even quicker — and Premium stopped crashing.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatwestillneedtosolve\">What We Still Need to Solve</h2> \n<p>While it’s hard to overstate how much better our on-site experience is today, there are still a few pain points we need to solve.</p> \n<p>If a new article is published, or if content is updated — as it is multiple times per day — we need to re-run the Gatsby build before these changes show up.</p> \n<p>Our solution for that right now is a simple cron job that runs at pre-scheduled times over the course of a day. The long-term solution to this is to add a webhook to the WordPress publish and update button, so that a new build is triggered once pressed.</p> \n<p>We also need to get incremental builds running. Right now, the entire site needs to be rebuilt each time, and given our content archive, this can take a while. Gatsby just introduced incremental builds as we went live, and we’re working on implementing this on our site. Once that’s set up our builds will be much faster if the only thing that has changed is content.</p> \n<p>Our speed score is still not where we want it to be. While the site feels subjectively very fast, we are still not getting consistent scores in Lighthouse. We want to get both mobile and desktop into the green zone (scores of 90+) for optimal user experience and SEO.</p> \n<h2 id=\"wouldwedoitagain\">Would We Do It Again?</h2> \n<p>A launch of this type would normally be a pretty nerve-wracking event, and take a lot of work from the team on launch day.</p> \n<p>With Gatsby, our launch was really easy. We just had to move WordPress onto a new domain, and point sitepoint.com at the Gatsby version of the site.</p> \n<p>Then we sat back and watched the numbers to see what happened to our traffic. Within a few days, the data was starting to come in and we were seeing a 15% increase in traffic. User engagement metrics were up across the board. And we hadn’t even removed our ads yet (which, you may have noticed, we’ve since done).</p> \n<p>It’s not hard to figure out why the effects were so immediate. We had better SEO running on static HTML and CSS pages, and massive speed improvements made possible by the move to Gatsby.</p> \n<p>Since we made the move, we’ve increased our Lighthouse speed scores from 6-15 on mobile to the 50-60 range, and from the 30s on desktop into the 70s. We wanted to ensure speed remained top of mind with this change, so we’re using a great tool called <a href=\"https://calibreapp.com/\">Calibre</a> that runs speed tests over a number of top pages each day and alerts us to the scores. We are using this tool to continue to improve our score, so I hope to have another article for you in three months when we get everything to stay in the 90+ range.</p> \n<p>The team loves working in Gatsby. The blog codebase was something that nobody wanted to work on. Now, everyone wants to take those cards thanks to the great developer experience.</p> \n<p>If you’ve been eyeing a move to Gatsby and wondering if it’s ready for prime time, take our advice — it’s worth the switch.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/our-gatsby-redesign/?utm_source=rss\">Why We Moved a 20-Year-Old Site to Gatsby</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=j_AQq753JIs:OJFqwyYrAr8:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=j_AQq753JIs:OJFqwyYrAr8:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=j_AQq753JIs:OJFqwyYrAr8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=j_AQq753JIs:OJFqwyYrAr8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/j_AQq753JIs\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 06 Jul 2020 22:00:51 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594114523gatsby-redesign.jpg","linkMd5":"1f73e2fd1d81e7687b67bfe98b22474a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn82@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-27-174_f575e47057458eb9.webp","destWidth":1880,"destHeight":1410,"sourceBytes":26590,"destBytes":26590,"author":"Stuart Mitchell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594114523gatsby-redesign.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn82@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-27-174_f575e47057458eb9.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594113779Visual_Studio_Code_A_Power_User_s_Guide_—_SitePoint.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn64@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-42-860_9c5cbcbce096bfd2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=j_AQq753JIs:OJFqwyYrAr8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn13@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-38-528_a13e340578a3f901.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/j_AQq753JIs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn6@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-35-191_64b512f995074034.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483258},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Simple Strategies for Winning the Positions Other Developers Want","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176175","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/getting-jobs-other-web-developers-want/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Simple Strategies for Winning the Positions Other Developers Want\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1589506890developer-job.png\" alt=\"Simple strategies for getting positions other developers want\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1589506890developer-job-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1589506890developer-job.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>How do they do it?</strong></p> \n<p><strong>“How is [insert developer name] able to attract the promotions and job offers they’re getting? Their work is trash; I’m a much better developer! I work twice as hard, write better code, and produce 2x more work than they do? This is completely unfair.”</strong></p> \n<p>You’re right, it <em>is</em> unfair.</p> \n<p>This is a serious career problem, assuming that you’ve made an accurate assumption about your skills and performance. Seriously, what gives?</p> \n<h2 id=\"whymostdevelopersoptimizeforthewronggoal\">Why most developers optimize for the wrong goal</h2> \n<p>It’s a common mistake made by many employees in general. Here’s a quote from Reddit user <a href=\"https://www.reddit.com/user/Myidiotbox/\">Myidiotbox</a> that encapsulates both the attitude of many employees and the response they receive in return.</p> \n<p><a class=\"embedly-card\" href=\"https://www.reddit.com/r/WalgreensStores/comments/dvbygj/an_interesting_title/f7brws0\">Card</a></p> \n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"//embed.redditmedia.com/widgets/platform.js\" charset=\"UTF-8\"></script></p> \n<p>This is the unspoken attitude lurking beneath for many people.</p> \n<p>“I’m working really hard so I deserve X. I did my job well so I want Y.”</p> \n<p>Here’s the problem with this attitude.</p> \n<p>It takes you further away from the goals you want (such as being treated well, making more money, achieving significance, and so on). This perception is the primary reason so many developers fail to achieve the career goals they aspire to.</p> \n<p>Here are the goals (if you can call them that) a healthy employer looks for.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Can I count on this developer to deliver amazing work consistently?</li> \n <li>Is this developer loyal or will he betray me and jump ship as soon as he gets the chance?</li> \n <li>How easy is it to replace these developers?</li> \n <li>Could I replace them if they left?</li> \n <li>How long would it take and how much would it cost me?</li> \n <li>This developer is killing it, how do I help them produce more amazing work?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>See the problem?</p> \n<p>There’s a mismatch here. The vast majority of people are struggling with <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunning%E2%80%93Kruger_effect\">Dunning-Kruger effect</a> and are prone to <a href=\"https://www.apa.org/monitor/feb03/overestimate\">overestimate their competence</a>. They believe they’re doing a better job relative to their peers.</p> \n<p>But they’re not.</p> \n<p>Here’s why this is an issue. This mismatched thinking puts you at odds with your employer. This creates significant problems down the line, too, because it turns employees (you) in to mercenaries over time.</p> \n<p>If this sounds harsh, it’s not intended to be.</p> \n<p>Here are some simple strategies web developers can use to attract the positions other developers want with minimal effort.</p> \n<h3 id=\"strategy1becomeapatriotstayapatriot\">Strategy #1: Become a patriot, stay a patriot</h3> \n<p>In 2013, Gallup worked with then Nationwide CEO Steve Rasmussen to improve employee engagement. In the course of their relationship, Rasmussen shared a surprising observation.</p> \n<p>Employees are either <a href=\"https://news.gallup.com/businessjournal/157676/employees-either-patriots-mercenaries.aspx\"><strong>patriots</strong> or <em>mercenaries</em></a>.</p> \n<p>Not because they want to be but because they have to be.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Patriots totally identify with their company, and mercenaries are more likely to focus on personal outcomes.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p><strong>Patriot</strong> employees are engaged. They have ownership, they believe in their firm and their firm believes in them. Instead of looking out for themselves, they’re focused on looking out for their firm.</p> \n<p>On the other hand, <strong>mercenaries</strong> are focused on themselves. They tend to rely on serial job-hopping, power hoarding, and social climbing to get what they want. Mercenaries are focused on getting as much value as they can for themselves; they don’t care much about their company.</p> \n<p>It’s no surprise then that they’re <em>disengaged</em>.</p> \n<p>If the interests of the firm happen to align with their own interests, they’ll do what’s best for the firm. But they’re not really focused on putting their firm ahead of themselves.</p> \n<p>Most of the time they <em>can’t</em>.</p> \n<p>Why? Because their employer is a mercenary: these employers are focused on squeezing as much value as they can out of their employees. Then, they’re tossed aside once they’re burned out and used up.</p> \n<p>You’ll want to stay a patriot.</p> \n<p>This means you continue to buy in to your company’s vision. You continue to believe in your employer or co-workers and you look out for them. The instant you can’t do that, you start looking for another job. Here’s why it’s important to remain a patriot.</p> \n<p><em><a href=\"https://youtu.be/h1Yg8QSEvWw?t=4233\">Intention has a smell</a>.</em></p> \n<p>The exceptional opportunities, benefits, and rewards go overwhelmingly to people who like, trust, and believe in you. These people can <em>smell</em> your intentions, partially due to the fact that <a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/231225277_Chemosignals_Communicate_Human_Emotions\">humans communicate chemically</a>.</p> \n<p>Additionally, there’s a certain kind of tone, inflection, attention, and posture that’s communicated when we’re actually interested and engaged in something. If you’re like most humans on planet Earth, you know what that looks like. The better you are at remaining invested in your employer and co-workers — helping them solve tough problems, sticking with them through bad times — the easier it is win these coveted positions.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/getting-jobs-other-web-developers-want/?utm_source=rss\">Simple Strategies for Winning the Positions Other Developers Want</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=nYXImqAXYUc:HjPc97AjsuU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=nYXImqAXYUc:HjPc97AjsuU:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=nYXImqAXYUc:HjPc97AjsuU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=nYXImqAXYUc:HjPc97AjsuU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/nYXImqAXYUc\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 18 May 2020 07:54:44 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1589506890developer-job.png","linkMd5":"3a0d9c31ddec8d70e52effae13ecf803","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn41@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-26-865_e21076c054e56216.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":9584,"destBytes":9584,"author":"Andrew McDermott","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1589506890developer-job.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn41@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-26-865_e21076c054e56216.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=nYXImqAXYUc:HjPc97AjsuU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn71@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-45-479_c51a799351c9c23d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/nYXImqAXYUc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn97@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-44-544_3391ff1fd078004f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483271},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"75 Zsh Commands, Plugins, Aliases and Tools","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175281","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/zsh-commands-plugins-aliases-tools/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"75 Zsh Commands, Plugins, Aliases and Tools\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583201866zsh-commands.jpg\" alt=\"75 Zsh Commands, Plugins, Aliases and Tools\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583201866zsh-commands-300x170.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583201866zsh-commands.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>I spend a lot of my day in the terminal, and my shell of choice is <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z_shell\">Zsh</a> — a highly customizable Unix shell that packs some very powerful features. As I’m a <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://dev.to/drm317/the-lazy-developer-5goe\">lazy developer</a><sup>TM</sup>, I’m always looking for ways to type less and to automate all the things. Luckily this is something that Zsh lends itself well to.</strong></p> \n<p>In this post, I’m going to share with you 75 commands, plugins, aliases and tools that will hopefully save you some keystrokes and make you more productive in your day-to-day work.</p> \n<p>If you don’t have Zsh installed on your machine, then check out <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/zsh-tips-tricks/\">this post</a>, where I show you how to get up and running.</p> \n<h2 id=\"15thingszshcandooutofthebox\">15 Things Zsh Can Do out of the Box</h2> \n<p>Zsh shares a lot of handy features with Bash. None of the following are unique to Zsh, but they’re good to know nonetheless. I encourage you to start using the command line to perform operations such as those listed below. It might seem like more work than using a GUI at first, but once you get the hang of things, you’ll never look back.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Entering <code>cd</code> from anywhere on the file system will bring you straight back to your home directory.</li> \n <li>Entering <code>!!</code> will bring up the last command. This is handy if a command fails because it needs admin rights. In this case you can type <code>sudo !!</code>.</li> \n <li>You can use <code>&amp;&amp;</code> to chain multiple commands. For example, <code>mkdir project &amp;&amp; cd project &amp;&amp; npm init -y</code>.</li> \n <li>Conditional execution is possible using <code>||</code>. For example, <code>git commit -m \"whatever...\" || echo \"Commit failed\"</code>.</li> \n <li>Using a <code>-p</code> switch with the <code>mkdir</code> command will allow you to create parent directories as needed. Using brace expansion reduces repetition. For example, <code>mkdir -p articles/jim/sitepoint/article{1,2,3}</code>.</li> \n <li>Set <a href=\"https://opensource.com/article/19/8/what-are-environment-variables\">environment variables</a> on a per-command basis like so: <code>NODE_DEBUG=myapp node index.js</code>. Or, on a per-session basis like so: <code>export NODE_DEBUG=myapp</code>. You can check it was set by typing <code>echo $&lt;variable-name&gt;</code>.</li> \n <li>Pipe the output of one command into a second command. For example, <code>cat /var/log/kern.log | less</code> to make a long log readable, or <code>history | grep ssh</code> to search for any history entries containing “ssh”.</li> \n <li>You can open files in your editor from the terminal. For example, <code>nano ~/.zshrc</code> (nano), <code>subl ~/.zshrc</code> (Sublime Text), <code>code ~/.zshrc</code> (VS Code). If the file doesn’t exist, it will be created when you press <em>Save</em> in the editor.</li> \n <li>Navigation is an important skill to master. Don’t just rely on your arrow keys. For example, <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>a</kbd> will take you to the beginning of a line.</li> \n <li>Whereas <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>e</kbd> will take you to the end.</li> \n <li>You can use <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>w</kbd> to delete one word (backw­ards).</li> \n <li><kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>u</kbd> will remove everything from the cursor to the beginning of the line.</li> \n <li><kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>k</kbd> will clear everything from the cursor to the end of the line. These last three can be undone with <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>y</kbd>.</li> \n <li>You can copy text with <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>Shift</kbd> + <kbd>c</kbd>. This is much more elegant than right clicking and selecting <em>Copy</em>.</li> \n <li>Conversely, you can paste copied text with <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>shift</kbd> + <kbd>v</kbd>.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Try to commit those key combos to memory. You’ll be surprised at how often they come in handy.</p> \n<h2 id=\"15customaliasestoboostyourproductivity\">15 Custom Aliases to Boost Your Productivity</h2> \n<p>Aliases are terminal shortcuts for regular commands. You can add them to your <code>~/.zshrc</code> file, then reload your terminal (using <code>source ~/.zshrc</code>) for them to take effect.</p> \n<p>The syntax for declaring a (simple) alias is as follows:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">alias [alias-name]='[command]'\n</code></pre> \n<p>Aliases are great for often-used commands, long commands, or commands with a hard-to-remember syntax. Here are some of the ones I use on a regular basis:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>A <code>myip</code> alias, which prints your current public IP address to the terminal: <code>alias myip='curl http://ipecho.net/plain; echo'</code>.</li> \n <li>A <code>distro</code> alias to output information about your Linux distribution: <code>alias distro='cat /etc/*-release'</code>.</li> \n <li>A <code>reload</code> alias, as I can never seem to remember how to reload my terminal: <code>alias reload='source ~/.zshrc'</code>.</li> \n <li>An <code>undo-git-reset</code> alias: <code>alias undo-git-reset-head=\"git reset 'HEAD@{1}'\"</code>. This reverts the effects of running <code>git reset HEAD~</code>.</li> \n <li>An alias to update package lists: <code>alias sapu='sudo apt-get update'</code>.</li> \n <li>An alias to rerun the previous command with <code>sudo</code>: <code>alias ffs='sudo !!'</code>.</li> \n <li>Because I’m lazy, I have aliased <code>y</code> to the <code>yarn</code> command: <code>alias y='yarn'</code>. This means I can clone a repo, then just type <kbd>y</kbd> to pull in all the dependencies. I learned this one from Scott Tolinski on <a href=\"https://syntax.fm/\">Syntax</a>.</li> \n <li>Not one of the ones I use, but this alias blows away the <code>node_modules</code> folder and removes the <code>package-lock.json</code> file, before reinstalling a project’s dependencies: <code>alias yolo='rm -rf node_modules/ &amp;&amp; rm package-lock.json &amp;&amp; yarn install'</code>. As you probably know, yolo stands for <em>Y</em>ou <em>O</em>nly <em>L</em>ive <em>O</em>nce.</li> \n <li>An alias to open my <code>.zshrc</code> file for editing: <code>alias zshconfig='subl $HOME/.zshrc'</code>.</li> \n <li>An alias to update the list of Ruby versions <a href=\"https://github.com/rbenv/rbenv\">rbenv</a> can install: <code>alias update-available-rubies='cd ~/.rbenv/plugins/ruby-build &amp;&amp; git pull'</code></li> \n <li>An alias to kick off a server in your current directory (no npm packages required): <code>alias server='python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8000'</code>.</li> \n <li>You can also create an alias to open documentation in your browser: <code>alias npmhelp='firefox https://github.com/robbyrussell/oh-my-zsh/tree/master/plugins/npm'</code>.</li> \n <li>A global alias to pipe a command’s output to <code>less</code>: <code>alias -g L='| less'</code>. You can use it like so: <code>cat production.log L</code>.</li> \n <li>A global alias to pipe a command’s output to <code>grep</code>: <code>alias -g G='| grep'</code>. You can use it like so: <code>history G ssh</code>.</li> \n <li>You can also use functions to create aliases. The following (taken from <a href=\"https://dev.to/aspittel/my-terminal-setup-iterm2--zsh--30lm\">here</a>) creates an alias that adds, commits, and pushes code to GitHub:<br /> <code>bash<br /> function acp() {<br /> git add .<br /> git commit -m \"$1\"<br /> git push<br /> }<br /> </code></li> \n</ul> \n<p>There are lots of places to find more ideas for aliases online. For example, <a href=\"https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=9869231\">this Hacker News discussion</a>, or this post on <a href=\"https://blog.lftechnology.com/command-line-productivity-with-zsh-aliases-28b7cebfdff9\">command line productivity with Zsh</a>.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/zsh-commands-plugins-aliases-tools/?utm_source=rss\">75 Zsh Commands, Plugins, Aliases and Tools</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=1WGvMaXeLN8:KAfpXGVzn44:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=1WGvMaXeLN8:KAfpXGVzn44:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=1WGvMaXeLN8:KAfpXGVzn44:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=1WGvMaXeLN8:KAfpXGVzn44:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/1WGvMaXeLN8\"
