+0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583201866zsh-commands.jpg","linkMd5":"f4b87d225982f3481fd5760ee5c81155","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn33@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-24-645_193f88ce28374cb0.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":4614,"destBytes":4614,"author":"James Hibbard","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583201866zsh-commands.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn33@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-24-645_193f88ce28374cb0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=1WGvMaXeLN8:KAfpXGVzn44:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn69@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-35-401_6cb17fd070d5d9d1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/1WGvMaXeLN8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn46@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-37-076_9d2fb0dd59cb593a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483297},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"5 Projects to Help You Master Modern CSS","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175275","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/master-modern-css-projects/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"5 Projects to Help You Master Modern CSS\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583198333master-modern-css.jpg\" alt=\"5 Projects to Help You Master Modern CSS\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583198333master-modern-css-300x170.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583198333master-modern-css.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Many claim CSS is not a programming language. I agree — <em>it’s tougher</em>. A mastery of CSS requires skills in design, determination, inventiveness, experience, as well as coding (especially when using preprocessors such as <a href=\"https://sass-lang.com/\">Sass</a>).</strong></p> \n<p>CSS <em>suggests</em> layouts and styles to the browser. A browser can interpret those suggestions whichever way it chooses and, even then, the user or device can ignore or override any properties. Creating high-performance code which works well across all devices and screen resolutions is a challenge that few attempt or successfully complete. However, the rewards can be exhilarating.</p> \n<p>Starting with the easiest, the following project suggestions will help you on your journey to CSS mastery using books available at <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/\">SitePoint Premium</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1makeasiteprinterfriendly\">1. Make a Site Printer-friendly</h2> \n<p>Visit a site you’re working on and attempt to print (or print preview) a page. Are you happy with the results?</p> \n<p>HTML pages are a continuous medium which do not necessarily work well on printed media. Inappropriate sections, scaling, text sizes, column dimensions, and missing or cropped content all lead to an inaccessible printing experience that few developers consider.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, print CSS can be developed within a few hours. It’s generally a matter of resetting styles (black on white), removing unnecessary sections (menus, hero images, forms, social media widgets, etc.), linearizing the layout, and reducing the paper and ink requirements.</p> \n<p>Delve into <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-master-2nd-edition/read/2/jyqxmd9k\">Browser-based Developer Tools</a> (from <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-master-2nd-edition/\">CSS Master</a>) and <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/browser-devtool-secrets/\">Browser DevTool Secrets</a> to discover how to examine and modify styles after switching to print rendering.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-master-2nd-edition/read/8/jyqxmeaa\">Applying CSS Conditionally</a> describes how to define <code>@media</code> query rules including <code>print</code> stylesheets.</p> \n<p>Consider your <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/smashing-book-6-new-frontiers-in-web-design/read/4/jynr4gos\">Strategy Guide to CSS Custom Properties</a> (from <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/smashing-book-6-new-frontiers-in-web-design/\">New Frontiers In Web Design</a>) to determine whether CSS variables could help with printing properties. Also consider <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-animation-101/read/19/jyqr3yvo\">Accessibility</a> (from <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-animation-101/\">CSS Animation 101</a>) to switch off animations or print them in the best state.</p> \n<p>Finally, <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-tools-skills/read/6\">How to Create Printer-friendly Pages with CSS</a> (from <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-tools-skills/\">CSS Tools &amp; Skills</a>) provides a full print-optimization tutorial with tips to save ink and paper costs.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2applythemingtoanexistingsite\">2. Apply Theming to an Existing Site</h2> \n<p>A single color scheme is boring! Everyone expects a dark mode option in their OS and applications, so why not add one to your website?</p> \n<p>Until recently, theme switchers typically required an additional set of styles with JavaScript-powered switching controls. However, modern browsers make life easier with CSS Custom Properties (variables) and the <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/@media/prefers-color-scheme\"><code>prefers-color-scheme</code></a> <code>@media</code> rule.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/smashing-book-6-new-frontiers-in-web-design/read/4/jynr4gsd\">Strategies for Theming</a> (from <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/smashing-book-6-new-frontiers-in-web-design/\">New Frontiers In Web Design</a>) provides a range of ideas and considerations when designing your new theme.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-master-2nd-edition/read/8/jyqxmeaa\">Applying CSS Conditionally</a> (from <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/css-master-2nd-edition/\">CSS Master</a>) describes how to define <code>@media</code> query rules including <code>prefers-color-scheme</code>.</p> \n<p>Finally, <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/modern-css/read/7/jyr01bqg\">Modern CSS: Adding a CSS Dark Theme</a> (from <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/modern-css/read/\">Modern CSS</a>) provides a full dark-theme-enabling tutorial.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/master-modern-css-projects/?utm_source=rss\">5 Projects to Help You Master Modern CSS</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=7hndWz7b2J4:bsPYruNMV_w:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=7hndWz7b2J4:bsPYruNMV_w:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=7hndWz7b2J4:bsPYruNMV_w:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=7hndWz7b2J4:bsPYruNMV_w:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/7hndWz7b2J4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sat, 30 May 2020 21:00:45 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583198333master-modern-css.jpg","linkMd5":"36d42a3dafd082318a8b132a0dfb897f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn5@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-26-877_96d68a82ece1085f.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":9466,"destBytes":9466,"author":"Craig Buckler","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583198333master-modern-css.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn5@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-26-877_96d68a82ece1085f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=7hndWz7b2J4:bsPYruNMV_w:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn38@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-35-361_568d3d604cffa8e0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/7hndWz7b2J4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-45-520_4d266c25e07ad3a4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483269},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Create a QR Code Reader for Your Mobile Website","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=157902","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/create-qr-code-reader-mobile-website/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Create a QR Code Reader for Your Mobile Website\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/1591752091qr-code-reader.png\" alt=\"How to Create a QR Code Reader for Your Mobile Website\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/1591752091qr-code-reader-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/1591752091qr-code-reader.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>The barcode and QR code have modernized our shopping and searching experience. Customers carrying smartphones can now pick up a product anywhere in the world, scan its barcode or its QR code using one of the many free phone apps and find out its lowest price as well as where it can be bought.</strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/1499229151barcode_apps.png\" alt=\"Screenshots of apps with barcode scanner buttons\" title=\"Phone apps that support barcode scanning\" /></p> \n<p>Companies like Walmart and Amazon have embraced this technique to draw customers to their online and offline stores using their phone app. Other companies like Fedex and UPS allow customers to scan the codes on packages using a phone app, instead of needing to manually type in long lists of characters.</p> \n<p>If the users of your mobile website have a need to type in long codes like activation codes, or they like to look up specific products on your website based on a model number printed in a magazine or advertisement, then you too can take advantage of QR codes to eliminate the frustration of tiny keyboards and spare them the need to double check for errors.</p> \n<h2 id=\"qrcodescanningwithyourmobilewebsite\">QR Code Scanning with Your Mobile Website</h2> \n<p>You don’t need a native phone app to scan QR codes. It’s quite simple to create your own QR code reader. Your website running on a smartphone equipped with a camera and running a little JavaScript can do the same trick.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://ilrm9.csb.app/\">Here’s a demo</a> of a QR code scanner that works not only on Mobile but also in most modern devices. All you need is a camera and a QR code to scan.</p> \n<p>If you don’t have a QR code handy, here’s one that shows the first eight digits of Pi.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/1499242522Pi-encoded-as-QR.gif\" alt=\"Test the QR Code Reader: QR code encoding the value of Pi\" title=\"The digits of Pi encoded in a QR\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"creatingtheqrcodereader\">Creating the QR Code Reader</h2> \n<p>Our QR code reader will need some HTML and JavaScript but most importantly, a JavaScript library capable of interpreting the QR code.</p> \n<p>We’re not going to build that ourselves, because there are some great libraries out there doing this for us, so we don’t need to reinvent the wheel for our current purposes.</p> \n<p>Let’s begin by creating an <code>index.html</code> file.</p> \n<h3 id=\"addingthehtml\">Adding the HTML</h3> \n<p>We’ll need some very simple HTML for this project. Add the following to your body tag:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;div id=\"container\"&gt;\n    &lt;h1&gt;QR Code Scanner&lt;/h1&gt;\n\n    &lt;a id=\"btn-scan-qr\"&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/1499401426qr_icon.svg\"&gt;\n    &lt;a/&gt;\n\n    &lt;canvas hidden=\"\" id=\"qr-canvas\"&gt;&lt;/canvas&gt;\n\n    &lt;div id=\"qr-result\" hidden=\"\"&gt;\n        &lt;b&gt;Data:&lt;/b&gt; &lt;span id=\"outputData\"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;\n    &lt;/div&gt;\n&lt;/div&gt;\n\n&lt;script src=\"./src/qrCodeScanner.js\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>As you can see, we have a wrapper container with a title, the QR icon image wrapped in an <code>a</code> tag, a <code>canvas</code> and a <code>div</code> where we’ll show the result of the scan.</p> \n<p>Outside the container <code>div</code> we’re including the <code>qrCodeScanner.js</code> file. We’ll create it later, but first we’ll improve the look of our app.</p> \n<h3 id=\"addingstyles\">Adding Styles</h3> \n<p>Add the stylesheet to the head of our HTML:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"src/styles.css\" /&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now we want to create the <code>style.css</code> file within the <code>src</code> folder. We just want some basic styles for this sample app. Add the following to your css file:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"css language-css\">html {\n  height: 100%;\n}\n\nbody {\n  font-family: sans-serif;\n  padding: 0 10px;\n  height: 100%;\n  background: black;\n  margin: 0;\n}\n\nh1 {\n  color: white;\n  margin: 0;\n  padding: 15px;\n}\n\n#container {\n  text-align: center;\n  margin: 0;\n}\n\n#qr-canvas {\n  margin: auto;\n  width: calc(100% - 20px);\n  max-width: 400px;\n}\n\n#btn-scan-qr {\n  cursor: pointer;\n}\n\n#btn-scan-qr img {\n  height: 10em;\n  padding: 15px;\n  margin: 15px;\n  background: white;\n}\n\n#qr-result {\n  font-size: 1.2em;\n  margin: 20px auto;\n  padding: 20px;\n  max-width: 700px;\n  background-color: white;\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Nothing fancy at all. We’ll leave everything centered with a big QR button in the middle and the result underneath. We’re using black and white like the QR codes.</p> \n<h3 id=\"includingthedependentjavascriptlibraries\">Including the Dependent JavaScript Libraries</h3> \n<p>The secret to reading QR codes is math, and the substitute for math is open-source libraries. To read QR codes, we’ll be using the <a href=\"https://github.com/LazarSoft/jsqrcode\">JavaScript port</a> of the Java-based <a href=\"https://github.com/zxing/zxing\">image processing library</a> written by ZXing. The JavaScript version was ported by Lazar Laszlo.</p> \n<p>Because the JavaScript library consists of 17 files, we’ve taken the liberty of merging them into one file, wrapping the code in an anonymous function to prevent pollution of the global namespace and putting the file through Google Closure’s minifier to make the file size smaller.</p> \n<h3 id=\"someminortweakstothelibrary\">Some Minor Tweaks to the Library</h3> \n<p>In order to make the library more adaptable, we’ve added a few minor changes to the library’s output function to differentiate between a <em>success</em> response and an <em>error</em> response.</p> \n<p>Two important changes made were in <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/jsqrcode/blob/master/src/qrcode.js\">qrcode.js</a>, to these two lines:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">qrcode.result = \"error decoding QR Code\";\n//...\nqrcode.callback(\"Failed to load the image\");\n</code></pre> \n<p>These strings have been replaced by <code>Error</code> objects:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">qrcode.result = Error(\"error decoding QR Code\");\n//...\nqrcode.callback(Error(\"Failed to load the image\"));\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now I can detect in my callback function whether an error occurred, just by checking if the callback payload is an instance of <code>Error</code> or not.</p> \n<p>Those changes can be found in <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/jsqrcode/\">this fork</a> of the library.</p> \n<h3 id=\"addingthescripttag\">Adding the Script Tag</h3> \n<p>To use the library in our QR code reader, we first need to include it in our HTML using a regular script tag:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;script src=\"https://rawgit.com/sitepoint-editors/jsqrcode/master/src/qr_packed.js\"&gt;\n&lt;/script&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"treatingitasanapp\">Treating It as an App</h3> \n<p>Something we’ll need to do is tell mobile browsers that we don’t want to scale this site in portrait mode. This can be achieved by adding the following meta tag within the <code>head</code> element:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;meta name=\"viewport\" content=\"width=device-width; initial-scale=1.0; maximum-scale=1.0; user-scalable=0;\"/&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/create-qr-code-reader-mobile-website/?utm_source=rss\">How to Create a QR Code Reader for Your Mobile Website</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=5EHQxmPKy4U:aNk76Njbqgw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=5EHQxmPKy4U:aNk76Njbqgw:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Productive Remote Work (When Your Mental Health Says “No”)","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175036","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/productive-remote-work-when-your-mental-health-says-no/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Productive Remote Work (When Your Mental Health Says “No”)\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582026850remote-working.png\" alt=\"Productive Remote Working\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582026850remote-working-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582026850remote-working.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Remote work is <em>not</em> easy. It sounds like a dream (and it honestly is in a lot of ways), but there’s a darker side to remote work that one can’t understand until they’ve done it.</strong></p> \n<p>Here’s the deal. People that work remotely often suffer from suboptimal mental health, and so you’re probably wondering, why on earth do they do it? Well, the fact is, while remote working comes with some very unique challenges, so does <em>not</em> working remotely. The difference is that <em>remote</em> work can offer the flexibility you need to build a lifestyle that suits you.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582026150remote-work.jpg\" alt=\"people sitting at table with laptop\" /></p> \n<p>Indeed, remote work isn’t a silver bullet for burnout or wanderlust, but if you do happen to try it out and eventually wind up succumbing to loneliness, or a lack of motivation or productivity (as many remote workers do), at least you’ll have the opportunity to change things up and make things better.</p> \n<p>In the eyes of many, it’s the lesser of two evils.</p> \n<p>That being said, attempting to diagnose what your mind and body needs isn’t that easy. What might work one day might not work on another day, and what might work for one individual might not work for another individual. Humans are complex, and in the case of remote work, everyday productivity tricks often don’t cut it.</p> \n<p>Let’s take a look.</p> \n<h2 id=\"ifeellonely\">“I feel lonely”</h2> \n<p>Loneliness is a big issue (maybe the biggest?) for freelance remote workers and digital nomads in foreign countries, but it can also affect those that work in distributed teams (especially when some team members <em>aren’t</em> remote, as one can feel like an outsider at work using this setup). Let’s look at the solutions.</p> \n<h3 id=\"utilizecoworkingspaces\">Utilize co-working spaces</h3> \n<p>Co-working spaces aren’t for everyone. If you teach English, it’s obviously a no-no (not because of the noise, but because the noise would be distracting to <em>other</em> remote workers). If you’re only required to dive into the odd video call, though, many co-working spaces include a few hours of “booth time”.</p> \n<p>Throw in super-fast Wi-Fi, free coffee, daily events, and a likeminded crowd, joining a co-working space is like joining a community, and some co-working spaces (such as <a href=\"https://hubud.org/\">Hubud</a>) and <a href=\"https://www.dojobali.org/\">Dojo Bali</a>) are literally famous! <strong>Good vibes = a huge motivation boost</strong>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582026194co-working.jpg\" alt=\"happy co-workers sitting with laptops on comfy chairs\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"workfrombarsandcafs\">Work from bars and cafés</h3> \n<p>Cafés and bars work well too. The noise and seating options might be a tad unpredictable, and when going to a new place one has to find the Wi-Fi password, but all in all the experience is very much the same. It’s still fairly easy to meet other people, as it’s likely that you won’t be the only regular customer.</p> \n<p><em>Pro-tip: download <a href=\"https://www.wifimap.io/\">Wi-Fi Map app</a> to get the Wi-Fi passwords of networks near you!</em></p> \n<div style=\"margin-bottom: 1.5em;\"> \n <img style=\"margin-bottom: 0.5em;\" src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582026235october-1024x768.jpg\" />\n <span style=\"display:block; font-size:0.8em; text-align:center; margin: 0;\">My favourite café — October Coffee Gaya, Kota Kinabalu, Malaysia)</span> \n</div> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=83vgrFijiDc:xq4fEhd9h4U:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"4 Most High-Demand Skillsets for Remote Jobs","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175791","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/remote-jobs-high-demand-skillsets/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"4 Most High-Demand Skillsets for Remote Jobs\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586227008remote-job.png\" alt=\"4 Most In-demand Skill Sets for Remote Jobs\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586227008remote-job-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586227008remote-job.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p>Working remotely is on the rise, and will continue to do so long after COVID-19 runs its course. If you’re thinking about ditching the office but aren’t sure how, learning one (or more!) of the following skillsets will increase your chances of landing a remote job.</p> \n<h2 id=\"softwaredevelopment\">Software Development</h2> \n<p>Software development is the most in-demand remote job in the world. And with a median salary of $66,000/year, you can probably afford a decent home office setup in which to operate.</p> \n<p>Software development might be the job for you if you like solving problems, building things, and continuous learning. Even the best developers have to jump on GitHub or Stack Overflow from time to time to crowdsource a solution. In fact, development practically necessitates collaboration, making the development community extremely tight and incredibly helpful.</p> \n<p>So what skills does a remote software developer need in 2020? Well, a lot of them. Google “software development skills” and you’ll find list upon list of subjects like programming languages, algorithms, databases, and encryption. But good news (and, as you’ll find, a running theme in this article): you don’t have to learn everything.</p> \n<p>Instead, choose a software development concentration. For example, going from software development to Java development immediately cuts your required skill set in half. And you don’t have to stop there. Refining your concentration to mobile Java development, or even mobile game Java development, turns a near Herculean task into something much more reasonable.</p> \n<h2 id=\"digitalmarketing\">Digital Marketing</h2> \n<p>Digital marketing is another wildly in-demand skill set. Digital marketers are responsible for services like social media campaign planning, content coordination, SEO, and PPC ads. Remote digital marketing jobs average a median salary of $50,500/year, and nearly every industry is hiring.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/remote-jobs-high-demand-skillsets/?utm_source=rss\">4 Most High-Demand Skillsets for Remote Jobs</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=FEEuK1Jz_8Q:ZNyZtC5WRoI:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=FEEuK1Jz_8Q:ZNyZtC5WRoI:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=FEEuK1Jz_8Q:ZNyZtC5WRoI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img
