height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 26 May 2020 21:51:32 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586227008remote-job.png","linkMd5":"74a2f9391da25b0722b238ba0fd80dbb","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn86@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-25-204_a6bb76a9b86c68e9.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":11678,"destBytes":11678,"author":"Joshua Kraus","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586227008remote-job.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn86@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-25-204_a6bb76a9b86c68e9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=FEEuK1Jz_8Q:ZNyZtC5WRoI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn77@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-35-340_fa4c6b964968f3ad.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/FEEuK1Jz_8Q":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn95@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-38-454_0f940512b0dd3a34.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483269},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"10 Ways to Hide Elements in CSS","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=130922","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/hide-elements-in-css/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"10 Ways to Hide Elements in CSS\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/1582635109hide-with-css.jpg\" alt=\"Ten Ways to Hide Elements in CSS\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/1582635109hide-with-css-300x170.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/1582635109hide-with-css.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>There are multiple ways to hide an element in CSS, but they differ in the way they affect accessibility, layout, animation, performance, and event handling.</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"animation\">Animation</h2> \n<p>Some CSS hiding options are all or nothing. The element is either fully visible or fully invisible and there’s no in-between state. Others, such as transparency, can have a range of values, so interpolated CSS animations become possible.</p> \n<h2 id=\"accessibility\">Accessibility</h2> \n<p>Each method described below will visually hide an element, but it may or may not hide the content from assistive technologies. For example, a screen reader could still announce tiny transparent text. Further CSS properties or <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA\">ARIA attributes</a> such as <code>aria-hidden=\"true\"</code> may be necessary to describe the appropriate action.</p> \n<p>Be wary that animations can also cause disorientation, migraines, seizures, or other physical discomfort for some people. Consider using a <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media/prefers-reduced-motion\"><code>prefers-reduced-motion</code></a> media query to switch off animations when specified in user preferences.</p> \n<h2 id=\"eventhandling\">Event Handling</h2> \n<p>Hiding will either stop events being triggered on that element or have no effect — that is, the element is not visible but can still be clicked or receive other user interactions.</p> \n<h2 id=\"performance\">Performance</h2> \n<p>After a browser loads and parses the HTML DOM and CSS object model, the page is rendered in three stages:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Layout:</strong> generate the geometry and position of each element</li> \n <li><strong>Paint:</strong> draw out the pixels for each element</li> \n <li><strong>Composition</strong>: position element layers in the appropriate order</li> \n</ol> \n<p>An effect which only causes composition changes is noticeably smoother than those affecting layout. In some cases, the browser can also use hardware acceleration.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1opacityandfilteropacity\">1. <code>opacity</code> and <code>filter: opacity()</code></h2> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/opacity\"><code>opacity: N</code></a> and <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/filter\"><code>filter: opacity(N)</code></a> properties can be passed a number between 0 and 1, or a percentage between 0% and 100% denoting fully transparent and fully opaque accordingly.</p> \n<p>\n <!-- [CODEPEN: https://codepen.io/craigbuckler/pen/bGdNdXE] --></p> \n<p class=\"codepen\" data-height=\"300\" data-theme-id=\"6441\" data-default-tab=\"css,result\" data-user=\"SitePoint\" data-slug-hash=\"vYOgMKx\" style=\"height: 300px; box-sizing: border-box; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; border: 2px solid; margin: 1em 0; padding: 1em;\" data-pen-title=\"hide with opacity: 0\"> <span>See the Pen <a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint/pen/vYOgMKx\"><br /> hide with opacity: 0</a> by SitePoint (<a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint\">@SitePoint</a>)<br /> on <a href=\"https://codepen.io\">CodePen</a>.</span> </p> \n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://static.codepen.io/assets/embed/ei.js\"></script></p> \n<p>There’s little practical difference between the two in modern browsers, although <code>filter</code> should be used if multiple effects are applied at the same time (blur, contrast, grayscale etc.)</p> \n<p>Opacity can be animated and offers great performance, but be wary that a fully transparent element remains on the page and can trigger events.</p> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th>metric</th> \n   <th>effect</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td>browser support</td> \n   <td>good, but IE only supports <code>opacity</code> 0 to 1</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>accessibility</td> \n   <td>content not read if 0 or 0% is set</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>layout affected?</td> \n   <td>no</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>rendering required</td> \n   <td>composition</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>performance</td> \n   <td>best, can use hardware acceleration</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>animation frames possible?</td> \n   <td>yes</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>events triggered when hidden?</td> \n   <td>yes</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<h2 id=\"2coloralphatransparency\">2. <code>color</code> Alpha Transparency</h2> \n<p><code>opacity</code> affects the whole element, but it’s also possible to set the <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/color\"><code>color</code></a>, <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-color\"><code>background-color</code></a>, and <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/border-color\"><code>border-color</code></a> properties separately. Applying a zero alpha channel using <code>rgba(0,0,0,0)</code> or similar renders an item fully transparent:</p> \n<p>\n <!-- [CODEPEN: https://codepen.io/craigbuckler/pen/PoqqZOK] --></p> \n<p class=\"codepen\" data-height=\"300\" data-theme-id=\"6441\" data-default-tab=\"css,result\" data-user=\"SitePoint\" data-slug-hash=\"GRJrLNM\" style=\"height: 300px; box-sizing: border-box; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; border: 2px solid; margin: 1em 0; padding: 1em;\" data-pen-title=\"hide with color alpha\"> <span>See the Pen <a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint/pen/GRJrLNM\"><br /> hide with color alpha</a> by SitePoint (<a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint\">@SitePoint</a>)<br /> on <a href=\"https://codepen.io\">CodePen</a>.</span> </p> \n<p>Each property can be animated separately to create interesting effects. Note that transparency can’t be applied to elements with image backgrounds unless they’re generated using <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/linear-gradient\"><code>linear-gradient</code></a> or similar.</p> \n<p>The alpha channel can be set with:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><code>transparent</code>: fully transparent (in-between animations are not possible)</li> \n <li><code>rgba(r, g, b, a)</code>: red, green, blue, and alpha</li> \n <li><code>hsla(h, s, l, a)</code>: hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha</li> \n <li><code>#RRGGBBAA</code> and <code>#RGBA</code></li> \n</ul> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th>metric</th> \n   <th>effect</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td>browser support</td> \n   <td>good, but IE only supports <code>transparent</code> and <code>rgba</code></td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>accessibility</td> \n   <td>content still read</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>layout affected?</td> \n   <td>no</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>rendering required</td> \n   <td>painting</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>performance</td> \n   <td>good, but not as fast as <code>opacity</code></td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>animation frames possible?</td> \n   <td>yes</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>events triggered when hidden?</td> \n   <td>yes</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<h2 id=\"3transform\">3. <code>transform</code></h2> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform\"><code>transform</code></a> property can be used to translate (move), scale, rotate, or skew an element. A <code>scale(0)</code> or <code>translate(-999px, 0px)</code> off-screen will hide the element:</p> \n<p>\n <!-- [CODEPEN: https://codepen.io/craigbuckler/pen/VwLYvZR] --></p> \n<p class=\"codepen\" data-height=\"300\" data-theme-id=\"6441\" data-default-tab=\"css,result\" data-user=\"SitePoint\" data-slug-hash=\"PoqWgWE\" style=\"height: 300px; box-sizing: border-box; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; border: 2px solid; margin: 1em 0; padding: 1em;\" data-pen-title=\"hide with transform: scale(0);\"> <span>See the Pen <a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint/pen/PoqWgWE\"><br /> hide with transform: scale(0);</a> by SitePoint (<a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint\">@SitePoint</a>)<br /> on <a href=\"https://codepen.io\">CodePen</a>.</span> </p> \n<p><code>transform</code> offers excellent performance and hardware acceleration because the element is effectively moved into a separate layer and can be animated in 2D or 3D. The original layout space remains as is, but no events will be triggered by a fully hidden element.</p> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th>metric</th> \n   <th>effect</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td>browser support</td> \n   <td>good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>accessibility</td> \n   <td>content still read</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>layout affected?</td> \n   <td>no — the original dimensions remain</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>rendering required</td> \n   <td>composition</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>performance</td> \n   <td>best, can use hardware acceleration</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>animation frames possible?</td> \n   <td>yes</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td>events triggered when hidden?</td> \n   <td>no</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/hide-elements-in-css/?utm_source=rss\">10 Ways to Hide Elements in CSS</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Oh1_zwrYx2E:0jX8x8ocLow:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Oh1_zwrYx2E:0jX8x8ocLow:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Oh1_zwrYx2E:0jX8x8ocLow:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Oh1_zwrYx2E:0jX8x8ocLow:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/Oh1_zwrYx2E\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 25 Feb 2020 11:00:42 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/1582635109hide-with-css.jpg","linkMd5":"9704cd708a5e3a30a6be613c10a3df6c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn2@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-24-739_af03951de742e902.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":3660,"destBytes":3660,"author":"Craig Buckler","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/1582635109hide-with-css.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn2@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-24-739_af03951de742e902.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Oh1_zwrYx2E:0jX8x8ocLow:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-42-708_a3f9dfc90fdab769.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/Oh1_zwrYx2E":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn14@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-36-880_51de0b891510f453.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483315},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Node.js vs Deno: What You Need to Know","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176626","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/node-vs-deno/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Node.js vs Deno: What You Need to Know\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594638764deno-vs-node.png\" alt=\"Deno vs Node\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594638764deno-vs-node-300x158.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594638764deno-vs-node-768x404.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594638764deno-vs-node-1024x539.png 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Since its announcement, <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-introduction/\">Deno</a> has generated quite a lot of interest within the JavaScript community. As a JavaScript runtime designed by the creator of Node, you might expect there to be be a lot of similarities between the two projects, and there are. However, there are also important differences, meaning you can’t just substitute one for the other.</strong></p> \n<p>This article will take a look at Deno in relation to its “older cousin” to help understand what they have in common, and what sets them apart. (If you want to get the skinny on Deno first, check out <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-introduction/\">our recent introduction</a>.)</p> \n<h2 id=\"languagesupport\">Language Support</h2> \n<p>Both projects are JavaScript runtimes, allowing JavaScript code to be executed on a computer outside of a web browser. Let’s look at how they stack up in terms of language support.</p> \n<h3 id=\"nodejs\">Node.js</h3> \n<p>The current LTS release of Node (v12.18.1 as of writing) supports modern JavaScript syntax and features. It also supports about 75% of the ES2020 spec. ECMAScript modules are also supported, but are currently only classed as experimental: you need to use the <code>.mjs</code> file extension, or add the property <code>\"type\": \"module\"</code> to your project’s <code>package.json</code> file.</p> \n<p>In order to run TypeScript (or any other language) on Node, the code needs to be compiled to JavaScript that the V8 engine can execute. There are several different ways to do this, with different pros and cons, so getting up and running means having to choose one of these and follow the necessary setup process.</p> \n<h3 id=\"deno\">Deno</h3> \n<p>I was unable to find any mention of the JavaScript spec supported by Deno, but as it also uses V8 under the hood I would assume a similar level of support as in Node. My own tests show that Deno supports ES2020 features like <code>Promise.allSettled()</code> and the <code>globalThis</code> keyword. ECMAScript modules are the default, with CommonJS modules not supported unless you use the Node compatibility library (more about this later).</p> \n<p>TypeScript is supported as a first-class language in Deno, meaning that it works out-of-the-box: no installing additional tools to transpile to JavaScript first. Of course, the V8 engine doesn’t support TypeScript natively, so Deno is still transpiling the code under the hood, but this is all seamless and transparent to you as a developer.</p> \n<p>I also couldn’t find mention of which version of TypeScript Deno v1.0.1 uses, but it supports optional chaining and nullish coalescing (but not private class fields) which would peg it as TS 3.7.</p> \n<h2 id=\"apis\">APIs</h2> \n<p>Deno and Node both expose their own APIs to developers, allowing us to write programs that can actually do useful things like read and write files, and send and receive network requests.</p> \n<h3 id=\"nodejs-1\">Node.js</h3> \n<p>When Node was first released, there was no built-in support for Promises. As a result of this, most of the APIs for asynchronous operations were written to take an error-first callback:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const fs = require('fs');\nfs.readFile('readme.txt', (err, data) =&gt; {\n  if (err) {\n    // Handle the error\n  }\n  // Otherwise handle the data\n});\n</code></pre> \n<p>Even though Node developers now have access to Promises and the async/await syntax, the APIs still expect callbacks in order to maintain backwards compatibility.</p> \n<h3 id=\"deno-1\">Deno</h3> \n<p>Deno’s API has been designed to take advantage of modern JavaScript features. All the asynchronous methods return Promises. Deno also supports top level await, meaning you can use await in your main script without having to wrap it in an async function.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">try {\n  const data = await Deno.readFile('readme.txt');\n  // Handle the data\n} catch (e) {\n  // Handle the error\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>The development team also made the decision to use web standards where possible, which means they’ve implemented browser APIs where it’s practical to do so. Deno provides a global <code>window</code> object, and APIs such as <code>addEventListener</code> and <code>fetch</code>. Having access to <code>fetch</code> is particularly nice, as with Node you’d have to polyfill this or use a third-party library.</p> \n<h3 id=\"thecompatibilitymodule\">The compatibility module</h3> \n<p>Deno provides a <a href=\"https://deno.land/std/node/\">compatibility layer</a> with the aim of allowing you to reuse existing Node packages. It’s not yet complete, but it does currently support loading CommonJS modules via <code>require()</code>, among other things.</p> \n<h2 id=\"packagemanagement\">Package Management</h2> \n<p>Package management is one area where Deno represents a radical departure from Node’s way of doing things. As it’s still early days for Deno, it remains to be seen if its approach will prove to be advantageous.</p> \n<h3 id=\"nodejs-2\">Node.js</h3> \n<p>As you might be aware, Node comes with its own package manager called npm, which is used to install and manage third-party packages. npm is mainly used with the online <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/\">npm registry</a>, where most of the available third-party packages are listed.</p> \n<p>When you use npm to install a package into your project, a <code>package.json</code> file is used to specify the package name and acceptable version range. The package itself (plus any packages <em>it</em> depends on) are then downloaded into a <code>node_modules</code> folder inside your project.</p> \n<h3 id=\"deno-2\">Deno</h3> \n<p>Deno does away with the need for a package manager altogether. Instead, packages are linked to directly via a URL:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">import { Response } from \"https://deno.land/std@0.53.0/http/server.ts\";\n</code></pre> \n<p>On the first run of your code, Deno fetches and compiles all the dependencies. They are then cached on the file system, separately from your project, so subsequent runs are much faster.</p> \n<p>Similar to npm’s <code>package-lock.json</code> file, Deno allows you to specify a lock file that will be used to ensure that only dependencies that match the exact version you originally imported will be used</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/node-vs-deno/?utm_source=rss\">Node.js vs Deno: What You Need to Know</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QLbPXyg3tCk:cNrfEH5S1uc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QLbPXyg3tCk:cNrfEH5S1uc:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QLbPXyg3tCk:cNrfEH5S1uc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=QLbPXyg3tCk:cNrfEH5S1uc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/QLbPXyg3tCk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 12 Jul 2020 18:15:34 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594638764deno-vs-node.png","linkMd5":"3045a56b36052462cbc72689a5c5c6fe","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn97@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-26-868_ff93b8775ff6d50b.webp","destWidth":1900,"destHeight":1000,"sourceBytes":56292,"destBytes":56292,"author":"Nilson Jacques","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594638764deno-vs-node.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn97@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-26-868_ff93b8775ff6d50b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=QLbPXyg3tCk:cNrfEH5S1uc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn22@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-36-263_3f82878f5137b23e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/QLbPXyg3tCk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn94@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-37-515_f219d182aae9a954.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483258},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"6+ Best Websites for Free Fonts in 2020","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176109","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/free-fonts/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"6+ Best Websites for Free Fonts in 2020\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588729672free-web-fonts.png\" alt=\"6+ Best Websites for Free Fonts in 2020\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588729672free-web-fonts-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588729672free-web-fonts.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>I firmly believe that, in order to strike the optimal balance between minimalism and visual appeal, a user interface should display no more than what’s absolutely necessary while making those necessary elements look visually appealing.</strong></p> \n<p><em>Keep it simple, but make the simple look amazing.</em></p> \n<p>But, what does simple look like exactly?</p> \n<p>Well, strip away all of the over-the-top marketing gimmicks, redundant features, and cluttering visuals, and most of what’s left is the UI copy and text content. As boring as this sounds, let’s be honest: this is the most important aspect of any app or website. Information and the ability to navigate it is the entire reason users are using our app or website.</p> \n<p>So with the right typeface coupled with the right font styles (see “<a href=\"https://creativebloq.com/features/font-vs-typeface/\">Font vs typeface: the ultimate guide</a>”), we can create designs that are quite simple and yet visually appealing at the same time. This emphasizes the most important aspects of the design while using fewer resources and also inducing the least amount of unwanted cognitive load.</p> \n<p><em>Typography can be very powerful.</em></p> \n<p>But what are the best free font websites?</p> \n<h2 id=\"wherenottolookforfreefonts\">Where <em>not</em> to look for free fonts</h2> \n<p>Dribbble, Behance, Gumroad, and so on are home to a ton of hidden gems, but this involves sieving through a lot of digital resources, some of which are incomplete side ventures and “lite” versions. That being said, make sure that you bookmark awesome resources if you do happen to come across any. Even Instagram might surprise you, and Twitter shouldn’t be overlooked either.</p> \n<p>That aside, let’s take a look as the best free font websites.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1googlefontshttpsfontsgooglecom\">1. <a href=\"https://fonts.google.com/\">Google Fonts</a></h2> \n<p>Number one on this “best free fonts” list is obviously Google Fonts, which goes above and beyond what most free font websites offer. First of all, Google Fonts offers a fast and convenient CDN (content delivery network), making it super easy to embed webfonts into websites without having to actually host them.</p> \n<p>Google fonts can be subsetted by script and weight, and we can also control how they’re loaded on the Web by setting the <code>font-display</code> CSS property from the embed code’s query string, which improves website loading times. (The CSS-Tricks article on “<a href=\"https://css-tricks.com/google-fonts-and-font-display/\">Google Fonts and font-display</a>” explains how.)</p> \n<p>Mind you, self-hosting fonts is better for <em>privacy</em> (because it’s cookieless) and <em>speed</em> (because it offers developers more control). Either way, Google Fonts has a humungous repertoire.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588727787google-fonts-1024x640.png\" alt=\"A screenshot of some Google fonts\" width=\"1024\" height=\"640\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176111\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"2creativemarkethttpscreativemarketcomfreegoods\">2. <a href=\"https://creativemarket.com/free-goods/\">Creative Market</a></h2> \n<p>I know what you’re thinking: “Creative Market isn’t free, Daniel!”</p> \n<p>Ahhh, but what about the <a href=\"https://creativemarket.com/free-goods/\">Free Goods</a> section? What’s interesting about Free Goods is that these are actually <em>premium</em> fonts that are temporarily free. While the section isn’t that huge, <em>and isn’t guaranteed to include fonts specifically</em>, each and every week it’s refreshed with six new design assets (plus three more if you sign up and another three if you spend X amount on assets).</p> \n<p>I’ve been checking the Free Goods section on Creative Market every week for years, and I’ve built up a large repository of high-quality fonts that cost literally nothing. <a href=\"https://fontbundles.net/free-fonts/\">Font Bundles</a> runs a similar deal.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588728069creative-market.png\" alt=\"The Free Goods section of the Creative Market website\" width=\"1000\" height=\"625\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176112\" /></p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/free-fonts/?utm_source=rss\">6+ Best Websites for Free Fonts in 2020</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=KZNLI1VPuHE:ByXsZAgSrXU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=KZNLI1VPuHE:ByXsZAgSrXU:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=KZNLI1VPuHE:ByXsZAgSrXU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=KZNLI1VPuHE:ByXsZAgSrXU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/KZNLI1VPuHE\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 05 May 2020 12:39:35 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588729672free-web-fonts.png","linkMd5":"9c4327f69548b07f4d48898153325b38","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn73@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-27-547_c1f09b1d2edeeb4c.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":17200,"destBytes":17200,"author":"Daniel Schwarz","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588729672free-web-fonts.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn73@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-27-547_c1f09b1d2edeeb4c.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588727787google-fonts-1024x640.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588728069creative-market.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=KZNLI1VPuHE:ByXsZAgSrXU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn65@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-44-537_c5ddec45922f703a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/KZNLI1VPuHE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn12@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-43-306_0465361c9c8cf14a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483272},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"15+ Figma Plugins to Help You Design Better","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175796","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/15-figma-plugins-to-help-you-design-better/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"15+ Figma Plugins to Help You Design Better\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586229130figma-plugins.png\" alt=\"15+ Figma Plugins to Help You Design Better\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586229130figma-plugins-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586229130figma-plugins.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong><a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://figma.com/\">Figma</a>, the second most-used tool for designing user interfaces (and the <em>first</em> most-used tool when counting only Windows OS), has really taken the digital design industry by storm lately, with even Adobe XD shipping their own version of Figma’s multiplayer feature (naming it “coediting”).</strong></p> \n<p>However, the hot topic at Figma right now is the release of <em>plugins</em> — extensions that Figma users can install on Figma to allow for extra functionality or to improve their design workflow.</p> \n<p>Let’s take a look at some of the <em>best Figma plugins</em> so far.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1arrowautohttpsfigmacomcplugin751007211632768205arrowautocreateuserflows\">1. <a href=\"https://figma.com/c/plugin/751007211632768205/Arrow-Auto/\">Arrow Auto</a> (create user flows)</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876187561.png\" alt=\"Arrow Auto\" width=\"2048\" height=\"1024\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176033\" /></p> \n<p>Arrow Auto adds flowchart functionality to Figma, which is useful for creating user flow maps. Select any two objects on the canvas and Arrow Auto will enable you to draw a connector between them. You can also hide and show the flows on demand.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://figma.com/community/plugin/733902567457592893/Autoflow/\">Autoflow</a> is a decent (and maybe nicer looking) alternative, but Arrow Auto has more features, including the ability to switch connector directions and also move connected objects around while keeping connectors intact.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2anglehttpsangleshutilizedevicemockups\">2. <a href=\"https://angle.sh/\">Angle</a> (utilize device mockups)</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876194922.jpg\" alt=\"Angle\" width=\"1500\" height=\"708\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176050\" /></p> \n<p>Angle allows you to display your screens (i.e. artboards) from within a number of realistic or matte-effect device frames that each come with a variety of angle options <em>and</em> shadow styles.</p> \n<p>Impressively, they’re 100% vector as well.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://figma.com/community/plugin/750673765607708804/Artboard-Studio-Mockups/\">Artboard Studio</a> isn’t quite the same thing, as it allows for inserting a whole bunch of random 3D objects onto the canvas (like a kiwi, for example). If you only care about device mockups, I’d install Angle. <a href=\"https://figma.com/c/plugin/769588393361258724/Vectary-3D/\">Vectory 3D</a> is similar to Artboard Studio, but it outputs actual 3D assets.</p> \n<h2 id=\"3masterhttpsfigmacomcplugin767721682134156281mastermanagecomponentsmoreeasily\">3. <a href=\"https://figma.com/c/plugin/767721682134156281/Master/\">Master</a> (manage components more easily)</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876189373.jpg\" alt=\"Master\" width=\"1909\" height=\"958\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176036\" /></p> \n<p>Master offers a better way to manage components, such as the ability to turn multiple identical objects into a component, duplicate components into other Figma files, and much more.</p> \n<h2 id=\"4cleandocumenthttpsfigmacomcplugin767379019764649932cleandocumentautocleandocuments\">4. <a href=\"https://figma.com/c/plugin/767379019764649932/Clean-Document/\">Clean Document</a> (auto-clean documents)</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876189474.png\" alt=\"Clean Document\" width=\"1920\" height=\"960\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176037\" /></p> \n<p>Clean Document, well … cleans your document! It deletes hidden layers, sorts them intelligently, renames them according to your liking, ungroups single-layer groups, and even rounds dimensions to the nearest <em>pixel</em>. A terrific tool for obsessive neat freaks!</p> \n<h2 id=\"5similayerhttpsfigmacomcommunityplugin735733267883397781similayerselectsimilarlayers\">5. <a href=\"https://figma.com/community/plugin/735733267883397781/Similayer/\">Similayer</a> (select similar layers)</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876189665.jpg\" alt=\"Similayer\" width=\"1500\" height=\"750\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176038\" /></p> \n<p>Quite simply, Similayer allows you to select layers based on their similarity to the layer that’s currently selected. Let’s say that you wanted to change a shadow style that’s being used on a number of different elements: Similayer could do that.</p> \n<p>You could also use it to batch-reassign multiple components.</p> \n<h2 id=\"6viewportshttpsfigmacomcommunityplugin732240841094697441viewportschangetheviewport\">6. <a href=\"https://figma.com/community/plugin/732240841094697441/Viewports/\">Viewports</a> (change the viewport)</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876190436.jpg\" alt=\"Viewports\" width=\"1500\" height=\"750\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176039\" /></p> \n<p>Find out the correct market share of all viewport dimensions, then apply them to frames. It’s <strong>insane</strong> how useful this is!</p> \n<p>Viewport data is live-sourced from StatCounter.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/15-figma-plugins-to-help-you-design-better/?utm_source=rss\">15+ Figma Plugins to Help You Design Better</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=aJatg19OyDI:3Qcrd_Qs6WE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=aJatg19OyDI:3Qcrd_Qs6WE:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=aJatg19OyDI:3Qcrd_Qs6WE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=aJatg19OyDI:3Qcrd_Qs6WE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/aJatg19OyDI\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Apr 2020 22:30:07 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586229130figma-plugins.png","linkMd5":"580dcc185f436ae190ed423490e633d0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn65@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-28-330_0788fcbc6d815128.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":7976,"destBytes":7976,"author":"Daniel Schwarz","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586229130figma-plugins.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn65@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-28-330_0788fcbc6d815128.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876187561.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876194922.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876189373.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876189474.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876189665.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15876190436.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=aJatg19OyDI:3Qcrd_Qs6WE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn57@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-37-523_add8401fcf300e14.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/aJatg19OyDI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn18@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-45-631_dfd853d447ff60c6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483274},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Ensure Flexible, Reusable PHP Code with Insphpect","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176468","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-ensure-flexible-reusable-php-code-with-insphpect/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Ensure Flexible, Reusable PHP Code with Insphpect\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593522244code.png\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593522244code-300x158.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593522244code-768x405.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593522244code-1024x541.png 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong><a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://insphpect.com\">Insphpect</a> is a tool I wrote as part of my PhD project. It scans code for object-oriented programming techniques that hinder code reusability and flexibility.</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"why\">Why?</h2> \n<p>Let me begin with two mundane observations:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Business requirements change over time.</li> \n <li>Programmers are not clairvoyant.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>New product launches, emergency lockdown regulations, expanding into new markets, economic factors, updated data protection laws: there are lots of potential causes for business software to need updating.</p> \n<p>From those two observations we can infer that programmers know that the code they write is going to change, but not what those changes will be or when they will happen.</p> \n<p>Writing code in such a way that it can be easily adapted is a skill that takes years to master.</p> \n<p>You’re probably already familiar with programming practices that come back and haunt you. Novice programmers quickly realize that global variables are more trouble than they’re worth, and the once incredibly popular Singleton Pattern has been <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/whats-so-bad-about-the-singleton/\">a dirty word for the last decade</a>.</p> \n<p>How you code your application has a big impact on how easy it is to adapt to meet new requirements. As you progress through your career, you learn techniques that make adapting code easier. Once you’ve grasped fundamentals of object-oriented programming you wonder how you ever did without it!</p> \n<p>If you ask ten developers to produce software, given the same requirements, you’ll get ten different solutions. Some of those solutions will inevitably be better than others.</p> \n<p>Consider a ship in a bottle and a model ship made of Lego. Both are model ships, but changing the sails on the ship in a bottle is very difficult, and reusing the parts is near impossible. However, with a Lego ship, you can easily swap out the sails or use the same components to build a model rocket, house or a car.</p> \n<p>Certain programming techniques lead to the <em>ship-in-a-bottle</em> approach and make your code difficult to change and adapt.</p> \n<h2 id=\"insphpect\">Insphpect</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://insphpect.com\">Insphpect</a> is a tool which scans your code for programming practices that lead to this kind of a ship in a bottle design.</p> \n<p>It grades your code based on how flexible it is, and highlights areas where flexibility can be improved.</p> \n<h3 id=\"whatdoesinsphpectlookfor\">What does Insphpect look for?</h3> \n<p>Currently, Insphpect looks for the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://insphpect.com/traits/tight-coupling\">tight coupling</a></li> \n <li>hardcoded configuration</li> \n <li>singletons</li> \n <li>setter injection</li> \n <li>using the <code>new</code> keyword in a constructor</li> \n <li>service locators</li> \n <li>inheritance</li> \n <li>static methods</li> \n <li>global state</li> \n <li>files that have more than one role (e.g. defining a class and running some code)</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If it detects anything it identifies as inflexible, it highlights the code, explains why it highlighted the issue, then grades your whole project and individual classes on a score of 0-100 (with 100 being no issues detected). As a proof of concept, for some detections it’s able to automatically generate a patch file that re-writes the code to remove the inflexibility entirely.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://insphpect.com/report/5e63a943a8da7\">Take a look a sample report here</a>.</p> \n<p>Insphpect is currently in the testing phase, and it would really help my research progress if you can check it out and complete the survey in the “Give your feedback” section of the site.</p> \n<h3 id=\"background\">Background</h3> \n<p>Are those bad practices really bad, though?</p> \n<p>This was one of the more difficult parts of the background research, and you can read about how this was done in detail on the <a href=\"https://insphpect.com/background\">Insphpect website</a>.</p> \n<p>However, this can be summarized as:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The opinions of each bad practice were collected from 100 authors per practice.</li> \n <li>The author’s opinion on the practice was graded on a scale of 1–5.</li> \n <li>The author’s methodological rigor was graded on a scale of 1–7 based on the Jadad score used for clinical trials.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>These were then plotted like the graph below:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593053893singleton-1024x612.png\" alt=\"Singleton pattern results\" width=\"1024\" height=\"612\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176470\" /></p> \n<p>Each horizontal line represents an article, and the left (orange) bar for each article is the recommendation going from 5 — Avoid this practice at all costs (Far left) — to 1 — Favor this practice over alternatives.</p> \n<p>The right (blue) bar for each article is the Jadad style score measuring analytic rigor. A score of seven means the article describes the practice, provides code examples, discusses alternative approaches, provides like-for-like code samples, discusses the pros/cons of each approach and makes a recommendation of which approach should be used.</p> \n<p>In the case of the singleton above, authors who compare the singleton to alternative approaches, discuss the pros/cons, etc., are significantly more likely to suggest using alternative approaches.</p> \n<h2 id=\"walkthrough\">Walkthrough</h2> \n<p>Currently, Insphpect allows uploading code via a Git repository URL or a ZIP file.</p> \n<p>So not to point out flaws in other people’s work, let’s take a look at one of my own projects to see what it identifies.</p> \n<p>We’ll use <a href=\"https://github.com/Level-2/Transphporm\">https://github.com/Level-2/Transphporm</a> as an example project.</p> \n<p>This is quite a good example, because it has a very high score on another code-quality tool <a href=\"https://scrutinizer-ci.com/g/Level-2/Transphporm/\">Scrutinizer</a>.</p> \n<p>Firstly, enter the git URL <code>https://github.com/Level-2/Transphporm</code> into the text box at the top of the home page and press “Go”. It will take a few seconds to minutes, depending on the size of the project, and will generate a report that looks something like this:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593053927report1.png\" alt=\"Transphporm Report\" width=\"600\" height=\"533\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176472\" /></p> \n<p>Once you’re on the report page, you’ll see a summary at the top with an overall grade out of 100, with 100 being very good and 0 being very poor.</p> \n<p>Underneath the summary, you’ll see a list of all the classes in the project, each with its own grade.</p> \n<p>Don’t worry if your code doesn’t get a perfect score. It’s unlikely that it will. Remember, Insphpect is a tool that identifies flexibility in your code. There are parts of your code (like the entry point) where flexibility isn’t warranted.</p> \n<p>For Transphporm, it has highlighted issues in seven classes.</p> \n<p>Let’s take a look at some of those. Scroll down to <code>Transphporm\\Parser\\CssToXpath</code> and click the link. You’ll see a score for that particular class and a list of issues which have been identified.</p> \n<p>In this case, it has identified a static variable and a static method. Clicking on one of the red lines will reveal an explanation of why the line was flagged up.</p> \n<p>For example, clicking line 12 will give an explanation of why static variables are less flexible than instance variables.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593053956report2.png\" alt=\"Single class report\" width=\"800\" height=\"684\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176473\" /></p> \n<p>Although there’s a more in-depth explanation of the issues caused by static properties on the <a href=\"https://insphpect.com/report/class/5e63a8f479b6d/Transphporm%5CParser%5CCssToXpath\">report</a>, as a quick refresher, static variables have one value which is shared across all the instances of the class.</p> \n<p>This is inherently less flexible than an instance variable, because using an instance variable allows each instance to have a different value.</p> \n<p>For example, consider the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"php language-php\">class User {\n    public static $db;\n    public $id;\n    public $name;\n    public $email;\n\n    public function save() {\n        $stmt = self::$db-&gt;prepare('REPLACE INTO user (id, name, email) VALUES (:id, :name, :email)');\n\n        $stmt-&gt;execute([\n            'id' =&gt; $this-&gt;id,\n            'name' =&gt; $this-&gt;name.\n            'email' =&gt; $this-&gt;email\n        ]);\n    }\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Because <code>$db</code> is static, every instance of this class shares the same <code>$db</code> instance and records will always be inserted into the same database.</p> \n<p>While this sounds reasonable, let me give you a real-world example.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-ensure-flexible-reusable-php-code-with-insphpect/?utm_source=rss\">How to Ensure Flexible, Reusable PHP Code with Insphpect</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=21YsXuwutH4:O13SFdpp0xY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=21YsXuwutH4:O13SFdpp0xY:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=21YsXuwutH4:O13SFdpp0xY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=21YsXuwutH4:O13SFdpp0xY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/21YsXuwutH4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 29 Jun 2020 19:56:36 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593522244code.png","linkMd5":"c4a9c66012adbc54e7d210ad77d88ab3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn61@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-26-981_2e5433e41f94f41b.webp","destWidth":4167,"destHeight":2200,"sourceBytes":68948,"destBytes":68948,"author":"Tom Butler","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593522244code.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn61@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-26-981_2e5433e41f94f41b.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593053893singleton-1024x612.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn86@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-38-690_42ea3fe4cdd0d957.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593053927report1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn17@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-46-983_791b083817cdac0d.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1593053956report2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn50@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-36-866_fb20b2890af7543f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=21YsXuwutH4:O13SFdpp0xY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn14@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-35-263_ab3704682f596b9f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/21YsXuwutH4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn20@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-40-779_48da90385ac58c3e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483261},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Build a File Upload Form with Express and DropzoneJS","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=118985","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/file-upload-form-express-dropzone-js/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Build a File Upload Form with Express and DropzoneJS\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1582725021file-upload.jpg\" alt=\"How to Build a File Upload Form with Express and DropzoneJS\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1582725021file-upload-300x170.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1582725021file-upload.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Let’s face it, nobody likes forms. Developers don’t like building them, designers don’t particularly enjoy styling them, and users certainly don’t like filling them in.</strong></p> \n<p>Of all the components that can make up a form, the file control could just be the most frustrating of the lot. It’s a real pain to style, it’s clunky and awkward to use, and uploading a file will slow down the submission process of any form.</p> \n<p>That’s why a plugin to enhance them is always worth a look, and <a href=\"http://www.dropzonejs.com\">DropzoneJS</a> is just one such option. It will make your file upload controls look better, make them more user-friendly, and by using AJAX to upload the file in the background, it will at the very least make the process <em>seem</em> quicker. It also makes it easier to validate files before they even reach your server, providing near-instantaneous feedback to the user.</p> \n<p>We’re going to take a look at DropzoneJS in some detail. We’ll show how to implement it. and look at some of the ways in which it can be tweaked and customized. We’ll also implement a simple server-side upload mechanism using Node.js.</p> \n<p>As ever, you can find the code for this tutorial on our <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/image-uploads-dropzonejs-node-express\">GitHub repository</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"introducingdropzonejs\">Introducing DropzoneJS</h2> \n<p>DropzoneJS allows users to upload files using drag and drop. Whilst the usability benefits <a href=\"http://ux.stackexchange.com/questions/56829/what-is-the-usability-benefit-of-drag-files-images-here\">could justifiably be debated</a>, it’s an increasingly common approach and one which is in tune with the way a lot of people work with files on their desktop. It’s also <a href=\"http://caniuse.com/#feat=dragndrop\">pretty well supported</a> across major browsers.</p> \n<p>DropzoneJS isn’t simply a drag and drop based widget, however. Clicking the widget launches the more conventional file chooser dialog approach.</p> \n<p>Here’s an animation of the widget in action:</p> \n<p><img src=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/1447336497dropzone-1.gif\" alt=\"The DropzoneJS widget in action\" width=\"480\" height=\"339\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-118991\" /></p> \n<p>Alternatively, take a look at <a href=\"http://www.dropzonejs.com/examples/simple.html\">this most minimal of examples</a>.</p> \n<p>You can use DropzoneJS for any type of file, though the nice little thumbnail effect makes it ideally suited to uploading images in particular.</p> \n<h3 id=\"features\">Features</h3> \n<p>To summarize some of the plugin’s features and characteristics, DropzoneJS:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>can be used <em>with or without jQuery</em></li> \n <li>has drag and drop support</li> \n <li>generates thumbnail images</li> \n <li>supports multiple uploads, optionally in parallel</li> \n <li>includes a progress bar</li> \n <li>is fully themeable</li> \n <li>includes extensible file validation support</li> \n <li>is available as an AMD module or RequireJS module</li> \n <li>comes in at around 43KB when minified and 13KB when gzipped</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"browsersupport\">Browser Support</h3> \n<p>Taken from the official documentation, browser support is as follows:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Chrome 7+</li> \n <li>Firefox 4+</li> \n <li>IE 10+</li> \n <li>Opera 12+ (Version 12 for macOS is disabled because their API is buggy)</li> \n <li>Safari 6+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>There are a couple of ways to handle fallbacks for when the plugin isn’t fully supported, which we’ll look at later.</p> \n<h2 id=\"gettingsetup\">Getting Set Up</h2> \n<p>The simplest way to get started with DropzoneJS is to <a href=\"https://cdnjs.com/libraries/dropzone\">include the latest version from a CDN</a>. At the time of writing, this is version <code>5.5.1</code>.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, you can <a href=\"https://gitlab.com/meno/dropzone/-/releases\">download the latest release from the project’s GitLab page</a>. There’s also a third-party package providing support for <a href=\"https://github.com/paramaggarwal/react-dropzone\">ReactJS</a>.</p> \n<p>Then, make sure you include both the main JavaScript file and the CSS styles in your page. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;\n&lt;html lang=\"en\"&gt;\n&lt;head&gt;\n  &lt;meta charset=\"UTF-8\"&gt;\n  &lt;title&gt;File Upload Example&lt;/title&gt;\n  &lt;link\n    rel=\"stylesheet\"\n    href=\"https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/dropzone/5.5.1/min/dropzone.min.css\"&gt;\n&lt;/head&gt;\n&lt;body&gt;\n\n  &lt;script src=\"https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/dropzone/5.5.1/min/dropzone.min.js\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n&lt;/body&gt;\n&lt;/html&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Note that the project supplies two CSS files — a <code>basic.css</code> file with some minimal styling, and a more extensive <code>dropzone.css</code> file. Minified versions of <code>dropzone.css</code> and <code>dropzone.js</code> are also available.</p> \n<h2 id=\"basicusage\">Basic Usage</h2> \n<p>The simplest way to implement the plugin is to attach it to a form, although you can use any HTML such as a <code>&lt;div&gt;</code>. Using a form, however, means fewer options to set — most notably the URL, which is the most important configuration property.</p> \n<p>You can initialize it simply by adding the <code>dropzone</code> class. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;form id=\"upload-widget\" method=\"post\" action=\"/upload\" class=\"dropzone\"&gt;&lt;/form&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Technically, that’s all you need to do, though in most cases you’ll want to set some additional options. The format for that is as follows:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">Dropzone.options.WIDGET_ID = {\n  //\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>To derive the widget ID for setting the options, take the ID you defined in your HTML and camel-case it. For example, <code>upload-widget</code> becomes <code>uploadWidget</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">Dropzone.options.uploadWidget = {\n  //\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can also create an instance programmatically:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const uploader = new Dropzone('#upload-widget', options);\n</code></pre> \n<p>Next up, we’ll look at some of the available configuration options.</p> \n<h2 id=\"basicconfigurationoptions\">Basic Configuration Options</h2> \n<p>The <code>url</code> option defines the target for the upload form, and is the only required parameter. That said, if you’re attaching it to a form element then it’ll simply use the form’s <code>action</code> attribute, in which case you don’t even need to specify that.</p> \n<p>The <code>method</code> option sets the HTTP method and again, it will take this from the form element if you use that approach, or else it’ll simply default to <code>POST</code>, which should suit most scenarios.</p> \n<p>The <code>paramName</code> option is used to set the name of the parameter for the uploaded file. If you’re using a file upload form element, it will match the <code>name</code> attribute. If you don’t include it, it defaults to <code>file</code>.</p> \n<p><code>maxFiles</code> sets the maximum number of files a user can upload, if it’s not set to null.</p> \n<p>By default, the widget will show a file dialog when it’s clicked, though you can use the <code>clickable</code> parameter to disable this by setting it to <code>false</code>, or alternatively you can provide an HTML element or CSS selector to customize the clickable element.</p> \n<p>Those are the basic options, but let’s now look at some of the more advanced options.</p> \n<h3 id=\"enforcingmaximumfilesize\">Enforcing Maximum File Size</h3> \n<p>The <code>maxFilesize</code> property determines the maximum file size in megabytes. This defaults to a size of 1000 bytes, but using the <code>filesizeBase</code> property, you could set it to another value — for example, 1024 bytes. You may need to tweak this to ensure that your client and server code calculate any limits in precisely the same way.</p> \n<h3 id=\"restrictingtocertainfiletypes\">Restricting to Certain File Types</h3> \n<p>The <code>acceptedFiles</code> parameter can be used to restrict the type of file you want to accept. This should be in the form of a comma-separated list of MIME types, although you can also use wildcards.</p> \n<p>For example, to only accept images:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">acceptedFiles: 'image/*',\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"modifyingthesizeofthethumbnail\">Modifying the Size of the Thumbnail</h3> \n<p>By default, the thumbnail is generated at 120x120px. That is, it’s square. There are a couple of ways you can modify this behavior.</p> \n<p>The first is to use the <code>thumbnailWidth</code> and/or the <code>thumbnailHeight</code> configuration options.</p> \n<p>If you set both <code>thumbnailWidth</code> and <code>thumbnailHeight</code> to <code>null</code>, the thumbnail won’t be resized at all.</p> \n<p>If you want to completely customize the thumbnail generation behavior, you can even override the <code>resize</code> function.</p> \n<p>One important point about modifying the size of the thumbnail is that the <code>dz-image</code> class provided by the package sets the thumbnail size in the CSS, so you’ll need to modify that accordingly as well.</p> \n<h3 id=\"additionalfilechecks\">Additional File Checks</h3> \n<p>The <code>accept</code> option allows you to provide additional checks to determine whether a file is valid before it gets uploaded. You shouldn’t use this to check the number of files (<code>maxFiles</code>), file type (<code>acceptedFiles</code>), or file size (<code>maxFilesize</code>), but you can write custom code to perform other sorts of validation.</p> \n<p>You’d use the <code>accept</code> option like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">accept: function(file, done) {\n  if (!someCheck()) {\n    return done('This is invalid!');\n  }\n  return done();\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>As you can see, it’s asynchronous. You can call <code>done()</code> with no arguments and validation passes, or provide an error message and the file will be rejected, displaying the message alongside the file as a popover.</p> \n<p>We’ll look at a more complex, real-world example later, when we look at how to enforce minimum or maximum image sizes.</p> \n<h2 id=\"sendingadditionalheaders\">Sending Additional Headers</h2> \n<p>Often you’ll need to attach additional headers to the uploader’s HTTP request.</p> \n<p>As an example, one approach to CSRF (cross-site request forgery) protection is to output a token in the view, then have your <code>POST/PUT/DELETE</code> endpoints check the request headers for a valid token. Suppose you outputted your token like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;meta name=\"csrf-token\" content=\"CL2tR2J4UHZXcR9BjRtSYOKzSmL8U1zTc7T8d6Jz\"&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Then, you could add this to the configuration:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">headers: {\n  'x-csrf-token': document.querySelector('meta[name=csrf-token]').getAttributeNode('content').value,\n},\n</code></pre> \n<p>Alternatively, here’s the same example but using jQuery:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">headers: {\n  'x-csrf-token': $('meta[name=\"csrf-token\"]').attr('content')\n},\n</code></pre> \n<p>Your server should then verify the <code>x-csrf-token</code> header, perhaps using some <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/csrf\">middleware</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"handlingfallbacks\">Handling Fallbacks</h2> \n<p>The simplest way to implement a fallback is to insert a <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> into your form containing input controls, setting the class name on the element to <code>fallback</code>. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;form id=\"upload-widget\" method=\"post\" action=\"/upload\" class=\"dropzone\"&gt;\n  &lt;div class=\"fallback\"&gt;\n    &lt;input name=\"file\" type=\"file\" /&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;\n&lt;/form&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Alternatively, you can provide a function to be executed when the browser doesn’t support the plugin using the <code>fallback</code> configuration parameter.</p> \n<p>You can force the widget to use the fallback behavior by setting <code>forceFallback</code> to <code>true</code>, which might help during development.</p> \n<h2 id=\"handlingerrors\">Handling Errors</h2> \n<p>You can customize the way the widget handles errors by providing a custom function using the <code>error</code> configuration parameter. The first argument is the file, the error message the second, and if the error occurred server-side, the third parameter will be an instance of <code>XMLHttpRequest</code>.</p> \n<p>As always, client-side validation is only half the battle. You must also perform validation on the server. When we implement a simple server-side component later, we’ll look at the expected format of the error response, which when properly configured will be displayed in the same way as client-side errors (illustrated below).</p> \n<p><img src=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/1447336481dropzone-2.gif\" alt=\"Displaying errors with DropzoneJS\" width=\"480\" height=\"326\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-118990\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"overridingmessagesandtranslation\">Overriding Messages and Translation</h2> \n<p>There are a number of additional configuration properties which set the various messages displayed by the widget. You can use these to customize the displayed text, or to translate them into another language.</p> \n<p>Most notably, <code>dictDefaultMessage</code> is used to set the text which appears in the middle of the dropzone, prior to someone selecting a file to upload.</p> \n<p>You’ll find a complete list of the configurable string values — all of which begin with <code>dict</code> — <a href=\"http://www.dropzonejs.com/#configuration-options\">in the documentation</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"events\">Events</h2> \n<p>There are a number of events you can listen to in order to customize or enhance the plugin.</p> \n<p>There are two ways to listen to an event. The first is to create a listener within an initialization function:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">Dropzone.options.uploadWidget = {\n  init: function() {\n    this.on('success', function(file, resp){\n      ...\n    });\n  },\n  ...\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>This is the alternative approach, which is useful if you decide to create the Dropzone instance programatically:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const uploader = new Dropzone('#upload-widget');\nuploader.on('success', function(file, resp){\n  ...\n});\n</code></pre> \n<p>Perhaps the most notable aspect is the <code>success</code> event, which is fired when a file has been successfully uploaded. The <code>success</code> callback takes two arguments: the first a file object, and the second an instance of <code>XMLHttpRequest</code>.</p> \n<p>Other useful events include <code>addedfile</code> and <code>removedfile</code>, for when a file has been added or removed from the upload list; <code>thumbnail</code>, which fires once the thumbnail has been generated; and <code>uploadprogress</code>, which you might use to implement your own progress meter.</p> \n<p>There are also a bunch of events which take an event object as a parameter and which you could use to customize the behavior of the widget itself — <code>drop</code>, <code>dragstart</code>, <code>dragend</code>, <code>dragenter</code>, <code>dragover</code> and <code>dragleave</code>.</p> \n<p>You’ll find a complete list of events in the relevant section <a href=\"http://www.dropzonejs.com/#event-list\">of the documentation</a>.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/file-upload-form-express-dropzone-js/?utm_source=rss\">How to Build a File Upload Form with Express and DropzoneJS</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=0e80W9LHE2E:kSNOsBeVCMo:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=0e80W9LHE2E:kSNOsBeVCMo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/0e80W9LHE2E\"
