+0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1582725021file-upload.jpg","linkMd5":"43a50134081c8b598378a5bfa2ad471a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn49@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-28-958_5dbd8477f49e6038.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":1582,"destBytes":1582,"author":"Lukas White","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1582725021file-upload.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn49@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-28-958_5dbd8477f49e6038.webp","http://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/1447336497dropzone-1.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn37@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-40-327_50e4ee3dcbaab828.webp","http://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/1447336481dropzone-2.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn29@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-41-566_1fb35d2f0941a908.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=0e80W9LHE2E:kSNOsBeVCMo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn1@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-46-667_53a7a82ef74bdbd5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/0e80W9LHE2E":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn9@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-37-635_bee1369a0d422b09.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483298},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Migrate from WordPress to a Static Site Generator","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176744","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/migrate-wordpress-static-site-generator/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Migrate from WordPress to a Static Site Generator\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596713533wp-to-ssg.jpg\" alt=\"WordPress to Static Site Generator\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596713533wp-to-ssg-300x165.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596713533wp-to-ssg-768x421.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596713533wp-to-ssg-1024x561.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>In this article, you’ll learn how to turn your WordPress-driven site into a static site with just a handful of powerful tools.</strong></p> \n<p>Why would you do this? Because you can get insane speed gains and therefore boost your site’s performance in search engines, and also reduce (or eliminate) your hosting bill and dramatically improve your security.</p> \n<h2 id=\"thebenefitsofgoingstatic\">The Benefits of Going Static</h2> \n<p>Fantastic speedups are certainly no small feat, but that isn’t all you can get from turning your dynamic WordPress (WP) site install into a static one.</p> \n<p>Let’s summarize:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Reduced page load speed</strong>. Pages aren’t preprocessed at runtime (user’s request), and content isn’t pulled from the database. As a result, the web server will respond <em>a lot</em> faster (10x and even more).</li> \n <li><strong>Reduced latency through CDN’s</strong>. You can just drop these now-static pages on a distributed content delivery network (CDN), hugely improving response times all around the world.</li> \n <li><strong>Easier management</strong>. Once you’ve set your workflow — which is what we’ll do here — you’ll see that you actually won’t need to spend any additional effort in maintenance, WP upgrades or server updates.</li> \n <li><strong>Dramatically enhanced security</strong>. HTTPS out of the box with only static pages that aren’t being run by some bogus PHP version or an outdated WP, and most probably not even by Apache.</li> \n <li><strong>Improved SEO</strong>. Google values not only your content but how easy and secure the access to it is. This is, in fact, one of the few search engine optimizations still valid these days: a faster, more secure site will perform better on the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_engine_results_page\">search engine results page</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>Peace of mind</strong>. No need to upgrade PHP, no unpatched WP concerns, even no Linux servers being managed. Just relax and have your coffee/beer/tea/ginseng after your deployment.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"iswordpresssecurewellitscomplicated\">“Is WordPress Secure?” Well, It’s Complicated …</h2> \n<p>WP developers follow <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/about/security\">good standards and security practices</a>, although a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-term_support\">long-term support</a> (LTS) is still very much missing. However, because of its very architecture, there are things that are out of the WP Security Team’s hands and transferred directly into yours:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>updating your server</li> \n <li>installing WP updates</li> \n <li>installing PHP updates</li> \n <li>installing updates for plugins and themes (if available, at all)</li> \n <li>managing WP and PHP (neither of which has LTS) mayor upgrades every once in a while</li> \n</ul> \n<p>All of this is a <em>constant</em> process, and plugins are not a minor threat, specially unmaintained ones, as these often have security holes by which attackers take control of WP installations. That is precisely why it took <a href=\"https://automattic.com/\">Automattic</a>, the company behind WP, years to accommodate WordPress.com (WP.com) — the commercial managed version of WordPress.org (WP.org) — to be able to offer <em>some</em> plugins.</p> \n<p>WP <em>could</em> be secure with a fair amount of conscious effort. And while you could argue that these are efforts any decent developer should put in, it’s also true that you can potentially lift this weight off your shoulders by turning your WP site into a static one, and while doing so redefining its architecture and removing <em>for good</em> nearly all of the available spots that could turn into a security threat. After all, there isn’t much an attacker can do with plain HTML, CSS files and flat images.</p> \n<p>However, you’ll still need to take care of <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting\">cross-site scripting</a> and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_request_forgery\">cross-site request forgery</a>. 🤷‍♂️</p> \n<h2 id=\"preliminariesenterstaticsitegenerators\">Preliminaries: Enter Static Site Generators</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://jamstack.org/\"><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595294384Jamstack_Logo_Original.png\" /></a></p> \n<p><small><em>Provided: Netlify</em></small></p> \n<p>We briefly reviewed static site generators (SSGs) on our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/jamstack-tools-services-apis/\">list of 100 Jamstack tools, APIs and services to power your sites</a> article, and there are <em>tons</em> more than we’ll cover here, so make sure to check <a href=\"https://www.staticgen.com/\">StaticGen</a> to learn more.</p> \n<p>Some SSGs are specifically targeted at WordPress, such as <a href=\"https://wp2static.com/\">WP2Static</a>, but we’ll focus on a more general-purpose one, <a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.org/\">GatsbyJS</a> — the <em>“free and open source framework based on React that helps developers build blazing fast websites and apps”</em>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"migratingwordpress\">Migrating WordPress</h2> \n<p>I’ll have to admit that, as much as I wanted this process to be dead simple, there are a number of things that could make it a little more cumbersome and time consuming, such as the existing plugins you may have installed (the fewer the easier) and the way in which you’ve formatted your posts (the simpler the better). Think of this as a guideline that you might need to adjust to your specific case.</p> \n<p>Essentially, this is what we’ll do:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>set up GatsbyJS</li> \n <li>export WP posts/pages to Markdown</li> \n <li>generate the static assets</li> \n</ol> \n<h3 id=\"step1forkthegatsbystarters\">Step 1: Fork the Gatsby Starters</h3> \n<p>We’ll start by forking either the <strong><a href=\"https://github.com/vagr9k/gatsby-advanced-starter/\">Gatsby Advanced Starter</a></strong> or the <strong><a href=\"https://github.com/Vagr9K/gatsby-material-starter\">Gatsby Material Starter</a></strong>, both of which are tweaked general purpose primers for a GatsbyJS project, the second one with an “opinionated” <a href=\"https://material.io/\">Material Design</a> template (<a href=\"https://vagr9k.github.io/gatsby-material-starter/\">demo</a>).</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_web_application\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Progressive_Web_Apps_Logo.svg/200px-Progressive_Web_Apps_Logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Right off the bat these starters will get you a fully featured React-powered <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/progressive-web-apps-a-crash-course/\">progressive web application</a> (PWA) with all batteries included:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>blazing fast loading times (pre-rendered HTML, JS auto chunk loading)</li> \n <li>Markdown posts (code syntax highlight, embed YouTube videos, embed Tweets)</li> \n <li>pagination, tags, categories</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://disqus.com/\">Disqus</a> support</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.netlifycms.org\">NetlifyCMS</a> support</li> \n <li>SEO goodies (<a href=\"https://marketingplatform.google.com/about/analytics/\">Google Analytics</a> support, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitemaps\">Sitemaps</a> and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robots_exclusion_standard\">robots.txt</a> generation, meta tags, <a href=\"https://schema.org/\">Schema.org JSON-LD</a> for Google Rich Snippets, <a href=\"https://ogp.me/\">OpenGraph Tags</a> for Facebook/Google+/Pinterest, <a href=\"https://developer.twitter.com/en/docs/tweets/optimize-with-cards/overview/markup\">Twitter Tags</a> for Twitter Cards)</li> \n <li>syndication feeds (RSS)</li> \n <li>social features (Twitter, LinkedIn and Telegram share button; Facebook and Reddit share/share count)</li> \n <li>development tools (<a href=\"https://eslint.org/\">ESLint</a>, <a href=\"https://prettier.io/\">Prettier</a>, <a href=\"https://github.com/remarkjs/remark-lint\">Remark-Lint</a>, deploying support for <a href=\"https://pages.github.com/\">GitHub pages</a> and <a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/\">Netlify</a>, <a href=\"https://codeclimate.com/\">CodeClimate</a> config file and badge)</li> \n <li>and more!</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The claim is that after a successful migration and deployment to a CDN, your site should be so performant that an audit with <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/\">Google Lighthouse</a> should report the best results possible:</p> \n<p>\n <center></center></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Vagr9K/gatsby-advanced-starter/master/docs/pwa-score.png\" alt=\"\" /></p> \n<h4 id=\"installationandconfiguration\">Installation and Configuration</h4> \n<p>You’ll first need to install GatsbyJS and <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/\">Node.js</a> so that you can use the <code>gatsby</code> CLI and the Node.js packet manager <code>npm</code>. For Node.js just <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/download/\">download and install</a>, for GatsbyJS see the <a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/quick-start/\">Quick Start</a> or <a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.org/tutorial/part-zero/\">Set Up Your Development Environment</a>.</p> \n<p>Once you sort that out, this is how you start a project (remember you can also clone <code>gatsby-material-starter</code>):</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">gatsby new YourProjectName https://github.com/Vagr9K/gatsby-advanced-starter\nnpm run develop # or gatsby develop\n</code></pre> \n<p>The configuration for the Advanced (<a href=\"https://github.com/vagr9k/gatsby-advanced-starter/#configuration\">example</a>) and Material (<a href=\"https://github.com/Vagr9K/gatsby-material-starter#configuration\">example</a>) starters are pretty much the same.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.netlifycms.org/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Netlify_CMS_logo.svg/200px-Netlify_CMS_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>As mentioned, there is Netlify CMS support right out-of-the-box which you can sync with your Git repository enable by editing <code>static/admin/config.yml</code> as follows:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"yaml language-yaml\">backend:\n  name: github\n  branch: master\n  repo: your-user/your-repo\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can also integrate Netlify CMS with GitLab or Bitbucket (see <a href=\"https://www.netlifycms.org/docs/backends-overview/\">Backend Configuration</a>).</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/migrate-wordpress-static-site-generator/?utm_source=rss\">How to Migrate from WordPress to a Static Site Generator</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"21 Node.js Interview Questions with Solutions","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=177156","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/node-js-interview-questions/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"21 Node.js Interview Questions with Solutions\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597280671nodejs-questions.png\" alt=\"21 Node.js Interview Questions for Landing Your Next Job\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597280671nodejs-questions-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597280671nodejs-questions.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Preparing for a job interview is always a daunting task. Most likely you don’t know exactly what you’ll be asked and nerves can easily take over, making you forget even your own name. I’ve compiled 21 Node.js questions for job interviews that go from very simple stuff to some more technically advanced topics to help you in the process.</strong></p> \n<p>Node.js is not exclusively used in the back end. We also use it to create front-end applications, and this has become a very important part of the Web Development ecosystem. This means that it’s very useful for a Node.js developer to be familiar with the role this technology plays in different JavaScript environments. For this reason, I’ve included some questions and answers along those lines.</p> \n<h2 id=\"guidelines\">Guidelines</h2> \n<p>I would recommend trying to answer the questions yourself before reading the answers. If you didn’t get them all, try again tomorrow to see how much you’ve retained.</p> \n<p>There’s also the chance you’re here looking for interview question examples for your candidates. I believe these should be varied enough as a starting point to help you assess their level.</p> \n<p>More than just answering a question correctly, I think it’s the details that show how much someone knows. A good answer might ignite a conversation that could potentially render a stressful experience into a casual chat with a colleague. That’s an ideal result for both parties.</p> \n<h2 id=\"nodejsquestions\">Node.js Questions</h2> \n<h3 id=\"whatisnodejs\">What is Node.js?</h3> \n<p>Node.js is a JavaScript runtime environment based on the V8 engine. It allows us to run JavaScript outside of the browser — typically, in a web server.</p> \n<h3 id=\"whatisnodejsgoodfor\">What is Node.js good for?</h3> \n<p>Node.js is great at handling multiple connections with low cyclomatic complexity, given that its single-threaded nature requires that we liberate the event loop as soon as possible. This makes Node.js an ideal choice for microservices and real-time applications.</p> \n<h3 id=\"whatisnpm\">What is npm?</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/\">npm</a> stands for Node.js Package Manager. It consists of a command-line interface that we can use to access an online registry of public and private packages.</p> \n<h3 id=\"howdoyoucreateanodejsappfromscratch\">How do you create a Node.js app from scratch?</h3> \n<p>We can start by creating a project folder. Then, we navigate to that folder in the command line and run <code>npm init</code>. Finally, we follow the steps to fill our app information.</p> \n<h3 id=\"whatdoesnpminstalldo\">What does “npm install” do?</h3> \n<p>It installs the dependencies found in the <code>package.json</code> file.</p> \n<h3 id=\"howdoyouinstallalibraryinnodejs\">How do you install a library in Node.js?</h3> \n<p><code>npm install name-of-the-library</code> will install our library and include it as a <code>dependency</code>. If we add the <code>--save-dev</code> parameter it will be included as a <code>devDependency</code>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"howdoyoucreateacustomscript\">How do you create a custom script?</h3> \n<p>We need to go into the <code>package.json</code> and add our custom script within the <code>scripts</code> field. We can then run our script by going to the terminal and running <code>npm run name-of-script</code>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"isitpossibletocreateafrontendapplicationwithnodejs\">Is it possible to create a front-end application with Node.js?</h3> \n<p>The browser can’t run a Node.js application, but you could use something like webpack or Parcel to bundle the code and turn it into something a browser could run. It’s very common nowadays to use a Node.js environment for building front-end applications. A good example of Node.js in the front end is the <a href=\"https://www.electronjs.org/\">Electron</a> framework, which makes use of both Node.js and chromium to build “native” apps like, for instance, <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">VS Code</a>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"canyoumentionthreepopularnodejsframeworks\">Can you mention three popular Node.js frameworks?</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://expressjs.com/\">Express.js</a> is probably the most popular framework to date. <a href=\"https://koajs.com/\">Koajs</a> is probably one of the fastest and <a href=\"https://sailsjs.com/\">Sails.js</a> works great for real-time bilateral communication apps given that use socket.io.</p> \n<h3 id=\"whatisexpressjsgoodfor\">What is Express.js good for?</h3> \n<p>Express.js makes it dead easy to set routes for our web app, which makes it an obvious choice to create <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/developers-rest-api/\">REST APIs</a>. It’s quite flexible and easy to use, and its middleware architecture helps to keep a simple and scalable system.</p> \n<h3 id=\"whatiscrypto\">What is Crypto?</h3> \n<p>Crypto is a Node.js internal library that provides cryptographic functionality to do things like, for example, encrypting and decrypting passwords.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/node-js-interview-questions/?utm_source=rss\">21 Node.js Interview Questions with Solutions</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=EUCGbVP1-hc:d3ieu6Rz7Jg:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=EUCGbVP1-hc:d3ieu6Rz7Jg:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img Orac","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597280671nodejs-questions.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn57@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-27-030_1005dd71fcf2f6ef.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=EUCGbVP1-hc:d3ieu6Rz7Jg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn8@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-39-925_bdb4507b9c5b1629.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/EUCGbVP1-hc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn56@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-39-438_d83a8b592a2b50f7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483245},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Get Cloud Certified with ExamPro&#8217;s Smart Learning Platform","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=177312","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-exampro-helps-developers-get-cloud-certified/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Get Cloud Certified with ExamPro’s Smart Learning Platform\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597714771exampro.png\" alt=\"How ExamPro's Smart Learning Helps Developers Get Cloud Certified\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597714771exampro-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597714771exampro.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.exampro.co/\">ExamPro</a> is a study platform to help people pass cloud certification exams.</strong></p> \n<p>Cloud certification exams are challenging, and involve retaining large quantities of technical information. They also open up significant new doors for career advancement and learning potential.</p> \n<p>What if there was a platform that reduced your study time and increased your chances of passing? ExamPro helps participants pass by using a smart learning methodology powered by an AI instructor that reviews your study habits.</p> \n<p>ExamPro’s founders talk about what they’ve built, and the pain points the product addresses for developers.</p> \n<hr style=\"margin: 0 0 20px 0\" /> \n<p><img style=\"margin: 40px 20px 0 0\" src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597713491road.png\" alt=\"A road disappearing in the distance\" width=\"161\" height=\"161\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-177314\" /></p> \n<p>This article is part of The Roadmap, where we look at the creation and promotion of products from the developer’s perspective. We’ll share top lessons from product leaders, and give technical founders a space to share their early-stage products with you. If you’re interested in being featured, <a href=\"https://sitepoint.typeform.com/to/dDQrtqzy\">let us know</a>.</p> \n<hr style=\"margin: 0 0 40px 0\" /> \n<h2 id=\"thecloudhaschangedthewaywebuildapplications\">The Cloud Has Changed the Way We Build Applications</h2> \n<p>Before Cloud Service Providers (CSPs) like Amazon Web Services, you would have to build and maintain your digital infrastructure yourself.</p> \n<p>Previously, if you wanted to add a full-text search engine to your web application, you would have to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>install open-source software such as ElasticSearch</li> \n <li>maintain that server via upgrade and security patches</li> \n <li>configure the open-source software to be highly optimized</li> \n <li>scale by adding load balancing and orchestrating multiple servers</li> \n <li>and create a schedule for data backups.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Now with AWS, you can use the AWS ElasticSearch Service. It will launch a server that scales and is secure by default, and is already configured to be highly optimized. AWS employs world-class engineers to maintain that service.</p> \n<p>Widespread cloud adoption has driven the cost down through cost-sharing of the underlying servers so far that it’s hard to justify paying for an in-house engineer when you can just pay to use the service for a fraction of a penny per hour.</p> \n<h2 id=\"usingthecloudhasintroducedanewdemandfromtechcompanies\">Using the Cloud Has Introduced a New Demand from Tech Companies</h2> \n<p>AWS is the most popular CSP among startups and technology companies. A CSP is a company with a collection of cloud services that you can use to build applications hosted on the cloud.</p> \n<p>AWS is a special kind of CSP because it has hundreds of cloud services for any conceivable use case, and they all seamlessly work together.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Do you need to host a database? Then use AWS RDS.</li> \n <li>Do you need a server? Then use AWS EC2.</li> \n <li>Do you need a chatbot? Then use AWS Lex.</li> \n <li>Do need to generate reports for terabytes of data? Then use AWS Redshift.</li> \n <li>Do you need long-term storage for 7 years? Then use AWS Glacier.</li> \n <li>Do you need to rent a satellite? Then use AWS Ground Station.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>And then the list goes on and on.</p> \n<p>AWS allows companies to compete globally and have access to a wide range of cloud services to build complex applications. </p> \n<p>For a company to take advantage of the cloud, they need someone who knows how to use AWS. Since there are 200+ services, they will need knowledgeable people in different combinations of cloud services based on their use case and business goals.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatareawscertifications\">What Are AWS Certifications?</h2> \n<p>AWS has officially created AWS Certifications to help companies identify qualified hiring candidates for cloud roles, and as of writing this article, they have 12 possible AWS certifications:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Certified Cloud Practitioner (CCP)</li> \n <li>Solutions Architect Associate (SAA)</li> \n <li>Developer Associate</li> \n <li>SysOps Administrator Associate</li> \n <li>DevOps Professional</li> \n <li>Solutions Architect Professional</li> \n <li>Machine Learning Specialty</li> \n <li>Data Analytics Specialty</li> \n <li>Databases Specialty</li> \n <li>Security Specialty</li> \n <li>Advanced Networking Specialty</li> \n <li>Alexa Skill Builder Specialty</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The two most popular AWS certifications are the CCP and the SAA, because they cover the broadest number of AWS services. </p> \n<p>The CCP is the introduction to AWS. The certification costs $100 USD to sit the exam at a test center or online, which can be passed with one to two weeks of study and is valid for three years.<br /> The SAA covers more in-depth services included in the CCP. The certification costs $150 USD to sit the exam at a test center or online, which can be passed with three to five weeks of study and is valid for three years.</p> \n<p>When you pass an AWS Certification, you get the next half off, so it’s common for people to take the CCP for $100 USD and then take the SAA at $75 USD.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-exampro-helps-developers-get-cloud-certified/?utm_source=rss\">Get Cloud Certified with ExamPro’s Smart Learning Platform</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=NSx66dwdRyg:1PwyDL6j94M:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=NSx66dwdRyg:1PwyDL6j94M:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=NSx66dwdRyg:1PwyDL6j94M:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=NSx66dwdRyg:1PwyDL6j94M:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/NSx66dwdRyg\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 19 Aug 2020 19:30:12 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597714771exampro.png","linkMd5":"ea8bb5a4c36805319d6d50e4d376abfb","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn21@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-143_6e008f9b6a91a956.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":17266,"destBytes":17266,"author":"Andrew Brown","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597714771exampro.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn21@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-143_6e008f9b6a91a956.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597713491road.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn85@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-44-072_6b2bde8f861a8604.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=NSx66dwdRyg:1PwyDL6j94M:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn80@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-44-469_6aa6fea8d3dbe430.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/NSx66dwdRyg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn48@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-46-776_7cdd46c957a63067.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483244},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Redesign the Django Admin with Bootstrap","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176063","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-hack-redesign-customize-the-django-admin-with-bootstrap/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Redesign the Django Admin with Bootstrap\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588125191django-admin.jpg\" alt=\"Hacking the Django Admin with Bootstrap\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588125191django-admin-300x170.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588125191django-admin.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>The <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/admin/\">Django administration site</a> is great — fully-featured, easy to use, secure by design, rock solid … and somewhat ugly, which can be something of a downside when you want to integrate it with the look and feel of the rest of your website. Let’s sort that out.</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"ifitaintbroke\">If It Ain’t Broke …</h2> \n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588121363admin.png\" width=\"981\" height=\"327\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176065\" alt=\"The default Django admin\" />\n <figcaption style=\"text-align:center; font-size:0.8em; margin: 12px 0 20px\">\n  The default Django admin. (\n  <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/_images/admin02.png\">Source</a>) \n </figcaption>\n</figure> \n<p>Say you’ve just <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/web-app-prototype-django-vue/\">prototyped a web app with Django and Vue.js</a>. For a wide array of cases, using Django’s admin for back office purposes as is, and even handling it over to your client after <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/auth/default/\">appropriately setting permissions</a>, is just fine. After all, it works perfectly well and <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/admin/\">it can be heavily customized with the built-in tools</a> to cover many situations.</p> \n<p>So again, why bother?</p> \n<h3 id=\"reasonstohackthelookandfeeloftheadmin\">Reasons to Hack the Look and Feel of the Admin</h3> \n<p>However, there are a number of valid reasons to take integration a step further:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Branding</strong>: there’s nothing wrong in wanting the name and colors of your company instead of “Django administration” (and for the record, this is in compliance with Django’s <a href=\"https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/LICENSE\">BSD license</a>).</li> \n <li><strong>Seamless integration between main site and admin</strong>: you might want to be able to transition between back office functionality while navigating the site, and vice versa, by having a common <a href=\"https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.1/components/navbar/\">navigation bar</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>Prettifying</strong>: while the admin looks okay, and it has even implemented <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Responsive_web_design\">responsive web design</a> principles ever since v2 (it works well on both, mobile and desktop), there’s <em>a lot</em> a well-crafted style sheet can do to make it look better.</li> \n <li><strong>Bypass functionality</strong>: you might also just want to create custom dropdown menus for the admin, displaying the options that you actually use and hiding from the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface\">user interface</a> what you don’t really need, which could make for a better <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_experience\">user experience</a>.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"apracticalexample\">A Practical Example</h2> \n<p>For this example, and not to repeat ourselves, we’ll resume the simple publishing web application we started for the <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/web-app-prototype-django-vue\">Prototyping a Web App with Django and Vue.js</a> article.</p> \n<p>In a nutshell:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>a Django app with two <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/db/models/\">models</a>:</li> \n <li><strong><code>Article</code></strong> with fields <code>name</code> <code>author</code> (linked), <code>content</code> and <code>slug</code></li> \n <li><strong><code>Author</code></strong>: with fields <code>name</code> and <code>slug</code></li> \n <li>A single <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/http/views/\">view</a> called <code>frontend</code> that queries all registries in both models.</li> \n <li>A single template called <code>template</code>.</li> \n <li>Implementation of <a href=\"https://vuejs.org/\">Vue.js</a> with <a href=\"https://router.vuejs.org/\">Vue Router</a> and <a href=\"https://vuex.vuejs.org/\">Vuex</a> for a reactive scalable interface.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>We won’t particularly care for the Vue.js integration in this installment, and we won’t modify it here.</p> \n<h3 id=\"thebasictemplate\">The Basic Template</h3> \n<figure style=\"margin-top:20px; float:right; padding-left:20px\"> \n <img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588121766Django_logo.png\" alt=\"\" />\n <figcaption style=\"text-align:center; font-size:0.8em; margin: 12px 0 20px\">\n  <a href=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Django_logo.svg/100px-Django_logo.svg.png\">Source</a> \n </figcaption>\n</figure> \n<p><a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/templates/\">Django templates</a> are very versatile and powerful, and can either be created at the <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/applications/\">app level</a> (a component of the Django site) or at the site level, and can even override the templates that come with Django (which is what we’ll do here).</p> \n<figure style=\"float:right; padding-left:20px\"> \n <img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588121945Bootstrap_logo.png\" alt=\"Bootstrap logo\" />\n <figcaption style=\"text-align:center; font-size:0.8em; margin: 12px 0 20px\">\n  <a href=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Bootstrap_logo.svg/100px-Bootstrap_logo.svg.png\">Source</a> \n </figcaption>\n</figure> \n<p>We created a basic template that links to <a href=\"https://getbootstrap.com/\">Bootstrap</a>‘s JavaScript and style sheet, and also its companion tools, <a href=\"https://jquery.com/\">jQuery</a> and <a href=\"https://popper.js.org/\">Popper</a>.</p> \n<p>Here’s the base template we’re using for the main site, not at all different from what we would normally use for any other Django site:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;!doctype html&gt;\n&lt;html lang=\"en\"&gt;\n  &lt;head&gt;\n    &lt;!-- Required meta tags --&gt;\n    &lt;meta charset=\"utf-8\"&gt;\n    &lt;meta name=\"viewport\" content=\"width=device-width, initial-scale=1, shrink-to-fit=no\"&gt;\n\n    &lt;!-- Bootstrap CSS --&gt;\n    &lt;link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"https://stackpath.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/4.4.1/css/bootstrap.min.css\" integrity=\"sha384-Vkoo8x4CGsO3+Hhxv8T/Q5PaXtkKtu6ug5TOeNV6gBiFeWPGFN9MuhOf23Q9Ifjh\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\"&gt;\n\n    &lt;title&gt;Django and Vue.js&lt;/title&gt;\n  &lt;/head&gt;\n  &lt;body class=\"bg-light\"&gt;\n    &lt;div class=\"bg-white container\"&gt;\n      &lt;h1&gt;Prototyping a Web App with Django and Vue.js&lt;/h1&gt;\n\n      &lt;!-- Content --&gt;\n    &lt;/div&gt;\n\n    &lt;!-- Vue.js --&gt;\n    &lt;script src=\"https://unpkg.com/vue\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n    &lt;script src=\"https://unpkg.com/vue-router\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n\n    &lt;!-- jQuery first, then Popper.js, then Bootstrap JS --&gt;\n    &lt;script src=\"https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.4.1.slim.min.js\" integrity=\"sha384-J6qa4849blE2+poT4WnyKhv5vZF5SrPo0iEjwBvKU7imGFAV0wwj1yYfoRSJoZ+n\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n    &lt;script src=\"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/popper.js@1.16.0/dist/umd/popper.min.js\" integrity=\"sha384-Q6E9RHvbIyZFJoft+2mJbHaEWldlvI9IOYy5n3zV9zzTtmI3UksdQRVvoxMfooAo\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n    &lt;script src=\"https://stackpath.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/4.4.1/js/bootstrap.min.js\" integrity=\"sha384-wfSDF2E50Y2D1uUdj0O3uMBJnjuUD4Ih7YwaYd1iqfktj0Uod8GCExl3Og8ifwB6\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n  &lt;/body&gt;\n&lt;/html&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Next, we’ll integrate this into the admin, and add a shared navigation bar across both ends — the main site and the back office!</p> \n<h2 id=\"integratingthemainuitemplatewiththeadmin\">Integrating the Main UI Template with the Admin</h2> \n<p>As mentioned, we can <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/howto/overriding-templates/\">override templates</a>, including those of the admin. However, because of Django’s design, and unsurprisingly, the main site and the back office are two different systems, each with its own templates, style sheets, and <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/\"><code>contrib</code> packages</a>. So even if they will be <em>almost</em> identical, <em>we’ll need to maintain two different templates — one for the main UI, and one for the admin.</em></p> \n<h3 id=\"enablingadirectoryfortemplatesingeneral\">Enabling a Directory for Templates in General</h3> \n<p>First, we need to tell Django where we’ll store the hacked admin template in the base directory.</p> \n<p>Se we’ll need to edit <code>myproject/settings.py</code>. firstly, find the <code>TEMPLATES</code> constant and this <code>DIRS</code> key:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"python language-python\">'DIRS': [],\n</code></pre> \n<p>Change that code to this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"python language-python\">'DIRS': [os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'templates')],\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"wrappingtheadmintemplateadminbasehack\">Wrapping the Admin Template (<code>admin/base</code> Hack)</h3> \n<p>If we just wanted to do cosmetic changes, like passing a custom style sheet to the admin, or removing/replacing its header, we could get along with that by just editing the <code>admin/base_site</code> template and skipping this current step altogether. However, if we want to go all the way and “<a href=\"https://www.quora.com/In-programming-what-is-a-wrapper\">wrap</a>” the admin section as if it was contained within our main site, with the possibility to have a common header and footer, then keep reading.</p> \n<p>We’ll need to copy Django’s <a href=\"https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/contrib/admin/templates/admin/base.html\"><code>admin/base.html</code></a> to our templates directory in <code>templates/admin/base.html</code>, so that we can place our wrappers.</p> \n<p>We’ll edit the code around the <code>container</code> section, so that it goes from this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;!-- Container --&gt;\n&lt;div id=\"container\"&gt;\n(...)\n&lt;/div&gt;\n&lt;!-- END Container --&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>to this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">{% block bodyheader %}{% endblock %}\n\n&lt;!-- Container --&gt;\n&lt;div id=\"container\"&gt;\n(...)\n&lt;/div&gt;\n&lt;!-- END Container --&gt;\n\n{% block bodyfooter %}{% endblock %}\n</code></pre> \n<p>And that’s all! We simply created <code>bodyheader</code> and <code>bodyfooter</code> block tags, so that we could inject the code that will wrap the admin on the next step.</p> \n<h3 id=\"codingacustomadmintemplateadminbase_sitehack\">Coding a Custom Admin Template (<code>admin/base_site</code> Hack)</h3> \n<p>Then, we’ll code the actual template in <code>templates/admin/base_site.html</code> (we’ll need to create the directories on the root of our project):</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">{% extends \"admin/base_site.html\" %}\n\n{% block title %}Django with Bootstrap | Admin site{% endblock %}\n\n{% block branding %}{% endblock %}\n{% block breadcrumbs %}{% endblock %}\n\n{% block bodyclass %}bg-light{% endblock %}\n\n{% block extrastyle %}\n    &lt;link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"https://stackpath.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/4.4.1/css/bootstrap.min.css\" integrity=\"sha384-Vkoo8x4CGsO3+Hhxv8T/Q5PaXtkKtu6ug5TOeNV6gBiFeWPGFN9MuhOf23Q9Ifjh\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\"&gt;\n    &lt;style&gt;\n      #header, .breadcrumbs { display: none; }\n\n      /* Bootstrap issues with admin */\n      * { box-sizing: unset; }\n      div.module caption { caption-side: top !important; }\n      .collapse { display: block !important; }\n    &lt;/style&gt;\n{% endblock %}\n\n{% block bodyheader %}\n    &lt;div class=\"bg-white container\"&gt;\n\n      &lt;div class=\"jumbotron\"&gt;\n        &lt;h1 class=\"display-4\"&gt;Hacking the Django Admin with Bootstrap&lt;/h1&gt;\n        &lt;p class=\"lead\"&gt;\n          The &lt;a ref=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/admin/\"&gt;Django administration site&lt;/a&gt; is great—full-featured, easy to use, secure by design, rock solid… and somewhat ugly, which can be something of a downside when you want to integrate it with the look-and-feel of the rest of the website. Let’s sort that out.\n        &lt;/p&gt;\n      &lt;/div&gt;\n{% endblock %}\n\n{% block bodyfooter %}\n    &lt;/div&gt;\n\n    &lt;!-- jQuery first, then Popper.js, then Bootstrap JS --&gt;\n    &lt;script src=\"https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.4.1.slim.min.js\" integrity=\"sha384-J6qa4849blE2+poT4WnyKhv5vZF5SrPo0iEjwBvKU7imGFAV0wwj1yYfoRSJoZ+n\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n    &lt;script src=\"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/popper.js@1.16.0/dist/umd/popper.min.js\" integrity=\"sha384-Q6E9RHvbIyZFJoft+2mJbHaEWldlvI9IOYy5n3zV9zzTtmI3UksdQRVvoxMfooAo\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n    &lt;script src=\"https://stackpath.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/4.4.1/js/bootstrap.min.js\" integrity=\"sha384-wfSDF2E50Y2D1uUdj0O3uMBJnjuUD4Ih7YwaYd1iqfktj0Uod8GCExl3Og8ifwB6\" crossorigin=\"anonymous\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n{% endblock %}\n</code></pre> \n<h4 id=\"breakdown\">Breakdown</h4> \n<p>Let’s try to explain what we’re doing here:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>We tell the template engine that we are “extending” the <code>admin/base_site.html</code> template, to effectively override some of its definitions.</li> \n <li>We make use of the <code>title</code> block to customize a title for the admin page being browsed.</li> \n <li>We empty the content of <code>branding</code> and <code>breadcrumbs</code> blocks, as we don’t really need them.</li> \n <li>We use the <code>bodyclass</code> block to set Bootstrap’s <code>bg-light</code>, as we did in the <code>frontend</code> template.</li> \n <li>We use the <code>extrastyle</code> block to embed Bootstrap, and some CSS code.<br /> a. Okay, <code>#header, .breadcrumbs { display: none; }</code> is something of a restatement of number 3; but it’s useful to know you can disable the branding and breadcrumbs sections both ways.<br /> b. There can be some issues when overlapping Bootstrap with Django’s CSS in the admin, so these are some fixes.</li> \n <li>Use the <code>bodyheader</code> and <code>bodyfooter</code> blocks to wrap the admin content.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Now that we have access to the admin template, we could further its style sheet, or just leave it at that with a shared style with the main UI.</p> \n<h3 id=\"caveats\">Caveats</h3> \n<p>We’re maintaining two different templates (main UI and admin) to do essentially the same presentation. Admittedly, this isn’t ideal, as we’re explicitly breaking one of the maxims of software development: <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_repeat_yourself\">don’t repeat yourself</a> (DRY).</p> \n<p>As we commented, this is because the Django admin has been designed to be detached from the main UI. And there’s nothing wrong with that, just as there isn’t anything wrong with thinking out of the box. But yes, that forces us to use two templates with nearly the same content.</p> \n<p><em>Actually</em>, in principle we could design a template pattern that included that navbar and other common elements from the main UI and the admin, and reuse them from that single source; but at this point, and for the purpose of this article, that approach would be a little overkill. Anyway, I’ll leave the idea planted for you. 😉</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-hack-redesign-customize-the-django-admin-with-bootstrap/?utm_source=rss\">How to Redesign the Django Admin with Bootstrap</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=EuknvqxyD8A:Q5hDN5PvF50:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=EuknvqxyD8A:Q5hDN5PvF50:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=EuknvqxyD8A:Q5hDN5PvF50:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/EuknvqxyD8A\" del Alba","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588125191django-admin.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn1@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-25-680_2d11cf13d5de959a.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588121363admin.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588121766Django_logo.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588121945Bootstrap_logo.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=EuknvqxyD8A:Q5hDN5PvF50:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn1@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-44-755_af3f85d4c270ab59.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/EuknvqxyD8A":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn64@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-45-245_d0326766a615177f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483270},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Managing Dates and Times Using Moment.js","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=80121","description":"<br />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 15 Mar 2020 11:00:22 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/1584337699m0021-12.jpg","linkMd5":"2b214caa766f988ff2d519437bfffa83","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn38@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-25-851_4e0bf1ca76468727.webp","destWidth":2000,"destHeight":1233,"sourceBytes":37506,"destBytes":37506,"author":"Jay Raj","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/1584337699m0021-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn38@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-25-851_4e0bf1ca76468727.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=PZIzt-pPIjE:ROZ-YPKMQWA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn10@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-43-980_fe26cc5514d96a13.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/PZIzt-pPIjE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn24@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-46-598_c89b1da2c70653dd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483291},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Design for Screen Readers with Adobe XD CC","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175102","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-design-for-screen-readers-with-adobe-xd-cc/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Design for Screen Readers with Adobe XD CC\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582544632screen-readers.png\" alt=\"Designing for Screen Readers with the Help of Adobe XD CC\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582544632screen-readers-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582544632screen-readers.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>When it comes to accessibility, designers tend to focus on colors (i.e. contrast) and UX copy (i.e. wording), whereas developers tend to focus on ARIA attributes (i.e. code that makes websites more accessible). This is due to the fact that, often enough, thick lines are drawn between “who does what”.</strong></p> \n<p>Also, because creating accessible apps and websites isn’t considered to be exciting, this line is hardly ever questioned.</p> \n<p><strong>Accessibility is still a black sheep, even in 2020.</strong></p> \n<p><em>So</em>, since UX copy is the responsibility of the designer and ARIA attributes are the responsibility of the developer, exactly whose responsibility is it to cater for screen readers? Since:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Screen reader UX copy is expressed as Braille or dictation (so how do we communicate this when our UI tools are visual?)</li> \n <li>Implementation is developer territory (so can we really shift the responsibility of writing UX copy to developers?)</li> \n</ol> \n<p>As you can see, it’s a <em>two-person job</em> — and yet, the tools simply don’t exist to facilitate this. I mean, make no mistake, some aspects of accessibility design are one-sided (for example, UI designers can very easily take care of color contrast by themselves). However, other aspects such as designing for screen readers requires collaboration between designers and developers.</p> \n<p>This is where Adobe XD CC’s <em>design handoff</em> and <em>voice prototyping</em> features come in handy. In this article, we’ll discuss what to consider when designing for screen readers, and we’ll also walk through how to use the features mentioned above.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatarescreenreaders\">What Are Screen Readers?</h2> \n<p>A screen reader is a type of assistive technology that communicates what’s happening on the screen (for those with visual impairments). Screen reader software can be used in combination with the keyboard (for example, users will <kbd>tab</kbd> and <kbd>enter</kbd> as opposed to using the mouse), but it can also be used in combination with screen reader hardware, which allows for more efficient navigation and also caters for users that use Braille.</p> \n<p>If you’re an Apple user, for example, you’ll be somewhat aware of <a href=\"https://www.apple.com/my/accessibility/mac/vision/\">Apple VoiceOver</a>, which is the native Apple dictation software that acts as a screen reader. Windows users, however, commonly use either <a href=\"https://www.freedomscientific.com/products/software/jaws/\">JAWS</a> or <a href=\"https://www.nvaccess.org/\">NVDA</a>, since there aren’t any native screen reader tools in the Windows operating system.</p> \n<p>Let’s dive in.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1useheadings\">1. Use Headings</h2> \n<p>Screen readers often use headings as a way of deciphering a website’s structure, and if we think too visually we run the risk of leaving out these headings. In the example below, the omission of the “Chapters” heading causes screen readers to assume that the list of chapters is a continuation of the content on the left-hand side, which it obviously isn’t.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582543608heading-1024x640.png\" alt=\"&quot;Chapters&quot; needs to be a heading\" width=\"1024\" height=\"640\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-175104\" /></p> \n<p>As a result, screen-reader users won’t be able to skip to “Chapters”, and they might not discover the information within.</p> \n<p>While there are code workarounds available (such as the <code>aria-label</code> attribute), having a <em>visible</em> heading inclusively offers a clearer experience for <em>everybody</em>, whether disabled or not.</p> \n<p>Of course, the section is very obviously a list of chapters, as we can infer from the context (i.e. the content). However, those using screen readers <em>very rarely</em> have the luxury of context. It’s like trying to find an object in storage where none of the boxes are labeled. Our designs need these labels and headings.</p> \n<p>On the technical side, the rule is that every section (as defined by a <code>&lt;section&gt;</code> or <code>&lt;article&gt;</code> tag) should have not only a heading, but an explicit heading that conflicts with no other heading. As an example, if the highest level heading within a section is an <code>&lt;h2&gt;</code>, then there should be no other <code>&lt;h2&gt;</code> heading within that section. Otherwise, screen readers are clueless as to which heading is the label for the section.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582543648heading2-1024x640.png\" alt=\"The same heading for like sections\" width=\"1024\" height=\"640\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-175106\" /></p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-design-for-screen-readers-with-adobe-xd-cc/?utm_source=rss\">How to Design for Screen Readers with Adobe XD CC</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QClTMds4s8o:lu4wDWOz06M:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QClTMds4s8o:lu4wDWOz06M:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QClTMds4s8o:lu4wDWOz06M:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=QClTMds4s8o:lu4wDWOz06M:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/QClTMds4s8o\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 26 Feb 2020 23:00:36 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582544632screen-readers.png","linkMd5":"1802bede153efd4d79266941be34d026","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn10@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-25-728_4d951bd672088038.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":5484,"destBytes":5484,"author":"Daniel Schwarz","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582544632screen-readers.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn10@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-25-728_4d951bd672088038.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582543608heading-1024x640.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn34@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-39-018_69255e9cae2c6052.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582543648heading2-1024x640.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn85@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-36-590_8100b12f6d23739a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=QClTMds4s8o:lu4wDWOz06M:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn73@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-36-700_0c5783ef11bea389.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/QClTMds4s8o":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn37@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-35-089_5fe697ca63faee3a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483297},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Build a Simple Beginner App with Node, Bootstrap and MongoDB","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=162947","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-simple-beginner-app-node-bootstrap-mongodb/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Build a Simple Beginner App with Node, Bootstrap and MongoDB\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1582112966app-development.png\" alt=\"Building a Simple Beginner App with Node, Bootstrap and MongoDB\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1582112966app-development-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1582112966app-development.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>If you’re just getting started with Node.js and want to try your hand at building a web app, things can often get a little overwhelming. Once you get beyond the “Hello, World!” tutorials, much of the material out there has you copy-pasting code, with little or no explanation as to what you’re doing or why.</strong></p> \n<p>This means that, by the time you’ve finished, you’ve built something nice and shiny, but you also have relatively few takeaways that you can apply to your next project.</p> \n<p>In this tutorial, I’m going to take a slightly different approach. Starting from the ground up, I’ll demonstrate how to build a no-frills web app using Node.js, but instead of focusing on the end result, I’ll focus on a range of things you’re likely to encounter when building a real-world app. These include routing, templating, dealing with forms, interacting with a database and even basic authentication.</p> \n<p>This won’t be a JavaScript 101. If that’s the kind of thing you’re after, <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/beginners-guide-javascript-variables-and-datatypes/\">look here</a>. It will, however, be suitable for those people who feel reasonably confident with the JavaScript language, and who are looking to take their first steps in Node.js.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatwellbebuilding\">What We’ll Be Building</h2> \n<p>We’ll be using <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/\">Node.js</a> and the <a href=\"http://expressjs.com/\">Express framework</a> to build a simple registration form with basic validation, which persists its data to a <a href=\"https://www.mongodb.com/\">MongoDB database</a>. We’ll add a view to list successful registration, which we’ll protect with basic HTTP authentication, and we’ll use <a href=\"https://getbootstrap.com/\">Bootstrap</a> to add some styling. The tutorial is structured so that you can follow along step by step. However, if you’d like to jump ahead and see the end result, <a href=\"https://github.com/jameshibbard/demo-node-app\">the code for this tutorial is also available on GitHub</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"basicsetup\">Basic Setup</h2> \n<p>Before we can start coding, we’ll need to get Node, npm and MongoDB installed on our machines. I won’t go into depth on the various installation instructions, but if you have any trouble getting set up, please <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/community/\">visit our forums</a> and ask for help there.</p> \n<h3 id=\"nodejs\">Node.js</h3> \n<p>Many websites will recommend that you head to <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/download/\">the official Node download page</a> and grab the Node binaries for your system. While that works, I would suggest that you use a version manager instead. This is a program which allows you to install multiple versions of Node and switch between them at will. There are various advantages to using a version manager. For example, it negates potential permission issues which would otherwise see you installing packages with admin rights.</p> \n<p>If you fancy going the version manager route, please consult our quick tip: <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">Install Multiple Versions of Node.js Using nvm</a>. Otherwise, grab the correct binaries for your system from the link above and install those.</p> \n<h3 id=\"npm\">npm</h3> \n<p>npm is a JavaScript package manager which comes bundled with Node, so no extra installation is necessary here. We’ll be making quite extensive use of npm throughout this tutorial, so if you’re in need of a refresher, please consult <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/beginners-guide-node-package-manager/\">A Beginner’s Guide to npm — the Node Package Manager</a>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"mongodb\">MongoDB</h3> \n<p>MongoDB is a document database which stores data in flexible, JSON-like documents. If you’ve never worked with Mongo before, you might like to check out our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/an-introduction-to-mongodb/\">beginner-friendly introduction to MongoDB</a>.</p> \n<p>The quickest way to get up and running with Mongo is to use a service such as mLabs. They have a free sandbox plan which provides a single database with 0.5GB of storage running on a shared virtual machine. This is more than adequate for a simple app with a handful of users. If this sounds like the best option for you, please consult their <a href=\"http://docs.mlab.com/\">quick-start guide</a>.</p> \n<p>You can also install Mongo locally. To do this, please visit the <a href=\"https://www.mongodb.com/download-center/community\">official download page</a> and download the correct version of the community server for your operating system. There’s a link to detailed, OS-specific installation instructions beneath every download link, which you can consult if you run into trouble.</p> \n<h3 id=\"amongodbgui\">A MongoDB GUI</h3> \n<p>Although not strictly necessary for following along with this tutorial, you might also like to install <a href=\"https://www.mongodb.com/products/compass\">Compass, the official GUI for MongoDB</a>. This tool helps you visualize and manipulate your data, allowing you to interact with documents with full CRUD functionality.</p> \n<h3 id=\"checkthateverythingisinstalledcorrectly\">Check that Everything is Installed Correctly</h3> \n<p>To check that Node and npm are installed correctly, open your terminal and type:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">node -v\n</code></pre> \n<p>followed by:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm -v\n</code></pre> \n<p>This will output the version number of each program (<code>12.14.1</code> and <code>6.13.6</code> respectively at the time of writing).</p> \n<p>If you installed Mongo locally, you can check the version number using:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mongo --version\n</code></pre> \n<p>This should output a bunch of information, including the version number (<code>4.2.2</code> at the time of writing).</p> \n<h3 id=\"checkthedatabaseconnectionusingcompass\">Check the Database Connection Using Compass</h3> \n<p>If you’ve installed Mongo locally, you start the server by typing the following command into a terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mongod\n</code></pre> \n<p>Next, open Compass. You should be able to accept the defaults (server: <code>localhost</code>, port: 27017), press the <em>CONNECT</em> button, and establish a connection to the database server.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1579778337MongoDB-Compass-localhost27017_001.png\" alt=\"MongoDB Compass connected to localhost:27107\" /></p> \n<p><em><small>MongoDB Compass connected to localhost</small></em></p> \n<p>Note that the databases <code>admin</code>, <code>config</code> and <code>local</code> are created automatically.</p> \n<h4 id=\"usingacloudhostedsolution\">Using a Cloud-hosted Solution</h4> \n<p>If you’re using mLabs, create a database subscription (as described in their <a href=\"http://docs.mlab.com/\">quick-start guide</a>), then make a note of the connection details.</p> \n<p>Open Compass, click <em>New Connection</em>, then <em>Fill in connection fields individually</em>. Select <em>Username / Password</em> as the authentication method, then fill out the rest of the details. Finally, click <em>CONNECT</em> and you should be off to the races.</p> \n<p><em>Note: if you wish to use a connection string, it should look like this: <code>mongodb://&lt;dbuser&gt;:&lt;dbpassword&gt;@ds211709.mlab.com:11709/?authSource=&lt;dbname&gt;</code>.</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1579781817MongoDB-Compass-ds211709.mlab_.com11709_002.png\" alt=\"MongoDB Compass connected to mLabs\" /></p> \n<p><em><small>MongoDB Compass connected to mLabs</small></em></p> \n<p>Note that I called my database <code>sp-node-article</code>. You can call yours what you like.</p> \n<h2 id=\"initializetheapplication\">Initialize the Application</h2> \n<p>With everything set up correctly, the first thing we need to do is initialize our new project. To do this, create a folder named <code>demo-node-app</code>, enter that directory and type the following in a terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm init -y\n</code></pre> \n<p>This will create and auto-populate a <code>package.json</code> file in the project root. We can use this file to specify our dependencies and to create various <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/guide-to-npm-as-a-build-tool/\">npm scripts</a>, which will aid our development workflow.</p> \n<h3 id=\"installexpress\">Install Express</h3> \n<p>Express is a lightweight web application framework for Node.js, which provides us with a robust set of features for writing web apps. These features include such things as route handling, template engine integration and a middleware framework, which allows us to perform additional tasks on request and response objects. There’s nothing you can do in Express that you couldn’t do in plain Node.js, but using Express means we don’t have to re-invent the wheel and it reduces boilerplate.</p> \n<p>So let’s install <a href=\"http://expressjs.com/\">Express</a>. To do this, run the following in your terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install express\n</code></pre> \n<p>This will see Express added to the <code>dependencies</code> section of the <code>package.json</code> file. This signals to anyone else running our code that Express is a package our app needs to function properly.</p> \n<h3 id=\"installnodemon\">Install nodemon</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://github.com/remy/nodemon\">nodemon</a> is a convenience tool. It will watch the files in the directory it was started in, and if it detects any changes, it will automatically restart your Node application (meaning you don’t have to). In contrast to Express, nodemon is not something the app requires to function properly (it just aids us with development), so install it using:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install --save-dev nodemon\n</code></pre> \n<p>This will add nodemon to the <code>dev-dependencies</code> section of the <code>package.json</code> file.</p> \n<h3 id=\"createsomeinitialfiles\">Create Some Initial Files</h3> \n<p>We’re almost through with the setup. All we need to do now is create a couple of initial files before kicking off the app.</p> \n<p>In the <code>demo-node-app</code> folder create an <code>app.js</code> file and a <code>start.js</code> file. Also create a <code>routes</code> folder, with an <code>index.js</code> file inside. After you’re done, things should look like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">.\n├── app.js\n├── node_modules\n│   └── ...\n├── package.json\n├── package-lock.json\n├── routes\n│   └── index.js\n└── start.js\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now, let’s add some code to those files.</p> \n<p>In <code>app.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const express = require('express');\nconst routes = require('./routes/index');\n\nconst app = express();\napp.use('/', routes);\n\nmodule.exports = app;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here, we’re importing both the <code>express</code> module and (the export value of) our routes file into the application. The <code>require</code> function we’re using to do this is a built-in Node function which imports an object from another file or module. If you’d like a refresher on importing and exporting modules, read <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/understanding-module-exports-exports-node-js/\">Understanding module.exports and exports in Node.js</a>.</p> \n<p>After that, we’re creating a new Express app using the <a href=\"http://expressjs.com/en/api.html#express\">express</a> function and assigning it to an <code>app</code> variable. We then tell the app that, whenever it receives a request from forward slash anything, it should use the routes file.</p> \n<p>Finally, we export our app variable so that it can be imported and used in other files.</p> \n<p>In <code>start.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const app = require('./app');\n\nconst server = app.listen(3000, () =&gt; {\n  console.log(`Express is running on port ${server.address().port}`);\n});\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here we’re importing the Express app we created in <code>app.js</code>. (Note that we can leave the <code>.js</code> off the file name in the <code>require</code> statement.) We then tell our app to listen on port 3000 for incoming connections and output a message to the terminal to indicate that the server is running.</p> \n<p>And in <code>routes/index.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const express = require('express');\n\nconst router = express.Router();\n\nrouter.get('/', (req, res) =&gt; {\n  res.send('It works!');\n});\n\nmodule.exports = router;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here, we’re importing Express into our routes file and then grabbing the router from it. We then use the router to respond to any requests to the root URL (in this case <code>http://localhost:3000</code>) with an “It works!” message.</p> \n<h3 id=\"kickofftheapp\">Kick off the App</h3> \n<p>Finally, let’s add an npm script to make nodemon start watching our app. Change the <code>scripts</code> section of the <code>package.json</code> file to look like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">\"scripts\": {\n  \"watch\": \"nodemon ./start.js\"\n},\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <code>scripts</code> property of the <code>package.json</code> file is extremely useful, as it lets you specify arbitrary scripts to run in different scenarios. This means that you don’t have to repeatedly type out long-winded commands with a difficult-to-remember syntax. If you’d like to find out more about what npm scripts can do, read <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/guide-to-npm-as-a-build-tool/\">Give Grunt the Boot! A Guide to Using npm as a Build Tool</a>.</p> \n<p>Now, type <code>npm run watch</code> from the terminal and visit <a href=\"http://localhost:3000\">http://localhost:3000</a>.</p> \n<p>You should see “It works!”</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-simple-beginner-app-node-bootstrap-mongodb/?utm_source=rss\">Build a Simple Beginner App with Node, Bootstrap and MongoDB</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Properly Organize Files in Your Codebase &#038; Avoid Mayhem","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175064","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/organize-project-files/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Properly Organize Files in Your Codebase &amp; Avoid Mayhem\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582120005organize-files.png\" alt=\"How to Properly Organize Files on a Project and Avoid Mayhem\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582120005organize-files-300x163.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582120005organize-files.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>The main library, data, UI, docs and wiki, tests, legacy and third-party components … How do we keep track and maintain order within all of this?</strong> Organizing the files in your codebase can become a daunting task.</p> \n<p>Relax — we’ve got this! In this article, we’ll review the most common systems for both small and large projects, with some easy-to-follow best practices.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whybother\">Why Bother?</h2> \n<p>As with pretty much all of the tasks related to <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/effective-project-management-traditional-agile-extreme-hybrid-8th-edition?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">project management</a> — documentation, software commits, deployment — you’ll benefit from taking a conscious, programmatic approach. <em>Not only it will reduce problems now, but it will also save you and your team quality time in the future</em> when you need to quickly access and review things.</p> \n<p>You surely can recall function names from the top of your head for whatever is it that you’re coding right now, and quickly find a file you need to edit, and sharply tell what works from what doesn’t — or so you think. But could you say the same about that project you were working on last year?</p> \n<p>Let’s admit it: <strong>software projects can go on spans of inactivity that last for months, and even years</strong>. A simple <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/README\">README file</a> could do <em>a lot</em> for your colleagues or your future self. But let’s think about the other ways you could structure your project, and establish some basic rules to name files, address project documentation, and to some degree organize an effective workflow that would stand the test of time.</p> \n<h2 id=\"makingsenseofthings\">Making Sense of Things</h2> \n<p>We’ll establish a “baseline” for organizing files in a project — a logic that will serve us for a number of situations within the scope of software development.</p> \n<p>As with our rules for <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/committing-changes-right-way/\">committing changes to your codebase the right way</a>, none of this is carved in stone, and for what it’s worth, you and your team might come up with different guidelines. In any case, <em>consistency is the name of the game</em>. Be sure you understand (and discuss or dispute) what the rules are, and follow them once you’ve reached a consensus.</p> \n<h3 id=\"themandatoryset\">The Mandatory Set</h3> \n<p>This is a reference list of files that nearly every software project should have:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>README</strong>: this is what GitHub renders for you right under the sourcetree, and it can go <em>a long way</em> to explaining what the project is about, how files are organized, and where to find further information.</li> \n <li><strong>CHANGELOG</strong>: to list what’s new, modified or discontinued on every version or revision — normally in a reverse chronological order for convenience (last changes first).</li> \n <li><strong>COPYING LICENSE</strong>: a file containing the full text of the license covering the software, including some additional copyright information, if necessary (such as third-party licenses).</li> \n <li><strong>.gitignore</strong>: assuming you use <a href=\"https://git-scm.com/\">Git</a> (you most probably do), this will also be a must to tell what files not to sync with the repository. (See <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/jump-start-git/read/2/jyzj6fb9?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Jump Start Git’s primer on .gitignore</a> and the <a href=\"https://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore\">documentation</a> for more info, and have a look at <a href=\"https://github.com/github/gitignore\">a collection of useful .gitignore templates</a> for some ideas.)</li> \n</ul> \n<h4 id=\"supportingactors\">Supporting Actors</h4> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/organize-project-files/?utm_source=rss\">How to Properly Organize Files in Your Codebase &amp; Avoid Mayhem</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a
