06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Interested in Learning React? These Will Help","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175869","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/interested-in-learning-react-these-will-help/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Interested in Learning React? These Will Help\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587004995learning.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587004995learning-300x225.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587004995learning-768x576.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587004995learning-1024x768.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p>React is a really popular JavaScript framework. Like, <em>really</em> popular.</p> \n<p>So?</p> \n<p>Well, if you’re a front-end developer (or soon to be 😉), React is a great way to save time in wrangling code to make amazing, responsive user interfaces. </p> \n<p>Think single-page applications (SPAs) with changing states, reusable components, and mobile apps – even across both iOS and Android!</p> \n<p>Heck, we even use it!</p> \n<p>So if you haven’t dipped your toe into the world of React, we think it’s time you took a look. Here’s some of our popular content: </p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-design-patterns-and-best-practices-second-edition/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15870028431.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175873\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-design-patterns-and-best-practices-second-edition/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">React Design Patterns and Best Practices – Second Edition</a></h2> \n<p>We will be taking a complete journey through the most valuable design patterns in React, this book demonstrates how to apply design patterns and best practices in real-life situations, whether that’s for new or already existing projects. It will help you to make your applications more flexible, perform better, and easier to maintain.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-material-ui-cookbook/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15870035952.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175889\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-material-ui-cookbook/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">React Material-UI Cookbook</a></h2> \n<p>React Material-UI Cookbook is your ultimate guide to building compelling user interfaces with React and Material Design. Filled with practical and to-the-point recipes, you will learn how to implement sophisticated-UI components. You will also learn how to apply the vast selection of Material-UI components using modern React tools and techniques.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/5-practical-react-projects?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15870035973.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175890\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/5-practical-react-projects?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">5 Practical React Projects</a></h2> \n<p>Progress your React skills by building a Reddit clone with React and Firebase, a CRUD app with React, Redux and FeatherJS, a ToDo app with React, Redux and Immutable.js, a game with Three.js, React and WebGL, and a procedurally generated game terrain with React, PHP and WebSockets.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-and-react-native-second-edition/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15870036004.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175891\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-and-react-native-second-edition/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">React and React Native – Second Edition</a></h2> \n<p>Learn how to use React and Reactive Native to build mobile, desktop and native applications with React and React Native. From composable and Native UIs through to device-specific APIs and offline development, this book has everything you need to create engaging and user-friendly React applications which run on all major platforms.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-tools-resources?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15870036015.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175892\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-tools-resources?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">React: Tools &amp; Resources</a></h2> \n<p>Enhance your React projects and workflow with a range of tools and resources such as Redux, React Router, Jest, animated components and Preact.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/mastering-react-test-driven-development/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15870036066.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175893\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/mastering-react-test-driven-development/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">Mastering React Test-Driven Development</a></h2> \n<p>This book is a comprehensive walkthrough of Test-Driven Development (TDD) for React. It takes a first-principles approach to teach the TDD process using vanilla Jest. Readers build their own test library as they refactor out repeated code in tandem with building a real-world application. It also covers acceptance testing using Cucumber and Puppeteer.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/build-your-own-react-universal-blog-app/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15870036077.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175894\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/build-your-own-react-universal-blog-app/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">Build Your Own React Universal Blog App</a></h2> \n<p>An introductory course to building your first universal React app. Starting with an introduction to React, and then getting familiar with the invaluable React toolkit – Create React App, we’ll then walk you through the steps of creating a universal React blog app from scratch.</p> \n<p>Want to use React in mobile development? Check out React Native!</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-native-blueprints/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/15870036109.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175895\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-native-blueprints/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">React Native Blueprints</a></h2> \n<p>Develop real-world Android and iOS apps with React Native, building fun projects from scratch while discovering more efficient techniques. Learn to build professional Android and iOS apps with your JS skills. Use Isomorphic principles to build mobile apps that offer a native user experience.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/mastering-react-native/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158700361010.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175896\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/mastering-react-native/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">Mastering React Native</a></h2> \n<p>Get up to speed with all the React Native building blocks necessary for creating expert, cutting-edge apps. Learn how to apply Flexbox, build rich animations, integrate third-party libraries, develop customized components, combine React Native with Redux, Redux middleware, a remote API, and more.</p> \n<p>Not quite React, but some nice complimentary content:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/learning-redux/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158700361211.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"188\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175897\" /></a></p> \n<h2><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/learning-redux/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">Learning Redux</a></h2> \n<p>With Redux, build consistent web apps that run in different environments (client, server and native), and are easy to test, by centralizing the state of your app. Take your web apps to the next level by combining the power of Redux with other frameworks such as React and Angular.</p> \n<p>Want to see more React content? <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/search?q=react&amp;firstSearch=true\">Visit our library</a>!</p> \n<h3>Want access to our <em>entire</em> library of 400+ books and courses for just $3/month?</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/products/Z2lkOi8vbGVhcm5hYmxlL1Byb2R1Y3QvMzcz?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">Join SitePoint Premium</a> today and get access to all these books, PLUS over 400 other books and courses for just $3/month for your first three months! ($9/month thereafter, cancel anytime).</p> \n<h3>Looking for a Remote Job?</h3> \n<p>Search hundreds of remote jobs on <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/jobs/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_campaign=react-books\">SitePoint Remote</a>, with over 20 new jobs posted each day!</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/interested-in-learning-react-these-will-help/?utm_source=rss\">Interested in Learning React? These Will Help</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=2YSnXVIMcus:VsZKW0mJULc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=2YSnXVIMcus:VsZKW0mJULc:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a ttps://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=2YSnXVIMcus:VsZKW0mJULc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn47@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-38-928_5225d53cb838c257.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/2YSnXVIMcus":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn79@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-45-539_d873c4c8d33b89d9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483277},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"100 Jamstack Tools, APIs &#038; Services to Power Your Sites","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176713","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/jamstack-tools-services-apis/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"100 Jamstack Tools, APIs &amp; Services to Power Your Sites\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595510644jamstack-apis.png\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595510644jamstack-apis-300x158.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595510644jamstack-apis-768x404.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595510644jamstack-apis.png 794w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>We’ve <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/learn-jamstack/\">explained the Jamstack</a>, a popular new way to build secure, scalable, high-performance sites. Now we’ll introduce you to the tools, services, and APIs that power Jamstack sites.</strong></p> \n<p>The <em>A</em> in Jamstack stands for <em>API</em>. APIs can do <em>anything</em> for you, from sending a form to authenticating a user, or from storing and retrieving data in real time to shopping for products.</p> \n<p>In this article, we’ll do an extensive review of existing APIs and how they compare to one another. This review couldn’t possibly encompass the whole spectrum of third-party APIs that you can integrate into your website, but hopefully you’ll still find the coverage enlightening enough.</p> \n<p><em>We’ll use the words “headless”, “detached”, and “serverless” a lot in this article. If you haven’t already, check out <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/learn-jamstack/\">our introduction to the Jamstack</a>, which covers all the basics.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"hostingmostlyforfree\">Hosting (Mostly for Free)</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://jamstack.org/\"><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595294384Jamstack_Logo_Original.png\" /></a></p> \n<p><small><em>Provided: Netlify</em></small></p> \n<p>Hosting a Jamstack site usually involves automated deployment pipelines. For example, you might have a repository in GitHub which, on every push, automatically triggers an online deployment (via <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webhook\">webhooks</a>), running the necessary <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_build_automation_software\">build tools</a> (such as Jekyll) and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regression_testing\">regression tests</a> (via Travis CI).</p> \n<p>Sound difficult? It can be a surprisingly simple process!</p> \n<p>Most of the services here include these goodies out of the box:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>SSD drives</li> \n <li>CDN deployments</li> \n <li>free SSL (including for custom domains)</li> \n <li>command line deployments and rollbacks</li> \n</ul> \n<p><em>Note: look out for another article in this series, coming soon, covering how to use these services.</em></p> \n<h3 id=\"services\">Services</h3> \n<h4 id=\"googlefirebaseandawsamplify\">Google Firebase and AWS Amplify</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/hosting\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Firebase_Logo.svg/200px-Firebase_Logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>\n <!-- ![The Firebase logo](firebase-logo.png)\n\n<small><a href=https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Firebase_Logo.svg/200px-Firebase_Logo.svg.png\">Image source</a> --></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/hosting\">Firebase Hosting</a></strong> is Google’s take on a hosting service that’s easy to understand and implement, and it’s free to use (<a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/pricing\">limits apply</a>). Firebase’s backbone actually lies on top of the <a href=\"https://cloud.google.com/\">Google Cloud Platform</a> (GCP), and you can in fact access and tweak some Firebase deployments through the GCP console. But by implementing something of an “gateway” (Firebase) that transparently handles GCP resources for us, Google gave developers a brand new and highly improved user experience (UX) … and the <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/Firebase\">Firebase’s YouTube channel</a> is just brilliant! 👏</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/amplify/\"><img src=\"https://docs.amplify.aws/assets/logo-dark.svg\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/amplify/\">AWS Amplify</a> is also an effort to reduce the complexities of <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/\">Amazon Web Services</a> (AWS) for web and mobile deployment that doesn’t quite offer free hosting but 12 months of free use for new accounts for its <strong><a href=\"https://docs.amplify.aws/lib/storage/getting-started/q/platform/js\">Storage with Amplify</a></strong> as part of the <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/free/\">AWS Free Tier</a>.</p> \n<p>Google really made a brilliant move with the Firebase family of products by “detaching” them from the GCP, but Amazon went half-way with AWS Amplify. It sure is a dramatic improvement from the regular AWS workflow, especially for novice users, and its <a href=\"https://docs.amplify.aws/\">documentation hub</a> is superb and way more down-to-earth than the way Amazon usually documents services. But Amplify is still accessed from the same old <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/console/\">(horrifically bloated) console</a>. You still need a credit card to just open an account, deployments are still region-specific (no built-in CDN, seriously?), and the workflow isn’t as straightforward when compared to that of Firebase or Netlify.</p> \n<h4 id=\"githubpagesandgitlabpages\">GitHub Pages and GitLab Pages</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://pages.github.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Octicons-logo-github.svg/200px-Octicons-logo-github.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Both hosting services for Git repositories also have a built-in service to host static pages right out of your codebases, 100% free: <a href=\"https://pages.github.com/\">GitHub Pages</a> and <a href=\"https://about.gitlab.com/stages-devops-lifecycle/pages/\">GitLab Pages</a>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://about.gitlab.com/stages-devops-lifecycle/pages/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/GitLab_logo.svg/200px-GitLab_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>In a future article we’ll cover how to use these services, but in the meantime make sure to check out these easy-to-follow guides:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://guides.github.com/features/pages/\">Getting Started with GitHub Pages</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://about.gitlab.com/blog/2016/04/07/gitlab-pages-setup/\">Hosting on GitLab.com with GitLab Pages</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h4 id=\"netlifyandheroku\">Netlify and Heroku</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Netlify_logo.svg/200px-Netlify_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>In a very short period of time, <strong><a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/\">Netlify</a></strong> not only coined the <em>Jamstack</em> term but also positioned itself as the place to go for all things static. While you could certainly accomplish more with an elaborated AWS pipeline, the simplicity and unparalleled ease of use that Netlify offers is unbeatable. Want to host a static site? Just <a href=\"https://app.netlify.com/drop\">drop it here</a> and it’s online. Want automatic updates? <a href=\"https://docs.netlify.com/configure-builds/get-started/\">Link a repo</a> and just push a commit. And batteries are included — instant builds, worldwide CDN, free SSL, CLI tool, on-click rollbacks, and more.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.heroku.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a9/Heroku_logo.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.heroku.com/\">Heroku</a></strong> is the only service in this list that allows you to host dynamic pages: Node.js, Ruby, Python, Java, PHP, Go, Scala and Clojure (check their <a href=\"https://devcenter.heroku.com/categories/language-support\">Language Support</a> page). So if you aren’t yet quite ready to go static, this might be a good way to test your dynamic sites online for free.</p> \n<h4 id=\"othersservices\">Other Services</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://workers.cloudflare.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/37/Cloudflare-logo-vector.svg/200px-Cloudflare-logo-vector.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>With 194 data centers as of 2020, <a href=\"https://www.cloudflare.com/\">Cloudflare</a> is — <a href=\"https://www.dnsperf.com/dns-providers-list/\">by many metrics</a> — the company that offers the lowest latency for their DNS and CDN services around the world. They serve big companies but also have a number of services oriented to developers, like <strong><a href=\"https://workers.cloudflare.com/sites\">Workers Sites</a></strong>. The service isn’t free ($5/mo minimum charge) but it’s as top performant as you can get, and fairly easy to use.</p> \n<p>Other tools targeted at static pages include <strong><a href=\"https://www.aerobatic.com/\">Aerobatic</a></strong>, which offers a free trial with no credit card required and support for internationalization (i18n) and full-text search <a href=\"https://www.aerobatic.com/docs/plugins/\">built-in plugins</a>; <strong><a href=\"https://surge.sh/\">Surge.sh</a></strong> with <a href=\"https://surge.sh/help/getting-started-with-surge\">npm run scripts</a> and <a href=\"https://surge.sh/help/integrating-with-travis-ci\">CI services</a>; and <strong><a href=\"https://vercel.com/\">Vercel</a></strong> (formerly ZEIT Now) with an <a href=\"https://vercel.com/edge-network\">Edge Network</a> serving big names such as Twilio and The Washington Post.</p> \n<h3 id=\"comparison\">Comparison</h3> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th>Service</th> \n   <th style=\"text-align:center;\">Free plan</th> \n   <th style=\"text-align:center;\">Easy-of-use</th> \n   <th style=\"text-align:center;\">Tooling</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://www.aerobatic.com/\">Aerobatic</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">1 month</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/hosting\">Firebase Hosting</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">yes</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">very good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://pages.github.com/\">GitHub Pages</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">completely free</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">poor</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://about.gitlab.com/stages-devops-lifecycle/pages/\">GitLab Pages</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">completely free</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://www.heroku.com/\">Heroku</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">yes</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">somewhat easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">very good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/\">Netlify</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">yes</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">extremely easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">very good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://docs.amplify.aws/lib/storage/getting-started/q/platform/js\">Storage with Amplify</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">1-year (new accounts)</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">somewhat easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">very good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://surge.sh/\">Surge.sh</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">yes</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://vercel.com/\">Vercel</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">yes</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://workers.cloudflare.com/sites\">Workers Sites</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">no</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">somewhat easy</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">good</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<h2 id=\"storingandretrievingdatarealtimenosqldatabases\">Storing and Retrieving Data: Real-time NoSQL Databases</h2> \n<p>NoSQL solutions like MongoDB have been coexisting with relational databases like MySQL for some time (see <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/sql-vs-nosql-differences/\">the differences</a> and <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/sql-vs-nosql-choose/\">how to choose</a>), but <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_database\">real-time</a> processing takes NoSQL to the next level by enabling cloud storage for state management, such as a user entering their name or clicking a radio button.</p> \n<p>If you’re familiar with <a href=\"https://redux.js.org/\">Redux</a> and <a href=\"https://vuex.vuejs.org/\">Vuex</a> — React and Vue.js libraries for state management, respectively — think of integrating <em>that</em> concept with a cloud storage provider.</p> \n<h3 id=\"services-1\">Services</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/dynamodb/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fd/DynamoDB.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/dynamodb/\">Amazon DynamoDB</a></strong> is a <em>“fully managed, multiregion, multimaster, durable database with built-in security, backup and restore, and in-memory caching for internet-scale applications”</em>. But as with many things AWS, it’s difficult to implement and <em>very hard</em> to debug (see <a href=\"https://read.acloud.guru/why-amazon-dynamodb-isnt-for-everyone-and-how-to-decide-when-it-s-for-you-aefc52ea9476\">Why Amazon DynamoDB isn’t for everyone</a>, by Forrest Brazeal). In all fairness to Amazon, they also built <strong><a href=\"https://docs.amplify.aws/lib/datastore/getting-started/q/platform/js\">DataStore</a></strong> into AWS Amplify (with <a href=\"https://graphql.org/\">GraphQL</a> and REST API support) with a more straightforward approach, in line with the simplicity of the rest of Amplify’s products.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/firestore\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Cloud-Firestore-Logo.svg/200px-Cloud-Firestore-Logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/firestore\">Google Firestore</a></strong> made real-time NoSQL databases — a fairly complex topic in and of itself — as simple as they can be, with pretty much all the capabilities DynamoDB has. It’s <a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/docs/firestore\">very well documented</a> (with <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLl-K7zZEsYLluG5MCVEzXAQ7ACZBCuZgZ\">introductory clips</a> that are fun to watch). And React and Vue.js have wrappers around Firestore with <a href=\"http://react-redux-firebase.com/\">react-redux-firebase</a> and <a href=\"https://vuefire.vuejs.org/vuexfire/\">Vuexfire</a>, respectively.</p> \n<p>Cloudflare sure knows how to take performance to the very extreme, and <strong><a href=\"https://www.cloudflare.com/products/workers-kv/\">Workers KV</a></strong>, a serverless key-value storage for applications, is a fine example of what a well engineered product looks like. The premise of Workers KV is that you can access a <em>key</em> as if it were a local file within your app, and the content will be the <em>value</em> stored for that key. That’s it — no API to implement, no extra coding. And because of the unbeatable performance of the Cloudflare CDN, this approach can actually be <em>faster</em> than querying a NoSQL database. And as simple as it is, it scales seamlessly to millions of requests. 👏</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://fauna.com/\"><img src=\"https://fauna.com/assets/img/Fauna-logo-white.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>And finally, there’s <strong><a href=\"https://fauna.com/\">FaunaDB</a></strong>, a startup that crafted a solution with native GraphQL and a <a href=\"https://fauna.com/pricing\">simple pricing</a> (including a free plan) that can be implemented in minutes.</p> \n<h2 id=\"managingcontentheadlesscms\">Managing Content: Headless CMS</h2> \n<p>In the “monolithic” way of doing things, whenever we used a given <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_management_system\">content management system</a> — such as WordPress, Django, or Joomla! — it meant that we <em>also</em> needed to use the front-end engine that came attached to it, as back and front end were “coupled” components of a single piece of software (see <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/learn-jamstack/\">our introduction to the Jamstack</a> for more info about <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupling_(computer_programming)\">tightly vs loosely coupled</a> sites).</p> \n<p>Enter the headless CMS — a back end only without a front end. Since a headless CMS would normally expose an API or generate static content in the way of Markdown or HTML files, the front end can be <em>anywhere</em> really. In fact, multiple and simultaneous interfaces can be created for web sites, mobile apps, and Internet of Things (IoT) apps.</p> \n<p>\n <center></center></p> \n<p><script type=\"text/javascript\" src=\"https://ssl.gstatic.com/trends_nrtr/2213_RC01/embed_loader.js\"></script><br /> <script type=\"text/javascript\"> trends.embed.renderExploreWidget(\"TIMESERIES\", {\"comparisonItem\":[{\"keyword\":\"headless cms\",\"geo\":\"\",\"time\":\"today 5-y\"}],\"category\":0,\"property\":\"\"}, {\"exploreQuery\":\"date=today%205-y&amp;q=headless%20cms\",\"guestPath\":\"https://trends.google.com:443/trends/embed/\"}); </script></p> \n<h3 id=\"productsandservices\">Products and Services</h3> \n<p>There are a number of headless CMSs, both as software you can download and configure where you do the deployments yourself, or offered in the software-as-a-service (SaaS) model where everything is taken care of for you.</p> \n<p>Some features you can expect to find:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalization_and_localization\">localization (l10n) and internationalization (i18n)</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microservices\">microservices</a> architecture with a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_state_transfer\">RESTful API</a></li> \n <li>editor interface</li> \n <li>customization</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Versioning_file_system\">versioning</a>*</li> \n</ul> \n<p>* <em>Since some headless CMS will integrate smoothly with your git repo, the versioning capability can actually be a remarkable improvement over a regular CMS.</em></p> \n<h4 id=\"selfhostedheadlesscms\">Self-hosted Headless CMS</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://ghost.org/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Ghost-Logo.svg/200px-Ghost-Logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://ghost.org/\">Ghost</a></strong>, <em>“the #1 open source headless Node.js CMS”</em>, is certainly the one with <a href=\"https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost\">the most stars on GitHub</a>. Not only can Ghost handle content, but it also offers a number of integrations to manage payments (Stripe), email lists (MailChimp), shopping (Shopify), and many more. And then there’s <strong><a href=\"https://ghost.org/pricing/\">Ghost(Pro)</a></strong>, which is the official managed hosting for Ghost with commercial support.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://strapi.io/\"><img src=\"https://strapi.io/assets/strapi-logo-light.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Fairly close to Ghost in popularity comes <strong><a href=\"https://strapi.io/\">Strapi</a></strong>, with REST and GraphQL APIs, and 1-click deployments on Heroku, AWS, and DigitalOcean. It has “starters” (template projects) to work seamlessly with Gatsby, Vue.js with Nuxt.js, React with Next.js, and Angular. It also runs on Node.js and has support for <a href=\"https://strapi.io/documentation/v3.x/guides/databases.html\">a number of database engines</a>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.netlifycms.org/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Netlify_CMS_logo.svg/200px-Netlify_CMS_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.netlifycms.org/\">Netlify CMS</a></strong> is also a popular option built as a single–page React app. There’s <strong><a href=\"https://directus.io/\">Directus</a></strong>, which wraps custom SQL databases with an API and provides an intuitive admin app to manage its content, and the commercial companion <strong><a href=\"https://directus.io/services.html\">Directus Cloud</a></strong>. There’s also <strong><a href=\"https://tinacms.org/\">TinaCMS</a></strong>, which is also React-based, and <strong><a href=\"https://docs.ponzu-cms.org/\">Ponzu</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://getcockpit.com/\">Copckpit</a></strong>, and many more, which you can explore oin the comprehensive list provided by <a href=\"https://headlesscms.org/\">headlesscms.org</a>.</p> \n<h4 id=\"saasheadlesscms\">SaaS Headless CMS</h4> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://cloudcannon.com/\">CloudCannon</a></strong> is <em>the cloud CMS for Jekyll</em> (we’ll review Jekyll later in the “static site generators” section), with smooth integration with GitHub, Bitbucket and Dropbox. They have a <a href=\"https://cloudcannon.com/pricing/\">free plan</a> as well but with no global CDN hosting.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.contentful.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Contentful.png/200px-Contentful.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.contentful.com/\">Contentful</a></strong> is something different: a content hub where business owners, marketers, developers and project managers can all go to set and manage all of the data sources of an organization. And <a href=\"https://www.contentful.com/resources/the-ultimate-guide-to-headless-cms/\">their headless CMS</a> is just <em>a part</em> of that strategy. The Contentful platform is <a href=\"https://www.contentful.com/features/\">fully featured</a>, <a href=\"https://www.contentful.com/resources/\">very well documented</a>, with <a href=\"https://github.com/contentful\">plenty of open-source tools</a>. And while the pricing is a bit confusing, there’s actually a free plan that only requires <a href=\"https://www.contentful.com/r/knowledgebase/how-attribution-works/\">attribution</a>.</p> \n<p>There are other SaaS headless CMSs with free plans, such as <strong><a href=\"https://www.datocms.com/\">DatoCMS</a></strong> and <strong><a href=\"https://www.sanity.io/\">Sanity</a></strong> with a proposition similar to that of Contentful; <strong><a href=\"https://forestry.io/\">Forestry</a></strong>, with support for a number of static generators; <strong><a href=\"https://graphcms.com/\">GraphCMS</a></strong>, with GraphQL support; and <strong><a href=\"https://prismic.io/\">Prismic</a></strong>. These are just a few of the many options.</p> \n<h2 id=\"sendinginformationformswithoutcode\">Sending Information: Forms without Code</h2> \n<p>Sending data through forms has forever been one of the main uses for server-side processing. There are essentially two approaches to addressing this problem on a static site, each with pros and cons.</p> \n<h3 id=\"frombuildersembeddedandhostedforms\">From Builders, Embedded and Hosted Forms</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.google.com/forms/about/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Google_Forms_logo.svg/100px-Google_Forms_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Many times integrating a “powered by” external form is more than enough to collect email addresses or to receive feedback.</p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.google.com/forms/about/\">Google Forms</a></strong> have offered this possibility since 2008 entirely for free, with a simple interface that stores submissions on <a href=\"https://www.google.com/sheets/about/\">Google Sheets</a>, and that can send alerts via email every time there’s a submission.</p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.formstack.com/\">Formstack</a></strong> takes forms to another level by providing an integrated workflow supporting digital signatures, document generation, Salesforce integration, and more. They offer a <a href=\"https://www.formstack.com/pricing\">free tryout but no free plans</a>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.typeform.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Typeform_Logo.svg/200px-Typeform_Logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Then you have the extremely easy-to-use form builders <strong><a href=\"https://www.jotform.com/\">JotForm</a></strong> and <strong><a href=\"https://www.wufoo.com/\">Wufoo</a></strong>, which integrate handling payments, among other things, or <strong><a href=\"https://www.typeform.com/\">Typeform</a></strong>, which makes forms and surveys … pretty? All of them offer free plans.</p> \n<h3 id=\"externalapiformprocessingasaservicefpaas\">External API: Form Processing as a Service (FPaaS)</h3> \n<p>Sometimes a builder won’t cut it, as you need more flexibility to present information and fields, or to fully integrate the look and feel of the form with the rest of your website. For this you will need to integrate an API.</p> \n<p>The way these services work is surprisingly easy: you specify a URL for submission that will do the processing for you. At most you’ll have to set a few things up but most probably won’t need to do any extra coding.</p> \n<p>There are a number of providers offering free plans, such as <strong><a href=\"https://www.form.io/\">Form.IO</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://formcarry.com/\">Formcarry</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://formspark.io/\">Formspark</a></strong>, and <strong><a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/products/forms/\">Netlify Forms</a></strong>. They all work in a similar way and are very easy to implement.</p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://formden.com/\">FormDen</a></strong> and <strong><a href=\"https://formkeep.com/\">FormKeep</a></strong> are <em>also</em> form builders that can otherwise be used just as back ends, though none of them offer free plans.</p> \n<h2 id=\"programmingserversidelogicfunctionasaservicefaas\">Programming Server-Side Logic: Function as a Service (FaaS)</h2> \n<p>Couldn’t find an API that does quite what you want? Create it! You don’t need to resort back to a hosted back-end system to process server-side logic, with all the hassle that comes with it (maintenance, bills, credentials, security patches). Instead, you can implement a micro-service in your language of choice (oftentimes JavaScript, Python, or Go), encapsulate that logic into functions, and offer them through a RESTful API.</p> \n<p>As with pretty much everything else in this list, you won’t be paying anything for a function that’s not being actively used, so no worries for just leaving it sitting there (but beware that spikes in traffic might also trigger extra billing).</p> \n<h3 id=\"providers\">Providers</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/\"><img src=\"https://d1.awsstatic.com/Digital%20Marketing/House/PAC/2up/PAC-Q4_House-Ads_Lambda_2up.62dc7e19b7b2e0a2c06821594c31f1ce00a6bdda.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>While the implementation details for <strong><a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/\">AWS Lambda</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/services/functions/\">Azure Functions</a></strong> and <strong><a href=\"https://cloud.google.com/functions\">Google Cloud Functions</a></strong> may differ, they all work in pretty much the same fashion and you’ll need a degree of familiarity with AWS, Azure or GCP. AWS Lambda has the richest language support of them all (and also <strong><a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/api-gateway/\">Amazon API Gateway</a></strong> to help you wrap your functions into a maintainable API with monitoring tools), while Azure — not surprisingly — has the best support for .NET Framework and .NET Core (with <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-functions/functions-versions\">different versions supporting different runtimes</a> and even <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-functions/functions-reference-node#typescript\">TypeScript transpiled to JavaScript</a>). But be aware that Azure systematically ranks as the slowest service by a margin.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/functions/\"><img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/gIevXsBMIsudknUwbVPdYrCrf7IovDjEfoJlUCLA0h6haxNkyDOxH-cTRYm-ifnSVpr3RL72XmKcIvZy7Alo=w80-h80\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/functions\">Cloud Functions for Firebase</a></strong> and <strong><a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/products/functions/\">Netlify Functions</a></strong> are wrappers around Google Cloud Functions and AWS Lambda, respectively. They greatly simplify the management of functions on the cloud, as you effectively can get away without even having an account on such services. Code deployment and versioning become trivial with Netlify — which also has very good <a href=\"https://community.netlify.com/\">community support</a> — as it will smoothly integrate with your repo offering stage, previewing, and rolling back at a click (or a commit). Simplicity naturally comes at the expense of losing some flexibility (see <a href=\"https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/firebase-cloud-functions-the-great-the-meh-and-the-ugly-c4562c6dc65d/\">Firebase Cloud Functions: the great, the meh, and the ugly</a> by Pier Bover).</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://cloud.ibm.com/functions/\"><img src=\"https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/31867515?s=200&amp;v=4\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://cloud.ibm.com/functions/\">IBM Cloud Functions</a></strong> (based on <a href=\"https://openwhisk.apache.org/\">Apache OpenWhisk</a>) and <strong><a href=\"https://workers.cloudflare.com/\">Cloudflare Workers</a></strong> are other services you might want to look at. IBM has an impressive list of supported languages, including the option to deploy Docker containers with your own runtime. However, it ranked somewhat poorly performance wise. And just as Netlify systematically manages to make things the simplest, Cloudflare again makes things the fastest (and <a href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20200511043849/https://serverless-benchmark.com/\">by a difference</a>).</p> \n<h3 id=\"comparison-1\">Comparison</h3> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th>service</th> \n   <th>languages</th> \n   <th style=\"text-align:right;\">overhead*</th> \n   <th style=\"text-align:right;\">coldstart*</th> \n   <th>difficulty</th> \n   <th>support</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/\">AWS Lambda</a></td> \n   <td><a href=\"https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-runtimes.html\">C#, Go, Java, JavaScript, PowerShell, Python, Ruby</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">86 ms 🟢</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">589 ms</td> \n   <td>high</td> \n   <td>👍 very good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/services/functions/\">Azure Functions</a></td> \n   <td><a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-functions/supported-languages\">C#, F#, Java, JavaScript and TypeScript, PowerShell, Python</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">760 ms 🔴</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">5,907 ms 🔴</td> \n   <td>high</td> \n   <td>👎 very poor</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/functions\">Cloud Functions for Firebase</a></td> \n   <td>JavaScript and <a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/docs/functions/typescript\">TypeScript</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">642 ms 🔴</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">168 ms</td> \n   <td>low</td> \n   <td>👍 very good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://workers.cloudflare.com/\">Cloudflare Workers</a></td> \n   <td><a href=\"https://blog.cloudflare.com/introducing-cloudflare-workers/\">JavaScript</a>, <a href=\"https://blog.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-workers-now-support-cobol/\">COBOL</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">70 ms 🟢</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">76 ms 🟢</td> \n   <td>intermediate</td> \n   <td><a href=\"https://community.cloudflare.com/tags/workers\">intermediate</a></td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://cloud.google.com/functions\">Google Cloud Functions</a></td> \n   <td><a href=\"https://cloud.google.com/functions/docs/writing\">Go, Java, Node.js, Python</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">642 ms 🔴</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">168 ms</td> \n   <td>high</td> \n   <td>👍 very good</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://cloud.ibm.com/functions/\">IBM Cloud Functions</a></td> \n   <td>.C#, Go, Java, JavaScript, PHP, Python, Ruby, Swift, and Docker containers</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">136 ms</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">2,103 ms 🔴</td> \n   <td>high</td> \n   <td>no info</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/products/functions/\">Netlify Functions</a></td> \n   <td><a href=\"https://docs.netlify.com/functions/build-with-go\">Go</a>, <a href=\"https://docs.netlify.com/functions/build-with-javascript\">Node.js</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">86 ms 🟢</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">589 ms</td> \n   <td>very low</td> \n   <td>👍 very good</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p>* <em>As measured by <a href=\"https://serverless-benchmark.com/\">λ Serverless Benchmark</a>, the <strong>overhead</strong> is the time from request to response without the time the function took (for a concurrency of 50), and the <strong>coldstart</strong> is how long the servers takes to respond when queried are spanned every 3 hours; the lower the values, the better.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"authenticatingusersidentityasaservice\">Authenticating Users: Identity as a Service</h2> \n<p>Identity as a Service (IDaaS), also called sometimes <em>Authentication as a Service</em> (AaaS), involves managing a full user registration, confirmation, and authentication with just APIs. The <em>Geist</em> of “stateless authentication” is that a user will authenticate against a third-party and come back to you with a valid “token” that you can verify, or revoke if need be.</p> \n<p>In some cases, a provider might even offer a “drop-in” user interface (UI) that will work seamlessly across desktop and mobile, all of which could potentially save you <em>very</em> long hours of work.</p> \n<h3 id=\"services-2\">Services</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://auth0.com/\"><img src=\"https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/2824157?s=200&amp;v=4\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://auth0.com/\">Auth0</a></strong> has been in business the longest and has <a href=\"https://auth0.com/docs/quickstarts/\">quickstart guides</a> for a number of scenarios. It’s an excellent provider if you want to implement a complex solution and already have some experience implementing authentication. But as they point out, <em>“identity is complex, deal with it”</em>. The large scope Auth0 services (universal login, single sign on (SSO), multifactor authentication, branch password detection, and so on) can be overwhelming if you’re just starting on the topic.</p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://firebase.google.com/products/auth\">Firebase Authentication</a></strong> (with its <a href=\"https://opensource.google/projects/firebaseui\">ready-to-use UI</a>) and <strong><a href=\"https://docs.amplify.aws/lib/auth/getting-started/q/platform/js\">Authentication with Amplify</a></strong> are also very comprehensive and flexible, and somewhat presented in a more straightforward manner than Auth0. Firebase also offers <em>anonymous</em> authentication! Curious? Check out this clip:</p> \n<p>\n <center>\n  <iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ApG8L2RKrSI\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe>\n </center></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://docs.netlify.com/visitor-access/identity/\"><img src=\"https://www.netlify.com/img/press/logos/logomark.png\" width=\"100\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Once again, Netlify seems to come up with the easiest solution to implement with <strong><a href=\"https://docs.netlify.com/visitor-access/identity/\">Netlify Identity</a></strong> and its open-source zero config <a href=\"https://github.com/netlify/netlify-identity-widget\">netlify-identity-widget</a> to <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nd9SpZwhTEA\">create a secure login in 10 minutes</a>! But of course, there are some limitations (check out <a href=\"https://jeancochrane.com/blog/netlify-identity-dealbreakers\">Four Dealbreakers in Netlify Identity</a>, by Jean Cochrane).</p> \n<p>You can also check <strong><a href=\"https://www.okta.com/\">Okta</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://fusionauth.io/\">FusionAuth</a></strong> and <strong><a href=\"https://www.loginradius.com/\">LoginRadius</a></strong>, all of which have free plans. There are no freebies for <a href=\"https://www.pingidentity.com/\">Ping Identity</a>, <a href=\"https://www.onelogin.com/\">OneLogin</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.ubisecure.com/\">Ubisecure</a>, which are more oriented to the enterprise sector. Finally, consider <a href=\"https://teams.cloudflare.com/access/\">Cloudflare Access</a>, as everything Cloudflare does is rock solid.</p> \n<h2 id=\"goingfaststaticsitegeneratorssg\">Going F·A·S·T: Static Site Generators (SSG)</h2> \n<p>I can hear some of you saying <em>“all of this might be okay for future projects, but my sites are already dynamic, so what to do?”</em> Here’s when static site generators enter the picture.</p> \n<p>You can have the best of both worlds — the convenience of a familiar CMS <em>and</em> static pages with <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/guides/code-splitting/\">code and data splitting</a>, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preload_(engineering)\">preloading</a>, caching, image optimization, and all sorts of performance enhancements. An SSR will bridge that gap by querying your database and generating static output out of it (for example, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown\">Markdown</a> pages), and with some settings to set your template, you’ll be all set.</p> \n<p>The listing here is <em>tiny</em> compared to the ever increasing list of SSRs. Have a look at <a href=\"https://www.staticgen.com/\">StaticGen</a> for more info.</p> \n<h3 id=\"mainproducts\">Main Products</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.org/\"><img src=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.org/Gatsby-Logo.svg\" width=\"200\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.org/\">GatsbyJS</a></strong> is powered by React.js and webpack, meaning that it can generate progressive web apps (aka PWAs, websites that look and feel like an apps). It also supports GraphQL (see <a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.com/how-it-works/write-modern-apps/\">Write Apps with Better Building Blocks</a>) and it has <a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.com/how-it-works/data-from-anywhere/\">+1,000 plugins to get data from anywhere</a> (WordPress, Drupal, Contentful, GraphCMS, DatoCMS, and many more). See <a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.org/features/jamstack/gatsby-vs-jekyll-vs-hugo/\">how GatsbyJS says it compares to its main competitors, Hugo and Jekyll</a>.</p> \n<p>All of this flexibility comes at a cost, as setting and customizing GatsbyJS can be a time-consuming process, and if you don’t have a decent understanding of React — and therefore JavaScript — you won’t be able to make much of it. That’s where <strong><a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.com/\">Gatsby Cloud</a></strong> comes in, offering support to build and maintain Gatsby sites <a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.com/pricing/\">for free or for a fee</a>, where you could automate your fast builds, access to previews, generate daily edits, and fire deployments with ease to Netlify, Cloudflare, AWS CloudFront or Akamai.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://gohugo.io/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Logo_of_Hugo_the_static_website_generator.svg/200px-Logo_of_Hugo_the_static_website_generator.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://gohugo.io/\">Hugo</a></strong> claims to be <em>“the world’s fastest framework for building websites”</em>, and it sure can generate massive sites in milliseconds. With built-in templates (literally <a href=\"https://themes.gohugo.io/\">hundreds of them available</a>) and native support for internationalization (i18n), it’s also one of the most popular SSGs. Hugo is a <a href=\"https://golang.org/\">Go app</a>, and while Go isn’t hard to set and learn, you’ll definitely need to be checking the documentation often if you aren’t familiar with it.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://jekyllrb.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/42/Jekyll_%28software%29_Logo.png\" width=\"200\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Unlike GatsbyJS, configuring and deploying <strong><a href=\"https://jekyllrb.com/\">Jekyll</a></strong> is a rather straightforward process. Furthermore, Jekyll is the only SSR supported by <a href=\"https://pages.github.com/\">GitHub Pages</a> (Tom Preston-Werner, creator of Jekyll, is also a co-founder of GitHub), and can smoothly deploy static sites for free right out of your GitHub repos! Jekyll uses Shopify’s <a href=\"https://shopify.github.io/liquid/\">Liquid template language</a>, which is also easy to learn. The downsides? As a <a href=\"https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/\">Ruby app</a>, Jekyll can be hard to set on a Windows environment, and optimizations such as minimizing JavaScript code and image preloading aren’t included by default. In fact, Jekyll doesn’t even aim at generating a PWA but just purely static sites — which might still be fine depending on what you need.</p> \n<h4 id=\"comparison-2\">Comparison</h4> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th>Product</th> \n   <th style=\"text-align:center;\">Language</th> \n   <th style=\"text-align:center;\">Templating</th> \n   <th style=\"text-align:center;\">Setting</th> \n   <th>GitHub stars</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://www.gatsbyjs.com/\">GatsbyJS</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">JavaScript</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">React.js</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">difficult</td> \n   <td><iframe src=\"https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=gatsbyjs&amp;repo=gatsby&amp;type=star&amp;count=true\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"0\" width=\"150\" height=\"20\" title=\"GitHub\"></iframe></td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://gohugo.io/\">Hugo</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">Go</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">Go (<a href=\"https://themes.gohugo.io/\">library</a>)</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">intermediate</td> \n   <td><iframe src=\"https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=gohugoio&amp;repo=hugo&amp;type=star&amp;count=true\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"0\" width=\"150\" height=\"20\" title=\"GitHub\"></iframe></td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td><a href=\"https://jekyllrb.com/\">Jekyll</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">Ruby</td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\"><a href=\"https://shopify.github.io/liquid/\">Liquid</a></td> \n   <td style=\"text-align:center;\">easy</td> \n   <td><iframe src=\"https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?user=jekyll&amp;repo=jekyll&amp;type=star&amp;count=true\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"0\" width=\"150\" height=\"20\" title=\"GitHub\"></iframe></td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<h3 id=\"others\">Others</h3> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://wp2static.com/\">WP2Static</a></strong> is an SSR designed specifically for WordPress (WP). It has a small but very interesting set of <a href=\"https://wp2static.com/addons/\">plugins</a>, like Algolia search, and Cloudflare Workers and Netlify deployments. <strong><a href=\"https://www.hardypress.com/\">HardyPress</a></strong> is actually a SaaS solution to generate static WP sites, and <a href=\"https://www.hardypress.com/pricing/\">for a fee</a> you’ll have an admin panel from where you can enter some credentials to access your online WP installations to manage everything: shut down live WP installs that were already imported, transparent deployment to global a CDN, HTTPS, forms, search. Other WP-related SSGs with commercial support are <strong><a href=\"https://www.getshifter.io/\">Shifter</a></strong>, <strong><a href=\"https://www.strattic.com/\">Strattic</a></strong>, and <strong><a href=\"https://sitesauce.app/\">Sitesauce</a></strong>.</p> \n<p>Since I am admittedly biased towards <a href=\"https://vuejs.org/\">Vue.js</a>, I had to include <strong><a href=\"https://vuepress.vuejs.org/\">VuePress</a></strong>, which is intended to generate single page applications (SPAs) and has a minimal setup with markdown-centered files, and it’s also powered by <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/\">webpack</a>. <strong><a href=\"https://gridsome.org/\">Gridsome</a></strong> and <strong><a href=\"https://nuxtjs.org/\">Nuxt.js</a></strong> are more featured Vue.js powered frameworks with SSR capabilities.</p> \n<h2 id=\"sellingandprocessingpaymentsheadlessshoppingcarts\">Selling and Processing Payments: Headless Shopping Carts</h2> \n<p>The architecture and benefits of headless ecommerce is not that different from that of a headless CMS: massive cost reduction (hosting, licenses, maintenance), less <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_to_market\">time to market</a>, seamless integration, and — a big one for commerce — “<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omnichannel\">omnichannel</a>” capabilities.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/jamstack-tools-services-apis/?utm_source=rss\">100 Jamstack Tools, APIs &amp; Services to Power Your Sites</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=v1tCq_jJpA8:mIeeV6z6D7A:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=v1tCq_jJpA8:mIeeV6z6D7A:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a busercontent.com/u/31867515?s=200&v=4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn37@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-37-839_111a730ee186e38e.webp","https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/2824157?s=200&v=4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn48@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-37-911_2f2eb0de1c39dd27.webp","https://www.netlify.com/img/press/logos/logomark.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn57@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-44-549_b4538bd62ff18194.webp","https://www.gatsbyjs.org/Gatsby-Logo.svg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-40-864_3a324ea1a2a5a68b.svg","https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Logo_of_Hugo_the_static_website_generator.svg/200px-Logo_of_Hugo_the_static_website_generator.svg.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn10@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-38-547_90b949f7cd050af5.webp","https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/42/Jekyll_%28software%29_Logo.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn56@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-42-898_d7d386b21378e44e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=v1tCq_jJpA8:mIeeV6z6D7A:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn40@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-44-505_461e531911e4e8ca.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/v1tCq_jJpA8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn57@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-36-234_745977f64d871577.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483309},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"The Rise of the No-Code Movement","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175501","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-rise-of-the-no-code-movement/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"The Rise of the No-Code Movement\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584405762Isometric-City-Building-Vector-Illustration.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584405762Isometric-City-Building-Vector-Illustration-300x200.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584405762Isometric-City-Building-Vector-Illustration-768x512.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584405762Isometric-City-Building-Vector-Illustration-1024x682.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p>In the internet age, technological innovation has largely been driven by a community of software engineers, web developers, and hardware hackers. Until recently, acclaimed startup accelerator Y Combinator only accepted founding teams with technical backgrounds. Furthermore, the most valuable companies of today are tech-enabled, so there’s been a focus on tech talent for future-proofing economies. Coding education provider Lambda School has raised close to $50M to close this skills gap and there are <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/library/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">many other courses</a> teaching the next generation to code. </p> \n<p>But what if coding was no longer vital to success in tech? Enter the world of no-code development platforms (NCDPs). </p> \n<p>Over the past couple of years, the rise of the no-code movement has started to change the landscape of tech. Ironically, Lamdba School itself is a product of the no-code movement, building its MVP (that has served 3,000 students) using a combination of tools such as Typeform, Airtable, and Retool. The no-code movement has also been called low code or visual development. The makers of no-code platforms are still discussing the best label for the movement but for now, I will stick with ‘no-code’. </p> \n<p>John Everhard summarizes no-code software <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/johneverhard/2019/01/15/what-really-is-low-codeno-code-development/#26adb5332a8e\">on Forbes</a> as a visual integrated development environment (IDE). “Within this environment, users (aka the citizen developer) drag-and-drop application components, connect them together and create a mobile or web app. Using this software, staff can design and build powerful applications that can scale for any organization—without writing any code.” All in all, users don’t need to understand code to be able to create an app and therein lies its power. </p> \n<h2 id=\"benefitsofnocode\">Benefits of No-Code</h2> \n<p>When we were in the thick of product development for <a href=\"https://www.cloudpeeps.com/\">CloudPeeps</a>, I remember how frustrating it was for our developers (and me!) when I needed to make any updates to our marketing pages or funnels. While I can happily edit HTML, having a custom-built platform meant deploying changes was limited to the devs. Prioritizing feature development alongside bug fixes and tweaks was a challenge. Progress was slow. We tried numerous A/B testing tools and moving some pages to popular CMSs, but the user experience started to suffer. While tools like Webflow existed then, they weren’t touted as mainstream solutions so we lacked the awareness to implement them. </p> \n<p>Since then, the rise of no-code tools has changed the game forever – not only for tasks like marketing pages but also for full-stack apps, which people can now build end-to-end. In 2014, if you wanted to build a marketplace, you had to develop it from scratch. After that, offerings like Sharetribe came along with standard marketplace software in a box with an ongoing price tag. Now, you can build whatever marketplace set-up you like using no-code tools. </p> \n<p>Evidently, saving time and money are two crucial benefits of no-code. Co-founder of Tiny product studio and indie investment fund Andrew Wilkinson recently <a href=\"https://twitter.com/awilkinson/status/1214285271090388994?s=11\">tweeted</a>: “I used to spend $25k-$100k building an app over 3-6 months. It was frustrating, expensive, and slow. Then I started using NoCode tools like Webflow, Bubble, Zapier, and Airtable. Suddenly I was able to build my app idea in days instead of months, at a fraction of the cost. Craziest of all, I could tweak and maintain it myself instead of hiring expensive devs.”. He likens ‘native-code’ to being a bulldozer: great to use when you need to build something sizeable and commercial grade. He compares ‘no-code’ to a pickup truck: powerful enough to help you get most simple and intermediate projects done. </p> \n<h2 id=\"whynow\">Why Now?</h2> \n<p>The tech industry has been increasingly criticized over the past decade for its lack of diversity and inclusion. Silicon Valley has bred a generation of founders who look like each other, talk like each other, and solve similar problems – and as these people gather further wealth through exits and investments, the cycle of sameness repeats. Teaching people to code and funding different founders is creating slow change, but the no-code movement has the potential to exponentially change the face of tech. If you no longer need access to engineers or capital to launch a product, anyone can have a crack at their idea. Perhaps it is the demand for the democratization of tech that has catapulted the no-code movement into the now. </p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-rise-of-the-no-code-movement/?utm_source=rss\">The Rise of the No-Code Movement</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=DXD7lVyKxHU:yOhbdE28NVY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=DXD7lVyKxHU:yOhbdE28NVY:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=DXD7lVyKxHU:yOhbdE28NVY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584405762Isometric-City-Building-Vector-Illustration.jpg","linkMd5":"6373e8ca6c646cf42a69485f7ea2066c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn18@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-24-738_e8c3fb0fd81a66cc.webp","destWidth":2000,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":62842,"destBytes":62842,"author":"Kate Kendall","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584405762Isometric-City-Building-Vector-Illustration.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn18@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-24-738_e8c3fb0fd81a66cc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=DXD7lVyKxHU:yOhbdE28NVY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn31@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-46-730_9db146dc50decd6b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/DXD7lVyKxHU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn94@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-41-405_4a89e1ef5fa74e8c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483290},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Quick Tip: Configuring NGINX and SSL with Node.js","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=90221","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/configuring-nginx-ssl-node-js/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Quick Tip: Configuring NGINX and SSL with Node.js\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/1583359805nginx-ssl.png\" alt=\"Quick Tip: Configuring NGINX and SSL with Node.js\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/1583359805nginx-ssl-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/1583359805nginx-ssl.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.nginx.com/\">NGINX</a> is a high-performance HTTP server as well as a <a href=\"https://medium.com/intrinsic/why-should-i-use-a-reverse-proxy-if-node-js-is-production-ready-5a079408b2ca\">reverse proxy</a>. Unlike traditional servers, NGINX follows an event-driven, asynchronous architecture. As a result, the memory footprint is low and performance is high. If you’re running a Node.js-based web app, you should seriously consider using NGINX as a reverse proxy.</strong></p> \n<p>NGINX can be very efficient in serving static assets. For all other requests, it will talk to your Node.js back end and send the response to the client. In this tutorial, we’ll discuss how to configure NGINX to work with Node.js. We’ll also see how to setup SSL in the NGINX server.</p> \n<p><em>Note: Node also has a built-in HTTPS module and can be configured to read the necessary certificate files without the need for a reverse proxy. You can find out more about this in our article <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-use-ssltls-with-node-js/\">How to Use SSL/TLS with Node.js</a>.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"installingnginx\">Installing NGINX</h2> \n<p>Assuming you already have Node.js installed on your machine (if not, check <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">here</a>), let’s see how to install NGINX.</p> \n<h3 id=\"installationonlinux\">Installation on Linux</h3> \n<p>If you’re running Ubuntu, you can use the following command to install NGINX:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo apt-get update\nsudo apt-get install nginx\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you’re running a Linux distro other than Ubuntu, check out <a href=\"https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/installing-nginx/installing-nginx-open-source/#prebuilt\">the NGINX installation docs</a> for more information.</p> \n<p>NGINX will start automatically once it’s installed.</p> \n<h3 id=\"installationonmacos\">Installation on macOS</h3> \n<p>If you’re on macOS, you can use <a href=\"http://brew.sh/\">Homebrew</a> to install NGINX easily. The steps are as following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p>Homebrew needs the directory <code>/usr/local</code> to be <code>chown</code>’d to your username. So, run the following command in terminal first:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo chown -R 'username here' /usr/local\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>Now the following two commands will install NGINX on your system:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">brew link pcre\nbrew install nginx\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>Once the installation is complete, you can type the following command to start NGINX:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo nginx\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>The NGINX config file can be found here: <code>/usr/local/etc/nginx/nginx.conf</code>.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"installationonwindows\">Installation on Windows</h3> \n<p>For Windows, head over to the NGINX <a href=\"http://nginx.org/en/download.html\">downloads</a> page and get the zip. The next step is unzipping the archive and moving to the directory in the command prompt as follows:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">unzip nginx-1.3.13.zip\ncd nginx-1.3.13\nstart nginx\n</code></pre> \n<p>As you can see, the command <code>start nginx</code> will start NGINX.</p> \n<p>Now that the installation is done, let’s see how you can configure a simple server.</p> \n<h2 id=\"settingupanodejsserver\">Setting Up a Node.js Server</h2> \n<p>First, let’s create a simple Node.js server. We’ll start by initiating a project and installing the <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/express\">Express package</a>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mkdir node-demo &amp;&amp; cd node-demo\nnpm init -y\nnpm i express\n</code></pre> \n<p>Create a file called <code>server.js</code>, with the following contents:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const express = require('express')\nconst app = express()\nconst port = 3000\n\napp.get('/', (req, res) =&gt; res.send('Hello World!'))\n\napp.listen(port, () =&gt; console.log(`Example app listening on port ${port}!`))\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can start the server by running <code>node server.js</code>.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/configuring-nginx-ssl-node-js/?utm_source=rss\">Quick Tip: Configuring NGINX and SSL with Node.js</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=AOxH7xop-hQ:NuQCo3DMr8Y:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=AOxH7xop-hQ:NuQCo3DMr8Y:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img
