+0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/1583359805nginx-ssl.png","linkMd5":"a987f49cff9dee58cbb130aeefa069f1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn45@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-26-850_c7bac35462b383b4.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":9122,"destBytes":9122,"author":"Nilson Jacques","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/1583359805nginx-ssl.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn45@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-26-850_c7bac35462b383b4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=AOxH7xop-hQ:NuQCo3DMr8Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn93@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-39-913_22e88df10fabcbee.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/AOxH7xop-hQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn74@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-37-313_353088ffdf66d8b5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483294},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Deno Guide: A Secure JavaScript &#038; TypeScript Runtime","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176551","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-introduction/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Deno Guide: A Secure JavaScript &amp; TypeScript Runtime\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593954503deno-js-runtime.png\" alt=\"Introducing Deno, a Node-like JS and TypeScript Runtime\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593954503deno-js-runtime-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593954503deno-js-runtime.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>May 2020 saw the release of Deno 1.0, and it’s been a pretty popular topic of conversation. If you’re wondering what the fuss is all about, you’ve come to the right place!</strong></p> \n<p>In this article, I hope to give you an overview of what Deno is. We’ll take a look at its key features, and ask why you might want to start learning this new tool.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatisdeno\">What is Deno?</h2> \n<p>So what is it Deno, and why was it created? Deno is a JavaScript and TypeScript runtime, meaning you can write programs in either language and execute them from the command line. Unlike JavaScript run within a browser, Deno programs can access resources on the host computer, such as the filesystem and environment variables.</p> \n<p>If you’re aware of Node.js, and you’re thinking that Deno sounds pretty similar, you’d be right. Deno is the brainchild of Node’s creator, Ryan Dahl, who created Deno to address what he sees as <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M3BM9TB-8yA\">the design flaws in Node</a>. The aims of the project are to provide a scripting environment that is secure by default, that treats TypeScript as a first-class language, and that is as browser-compatible as possible (where practical).</p> \n<h2 id=\"securityfeatures\">Security Features</h2> \n<p>Deno is designed to be secure out of the box. All code is executed in a secure sandbox by default, which means you need to give explicit permission to allow a program to access the network or the filesystem.</p> \n<p>Programs can be granted permissions with the following command-line flags:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>-A, –allow-all</strong>: allow all permissions (disables all security).</li> \n <li><strong>–allow-env</strong>: allow getting and setting of environment variables.</li> \n <li><strong>–allow-hrtime</strong>: allow high resolution time measurement (can be used in timing attacks and fingerprinting).</li> \n <li><strong>–allow-net=\\\n   <allow -net=\"\"></allow></strong>: allow network access. Optionally takes a comma-separated whitelist of domains.</li> \n <li><strong>–allow-plugin</strong>: allow loading plugins (unstable feature).</li> \n <li><strong>–allow-read=\\\n   <allow -read=\"\"></allow></strong>: allow file system read access. Optionally takes a comma-separated whitelist of directories or files.</li> \n <li><strong>–allow-run</strong>: allow running subprocesses.</li> \n <li><strong>–allow-write=\\\n   <allow -write=\"\"></allow></strong>: allow file system write access. Optionally takes a comma-separated whitelist of directories or files.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"firstclasstypescriptsupport\">First-class TypeScript Support</h2> \n<p>As I mentioned earlier, Deno can execute both JavaScript <em>and</em> TypeScript. What’s more, Deno supports TypeScript as a first-class language. This means it can load and run your TypeScript code without any additional build step. There’s no need to set up additional tooling to transpile your code into JavaScript first.</p> \n<p>Of course, since TypeScript is a superset of modern JavaScript, you can also write your code in good old JS if you want to! Deno supports some great, developer-friendly features such as ES Module imports</p> \n<h2 id=\"usingexternalcode\">Using External Code</h2> \n<p>As Ryan mentioned in his talk, one of his goals for Deno was to avoid the need for a package manager. Unlike with runtimes/languages such as Node.js and PHP (which use the npm and composer package managers respectively), there’s no package manager for Deno.</p> \n<p>Instead, external packages are imported directly via a URL:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">import { Client } from \"https://deno.land/x/mysql@2.2.0/mod.ts\";\n</code></pre> \n<p>The first time you run your script, Deno will fetch, compile, and cache all the imports so that subsequent starts are lightning fast. Obviously there are times when you may want to force Deno to re-fetch the imports, and you can do this with the <code>cache</code> subcommand:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">deno cache --reload my_module.ts\n</code></pre> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-introduction/?utm_source=rss\">Deno Guide: A Secure JavaScript &amp; TypeScript Runtime</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=kbeByFyya2g:x80Ei3mJkZ0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=kbeByFyya2g:x80Ei3mJkZ0:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=kbeByFyya2g:x80Ei3mJkZ0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=kbeByFyya2g:x80Ei3mJkZ0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/kbeByFyya2g\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 05 Jul 2020 08:44:42 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593954503deno-js-runtime.png","linkMd5":"bef69f4146418789a350a738954ac5ff","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn58@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-26-061_42634178d87bb92a.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":13082,"destBytes":13082,"author":"Nilson Jacques","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593954503deno-js-runtime.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn58@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-26-061_42634178d87bb92a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=kbeByFyya2g:x80Ei3mJkZ0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn21@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-35-205_d0f3407813e91d6f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/kbeByFyya2g":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn71@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-46-180_09a7a8b47d50d63d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483260},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"13 Best Practices for Building RESTful APIs","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=177401","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-restful-apis-best-practices/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"13 Best Practices for Building RESTful APIs\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597808919build-restful-api.png\" alt=\"13 Best Practices for Building RESTful APIs\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597808919build-restful-api-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597808919build-restful-api.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Facebook, GitHub, Google, and many other giants need a way to serve and consume data. A RESTful API is still one of the best choices in today’s dev landscape to serve and consume data.</strong></p> \n<p>But have you ever considered learning about industry standards? What are the best practices for designing a RESTful API? In theory, anyone can quickly spin up a data API in less than five minutes — whether it be Node.js, Golang, or Python.</p> \n<p>We’ll explore 13 best practices you should consider when building a RESTful API. But first, let’s clarify a RESTful API quickly.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatisarestfulapi\">What is a RESTful API?</h2> \n<p>A RESTful API needs to meet the following constraints for it to be called a RESTful API.</p> \n<ol> \n <li> <p><strong>Client-server</strong>: A RESTful API follows the client-server model where the server serves data and clients connect to the server to consume data. The interaction between client and server occurs through HTTP(S) requests that transfer the requested data.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Stateless</strong>: More importantly, a RESTful API should be stateless. Each request is treated as a standalone request. The server should not keep track of any internal state that might influence the result of future requests.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Uniform interface</strong>: Lastly, uniformity defines how the client and server interact. RESTful APIs define best practices for naming resources but define fixed HTTP operations that allow you to modify/interact with resources. The following HTTP operations can be accessed in RESTful APIs:</p> \n  <ul> \n   <li>GET request: retrieve a resource</li> \n   <li>POST request: create a resource or send information to the API</li> \n   <li>PUT request: create or replace a resource</li> \n   <li>PATCH request: update an existing resource</li> \n   <li>DELETE request: delete a resource</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ol> \n<p>With this deeper understanding of the characteristics of a RESTful API, it’s time to learn more about RESTful API best practices.</p> \n<h2 id=\"bestpracticesfordesigningyourfirstrestfulapi\">Best Practices For Designing Your First RESTful API</h2> \n<p>This article presents you with an actionable list of 13 best practices. Let’s explore!</p> \n<h3 id=\"1usehttpmethodscorrectly\">1. Use HTTP methods correctly</h3> \n<p>We’ve already discussed the possible HTTP methods you can use to modify resources: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE.</p> \n<p>Still, many developers tend to abuse GET and POST, or PUT and PATCH. Often, we see developers use a POST request to retrieve data. Furthermore, we see developers use a PUT request which replaces the resource while they only wanted to update a single field for that resource.</p> \n<p>Make sure to use the correct HTTP method as this will add a lot of confusion for developers using your RESTful API. It’s better to stick to the intended guidelines.</p> \n<h3 id=\"2namingconventions\">2. Naming conventions</h3> \n<p>Understanding the RESTful API naming conventions will help you a lot with designing your API in an organized manner. Design a RESTful API according to the resources you serve.</p> \n<p>For example, your API manages authors and books (yes, a classic example). Now, we want to add a new author or access an author with ID <code>3</code>. You could design the following routes to serve this purpose:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>api.com/addNewAuthor</li> \n <li>api.com/getAuthorByID/3</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Imagine an API that hosts many resources that each have many properties. The list of possible endpoints will become endless and not very user-friendly. So we need a more organized and standardized way of designing API endpoints.</p> \n<p>RESTful API best practices describe that an endpoint should start with the resource name, while the HTTP operation describes the action. Now we get:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>POST api.com/authors</li> \n <li>GET api.com/authors/3</li> \n</ul> \n<p>What if we want to access all books author with ID <code>3</code> has ever written? Also for this case, RESTful APIs have a solution:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>GET api.com/authors/3/books</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Lastly, what if you want to delete a book with ID <code>5</code> for an author with ID <code>3</code>. Again, let’s follow the same structured approach to form the following endpoint:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>DELETE api.com/authors/3/books/5</li> \n</ul> \n<p>In short, make use of HTTP operations and the structured way of resource mapping to form a readable and understandable endpoint path. The big advantage of this approach is that every developer understands how RESTful APIs are designed and they can immediately use the API without having to read your documentation on each endpoint.</p> \n<h3 id=\"3usepluralresources\">3. Use plural resources</h3> \n<p>Resources should always use their plural form. Why? Imagine you want to retrieve all authors. Therefore, you would call the following endpoint: <code>GET api.com/authors</code>.</p> \n<p>When you read the request, you can’t tell if the API response will contain only one or all authors. For that reason, API endpoints should use plural resources.</p> \n<h3 id=\"4correctuseofstatuscodes\">4. Correct use of status codes</h3> \n<p>Status codes aren’t here just for fun. They have a clear purpose. A status code notifies the client about the success of its request.</p> \n<p>The most common status code categories include:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-restful-apis-best-practices/?utm_source=rss\">13 Best Practices for Building RESTful APIs</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=TUkeqKbp0W8:0BrO2IX59l8:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=TUkeqKbp0W8:0BrO2IX59l8:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=TUkeqKbp0W8:0BrO2IX59l8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=TUkeqKbp0W8:0BrO2IX59l8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/TUkeqKbp0W8\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 18 Aug 2020 20:49:16 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597808919build-restful-api.png","linkMd5":"280829cec3cdbe959522102093fcc96d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn89@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-24-701_2db2eca7032bec72.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":10008,"destBytes":10008,"author":"Michiel Mulders","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597808919build-restful-api.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn89@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-24-701_2db2eca7032bec72.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=TUkeqKbp0W8:0BrO2IX59l8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn52@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-46-269_263634eae7c1327e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/TUkeqKbp0W8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn66@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-37-315_82ed0bd662533647.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483245},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Meet Polypane, a Browser That Makes You Five Times Faster","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176796","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/polypane-developer-browser/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Meet Polypane, a Browser That Makes You Five Times Faster\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596070474polypane.png\" alt=\"How to Develop Websites 5x Faster with Polypane\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596070474polypane-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596070474polypane.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>As developers, we like to use tools specifically made to make us as efficient as possible. We excessively research and get the perfect keyboard, our code editor or IDE is carefully picked and uses the perfect coding theme and coding font (Fira code, in my case). We have workflows to optimize our CSS and images and our build tools are optimized to do as much as possible as fast as possible.</strong></p> \n<p>And then we use the same browser that everyone else uses to like cat videos on Facebook.</p> \n<p>Isn’t that weird? We pick our code editor specifically out of dozens available; our keyboard has the perfect clickiness for our fingers; yet we use the same browser as everyone else. Just like we’re not using Word to write code just because everyone uses Word to write things, we shouldn’t accept using a regular browser to build websites.</p> \n<h2 id=\"regularbrowsers\">Regular Browsers</h2> \n<p>A typical workflow with a regular browser looks a little like this: Build the website on one size, then resize your browser and build the design for that. Then resize the browser again and build the design for that. Then … well, you get it. You’re doing it all one by one, repeating yourself over and over again. And if you’re unlucky, you get to do it all over a couple of times as you build, with new pages bringing new requirements that affect pages you’ve already finished.</p> \n<p>And you may want to do more than just build the visual side of your page. Do you want to check your pages for accessibility as you go? Add a browser extension. Do you want to create a full page screenshot to send to your boss or client? Add a browser extension. Do you want to check that your meta tags are correct? You guessed it, add a browser extension. With just a few basic things you already need half a dozen browser extensions. Have you used a browser with half a dozen extensions? It makes IE11 look fast in comparison.</p> \n<h2 id=\"polypaneworksdifferently\">Polypane Works Differently</h2> \n<p>When you open <a href=\"https://polypane.app\">Polypane</a>, you don’t see just a website. You see your website at multiple screen sizes at the same time, just as if you had a bunch of devices on your desk. What’s better, though, is that all these screen sizes are synced: if you interact with one you interact with all of them, whether you’re scrolling, clicking, hovering or typing. You’re interacting with a single website; you just happen to see it at multiple sizes at the same time.</p> \n<p>\n <video controls=\"\" width=\"100%\">\n  <source src=\"https://polypane.app/static/68568dbc740e534e7273939343f00331/intro.mp4\" type=\"video/mp4\" />\n </video><br /> \n <!-- [video]https://polypane.app/static/68568dbc740e534e7273939343f00331/intro.mp4 --></p> \n<p>Seeing all the screen sizes side by side means you no longer have to resize your browser and go through them one by one. And those screen sizes are yours to pick: you can pick from over 20 pre-configured devices, like phones, tablets and laptop sizes or you can resize them freeform however you like.</p> \n<p>Or you can ask Polypane to parse through the CSS of the page, find all the CSS media queries and create screen sizes from those, making sure you’re always testing the site on all the sizes you want to support.</p> \n<p>This alone makes Polypane a massive productivity boost. But if you eliminate resizing your browser all the time, what else can we do?</p> \n<p>Well, what about reloading?</p> \n<p>Polypane works with any hot reloading or live reloading system, just like any other modern browser out there. But Polypane also has a built-in live reloading server that requires zero configuration. Just tell it which folder to check and you’re done. It even works with plain HTML files! And best of all, if you update a CSS file or image, Polypane just refreshes that instead of reloading the full page.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/polypane-developer-browser/?utm_source=rss\">Meet Polypane, a Browser That Makes You Five Times Faster</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=ZdZ50rCWw08:SaKeEafODJE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=ZdZ50rCWw08:SaKeEafODJE:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=ZdZ50rCWw08:SaKeEafODJE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=ZdZ50rCWw08:SaKeEafODJE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/ZdZ50rCWw08\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 10 Aug 2020 21:02:46 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596070474polypane.png","linkMd5":"959888d267fa2e23892c33f6d7754d0b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn17@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-25-719_986c65a7c4157b2d.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":10346,"destBytes":10346,"author":"Kilian Valkhof","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596070474polypane.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn17@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-25-719_986c65a7c4157b2d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=ZdZ50rCWw08:SaKeEafODJE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn14@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-35-374_8396fc27b6615f93.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/ZdZ50rCWw08":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn52@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-46-791_90604a95663fcafa.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483247},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"GreenSock 3 Web Animation: Get to Know GSAP&#8217;s New Features","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=177086","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/greensock-3-animation-features/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"GreenSock 3 Web Animation: Get to Know GSAP’s New Features\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597120553gsap-3-web-animation.png\" alt=\"Animating the Web with the Latest Shiny GreenSock Animation Platform\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597120553gsap-3-web-animation-300x180.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597120553gsap-3-web-animation.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>On November 1st 2019, the <a href=\"https://greensock.com/\">GreenSock Animation Platform (GSAP)</a> released version 3, which is its major upgrade to date.</strong> </p> \n<p>GSAP is a powerful, backward-compatible, performant, and mature JavaScript animation library that allows you to animate pretty much anything on the web — such as DOM elements, JS objects, SVGs, CSS properties, etc.</p> \n<p>Its intuitive syntax empowers developers with the ability to create some mind blowing animation effects in a relatively short amount of time and with the minimum amount of code.</p> \n<p>In this article, I’m going to highlight some great new features of GSAP 3 and get you started on how to use them to get things moving on web in no time.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatsnewingsap3\">What’s New in GSAP 3</h2> \n<h3 id=\"morefeaturesandsmallerfilesizes\">More Features and Smaller File Sizes</h3> \n<p>GreenSock has been rebuilt from the ground up using ES6 modules. It’s still feature-packed, with more than 50 new library features, but it’s only half the size! </p> \n<h3 id=\"condensedsyntaxforfastcoding\">Condensed Syntax for Fast Coding</h3> \n<p>If you’ve ever used GSAP before, you’re already familiar with its intuitive, beginner-friendly syntax. The new API is even more simplified and quick to learn and use.</p> \n<p>For example, now you don’t need to decide whether you want to use TweenLite or TweenMax, TimelineLite or TimelineMax. There’s just one object, the <code>gsap</code> object:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// tween\ngsap.to(selector, {})\n\n// timeline\nconst tl = gsap.timeline()\n</code></pre> \n<p>Also, <code>duration</code> is no longer a parameter of the <code>to()</code>, <code>from()</code>, or <code>fromTo()</code> methods, but it’s set inside the <code>vars</code> object. In particular, the old</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">TweenMax.to(selector, 1, {})\n</code></pre> \n<p>becomes</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">gsap.to(selector, {\n  duration: 1\n})\n</code></pre> \n<p>Much more readable and also flexible. In fact, you can now set the <code>duration</code> using a function, for example.</p> \n<p>Another plus of this new, simplified API is that staggering animations are a breeze to code. No need to use the old <code>staggerTo()</code>, <code>staggerFrom()</code>, and <code>staggerFromTo()</code> methods because you can add staggers directly into the <code>vars</code> object of regular tweens:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">gsap.to(selector, {\n  x: 50,\n  duration: 1,\n  stagger: 0.5\n})\n</code></pre> \n<p>For more flexibility, you can use a stagger object like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">gsap.to(selector, {\n  x: 50,\n  duration: 1,\n  stagger: {\n    amount: 2,\n    from: 'center'\n  }\n})\n</code></pre> \n<p>Finally, GSAP’s eases have always been awesome, but a bit verbose. Not now. Version 3 comes with a more concise and readable syntax for setting eases. For example, instead of:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">Elastic.easeOut\nElastic.easeIn\nElastic.easeInOut\n</code></pre> \n<p>you simply write:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">'elastic'  // same as 'elastic.out'\n'elastic.in'  \n'elastic.inOut'\n</code></pre> \n<p>Another simplification consists in the possibility of replacing labels with the <code>&lt;</code> symbol to indicate the most recently added animation’s start time and the <code>&gt;</code> symbol to indicate the most recently added animation’s end time. Below is an example of how you could use labels in a timeline:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">gsap.timeline()\n  .add('start')\n  // this tween starts at the beginning of the\n  // entire animation\n  .to(selector, {}, 'start')\n  // this tween starts 0.5 seconds after\n  // the previous tween\n  .to(selector, {}, 'start+=0.5')\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can now rewrite the code above as follows:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">gsap.timeline()\n  .to(selector, {}, '&lt;')\n  .to(selector, {}, '&lt;0.5')\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"inheritabledefaultvaluesforthetimeline\">Inheritable Default Values for the Timeline</h3> \n<p>If the values for some of the settings in your timeline remain the same throughout the child tweens, gone are the days of having to write those values over and over again. GSAP 3 lets you set those properties once in the parent timeline and they will be inherited by the child tweens.</p> \n<p>For example, instead of writing:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const tl = new TimelineMax()\ntl.to(selector, 2, {\n  ease:  Power2.easeInOut,\n  rotation:  -180\n})\n  .to(selector, 2, {\n    ease:  Power2.easeInOut,\n    rotation:  -360\n})\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now, you can simply write:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const tl = gsap.timeline({defaults: {\n  duration: 2,\n  ease:  'power2.inOut'\n}} )\n\ntl.to(selector, {\n  rotation:  -180  \n})\n.to(selector, {\n  rotation:  -360\n})\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"keyframes\">Keyframes</h3> \n<p>Your GSAP 3 code gets even more concise and readable with keyframes. Keyframes, a concept that is quite familiar to CSS developers, are great in those cases when you want to animate the same element in different ways. Instead of creating a separate tween for each stage of the animation, you can now pass an array of keyframes to the <code>{} vars</code> object and all the steps of the animation will be perfectly sequenced inside the same tween. Here’s an example of how this works:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">gsap.to(selector, {keyframes: {\n  {x: 250, duration: 1},\n  {y: 100, duration: 1, delay: 0.5}\n}})\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"moreutilityfunctions\">More Utility Functions</h3> \n<p>This latest release of the GreenSock library comes packed with a bunch of new <a href=\"https://greensock.com/docs/v3/GSAP/UtilityMethods\">utility methods</a> like <code>snap()</code>, which lets you snap a value to an increment or to the closest value in an array, and <code>random()</code>, which makes it a breeze to generate a random number based on parameters or randomly select an element in an array, and tons more.</p> \n<h2 id=\"simpleanimations\">Simple Animations</h2> \n<p>Here’s an example of using the three basic GSAP methods: <code>to()</code>, <code>from()</code>, and <code>fromTo()</code>:</p> \n<p>\n <!-- https://codepen.io/antonietta/pen/BajzPrd --></p> \n<p class=\"codepen\" data-height=\"300\" data-theme-id=\"6441\" data-default-tab=\"html,result\" data-user=\"SitePoint\" data-slug-hash=\"oNxjjyO\" style=\"height: 300px; box-sizing: border-box; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; border: 2px solid; margin: 1em 0; padding: 1em;\" data-pen-title=\"GSAP3-to-from-fromTo-examples\"> <span>See the Pen <a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint/pen/oNxjjyO\"><br /> GSAP3-to-from-fromTo-examples</a> by SitePoint (<a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint\">@SitePoint</a>)<br /> on <a href=\"https://codepen.io\">CodePen</a>.</span> </p> \n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://static.codepen.io/assets/embed/ei.js\"></script></p> \n<h2 id=\"gsapeasesforlifelikeanimations\">GSAP Eases for Life-like Animations</h2> \n<p><strong>Eases</strong> are foundational components of animation. They embody the timing of tweens and thereby add interest and naturalness to the motion you create on screen.</p> \n<p>GSAP lets you add tons of eases by means of the <a href=\"https://greensock.com/docs/v3/Eases\">GreenSock Ease Equalizer</a>, a handy tool that offers a visual representation of GSAP easing options as you select and tweak the best fit for the particular effect you’re after.</p> \n<p>Let’s try some eases for our musical bird:</p> \n<p>\n <!-- https://codepen.io/antonietta/pen/bGEBaEY --></p> \n<p class=\"codepen\" data-height=\"300\" data-theme-id=\"6441\" data-default-tab=\"html,result\" data-user=\"SitePoint\" data-slug-hash=\"jOqbbpw\" style=\"height: 300px; box-sizing: border-box; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; border: 2px solid; margin: 1em 0; padding: 1em;\" data-pen-title=\"GSAP3-eases-example\"> <span>See the Pen <a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint/pen/jOqbbpw\"><br /> GSAP3-eases-example</a> by SitePoint (<a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint\">@SitePoint</a>)<br /> on <a href=\"https://codepen.io\">CodePen</a>.</span> </p> \n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://static.codepen.io/assets/embed/ei.js\"></script></p> \n<h2 id=\"anexampleofkeyframeanimationwithgsap\">An Example of Keyframe Animation with GSAP</h2> \n<p>As I pointed out above, GSAP 3 gives you the option of implementing a number of tweens on the same element in a more efficient and readable way using keyframes.</p> \n<p>Here’s an example:</p> \n<p>\n <!-- https://codepen.io/antonietta/pen/ExPXeeR --></p> \n<p class=\"codepen\" data-height=\"300\" data-theme-id=\"6441\" data-default-tab=\"html,result\" data-user=\"SitePoint\" data-slug-hash=\"ExKVVpe\" style=\"height: 300px; box-sizing: border-box; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; border: 2px solid; margin: 1em 0; padding: 1em;\" data-pen-title=\"GSAP3-keyframes-example\"> <span>See the Pen <a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint/pen/ExKVVpe\"><br /> GSAP3-keyframes-example</a> by SitePoint (<a href=\"https://codepen.io/SitePoint\">@SitePoint</a>)<br /> on <a href=\"https://codepen.io\">CodePen</a>.</span> </p> \n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://static.codepen.io/assets/embed/ei.js\"></script></p> \n<p>Using GSAP keyframes on the SVG bird element lets me apply a number of tweens without having to write each tween separately. The advantage is that I don’t need to repeat some of the code — for example, the selector code (<code>'.bird'</code>) or any of the settings that remain the same throughout the animation.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/greensock-3-animation-features/?utm_source=rss\">GreenSock 3 Web Animation: Get to Know GSAP’s New Features</a> on <a border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/D3zR2hdOs58\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 17:05:41 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597120553gsap-3-web-animation.png","linkMd5":"50620dc4b76570edbe0d0073af4c6351","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn70@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-24-650_8508968cccac4bc4.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":360,"sourceBytes":5490,"destBytes":5490,"author":"Maria Antonietta 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Fonts and Colors Used by Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google and More","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=83483","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/fonts-colors-used-facebook-twitter-google/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Fonts and Colors Used by Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google and More\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594257971fonts-colors.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><em>This article was updated in 2020 to show the newer fonts and colors used by social networks, including Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and various others. Google+ didn’t make a comeback.</em></p> \n<p><strong>Social login buttons, links to social media channels — in 2020 this is still a thing in web design and app design. I mean, what business isn’t on social media these days? <em>It’s a necessity!</em></strong></p> \n<p>Knowing what the different fonts and colors used by social networks are (so that we can use them in our designs) is quite handy. It’s something we “google” every time we design an app or website. (For example, “Facebook blue”, “Facebook hex value”, “What is the color used by Facebook?”, and so on).</p> \n<p>In fact, I bet that’s how you found this article!</p> \n<p>Well, I won’t keep you waiting any more. Let’s take a look at the fonts and colors used by Messenger (by Facebook), Instagram (by Facebook), WhatsApp (by Facebook), Facebook itself, Twitter, Pinterest, LinkedIn, Snapchat, and finally, Google/YouTube.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatsthefontusedby\">What’s the font used by […]? 🤔</h2> \n<p>Quick note: system fonts (i.e. <code>: system-ui</code> in CSS) are the standard unless otherwise stated. For each medium, this means:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Roboto</strong> for Android</li> \n <li><strong>Segoe UI</strong> for Windows</li> \n <li><strong>San Francisco</strong> for iOS/macOS</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Material design (i.e. YouTube and other Google apps) also uses <strong>Roboto</strong>. However, the actual Google logo uses Google’s very own Product Sans font (and this applies to the Alphabet logo too).</p> \n<h2 id=\"messengerbyfacebookhttpsfacebookbrandcommessenger\"><a href=\"https://facebookbrand.com/messenger/\">Messenger, by Facebook</a></h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594256305messenger-by-facebook.jpg\" alt=\"The Facebook Messenger logo\" width=\"1000\" height=\"500\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176605\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"messengercolorvalues\">Messenger Color Values</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Messenger hex value: <code>#0084FF</code></li> \n <li>Messenger RGB value: <code>rgb(0 132 255)</code></li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"messengerfonts\">Messenger Fonts</h3> \n<p>Messenger on macOS uses <strong>Helvetica Neue</strong> instead of San Francisco, but everything else follows the system default.</p> \n<h2 id=\"instagrambyfacebookhttpsinstagrambrandcom\"><a href=\"https://instagram-brand.com/\">Instagram, by Facebook</a></h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594256351instagram-by-facebook.jpg\" alt=\"The Instagram logo\" width=\"1000\" height=\"500\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176606\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"instagramcolorvalues\">Instagram Color Values</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Instagram hex value: <code>#E1306C</code></li> \n <li>Instagram RGB value: <code>rgb(225 48 108)</code></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Instagram uses <a href=\"https://brandpalettes.com/instagram-color-codes/\">many colors</a> in their branding, although the color value mentioned above is the one used in their own examples.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatsappbyfacebookhttpswhatsappbrandcom\"><a href=\"https://whatsappbrand.com/\">WhatsApp, by Facebook</a></h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594256394whatsapp-by-facebook.jpg\" alt=\"The WhatsApp logo\" width=\"1000\" height=\"500\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176607\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"whatsappcolorvalues\">WhatsApp Color Values</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>WhatsApp hex value: <code>#25D366</code></li> \n <li>WhatsApp RGB value: <code>rgb(37 211 102)</code></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"facebookbyfacebookhttpfacebookbrandcomfacebookapplol\"><a href=\"http://facebookbrand.com/facebookapp/\">Facebook, by Facebook</a> (lol)</h2> \n<p><img \n<h3 id=\"facebookcolorvalues\">Facebook Color Values</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Facebook hex value: <code>#1877F2</code></li> \n <li>Facebook RGB value: <code>rgb(24 119 242)</code></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 \n<h3 id=\"twittercolorvalues\">Twitter Color Values</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Twitter hex value: <code>#1DA1F2</code></li> \n <li>Twitter RGB value: <code>rgb(29 161 242)</code></li> \n</ul> \n<p> Continue Schwarz","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594257971fonts-colors.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn98@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-25-687_b018749250bbf122.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594256305messenger-by-facebook.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn5@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-47-110_0c2b785ab6e6c1bf.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594256351instagram-by-facebook.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn37@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-46-396_6cfb132fae5a6b09.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594256394whatsapp-by-facebook.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn42@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-42-953_161c1d3d89234931.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594256432facebook.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn17@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-44-292_6499e9a3bc7a4d94.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1594256512twitter.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn64@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-46-714_b6ad4a247fe84ce0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=LNXj6CcuK-Y:-Wp2-vkLs24:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn6@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-45-867_10253fed8c7154aa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/LNXj6CcuK-Y":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-42-832_b85b411ac59cb3c4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483258},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Build a Node.js CRUD App Using React and FeathersJS","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=153441","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/crud-app-node-react-feathersjs/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Build a Node.js CRUD App Using React and FeathersJS\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1583454183crud-app.png\" alt=\"Build a Node.js CRUD App Using React and FeathersJS\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1583454183crud-app-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1583454183crud-app.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Building a modern project requires splitting the logic into front-end and back-end code. The reason behind this move is to promote code re-usability. For example, we may need to build a native mobile application that accesses the back-end API. Or we may be developing a module that will be part of a large modular platform.</strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/1493756964crudappB-01.png\" alt=\"An operator, sat at an old-fashioned telephone switchboard - Build a CRUD App Using React, Redux and FeathersJS\" /></p> \n<p>The popular way of building a server-side API is to use Node.js with a library like Express or Restify. These libraries make creating RESTful routes easy. The problem with these libraries is that we’ll find ourselves writing a <em>ton</em> of <strong>repetitive code</strong>. We’ll also need to write code for authorization and other middleware logic.</p> \n<p>To escape this dilemma, we can use a framework like <a href=\"http://feathersjs.com/\">Feathers</a> to help us generate an API in just a few commands.</p> \n<p>What makes Feathers amazing is its simplicity. The entire framework is modular and we only need to install the features we need. Feathers itself is a thin wrapper built on top of Express, where they’ve added new features — <a href=\"https://docs.feathersjs.com/api/services.html\">services</a> and <a href=\"https://docs.feathersjs.com/api/hooks.html\">hooks</a>. Feathers also allows us to effortlessly send and receive data over WebSockets.</p> \n<h2 id=\"prerequisites\">Prerequisites</h2> \n<p>To follow along with this tutorial, you’ll need the following things installed on your machine:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/\">Node.js</a> v12+ and an up-to-date version of npm. Check <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">this tutorial</a> if you need help getting set up.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.mongodb.com/\">MongoDB</a> v4.2+. Check <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/an-introduction-to-mongodb/\">this tutorial</a> if you need help getting set up.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://yarnpkg.com/en/\">Yarn</a> package manager — installed using <code>npm i -g yarn</code>.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>It will also help if you’re familiar with the following topics:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>how to write modern JavaScript</li> \n <li>flow control in modern JavaScript (e.g. <code>async ... await</code>)</li> \n <li>the basics of <a href=\"https://reactjs.org/tutorial/tutorial.html\">React</a></li> \n <li>the basics of <a href=\"https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2018/01/understanding-using-rest-api/\">REST APIs</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Also, please note that you can find <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/react-crud-app\">the completed project code on GitHub</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"scaffoldtheapp\">Scaffold the App</h2> \n<p>We’re going to build a CRUD contact manager application using Node.js, React, Feathers and MongoDB.</p> \n<p>In this tutorial, I’ll show you how to build the application from the bottom up. We’ll kick-start our project using the popular <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/create-react-app/\">create-react-app</a> tool.</p> \n<p>You can install it like so:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install -g create-react-app\n</code></pre> \n<p>Then create a new project:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># scaffold a new react project\ncreate-react-app react-contact-manager\ncd react-contact-manager\n\n# delete unnecessary files\nrm src/logo.svg src/App.css src/serviceWorker.js\n</code></pre> \n<p>Use your favorite code editor and remove all the content in <code>src/index.css</code>. Then open <code>src/App.js</code> and rewrite the code like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">import React from 'react';\n\nconst App = () =&gt; {\n  return (\n    &lt;div&gt;\n      &lt;h1&gt;Contact Manager&lt;/h1&gt;\n    &lt;/div&gt;\n  );\n};\n\nexport default App;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Run <code>yarn start</code> from the <code>react-contact-manager</code> directory to start the project. Your browser should automatically open <code>http://localhost:3000</code> and you should see the heading “Contact Manager”. Quickly check the console tab to ensure that the project is running cleanly with no warnings or errors, and if everything is running smoothly, use <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>C</kbd> to stop the server.</p> \n<h2 id=\"buildtheapiserverwithfeathers\">Build the API Server with Feathers</h2> \n<p>Let’s proceed with generating the back-end API for our CRUD project using the <code>feathers-cli</code> tool:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># Install Feathers command-line tool\nnpm install @feathersjs/cli -g\n\n# Create directory for the back-end code\n# Run this command in the `react-contact-manager` directory\nmkdir backend\ncd backend\n\n# Generate a feathers back-end API server\nfeathers generate app\n\n? Do you want to use JavaScript or TypeScript? JavaScript\n? Project name backend\n? Description contacts API server\n? What folder should the source files live in? src\n? Which package manager are you using (has to be installed globally)? Yarn\n? What type of API are you making? REST, Realtime via Socket.io\n? Which testing framework do you prefer? Mocha + assert\n? This app uses authentication No\n\n# Ensure Mongodb is running\nsudo service mongod start\nsudo service mongod status\n\n● mongod.service - MongoDB Database Server\n   Loaded: loaded (/lib/systemd/system/mongod.service; disabled; vendor preset: enabled)\n   Active: active (running) since Wed 2020-01-22 11:22:51 EAT; 6s ago\n     Docs: https://docs.mongodb.org/manual\n Main PID: 13571 (mongod)\n   CGroup: /system.slice/mongod.service\n           └─13571 /usr/bin/mongod --config /etc/mongod.conf\n\n# Generate RESTful routes for Contact Model\nfeathers generate service\n\n? What kind of service is it? Mongoose\n? What is the name of the service? contacts\n? Which path should the service be registered on? /contacts\n? What is the database connection string? mongodb://localhost:27017/contactsdb\n\n# Install email and unique field validation\nyarn add mongoose-type-email\n</code></pre> \n<p>Let’s open <code>backend/config/default.json</code>. This is where we can configure our MongoDB connection parameters and other settings. Change the default paginate value to 50, since front-end pagination won’t be covered in this tutorial:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  \"host\": \"localhost\",\n  \"port\": 3030,\n  \"public\": \"../public/\",\n  \"paginate\": {\n    \"default\": 50,\n    \"max\": 50\n  },\n  \"mongodb\": \"mongodb://localhost:27017/contactsdb\"\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Open <code>backend/src/models/contact.model.js</code> and update the code as follows:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">require('mongoose-type-email');\n\nmodule.exports = function (app) {\n  const modelName = 'contacts';\n  const mongooseClient = app.get('mongooseClient');\n  const { Schema } = mongooseClient;\n  const schema = new Schema({\n    name : {\n      first: {\n        type: String,\n        required: [true, 'First Name is required']\n      },\n      last: {\n        type: String,\n        required: false\n      }\n    },\n    email : {\n      type: mongooseClient.SchemaTypes.Email,\n      required: [true, 'Email is required']\n    },\n    phone : {\n      type: String,\n      required: [true, 'Phone is required'],\n      validate: {\n        validator: function(v) {\n          return /^\\+(?:[0-9] ?){6,14}[0-9]$/.test(v);\n        },\n        message: '{VALUE} is not a valid international phone number!'\n      }\n    }\n  }, {\n    timestamps: true\n  });\n\n  ...\n\n  return  mongooseClient.model(modelName,  schema);\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>Mongoose introduces a new feature called <a href=\"https://mongoosejs.com/docs/guide.html#timestamps\">timestamps</a>, which inserts two new fields for you — <code>createdAt</code> and <code>updatedAt</code>. These two fields will be populated automatically whenever we create or update a record. We’ve also installed the <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/mongoose-type-email\">mongoose-type-email</a> plugin to perform email validation on the server.</p> \n<p>Now, open <code>backend/src/mongoose.js</code> and change this line:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{ useCreateIndex: true, useNewUrlParser: true }\n</code></pre> \n<p>to:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{ useCreateIndex: true, useNewUrlParser: true, useUnifiedTopology: true }\n</code></pre> \n<p>This will squash an annoying deprecation warning.</p> \n<p>Open a new terminal and execute <code>yarn test</code> inside the <code>backend</code> directory. You should have all the tests running successfully. Then, go ahead and execute <code>yarn start</code> to start the back-end server. Once the server has initialized, it should print <code>'Feathers application started on localhost:3030'</code> to the console.</p> \n<p>Launch your browser and access the URL <a href=\"http://localhost:3030/contacts\">http://localhost:3030/contacts</a>. You should expect to receive the following JSON response:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\"total\":0,\"limit\":50,\"skip\":0,\"data\":[]}\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"testtheapiwithpostwoman\">Test the API with Postwoman</h2> \n<p>Now let’s use <a href=\"https://postwoman.io/\">Postwoman</a> to confirm all of our endpoints are working properly.</p> \n<p>First, let’s create a contact. This link will open Postwoman with everything set up to <a href=\"https://postwoman.io/?method=POST&amp;url=http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A3030&amp;path=%2Fcontacts&amp;contentType=application%2Fjson&amp;rawParams=%7B%0A%20%20%22name%22%3A%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20%22first%22%3A%20%22Tony%22,%0A%20%20%20%20%22last%22%3A%20%22Stark%22%0A%20%20%7D,%0A%20%20%22phone%22%3A%20%22%2B18138683770%22,%0A%20%20%22email%22%3A%20%22tony%40starkenterprises.com%22%0A%7D\">send a POST request to the <code>/contacts</code> endpoint</a>. Make sure <em>Raw input enabled</em> is set to <em>on</em>, then press the green <em>Send</em> button to create a new contact. The response should be something like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  \"_id\": \"5e36f3eb8828f64ac1b2166c\",\n  \"name\": {\n    \"first\": \"Tony\",\n    \"last\": \"Stark\"\n  },\n  \"phone\": \"+18138683770\",\n  \"email\": \"tony@starkenterprises.com\",\n  \"createdAt\": \"2020-02-02T16:08:11.742Z\",\n  \"updatedAt\": \"2020-02-02T16:08:11.742Z\",\n  \"__v\": 0\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now let’s retrieve our newly created contact. This link will open Postwoman ready to <a href=\"https://postwoman.io/?method=GET&amp;url=http://localhost:3030&amp;path=/contacts\">send a GET request to the <code>/contacts</code> endpoint</a>. When you press the <em>Send</em> button, you should get a response like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  \"total\": 1,\n  \"limit\": 50,\n  \"skip\": 0,\n  \"data\": [\n    {\n      \"_id\": \"5e36f3eb8828f64ac1b2166c\",\n      \"name\": {\n        \"first\": \"Tony\",\n        \"last\": \"Stark\"\n      },\n      \"phone\": \"+18138683770\",\n      \"email\": \"tony@starkenterprises.com\",\n      \"createdAt\": \"2020-02-02T16:08:11.742Z\",\n      \"updatedAt\": \"2020-02-02T16:08:11.742Z\",\n      \"__v\": 0\n    }\n  ]\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>We can show an individual contact in Postwoman by sending a GET request to <code>http://localhost:3030/contacts/&lt;_id&gt;</code>. The <code>_id</code> field will always be unique, so you’ll need to copy it out of the response you received in the previous step. This is <a href=\"https://postwoman.io/?method=GET&amp;url=http://localhost:3030&amp;path=/contacts/5e36f3eb8828f64ac1b2166c\">the link for the above example</a>. Pressing <em>Send</em> will show the contact.</p> \n<p>We can update a contact by sending a PUT request to <code>http://localhost:3030/contacts/&lt;_id&gt;</code> and passing it the updated data as JSON. This is <a href=\"https://postwoman.io/?method=PUT&amp;url=http://localhost:3030&amp;path=/contacts/5e36f3eb8828f64ac1b2166c&amp;contentType=application/json&amp;rawParams=%7B%0A%20%20%22name%22:%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20%22first%22:%20%22Tony%22,%0A%20%20%20%20%22last%22:%20%22Stark%22%0A%20%20%7D,%0A%20%20%22phone%22:%20%22%2B18138683770%22,%0A%20%20%22email%22:%20%22ts@starkenterprises.com%22%0A%7D\">the link for the above example</a>. Pressing <em>Send</em> will update the contact.</p> \n<p>Finally we can remove our contact by sending a <code>DELETE</code> request to the same address — that is, <code>http://localhost:3030/contacts/&lt;_id&gt;</code>. This is <a href=\"https://postwoman.io/?method=DELETE&amp;url=http://localhost:3030&amp;path=/contacts/5e36f3eb8828f64ac1b2166c\">the link for the above example</a>. Pressing <em>Send</em> will delete the contact.</p> \n<p>Postwoman is an very versatile tool and I encourage you to use it to satisfy yourself that your API is working as expected, before moving on to the next step.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/crud-app-node-react-feathersjs/?utm_source=rss\">Build a Node.js CRUD App Using React and FeathersJS</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=TJJdk899z6c:2rHbjBt_29w:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=TJJdk899z6c:2rHbjBt_29w:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=TJJdk899z6c:2rHbjBt_29w:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=TJJdk899z6c:2rHbjBt_29w:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/TJJdk899z6c\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 25 Mar 2020 13:50:47 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1583454183crud-app.png","linkMd5":"8b6549da2ce91c4cbce48b4f9cd8b0f8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn5@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-24-685_b070779747e051bb.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":12434,"destBytes":12434,"author":"Michael Wanyoike","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1583454183crud-app.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn5@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-24-685_b070779747e051bb.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/1493756964crudappB-01.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn41@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-45-414_2a2e7f84a3aea4ac.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=TJJdk899z6c:2rHbjBt_29w:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn89@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-36-109_2709c399e9174a35.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/TJJdk899z6c":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn84@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-46-944_77de5edf6a105eeb.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483310},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Sending Emails in PHP with PHPMailer","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=102660","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/sending-emails-php-phpmailer/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Sending Emails in PHP with PHPMailer\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/1592182649phpmailer.png\" alt=\"Sending Emails in PHP with PHPMailer\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/1592182649phpmailer-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/1592182649phpmailer.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>PHPMailer is perhaps the most popular open-source PHP library to send emails with. It was first released way back in 2001, and since then it has become a PHP developer’s favorite way of sending emails programmatically, aside from a few other fan favorites like <a href=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/sending-email-with-swift-mailer/\">Swiftmailer</a>.</strong></p> \n<p>In this article, we’ll talk about why you should use PHPMailer instead of PHP’s <code>mail()</code> function, and we’ll show some code samples on how to use this library.</p> \n<h2 id=\"isitanalternativetophpsmailfunction\">Is It an Alternative to PHP’s <code>mail()</code> Function?</h2> \n<p>In most cases, it’s an alternative to PHP’s <code>mail()</code> function, but there are many other cases where the <code>mail()</code> function is simply not flexible enough to achieve what you need.</p> \n<p>First of all, PHPMailer provides an object-oriented interface, whereas <code>mail()</code> is not object oriented. PHP developers generally hate to create <code>$headers</code> strings while sending emails using the <code>mail()</code> function because they require a lot of escaping. PHPMailer makes this a breeze. Developers also need to write dirty code (escaping characters, encoding and formatting) to send attachments and HTML based emails when using the <code>mail()</code> function, whereas PHPMailer makes this painless.</p> \n<p>Also, the <code>mail()</code> function requires a local mail server to send out emails, which is not always trivial to set up. PHPMailer can use a non-local mail server (SMTP) if you have authentication.</p> \n<p>Further advantages include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>It can print various kinds of error messages in more than 40 languages when it fails to send an email.</li> \n <li>It has integrated SMTP protocol support and authentication over SSL and TLS.</li> \n <li>It can send an alternative plain-text version of email for non-HTML email clients.</li> \n <li>It has a very active developer community that keeps it secure and up to date.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>PHPMailer is also used by popular PHP content management systems like WordPress, Drupal, and Joomla.</p> \n<h2 id=\"installingphpmailer\">Installing PHPMailer</h2> \n<p>You can install <a href=\"https://github.com/PHPMailer/PHPMailer\">PHPMailer</a> using Composer:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">composer require phpmailer/phpmailer\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"sendingemailfromalocalwebserverusingphpmailer\">Sending Email from a Local Web Server Using PHPMailer</h3> \n<p>Here’s the simplest example of sending an email from a local web server using PHPMailer:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"php language-php\">&lt;?php\nuse PHPMailer\\PHPMailer\\PHPMailer;\nuse PHPMailer\\PHPMailer\\Exception;\n\nrequire_once \"vendor/autoload.php\";\n\n//PHPMailer Object\n$mail = new PHPMailer(true); //Argument true in constructor enables exceptions\n\n//From email address and name\n$mail-&gt;From = \"from@yourdomain.com\";\n$mail-&gt;FromName = \"Full Name\";\n\n//To address and name\n$mail-&gt;addAddress(\"recepient1@example.com\", \"Recepient Name\");\n$mail-&gt;addAddress(\"recepient1@example.com\"); //Recipient name is optional\n\n//Address to which recipient will reply\n$mail-&gt;addReplyTo(\"reply@yourdomain.com\", \"Reply\");\n\n//CC and BCC\n$mail-&gt;addCC(\"cc@example.com\");\n$mail-&gt;addBCC(\"bcc@example.com\");\n\n//Send HTML or Plain Text email\n$mail-&gt;isHTML(true);\n\n$mail-&gt;Subject = \"Subject Text\";\n$mail-&gt;Body = \"&lt;i&gt;Mail body in HTML&lt;/i&gt;\";\n$mail-&gt;AltBody = \"This is the plain text version of the email content\";\n\ntry {\n    $mail-&gt;send();\n    echo \"Message has been sent successfully\";\n} catch (Exception $e) {\n    echo \"Mailer Error: \" . $mail-&gt;ErrorInfo;\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>The code and comments should be sufficiently clear to explain everything that’s going on.</p> \n<h3 id=\"sendinganemailwithattachments\">Sending an Email with Attachments</h3> \n<p>Here’s an example of how to send an email with attachments using PHPMailer:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"php language-php\">&lt;?php\nuse PHPMailer\\PHPMailer\\PHPMailer;\nuse PHPMailer\\PHPMailer\\Exception;\n\nrequire_once \"vendor/autoload.php\";\n\n$mail = new PHPMailer;\n\n$mail-&gt;From = \"from@yourdomain.com\";\n$mail-&gt;FromName = \"Full Name\";\n\n$mail-&gt;addAddress(\"recipient1@example.com\", \"Recipient Name\");\n\n//Provide file path and name of the attachments\n$mail-&gt;addAttachment(\"file.txt\", \"File.txt\");        \n$mail-&gt;addAttachment(\"images/profile.png\"); //Filename is optional\n\n$mail-&gt;isHTML(true);\n\n$mail-&gt;Subject = \"Subject Text\";\n$mail-&gt;Body = \"&lt;i&gt;Mail body in HTML&lt;/i&gt;\";\n$mail-&gt;AltBody = \"This is the plain text version of the email content\";\n\ntry {\n    $mail-&gt;send();\n    echo \"Message has been sent successfully\";\n} catch (Exception $e) {\n    echo \"Mailer Error: \" . $mail-&gt;ErrorInfo;\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here, we’re attaching two files — <code>file.txt</code>, which resides in the same directory as the script, and <code>images/profile.png</code>, which resides in <code>images</code> directory of the script directory.</p> \n<p>To add attachments to the email, we just need to call the function <code>addAttachment</code> of the PHPMailer object by passing the file path as argument. For attaching multiple files, we need to call it multiple times.</p> \n<h3 id=\"troubleshooting\">Troubleshooting</h3> \n<p>In our two examples, we used PHPMailer’s <a href=\"https://github.com/PHPMailer/PHPMailer/blob/master/src/Exception.php\">Exception class</a> for debugging, so any errors thrown will help us debug any issues that may occur. We also added the argument <code>true</code> to <a href=\"https://github.com/PHPMailer/PHPMailer/blob/master/src/PHPMailer.php#L819\">PHPMailer constructor</a>, to output higher-level, more descriptive exceptions.</p> \n<p>Depending on the system we use, probably the most frequent error we’ll see will be related to running the <code>mail()</code> function in the background:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Mailer Error: Could not instantiate mail function.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>If we need more details on the error, we can also add something like this to the catch clause:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"php language-php\">print_r(error_get_last());\n</code></pre> \n<p>Usually, the problem with the mail function will be related to the missing mail server setup, in which case the <code>error_get_last</code> function will return something like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"php language-php\">Array (\n    [type] =&gt; 2\n    [message] =&gt; mail(): Failed to connect to mailserver at \"localhost\" port 25, verify your \"SMTP\" and \"smtp_port\" setting in php.ini or use ini_set()\n    [file] =&gt; OUR_PATH \\vendor\\phpmailer\\phpmailer\\src\\PHPMailer.php\n    [line] =&gt; 863\n)\n</code></pre> \n<p>This is the issue we’ll probably encounter most frequently, and we can solve it easily by using SMTP.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/sending-emails-php-phpmailer/?utm_source=rss\">Sending Emails in PHP with PHPMailer</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=AdFtZ6332zE:fIgRnc9a92c:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Meet Flipsnack, An Easy Design Tool for Incredible Magazines","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176566","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/flipsnack-an-easy-design-tool-for-incredible-magazines/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Meet Flipsnack, An Easy Design Tool for Incredible Magazines\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\"
