https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594288951artisan-768x387.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594288951artisan-1024x516.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><em>This article on Flipsnack was originally published on <a href=\"https://www.flipsnack.com/?utm_source=sitepoint&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=DesignStudio\" rel=\"sponsored\">Okta</a>. Thank you for supporting the partners who make SitePoint possible.</em></p> \n<p><strong>One of the most daunting tasks for anyone wanting to create any sort of online brochure, report, catalog, or magazine is the design aspect. These are generally needed either for promotion or for internal communication, and all companies need them at one point or another.</strong></p> \n<p>You might have all the content ready, or ideas for content, but then you’ll need to focus on the design, because it’s what brings it all together in harmony.</p> \n<p>There are professional tools which designers usually go for in this case. Most commonly used are InDesign, Affinity Publisher, QuarkXPress or others.</p> \n<p>These design tools have varying levels of complexity, require various levels of technical knowledge, and have different learning curves. For someone who’s never opened InDesign or worked with a similar professional design tool, the idea of designing a brochure or catalog can be a bit intimidating.</p> \n<p>If this sounds like you, then don’t panic. There is a tool out there that can help you create professional designs online easily, and it’s perfect for any type of design that has multiple pages (and it works for single page designs too). Its name is Flipsnack.</p> \n<p>Even if you don’t struggle with design, it’s still worth giving it a try.</p> \n<p>What makes <a href=\"https://www.flipsnack.com/?utm_source=sitepoint&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=DesignStudio\">Flipsnack</a> different from most professional design tools is that it’s really simple and straightforward. It’s so easy to use, in fact, that anyone from marketers, business owners to students can and have used it.</p> \n<h2 id=\"flipsnackdesignandpublishingtool\">Flipsnack: design and publishing tool</h2> \n<p>With over four million users now, Flipsnack is one of the world’s leading digital publishing platforms for online page-flip catalogs. People of all skill sets and from every corner of the globe have found Flipsnack the perfect place to create all sorts of publications. Some of them use Flipsnack to simply transform ready-made PDFs into interactive page flip catalogs, while others prefer to use its integrated design tool to build their catalog from scratch, page by page. The integrated design tool is called “Design Studio”.</p> \n<p>After you’re done creating and designing, Flipsnack offers multiple ways to share your creation if you want to. You can simply share a link via social media, send it via email, host it on your own website, and much more. But, if you want everything to remain private, you can do that, too. Flipsnack uses all the top tier security measures to ensure that your data stays locked away for safekeeping.</p> \n<h2 id=\"howdoesthedesignstudiowork\">How does the Design Studio work?</h2> \n<p>Flipsnack’s <a href=\"https://www.flipsnack.com/online-design-tool?utm_source=sitepoint&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=DesignStudio\">Design Studio</a> is a force to be reckoned with. It’s powerful, intuitive, easy to navigate, and easy to use. The goal for Flipsnack was to bring everything a person — designer or not — could possibly need to create a work of art within the Design Studio.</p> \n<p>The interface is drag-and-drop based, and even though easy to navigate, it’s packed with advanced functionalities which are critical when making a professional design: layers, smart guides, rulers, multiple select, group, lock and more.</p> [video width=\"1000\" height=\"427\" mp4=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594085205flipsnack-multiple-align.mp4\"][/video] \n<p>As far as capabilities go, even professional designers would be satisfied. Pretty much every aspect you could think about editing or designing, can be. There’s a wide range of fonts available, but the system supports font imports as well. All the options that you’d expect for editing texts are there. Users can upload their own images, or they can use free stock photos from Unsplash, directly from Flipsnack. Replacing an image with a different one requires just a simple drag-and-drop action.</p> \n<p>You can do anything from building basic layouts with texts and images, to designing more complex layouts, with image masks, shapes and even interactive elements. By adding videos in the design, GIFs, forms, interactive tags or captions, a basic design can become a really fun and engaging experience for the reader. Add shopping buttons in catalogs, create captions and descriptions that become displayed when the reader hovers their mouse over certain areas, and add links.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/flipsnack-an-easy-design-tool-for-incredible-magazines/?utm_source=rss\">Meet Flipsnack, An Easy Design Tool for Incredible Magazines</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=gdpsvljswxk:jF2S5iM3Zts:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=gdpsvljswxk:jF2S5iM3Zts:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=gdpsvljswxk:jF2S5iM3Zts:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=gdpsvljswxk:jF2S5iM3Zts:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/gdpsvljswxk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 08 Jul 2020 21:00:36 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594288951artisan.jpg","linkMd5":"dcc90a6392658c3134d102d724f95bd8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn74@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-34-175_7ada0fe90afcfa07.webp","destWidth":2340,"destHeight":1179,"sourceBytes":40226,"destBytes":40226,"author":"SitePoint Sponsors","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594288951artisan.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn74@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-34-175_7ada0fe90afcfa07.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=gdpsvljswxk:jF2S5iM3Zts:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn61@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-37-429_5b90ddcfb6af28eb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/gdpsvljswxk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn98@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-36-101_8b69775732e613d7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483258},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"15 React Interview Questions with Solutions","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176448","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/react-interview-questions-solutions/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"15 React Interview Questions with Solutions\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592875266react-interview-questions.png\" alt=\"15 React Interview Questions with Solutions\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592875266react-interview-questions-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592875266react-interview-questions.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>React’s popularity shows no sign of waning, with the demand for developers still outstripping the supply in many cities around the world. For less-experienced developers (or those who’ve been out of the job market for a while), demonstrating your knowledge at the interview stage can be daunting.</strong></p> \n<p>In this article, we’ll look at fifteen questions covering a range of knowledge that’s central to understanding and working effectively with React. For each question, I’ll summarize the answer and give links to additional resources where you can find out more.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1whatsthevirtualdom\">1. What’s the virtual DOM?</h2> \n<h3 id=\"answer\">Answer</h3> \n<p>The virtual DOM is an in-memory representation of the actual HTML elements that make up your application’s UI. When a component is re-rendered, the virtual DOM compares the changes to its model of the DOM in order to create a list of updates to be applied. The main advantage is that it’s highly efficient, only making the minimum necessary changes to the actual DOM, rather than having to re-render large chunks.</p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading\">Further reading</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://bitsofco.de/understanding-the-virtual-dom/\">Understanding the Virtual DOM</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.pluralsight.com/guides/virtual-dom-explained\">Virtual DOM Explained</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"2whatsjsx\">2. What’s JSX?</h2> \n<h3 id=\"answer-1\">Answer</h3> \n<p>JSX is an extension to JavaScript syntax that allows for writing code that looks like HTML. It compiles down to regular JavaScript function calls, providing a nicer way to create the markup for your components.</p> \n<p>Take this JSX:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">&lt;div className=\"sidebar\" /&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>It translates to the following JavaScript:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">React.createElement(\n  'div',\n  {className: 'sidebar'}\n)\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-1\">Further reading</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.newline.co/fullstack-react/30-days-of-react/day-2/\">What is JSX?</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://reactjs.org/docs/jsx-in-depth.html\">JSX in Depth</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/react-design-patterns-and-best-practices-second-edition/read/2/k71ebq0z?preview=true&amp;utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">JSX in React Design Patterns and Best Practices</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"3whatsthedifferencebetweenaclasscomponentandafunctionalone\">3. What’s the difference between a class component and a functional one?</h2> \n<h3 id=\"answer-2\">Answer</h3> \n<p>Prior to React 16.8 (the introduction of hooks), class-based components were used to create components that needed to maintain internal state, or utilize lifecycle methods (i.e. <code>componentDidMount</code> and <code>shouldComponentUpdate</code>). A class-based component is an ES6 class that extends React’s <code>Component</code> class and, at minimum, implements a <code>render()</code> method.</p> \n<p><strong>Class component</strong>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">class Welcome extends React.Component {\n  render() {\n    return &lt;h1&gt;Hello, {this.props.name}&lt;/h1&gt;;\n  }\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Functional components are stateless (again, &lt; React 16.8) and return the output to be rendered. They are preferred for rendering UI that only depends on props, as they’re simpler and more performant than class-based components.</p> \n<p><strong>Functional component</strong>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">function Welcome(props) {\n  return &lt;h1&gt;Hello, {props.name}&lt;/h1&gt;;\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p><em>Note: the introduction of hooks in React 16.8 means that these distinctions no longer apply (see questions 14 and 15).</em></p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-2\">Further reading</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/functional-components-vs-class-components-in-react/\">Functional Components vs Class Components in React</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://medium.com/@Zwenza/functional-vs-class-components-in-react-231e3fbd7108\">Functional vs Class-Components in React</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"4whatarekeysusedfor\">4. What are keys used for?</h2> \n<h3 id=\"answer-3\">Answer</h3> \n<p>When rendering out collections in React, adding a key to each repeated element is important to help React track the association between elements and data. The key should be a unique ID, ideally a UUID or other unique string from the collection item, but which can be an array index as a last resort:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">&lt;ul&gt;\n  {todos.map((todo) =&gt;\n    &lt;li key={todo.id}&gt;\n      {todo.text}\n    &lt;/li&gt;\n  )};\n&lt;/ul&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Not using a key can result in strange behavior when adding and removing items from the collection.</p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-3\">Further reading</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://reactjs.org/docs/lists-and-keys.html#keys\">Lists and Keys</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://kentcdodds.com/blog/understanding-reacts-key-prop\">Understanding React’s key prop</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"5whatsthedifferencebetweenstateandprops\">5. What’s the difference between state and props?</h2> \n<h3 id=\"answer-4\">Answer</h3> \n<p>props are data that are passed into a component from its parent. They should not be mutated, but rather only displayed or used to calculate other values. State is a component’s internal data that can be modified during the lifetime of the component, and is maintained between re-renders.</p> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-4\">Further reading</h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://github.com/uberVU/react-guide/blob/master/props-vs-state.md\">props vs state</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"6whycallsetstateinsteadofdirectlymutatingstate\">6. Why call setState instead of directly mutating state?</h2> \n<h3 id=\"answer-5\">Answer</h3> \n<p>If you try to mutate a component’s state directly, React has no way of knowing that it needs to re-render the component. By using the <code>setState()</code> method, React can update the component’s UI.</p> \n<h3 id=\"bonus\">Bonus</h3> \n<p>As a bonus, you can also talk about how state updates are not guaranteed to be synchronous. If you need to update a component’s state based on another piece of state (or props), pass a function to <code>setState()</code> that takes <code>state</code> and <code>props</code> as its two arguments:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">this.setState((state, props) =&gt; ({\n  counter: state.counter + props.increment\n}));\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"furtherreading-5\">Further reading</h3> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/react-interview-questions-solutions/?utm_source=rss\">15 React Interview Questions with Solutions</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=SC-S40MdoNw:Q_0HpXAQbd4:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=SC-S40MdoNw:Q_0HpXAQbd4:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a 2020 12:15:35 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Introduction to the Jamstack: Build Secure, High-Performance Sites","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176683","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/learn-jamstack/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Introduction to the Jamstack: Build Secure, High-Performance Sites\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595250945jamstack.png\" alt=\"Jamstack\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595250945jamstack-300x158.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595250945jamstack-768x404.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595250945jamstack-1024x539.png 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Every so often, web development takes a dramatic turn for the better. In this article, we introduce the Jamstack, explaining what it is and why it’s great.</strong></p> \n<p>Back in the day, dynamic sites exploded with the LAMP stack. Then the MEAN stack provided a foundation for the next generation of web apps. Now that APIs and reusable components are on the rise, static sites are fashionable again. It’s a “back to basics” of sorts — but not quite.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatisthejamstack\">What Is the Jamstack?</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595294384Jamstack_Logo_Original.png\" alt=\"Jamstack logo\" width=\"1204\" height=\"346\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176701\" /></p> \n<p><small>Provided: Netlify</small></p> \n<p>The <strong>Jamstack</strong> is a <em>redefinition of the modern web for faster and more secure websites</em>. These sites scale better and, with the proper toolset, are a lot easier (and more fun) to develop and maintain.</p> \n<p>Let’s break up the term:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>J stands for JavaScript</strong>. JS has come <em>a long way</em> since it was introduced by Netscape in 1995. With reactive and progressive libraries, you can design web apps that behave pretty much like mobile ones.</li> \n <li><strong>A stands for APIs</strong>. You don’t need to program every single functionality yourself, but can rely on third-party processing for a huge number of tasks.</li> \n <li><strong>M stands for Markup</strong>. You can reuse components that have already been developed, or create new ones that are a lot easier to maintain.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"isntthatjustbuzz\">Isn’t that just buzz?</h3> \n<p>In a way, yes. The term <a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/jamstack/\">Jamstack</a>, originally stylized as JAMstack, was coined by the company <a href=\"https://www.netlify.com/\">Netlify</a> as a way of promoting their “all-in-one platform for automating modern web projects.” The principles behind the Jamstack aren’t really new, as web components and APIs have existed for quite some time.</p> \n<p>But in very much the same way the term <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajax_(programming)\">Ajax</a> (asynchronous JavaScript and XML) was coined by another company back in the day — <a href=\"https://adaptivepath.com/\">Adaptive Path</a> — and even though the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XMLHttpRequest\">XMLHttpRequest</a> (XHR) API that made Ajax possible also existed for some time, <strong>both Ajax and JAMstack were a refreshing revamp of ideas with legitimate uses</strong> that were quickly adopted by the community. The hype is well-deserved: this way of working has been a revelation for many developers around the world.</p> \n<h3 id=\"staticsites\">Static sites?</h3> \n<p>“Static sites” are the antithesis of “dynamic websites”, right? So how to provide rich and dynamic interaction with just plain HTML files? Well, JavaScript.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/learn-jamstack/?utm_source=rss\">Introduction to the Jamstack: Build Secure, High-Performance Sites</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=sAB2NIOpLQ4:ImK0kyA1nAA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=sAB2NIOpLQ4:ImK0kyA1nAA:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=sAB2NIOpLQ4:ImK0kyA1nAA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=sAB2NIOpLQ4:ImK0kyA1nAA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/sAB2NIOpLQ4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Jul 2020 08:41:39 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595250945jamstack.png","linkMd5":"229215be6b1df7bed253fe5156645449","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn22@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-749_7fcf4cb4c4989ff7.webp","destWidth":1900,"destHeight":1000,"sourceBytes":22110,"destBytes":22110,"author":"Lucero del Alba","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595250945jamstack.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn22@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-749_7fcf4cb4c4989ff7.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1595294384Jamstack_Logo_Original.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-47-601_9e86febc64ea7762.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=sAB2NIOpLQ4:ImK0kyA1nAA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn54@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-38-224_6282c8f2f7426a8a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/sAB2NIOpLQ4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn6@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-38-292_3d996e68872f7f94.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483257},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Install Apache Web Server on Windows","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/blogs/?p=7949","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-install-apache-on-windows/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Install Apache Web Server on Windows\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593595022mar7-outline-02.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593595022mar7-outline-02-300x200.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593595022mar7-outline-02-768x512.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593595022mar7-outline-02-1024x683.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><em>This popular article was updated in 2020.</em></p> \n<p><strong>Starting web development is easy: you create a file called <code>something.html</code>, edit it in Notepad, and load it in a browser. Simple sites can be built using this process, but to really explore the possibilities, you need a web server.</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"whatisawebserver\">What is a Web Server?</h2> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/blogs/?p=7949#whyapache\"><em>(Skip to the next section if you prefer …)</em></a></p> \n<p>A web server is software that listens for requests and returns data (usually a file). When you type “www.mysite.com”, the request is forwarded to a machine running web server software which returns a file back to your browser — such as the contents of <code>index.html</code>. The browser might then make further requests based on the HTML content — like CSS, JavaScript, and graphic files.</p> \n<p>Since the web server sits between your browser and the requested file, it can perform processing that’s not possible by opening an HTML file directly. For example, it can parse PHP code which connects to a database and returns data.</p> \n<p>You can use your host’s web server for testing, but uploading will become tiresome and changes could go live before they’ve been fully tested. What you need is a local web server installation.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whyapache\">Why Apache?</h2> \n<p>In general, it’s good to use the web server software that your web host uses. Unless you’re creating ASP.NET applications on Microsoft IIS, your host is likely to use <a href=\"http://httpd.apache.org/\">Apache</a> — the most widespread and fully-featured web server available. It’s an open-source project, so it doesn’t cost anything to download or install.</p> \n<p>The following instructions describe how to install Apache on Windows. macOS comes with Apache and PHP. Most Linux users will have Apache pre-installed or available in the base repositories.</p> \n<h2 id=\"allinonepackages\">All-in-one Packages</h2> \n<p>There are some excellent all-in-one Windows distributions that contain Apache, PHP, MySQL and other applications in a single installation file — such as <a href=\"http://www.apachefriends.org/en/xampp.html\">XAMPP</a> (for Windows, Linux and macOS), <a href=\"http://www.wampserver.com/en/\">WampServer</a> and <a href=\"http://www.devside.net/server/webdeveloper\">WampDeveloper Pro</a>. There’s nothing wrong with using these packages, although manually installing Apache will help you learn more about the system and its configuration options.</p> \n<h2 id=\"theapacheinstallationwizard\">The Apache Installation Wizard</h2> \n<p>An excellent official <code>.msi</code> installation wizard is available from the <a href=\"http://httpd.apache.org/download.cgi\">Apache download page</a>. This option is certainly recommended for novice users or perhaps those installing Apache for the first time.</p> \n<h2 id=\"manualinstallation\">Manual Installation</h2> \n<p>Manual installation offers several benefits:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Backing up, reinstalling, or moving the web server can be achieved in seconds.</li> \n <li>You have more control over how and when Apache starts.</li> \n <li>You can install Apache anywhere, such as a portable USB drive (useful for client demonstrations).</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"step1configureiis\">Step 1: Configure IIS</h3> \n<p>Apache listens for requests on TCP/IP port 80. You need to uninstall or disable any program that uses that port. If you have a Professional or Server version of Windows, you may already have IIS installed. If you would prefer Apache, either <a href=\"http://support.microsoft.com/kb/321141\">remove IIS as a Windows component or disable its services</a>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"step2downloadthefiles\">Step 2: Download the files</h3> \n<p>We’re going to use the unofficial Windows binary from <a href=\"http://www.apachelounge.com/\">Apache Lounge</a>. This version has performance and stability improvements over the official Apache distribution, although I’m yet to notice a significant difference. However, it’s provided as a manually installable ZIP file from <a href=\"http://www.apachelounge.com/download/\">www.apachelounge.com/download/</a>.</p> \n<p>You should also <a href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=48145\">download and install the Windows C++ runtime from Microsoft.com</a>. You may have this installed already, but there is no harm installing it again.</p> \n<p>As always, remember to virus scan all downloads.</p> \n<h3 id=\"step3extractthefiles\">Step 3: Extract the Files</h3> \n<p>We’ll install Apache in <code>C:/Apache24</code>, so extract the ZIP file to the root of the <code>C:/</code> drive. Apache can be installed anywhere on your system, but you’ll need to change <code>SVROOT</code> configuration to point to your unzipped location — suh as <code>E:/Apache24</code>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"step4configureapache\">Step 4: Configure Apache</h3> \n<p>Apache is configured with the text file <code>conf/httpd.conf</code> contained in the Apache folder. Open it with your favorite text editor.</p> \n<p>Note that all file path settings use a forward slash (<code>/</code>) rather than the Windows backslash. If you installed Apache anywhere other than <code>C:/Apache24</code>, now is a good time to search and replace all references to <code>C:/Apache24</code>.</p> \n<p>There are several lines you should change for your production environment:</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p>Line 60, listen to all requests on port 80:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">Listen *:80\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>Line 162, enable mod-rewrite by removing the # (optional, but useful):</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">LoadModule rewrite_module modules/mod_rewrite.so\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>Line 227, specify the server domain name:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">ServerName localhost:80\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>Line 224, allow <code>.htaccess</code> overrides:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">AllowOverride All\n</code></pre> </li> \n</ul> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-install-apache-on-windows/?utm_source=rss\">How to Install Apache Web Server on Windows</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p> \n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=bMvXXM6WD0Y:gfocj87jjZk:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=bMvXXM6WD0Y:gfocj87jjZk:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div> \n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/bMvXXM6WD0Y\" +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593595022mar7-outline-02.jpg","linkMd5":"e881aca5e1aafd07dfbee3909e115ed2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn41@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-24-751_ae801ad141f96661.webp","destWidth":1800,"destHeight":1200,"sourceBytes":61584,"destBytes":61584,"author":"Craig Buckler","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593595022mar7-outline-02.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn41@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-24-751_ae801ad141f96661.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=bMvXXM6WD0Y:gfocj87jjZk:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn38@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-42-852_e62a329714c60576.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/bMvXXM6WD0Y":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-44-992_138ecbd0673d744b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483260},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Prepare for a Remote Job Search","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175086","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-prepare-for-a-remote-job-search/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Prepare for a Remote Job Search\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582616267womanworking.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582616267womanworking-300x200.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582616267womanworking-768x512.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582616267womanworking-1024x683.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>The number of people working remotely is at an all-time high, and that’s not just because telecommuting is pants-optional. By giving employees more control over their schedule and work environment, <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/jobs/\">remote jobs</a> can enhance the work-life balance that so many people struggle to maintain.</strong></p> \n<p>But if you’ve held in-house positions for most of your career, properly preparing for your remote job search can up your chances of impressing remote employers, nailing the interview, and landing a remote job that best fits your needs.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatareremoteemployerslookingfor\">What Are Remote Employers Looking For?</h2> \n<p>Remote employers are looking for three things in particular.</p> \n<h3 id=\"independence\">Independence</h3> \n<p>The office may at times feel like a panopticonic prison, but there is something to be said for workplace accountability. Can you stay focused without a boss periodically checking in on you? Can you stay productive without the sight and sound of other co-workers clacking away on their computers? When you work from home, the Damocles of the deadline is blunted and the motivating effect of being in close proximity to your team members weakens.</p> \n<p>Remote employers understand these challenges, which is why they look for candidates who can motivate themselves without external prompting. As trite as buzzwords like <em>self-starter</em> and <em>proactive</em> can be, they carry a significant amount of weight in the remote job search. Not only do you need to possess these qualities, you’ll need to be able demonstrate them to potential employers.</p> \n<h3 id=\"communication\">Communication</h3> \n<p>Working in an office allows employees to be more passive. Don’t know what’s going on? A co-worker can fill you in via a few seconds of conversation. Your boss is only a few steps away. Maybe there’s a whiteboard in the break room with announcements. Sharing a space with people just makes it much easier to stay in the loop.</p> \n<p>But if you’re on your own, you need to take initiative. To compensate for the lack of face-to-face, a good remote worker will put effort into the virtual communication tools at their disposal. They’ll reach out to people through email or Slack. They’ll suggest video chats or calls to hash things out. Even swapping memes in a group chat can help you stay engaged. But if you give in to the temptation of solitude, communication could suffer, and so could your work.</p> \n<h3 id=\"rationalthinking\">Rational Thinking</h3> \n<p>When communicating primarily through text, it’s all too common for our imaginations to run wild with unfounded anxieties. Emailed your boss a question and they didn’t respond within whatever time frame you’ve arbitrarily decided was reasonable? They must think it’s a dumb question and you’re dumb for asking it. They must not deem you important enough to expediently respond to. They must be offended by something you wrote. Asked a co-worker to do something and they responded with “k”? They hate you. They’re telling everyone how much they hate you. Everyone hates you. You’re garbage!</p> \n<p>Or … absolutely none of that is true and the coldness of non-verbal communication is messing with your head. Like any good employer, remote employers don’t want drama. They want rational critical thinkers who can vault the pitfalls of remote communication and maintain healthy work relationships. K?</p> \n<h2 id=\"howdoyoudemonstratetheseskillsonyourresume\">How Do You Demonstrate These Skills On Your Resume?</h2> \n<p>Even if you have little to no remote work experience, there are ways to frame your in-house work experience so that it demonstrates remote work skills. What have you done that demonstrates independence? Communication? Rational thinking? Figure it out and integrate it into your resume.</p> \n<p>For example, if you took the initiative on anything in a previous position, emphasize it. Say you <em>independently devised and implemented project x or volunteered to plan, create, and maintain project y</em>. Explain that you <em>created and ran program z with little oversight</em>.</p> \n<p>Here are some other ideas to get you thinking:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-prepare-for-a-remote-job-search/?utm_source=rss\">How to Prepare for a Remote Job Search</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=H3nrdjjNICg:4UKsWPEk4Ys:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img Kraus","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1582616267womanworking.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn46@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-27-352_d2db2069dea2b9cb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=H3nrdjjNICg:4UKsWPEk4Ys:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn46@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-41-183_0b681bc5f7e94fe9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/H3nrdjjNICg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn66@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-37-937_a145008cca033c4f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483298},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Migrate a React App to TypeScript","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175483","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-migrate-a-react-app-to-typescript/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Migrate a React App to TypeScript\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584071411os0004_17.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584071411os0004_17-300x250.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584071411os0004_17-768x640.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584071411os0004_17-1024x853.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p>When I first started learning TypeScript, one of the suggestions I often heard was, “convert one of your existing projects! It’s the best way to learn!” Soon after, a friend from Twitter <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nfFVygaWCuE\">offered to do</a> just that — show me how to migrate a React app to TypeScript. </p> \n<p>The purpose of this article is to be that friend for you and help you migrate your own project to TypeScript. For context, I will be using pieces from a personal project which I migrated while going through this process myself. </p> \n<h2 id=\"theplan\">The Plan</h2> \n<p>To make this process feel less daunting, we’ll break this down into steps so that you can execute the migration in individual chunks. I always find this helpful when taking on a large task. Here are all the steps we’ll take to migrate our project:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Add TypeScript</li> \n <li>Add <code>tsconfig.json</code></li> \n <li>Start simple</li> \n <li>Convert all files</li> \n <li>Increase strictness </li> \n <li>Clean it up </li> \n <li>Celebrate</li> \n</ol> \n<p>NOTE: the most important step in this whole process is number 9. Although we can only get there by working through them in sequential order. </p> \n<h3 id=\"1addtypescripttotheproject\">1. Add TypeScript to the Project</h3> \n<p>First, we need to add TypeScript to our project. Assuming your React project was bootstrapped with <code>create-react-app</code>, we can <a href=\"https://create-react-app.dev/docs/adding-typescript/#installation\">follow the docs</a> and run:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install --save typescript @types/node @types/react @types/react-dom @types/jest\n</code></pre> \n<p>or if you’re using <code>yarn</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">yarn add typescript @types/node @types/react @types/react-dom @types/jest\n</code></pre> \n<p>Notice we haven’t changed anything to TypeScript yet. If we run the command to start the project locally (<code>yarn start</code> in my case), nothing should be different. If that’s the case, then great! We’re ready for the next step. </p> \n<h3 id=\"2addthetsconfigjson\">2. Add the <code>tsconfig.json</code></h3> \n<p>Before we can take advantage of TypeScript, we need to configure this via the <code>tsconfig.json</code>. The simplest way for us to get started is to scaffold one using this command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npx tsc --init\n</code></pre> \n<p>This gets us some basics. </p> \n<p>We have not yet interacted with TypeScript. We have only taken the necessary actions to get things ready. Our next step is to migrate a file to TypeScript. With this, we can complete this step and move onto the next.</p> \n<h3 id=\"3startwithasimplecomponent\">3. Start with a Simple Component</h3> \n<p>The beauty of TypeScript is that you can incrementally adopt it. We can start with a simple component for our first piece of this migration. For my project, I’m going to start with an SVG component that looks like this:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-migrate-a-react-app-to-typescript/?utm_source=rss\">How to Migrate a React App to TypeScript</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=NAMSP5xdsCs:xU26N8oHv8g:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 2020 12:42:10 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585115151remote-workers.png","linkMd5":"c08508145ce294eb8a3e7d0e976a99e5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn82@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-25-700_8526d2c02f848a1f.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":9586,"destBytes":9586,"author":"SitePoint Team","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585115151remote-workers.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn82@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-25-700_8526d2c02f848a1f.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585112619working_remotely.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn46@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-36-781_b41ccfeb26d37ba7.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585112688influence_virtual_teams.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn82@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-36-433_3d3a8d191444e599.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585112736project_book.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn76@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-41-246_68d05408a875cf40.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585112769remotework.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-36-784_80ba13d381c9063b.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585112806remote-async-work.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn41@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-36-906_90b003f0299a079c.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585112839remote-working.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn84@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-44-166_8eeb1d26428cf0a7.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585112904womanworking.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn1@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-47-265_55f0733c0eabc8ba.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=sXF5qBeNnvI:0zcaBl0N89A:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn12@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-47-529_cbb05d2cd7e71402.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/sXF5qBeNnvI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn47@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-45-900_ed21ee4fd63ec492.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483289},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Build a Chrome Extension to Streamline Your Workflow","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175763","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-a-chrome-extension/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Build a Chrome Extension to Streamline Your Workflow\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1585789357chrome-extension.png\" alt=\"Build a Chrome Extension to Streamline Your Workflow\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1585789357chrome-extension-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1585789357chrome-extension.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>When I began as a JavaScript editor at SitePoint, our submission process was something of a mess — articles coming from every direction in a variety of formats. So we decided to standardize things and settled on submission via GitHub in Markdown.</strong></p> \n<p>This was a step forward, but we still needed to convert the Markdown into HTML for our WordPress back end. The powers that be at SitePoint HQ had vetoed the installation of any WordPress plugins, which made us consider if we could accomplish this task with a browser extension. Luckily we could!</p> \n<p>In the following post, I’m going to demonstrate how you can build your own Chrome extension to add additional functionality to WordPress. I’ll also introduce you to <a href=\"https://github.com/jameshibbard/SP-Tools\">SP-Tools</a>, the extension we use at SitePoint to make life as an editor that little bit easier.</p> \n<h2 id=\"theanatomyofachromeextension\">The Anatomy of a Chrome Extension</h2> \n<p>Despite what you might think, building a Chrome extensions isn’t difficult. Let’s start by looking at the various components.</p> \n<p><em>Parts of the following section are borrowed from another tutorial I wrote about <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-vue-chrome-extension/\">building a Chrome extension using Vue.js</a>.</em></p> \n<p>The core piece of any Chrome extension is a <a href=\"https://developer.chrome.com/extensions/manifest\">manifest file</a>. This is in a JSON format and provides important information about an extension, such as its version, resources, or the permissions it requires.</p> \n<p>A manifest file won’t do much on its own, so we can use a <a href=\"https://developer.chrome.com/extensions/content_scripts\">content script</a> to add some functionality. Content scripts are files that “run in the context of web pages”. That is to say, you specify the URL in your manifest file, then when your browser visits a page whose address matches the URL you specified, the content script is injected into the page and run.</p> \n<p>To demonstrate these concepts, let’s start by writing a Chrome extension to do something on the SitePoint main site.</p> \n<p>Make a new folder called <code>my-extension</code> and two files, <code>manifest.json</code> and <code>main.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mkdir my-extension\ncd my-extension\ntouch manifest.json main.js\n</code></pre> \n<p>Open up <code>manifest.json</code> and add the following code:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  \"name\": \"My Extension\",\n  \"version\": \"0.0.1\",\n  \"manifest_version\": 2,\n  \"content_scripts\": [\n    {\n      \"matches\": [ \"*://*.sitepoint.com/*\" ],\n      \"js\": [ \"main.js\" ]\n    }\n  ]\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <code>name</code>, <code>version</code> and <code>manifest_version</code> are all required fields. The <code>name</code> and <code>version</code> fields can be whatever you want; the <a href=\"https://developer.chrome.com/extensions/manifestVersion\">manifest version</a> should be set to 2 (as of Chrome 18).</p> \n<p>The <code>content_scripts</code> key allows us to register a content script (<code>main.js</code>), which will be run whenever we visit SitePoint. Notice how we can use <a href=\"https://developer.chrome.com/extensions/match_patterns\">match patterns</a> to specify parts of the URL, such as the protocol.</p> \n<p>Now let’s add the following code to <code>main.js</code> to make the browser say hello whenever we visit SitePoint:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">alert('Hello there!');\n</code></pre> \n<p>Finally, let’s install the extension. Open Chrome and enter <code>chrome://extensions/</code> in the address bar. You should see a page displaying the extensions you’ve installed.</p> \n<p>As we want to install our extension from a file (and not the Chrome Web Store) we need to activate <em>Developer mode</em> using the toggle in the top right-hand corner of the page. This should add an extra menu bar with the option <em>Load unpacked</em>. Click this button and select the <code>my-extension</code> folder you created previously. Click <em>Open</em> and the extension will be installed.</p> \n<p>Now when you visit SitePoint, this will happen:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/158348751501-chrome-ext.png\" alt=\"Basic Extension\" /></p> \n<p>Congratulations! You just made a Chrome extension.</p> \n<h3 id=\"backgroundscriptsandmessagepassing\">Background Scripts and Message Passing</h3> \n<p>So, that popup is pretty annoying right? To finish off this section, let’s add a context menu entry to fire it off manually, instead of having it appear on every page load.</p> \n<p>This introduces us to another important component of Chrome extensions — <a href=\"https://developer.chrome.com/extensions/background_pages\">background scripts</a>. These scripts can react to browser events (such as a user clicking a context menu entry) and they have full access to Chrome’s APIs. However, they <em>don’t</em> have access to the current page, and rely on message passing to communicate with content scripts.</p> \n<p>Update the manifest like so:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  \"name\": \"My Extension\",\n  \"version\": \"0.0.1\",\n  \"manifest_version\": 2,\n  \"permissions\": [ \"contextMenus\" ],\n  \"content_scripts\": [\n    {\n      \"matches\": [ \"*://*.sitepoint.com/*\" ],\n      \"js\": [ \"main.js\" ]\n    }\n  ],\n  \"background\": {\n    \"scripts\": [\"background.js\"],\n    \"persistent\": false\n  }\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Notice that we’re requesting the <code>contextMenus</code> permission, as we want to add something to the context menu, and that we’ve registered a non-persistent background script. Making the background script non persistent allows it to be unloaded when it’s not needed.</p> \n<p>Next, create a <code>background.js</code> file and add:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">chrome.runtime.onInstalled.addListener(() =&gt; {\n  chrome.contextMenus.create({\n    id: 'greet',\n    title: 'Say hi',\n    contexts: ['page'],\n    documentUrlPatterns: ['*://*.sitepoint.com/*'],\n  });\n});\n\nchrome.contextMenus.onClicked.addListener((info, tab) =&gt; {\n  if (info.menuItemId === 'greet') {\n    chrome.tabs.sendMessage(tab.id, { text: 'greet' }, (res) =&gt; {\n      console.log(res);\n    });\n  }\n});\n</code></pre> \n<p>We register the context menu entry when the extension is installed, then add an event listener to send a message to our content script whenever the entry is clicked.</p> \n<p>Change <code>main.js</code> like so:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">chrome.runtime.onMessage.addListener((msg, sender, sendResponse) =&gt; {\n  if (msg.text === 'greet') {\n    alert('hi');\n    sendResponse('I greeted the user');\n  }\n});\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here, we listen for a message from our background script. If it has a text of “greet”, we then fire off the alert and send back a message informing the background script that we did what was requested.</p> \n<p>To try this out, head back to the extensions page (at <code>chrome://extensions/</code>), then click the reload icon and reload any SitePoint page. When you right click, you should now see a context menu entry.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/158349074502-chrome-ext.png\" alt=\"Context menu entry for our extension\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"enhancingwordpressfunctionalitywithachromeextension\">Enhancing WordPress’ Functionality with a Chrome Extension</h2> \n<p>Now that we’ve familiarized ourselves with the basic components of a Chrome extension, let’s look at how we can make some additions to WordPress’ functionality.</p> \n<p>To follow along with this section, you’ll need a <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/support/article/how-to-install-wordpress/\">working installation of WordPress</a>. I installed mine locally. It’s running on an Apache server at <code>http://localhost/wp</code>.</p> \n<p>The code for this extension can be found on <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/wp-enhance\">GitHub</a>.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-a-chrome-extension/?utm_source=rss\">Build a Chrome Extension to Streamline Your Workflow</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=3-MWiZWU2gc:0wQV4NRWQkQ:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=3-MWiZWU2gc:0wQV4NRWQkQ:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=3-MWiZWU2gc:0wQV4NRWQkQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=3-MWiZWU2gc:0wQV4NRWQkQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/3-MWiZWU2gc\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 07 Apr 2020 00:00:10 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1585789357chrome-extension.png","linkMd5":"ff4ce09a06cbcb826bbcfc03576c33ad","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn9@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-27-781_2180f2f862b078a9.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":13126,"destBytes":13126,"author":"James Hibbard","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1585789357chrome-extension.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn9@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-27-781_2180f2f862b078a9.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/158348751501-chrome-ext.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn57@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-42-340_54baeb381bb9278c.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/158349074502-chrome-ext.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn25@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-37-090_041fe832ca330e13.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=3-MWiZWU2gc:0wQV4NRWQkQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-47-132_d68ebc071d399b74.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/3-MWiZWU2gc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn12@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-44-677_4938c8fbd3b0561a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483308},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Never Forget a TODO Comment with tickgit, Your Repo&#8217;s Project Manager","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176658","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/never-forget-a-todo-comment-with-tickgit-your-repos-project-manager/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Never Forget a TODO Comment with tickgit, Your Repo’s Project Manager\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594776548tickgit.png\" alt=\"How Tickgit Helps to Manage To-Do Comments in Git Projects\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594776548tickgit-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594776548tickgit.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>tickgit is a command-line tool and web application that helps developers do project management in their code, through the use of TODO comments and other plain-text markers. It’s a low-overhead way of managing your backlog without switching contexts.</strong></p> \n<p>tickgit scans source code for TODO markers (and HACK, FIXME, XXX, etc.) and presents those code comments as tickets, with a fuller context derived from Git history (who added it, when, where etc.).</p> \n<p>I am a solo developer building <a href=\"https://github.com/augmentable-dev/tickgit\">tickgit</a> and <a href=\"https://www.tickgit.com/\">tickgit.com</a> to help software engineers be more productive in their code. I hope you find this project interesting and useful!</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594774808interface-1024x648.png\" alt=\"the tickgit interface\" width=\"1024\" height=\"648\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176663\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"why\">Why?</h2> \n<p>Project management is an essential part of software development, even for solo developers building a side-project. Plenty of existing ticketing and task management systems help teams and individuals track pending work really thoroughly. Sometimes, though, using TODO comments and other markers <em>within</em> a codebase ends up being a more efficient way of keeping tabs on what needs to get done.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whytodocomments\">Why // TODO Comments?</h2> \n<p>TODO comments (or FIXME, HACK, OPTIMIZE, XXX, etc.) are a common way developers indicate that an area of code is worth addressing and returning to. The <a href=\"https://www.tickgit.com/browse?repo=github.com/torvalds/linux\">Linux codebase</a> has 4k+ of these types of comments, <a href=\"https://www.tickgit.com/browse?repo=github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes\">Kubernetes</a> has 2k+.</p> \n<p>If <a href=\"https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/65c137768abf696ee1c79a026d6df3a166dd8553/packages/react-interactions/events/src/dom/__tests__/Tap-test.internal.js#L331\">this</a> sort of thing is a familiar sight, you’ve no doubt seen or used them before:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"text language-text\">    // TODO: Get rid of this condition somehow. Perhaps with a dynamic version\n    // of the @gate pragma.\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"todosareeasy\">TODOs Are Easy</h3> \n<p>To-dos are easy to add and remove. You don’t need to leave your editor. They’re plaintext. You can include links to additional information. They’re flexible. You can even use emojis 😀✏️. You’re not constrained by the field requirements of an external ticketing system. You can be as thorough or succinct as you’d like in describing why you’re annotating an area of code.</p> \n<h3 id=\"nocontextswitching\">No Context Switching</h3> \n<p>To-dos are right next to the code they’re describing, which means you don’t lose the context of the codebase: the surrounding classes, functions, variables, etc. Using an external ticketing system requires you to either switch focus when trying to understand a ticket and the relevant pieces of code, or do a great deal of context-copying to help clarify your task.</p> \n<p>To-dos allow you to maintain your flow when writing code, and are often a lower mental burden than switching to and from tickets in an external system. To-dos, of course, can link back to an existing ticket for additional information if necessary.</p> \n<h3 id=\"trackablewithyourcode\">Trackable with Your Code</h3> \n<p>Since TODO comments are part of your code, they’re stored in version control. They can undergo code-review in your PRs. They have a history and can be attributed to authors, versions, and commits. This can enable project management aware reports about burndown, team responsibilities, tech debt, development efficiency, etc.</p> \n<h2 id=\"thecommandlinetool\">The Command-line Tool</h2> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://github.com/augmentable-dev/tickgit\">tickgit</a> command-line tool is an open-source project that scans a Git codebase for TODO comments. It runs a Git blame and outputs results with references to file paths and line numbers.</p> \n<p>It can be used to query ad-hoc for open TODO comments, and supports CSV output for consumption by other tools (spreadsheets, text processors, etc.).</p> \n<p>Here’s an example output:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594774842output-1024x420.png\" alt=\"example output\" width=\"1024\" height=\"420\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176664\" /></p> \n<p>The CLI is currently pretty simple, but with plans to improve to enable more use cases, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Customization of phrases to match (don’t match XXX but match <code>@TODO</code> in comments)</li> \n <li>Querying and filtering (show me all to-dos added this week, show me only mine, etc.)</li> \n <li>Aggregation queries count by author, average age by author, etc.</li> \n <li>A CI mode to fail with an error if certain criteria are met (no to-dos in certain branches, max 5 to-dos per author, etc.)</li> \n <li>Extract links and customized parsing of comments (extract an assignee, a due date, etc.)</li> \n</ul> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/never-forget-a-todo-comment-with-tickgit-your-repos-project-manager/?utm_source=rss\">Never Forget a TODO Comment with tickgit, Your Repo’s Project Manager</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=bapDbpDeEHc:Pt8N0doXifw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=bapDbpDeEHc:Pt8N0doXifw:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=bapDbpDeEHc:Pt8N0doXifw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=bapDbpDeEHc:Pt8N0doXifw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" 2020 23:00:54 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"6 Top JavaScript UI Frameworks &#038; Libraries for 2020","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176537","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/javascript-ui-frameworks/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"6 Top JavaScript UI Frameworks &amp; Libraries for 2020\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593783519library.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593783519library-300x225.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593783519library-768x576.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593783519library-1024x768.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><em>This article was created in partnership with <a href=\"https://www.sencha.com/\" rel=\"sponsored\">Sencha</a>. Thank you for supporting the partners who make SitePoint possible.</em></p> \n<p>JavaScript is the technology at the heart of today’s snappy and fast web apps. There are countless UI frameworks and libraries for building complex, reactive apps that scale well.</p> \n<p>Some will help you write more efficient, maintainable code. Or you need help designing a set of consistent, interoperable, and fast UI components. In almost any situation, you can find an option that does much of the heavy lifting for you. There’s no need to start from scratch and reinvent the wheel.</p> \n<p>The most popular JavaScript frameworks available present some common capabilities. In particular, they:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>can keep state and view synchronized</li> \n <li>offer routing functionality</li> \n <li>let developers build, reuse, and maintain user interface components…</li> \n <li>… that are efficient and fast to respond to user interaction.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The number of JS frameworks available is high and that number continues to grow. Take a look at these options. I’ve listed both stable, popular libraries and newer options for the curious.</p> \n<p>Let’s jump in with a sleek, enterprise-level JavaScript framework — Ext JS by Sencha.</p> \n<h2>1. Ext JS by Sencha</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sencha.com/products/extjs/\" rel=\"sponsored\"><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593782594Screenshot-Sencha-ExtJS.png\" alt=\"Sencha Ext JS\" width=\"1244\" height=\"700\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176543\" /></a></p> \n<p>Need to build a web app that handles large amounts of data, and need powerful, flexible front-end tools for displaying and working with it?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sencha.com/products/extjs/\" rel=\"sponsored\">Sencha Ext JS</a> is described as the…</p> \n<blockquote>\n <p>most comprehensive JavaScript framework for building data-intensive, cross-platform web and mobile applications for any modern device. Ext JS includes 140+ pre-integrated and tested high-performance UI components.</p>\n</blockquote> \n<p>Some of these components include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>a HTML5 calendar</li> \n <li>grids</li> \n <li>trees</li> \n <li>lists</li> \n <li>forms</li> \n <li>menus</li> \n <li>toolbars</li> \n <li>and much more</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Ext JS is a reliable, paid framework that comes with outstanding docs, tutorials, and <a href=\"https://www.sencha.com/support/\" rel=\"sponsored\">support packages</a>. <a href=\"https://www.sencha.com/blog/ext-js-performance-benchmarks/\" rel=\"sponsored\">Recent tests</a> showed that the Ext JS data grid was 300x faster than leading competitors. In fact, its Virtual Scrolling experience retrieves and shows large quantities of data in under a second.</p> \n<p>Advantages of Ext JS include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>quick, smooth development. Enjoy seamless integration between an enterprise framework and state-of-the-art components and tools.</li> \n <li>comprehensive set of secure components. You’ll never have to go out of the framework to find any missing widget or functionality.</li> \n <li>great design capabilities due to included integrated tools. Sencha Architect offers drag and drop capabilities. Sencha Stencils lets developers mock up, style, prototype and test UI concepts.</li> \n <li>awesome unit and end-to-end testing tools with <a href=\"https://www.sencha.com/products/test/\" rel=\"sponsored\">Sencha Test.</a></li> \n <li>a layout manager. Manage the display of data and content across different browsers and screen sizes. A responsive config system adapts the interface to device orientation and browser window sizes.</li> \n <li>easy to achieve accessibility compliance with the Ext JS ARIA package</li> \n <li>a robust data package that decouples the UI components from the data layer.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You can <a href=\"https://www.sencha.com/products/extjs/\" rel=\"sponsored\">find out more about Ext JS</a> on the framework’s site.</p> \n<h2>2. React</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593782999fb.jpg\" alt=\"Facebook\" width=\"1527\" height=\"755\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176544\" /></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://reactjs.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\">React</a> is enormously popular among front-end developers. It’s an open-source JavaScript library for building blazingly fast, interactive UIs. React was first created by Jordan Walke, a software engineer working for Facebook. It was first deployed on Facebook’s newsfeed in 2011, and on Instagram in 2012. It’s used by the likes of Netflix, Airbnb, Instagram, and the New York Times, to name a few.</p> \n<p>Reasons for choosing React to power your next project include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>React is quick to learn and use. It’s JavaScript with a small API.</li> \n <li>code components are stable and reusable. They’re a breeze to create and maintain using the API’s declarative syntax.</li> \n <li>A big company and a strong community support React.</li> \n <li>The library is stack agnostic, can also render on the server using Node.js, and on mobile apps with React Native.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>3. Angular</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593783142Angular.png\" alt=\"Angular\" width=\"1503\" height=\"813\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176545\" /><br /> <a href=\"https://angular.io/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Angular</a> is a free, open-source framework by Google that works for both desktop and mobile.</p> \n<p>There’s a learning curve, including getting familiar with TypeScript, a superset of JavaScript. Despite that, Angular remains a great framework to work with. Here are some of the reasons for using it:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>cross-platform – progressive web apps, native mobile apps, and desktop</li> \n <li>offers speed and performance</li> \n <li>has great features like filters, two-way data binding, directives, and more</li> \n <li>makes available awesome tooling for faster development</li> \n <li>has full support from Google and a strong community of developers behind it.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>For more details, don’t miss <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/angular-introduction/\"><em>Angular Introduction: What It Is, and Why You Should Use It</em></a> by <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/author/ibodrov\">Ilya Bodrov-Krukowski</a>.</p> \n<h2>4. Vue</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593783301Vue_js.png\" alt=\"Vue\" width=\"1503\" height=\"1015\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176546\" /><br /> <a href=\"https://vuejs.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Vue JS</a> is a free and open-source progressive JavaScript framework created by <a href=\"https://github.com/yyx990803/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Evan You</a>. It uses a template syntax (like Angular) and relies on a component-based architecture (like React).</p> \n<p>Here’s how Vue describes itself in its own <a href=\"https://github.com/vuejs/vue\" rel=\"nofollow\">GitHub repository page</a>:</p> \n<blockquote>\n <p>Vue (pronounced <code>/vjuː/</code>, like view) is a <strong>progressive framework</strong> for building user interfaces. It is designed from the ground up to be incrementally adoptable, and can easily scale between a library and a framework depending on different use cases. It consists of an approachable core library that focuses on the view layer only, and an ecosystem of supporting libraries that helps you tackle complexity in large Single-Page Applications.</p>\n</blockquote> \n<p>Here are some of Vue’s strongest points:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>developer-friendly. If you know the languages of the web (HTML, CSS and JavaScript), the Vue docs are all you need to start building right away.</li> \n <li>you can integrate it within a project progressively. It easily scales from a library to a full-fledged framework.</li> \n <li>small and comes with a super-fast virtual DOM.</li> \n <li>has an amazing community behind it, which makes it a stable framework to adopt.</li> \n <li>offers great documentation.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you’d like to delve deeper, read <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/vue-right-framework/\"><em>How to Tell If Vue.js Is the Right Framework for Your Next Project</em></a> by <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/author/kgawron\">Karolina Gawron</a>.</p> \n<h2>5. Ember</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593783359Ember_js_A_framework_for_ambitious_web_developers.png\" alt=\"Ember\" width=\"1483\" height=\"538\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176547\" /><br /> Released in December 2011 by <a href=\"https://yehudakatz.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Yehuda Katz</a> and <a href=\"https://tomdale.net/about-me/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Tom Dale</a>, <a href=\"https://emberjs.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Ember</a> is:</p> \n<blockquote>\n <p>A framework for ambitious web developers.</p>\n</blockquote> \n<p>Ember.js is a productive, battle-tested JavaScript framework for building modern web applications. It includes everything you need to build rich UIs that work on any device.</p> \n<p>This JavaScript framework is free, open-source, and has a strong community behind it. Here are some of the reasons why Ember is successful among developers:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>leverages the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_over_configuration\" rel=\"nofollow\">convention over configuration</a> approach championed by <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Heinemeier_Hansson\" rel=\"nofollow\">David Heinemeier Hansson.</a> It aims to lower the number of decisions that a developer has to make (without sacrificing flexibility).</li> \n <li>almost all you need to set up your app comes with Ember out of the box.</li> \n <li>backwards-compatible.</li> \n <li>quick to adopt the latest web standards and JavaScript features.</li> \n <li>offers great docs and resources.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>6. Svelte 3</h2> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593783451svelte.png\" alt=\"Svelte\" width=\"1503\" height=\"1015\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176548\" /><br /> Though it’s growing up quickly, <a href=\"https://svelte.dev/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Svelte 3</a> is the new kid on the frameworks block. <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Rich_Harris\" rel=\"nofollow\">Rich Harris</a> released Svelte in November 2016 as an open-source project. <a href=\"https://svelte.dev/blog/svelte-3-rethinking-reactivity\" rel=\"nofollow\"><strong>Version 3</strong></a> came out in April 2019 and was a complete overhaul.</p> \n<p>Svelte works differently from most frameworks listed so far. In particular:</p> \n<blockquote>\n <p>Whereas traditional frameworks like React and Vue do the bulk of their work in the <em>browser</em>, Svelte shifts that work into a <em>compile step</em> that happens when you build your app.</p>\n</blockquote> \n<p>Many frameworks use using techniques like virtual DOM diffing. Instead, Svelte surgically updates the DOM when the state of your app changes. Compiling code creates noticeable performance benefits.</p> \n<p>Svelte is quick for beginners to get started with. You can build components without lots of boilerplate code. Just use HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. The Svelte site features beginner-friendly resources. These include a tutorial, examples, and a detailed API for more seasoned Svelte devs. For help and support, you’re invited to join the dedicated <a href=\"https://discord.com/invite/yy75DKs\" rel=\"nofollow\">Discord server</a>.</p> \n<h2>Conclusion</h2> \n<p>Choosing a framework is always a circumstancial decision. It involves paying attention to what your specific project’s challenges are. It also means considering your team’s experience and preferences.</p> \n<p>For example, if your team needs to build data-intensive, enterprise-level projects that need a secure, reliable, and comprehensive framework with a large set of components that work well with each other, <a href=\"https://www.sencha.com/products/extjs/\" rel=\"sponsored\">Ext JS by Sencha</a> is a great option. You’ll never have to go out of the framework to search for components. For projects that start small but need flexibility and scaling capabilities, Vue could work well. And if your front-end team has extensive React expertise, going with React could be your best bet.</p> \n<p>Do you have any other JS UI frameworks or library you’d like to suggest? Which ones have you found yourself using the most as a developer? Let us know on Twitter.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/javascript-ui-frameworks/?utm_source=rss\">6 Top JavaScript UI Frameworks &amp; Libraries for 2020</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a
