3_4a1a591f978ba3e3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483259},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Keep Working Remotely in a Post-COVID-19 World","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176412","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/post-covid-19-remote-work/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Keep Working Remotely in a Post-COVID-19 World\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592446286remote-work-covid-19.png\" alt=\"How To Keep Working Remotely in a post-COVID-19 World\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592446286remote-work-covid-19-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592446286remote-work-covid-19.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Though the COVID-19 pandemic is still far from over, many companies and employees are already looking to the post-COVID world. For many organizations, the enforced move to remote working over the past few months has presented significant challenges.</strong></p> \n<p>On the other hand, there are many employees who, despite being reticent to move to remote working at the beginning of the pandemic, are now finding that remote work actually suits them rather well.</p> \n<p>If you fall into this category, you might be wondering how you can continue to work from home after the current crisis ends. Many of the strategies you can deploy to achieve this are, in fact, similar to those that make for effective remote working in the first place: ensuring <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/10-tips-for-effective-collaboration-in-remote-teams/\">effective collaboration in remote teams</a>, and making sure that you set yourself up <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/remote-work-tips-tricks-and-best-practices-for-success/\">for success with remote work</a>, to name a couple things.</p> \n<p>Nevertheless, your employer might be hesitant to let you continue to work remotely after the pandemic is over. If you don’t want to move back to the office, you’ll find some tips in this article on how to convince your boss to let you continue working from home.</p> \n<h2 id=\"thebenefitsofremoteworking\">The Benefits of Remote Working</h2> \n<p>If you don’t want to move back to your office in the next few months, you’re not alone. In fact, <a href=\"https://journal.getabstract.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/ga_remote_survey_2020_compressed.pdf\">nearly 43% of full-time American employees</a> say they want to work remotely more often even after the economy has reopened. One of the biggest reasons for this is the time that the average tech worker saves in commuting. The average American <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/10/07/nine-days-road-average-commute-time-reached-new-record-last-year/\">spent roughly 27 minutes</a> on their one-way commute to the office in 2018, which equates to more than 200 hours spent commuting per year.</p> \n<p>For tech companies, there are other benefits of remote working. Many software development firms are inherently multi-national, and co-ordinating employees across the globe can actually be easier if they’re working from home. As we’ve previously pointed out, <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-real-future-of-remote-work-is-asynchronous/\">the future of remote work is asynchronous</a>. Research has also found that the kind of creativity and flexibility that tech firms value is actually <a href=\"https://www.outsite.co/blog/how-remote-work-enhances-creativity-productivity\">increased by remote working</a> rather than decreased.</p> \n<p>Despite these findings, many organizations are still hesitant to let their employees work from home — at least once the global health crisis is over. So how can you continue to work from home after all this is over?</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/post-covid-19-remote-work/?utm_source=rss\">How to Keep Working Remotely in a Post-COVID-19 World</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Learn Regex: A Beginner&#8217;s Guide","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176493","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/learn-regex/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Learn Regex: A Beginner’s Guide\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593697150regex.png\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593697150regex-300x158.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593697150regex-768x404.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593697150regex-1024x539.png 1024w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593697150regex.png 1432w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>In this guide, you’ll learn regex, or regular expression syntax. By the end, you’ll be able to apply regex solutions in most scenarios that call for it in your web development work.</strong></p> \n<p>Regular expressions have many uses cases, which include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>form input validation</li> \n <li>web scraping</li> \n <li>search and replace</li> \n <li>filtering for information in massive text files such as logs</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Regular expressions, or <strong>regex</strong> as they’re commonly called, look complicated and intimidating for new users. Take a look at this example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"text language-text\">/^[a-zA-Z0-9.!#$%&amp;’*+/=?^_`{|}~-]+@[a-zA-Z0-9-]+(?:\\.[a-zA-Z0-9-]+)*$/\n</code></pre> \n<p>It just look like garbled text. But don’t despair, there’s method behind this madness.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/regular_expressions.png\" alt=\"xkcd.com/208\" /></p> \n<p><small><em>Credit: <a href=\"https://xkcd.com/208/\">xkcd</a></em></small></p> \n<p>I’ll show you how to master regular expressions in no time. First, let’s clarify the terminology used in this guide:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>pattern</strong>: regular expression pattern</li> \n <li><strong>string</strong>: test string used to match the pattern</li> \n <li><strong>digit</strong>: 0-9</li> \n <li><strong>letter</strong>: a-z, A-Z</li> \n <li><strong>symbol</strong>: !$%^&amp;*()_+|~-=`{}[]:”;'&lt;&gt;?,./</li> \n <li><strong>space</strong>: single white space, tab</li> \n <li><strong>character</strong>: refers to a letter, digit or symbol</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"basics\">Basics</h2> \n<p>To learn regex quickly with this guide, visit <a href=\"https://regex101.com/\">Regex101</a>, where you can build regex patterns and test them against strings (text) that you supply.</p> \n<p>When you open the site, you’ll need to select the <strong>JavaScript</strong> flavor, as that’s what we’ll be using for this guide. (Regex syntax is mostly the same for all languages, but there are some minor differences.)</p> \n<p>Next, you need to disable the <code>global</code> and <code>multi line</code> flags in Regex101. We’ll cover them in the next section. For now, we’ll look at the simplest form of regular expression we can build. Input the following:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/learn-regex/?utm_source=rss\">Learn Regex: A Beginner’s Guide</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=c4DByOl0ywk:UstbKCRGAak:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=c4DByOl0ywk:UstbKCRGAak:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=c4DByOl0ywk:UstbKCRGAak:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/c4DByOl0ywk\" +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593697150regex.png","linkMd5":"4740b751aff872acd443a394caeef880","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn29@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-29-245_f22669b0ba36e7ed.webp","destWidth":1432,"destHeight":754,"sourceBytes":213316,"destBytes":213316,"author":"Michael Wanyoike","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1593697150regex.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn29@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-29-245_f22669b0ba36e7ed.webp","https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/regular_expressions.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn64@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-43-421_31588b14338bffcb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=c4DByOl0ywk:UstbKCRGAak:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn21@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-37-897_420868b828705214.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/c4DByOl0ywk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn98@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-35-097_0e4fbf2e3c0f333f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483260},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Build a Command Line Weather App in Deno","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=177064","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-build-command-line-weather-app/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Build a Command Line Weather App in Deno\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597028804deno-runtime.png\" alt=\"Build a Terminal Weather App in Deno\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597028804deno-runtime-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597028804deno-runtime.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>If you’ve been following along with our <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-introduction/\">introductory</a> <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/node-vs-deno/\">articles</a> on Deno, you’re probably interested in having a go at writing your first program. In this article, we’re going to walk through installing the Deno runtime, and creating a command-line weather program that will take a city name as an argument and return the weather forecast for the next 24 hours.</strong></p> \n<p>To write code for Deno, I’d highly recommend <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">Visual Studio Code</a> with the official <a href=\"https://github.com/denoland/vscode_deno\">Deno plugin</a>. To make things a little more interesting, we’re going to be writing the app in TypeScript.</p> \n<h2 id=\"installingdeno\">Installing Deno</h2> \n<p>Firstly, let’s get Deno installed locally so we can begin writing our script. The process is straightforward, as there are installer scripts for all three major operating systems.</p> \n<h3 id=\"windows\">Windows</h3> \n<p>On windows, you can install Deno from PowerShell:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">iwr https://deno.land/x/install/install.ps1 -useb | iex\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"linux\">Linux</h3> \n<p>From the Linux terminal, you can use the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">curl -fsSL https://deno.land/x/install/install.sh |  sh\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"macos\">macOS</h3> \n<p>On a Mac, Deno can be installed with Brew:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">brew install deno\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"afterinstalling\">After installing</h3> \n<p>Once the install process is finished, you can check that Deno has been correctly installed by running the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">deno --version\n</code></pre> \n<p>You should now see something similar to this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">deno 1.2.0\nv8 8.5.216\ntypescript 3.9.2\n</code></pre> \n<p>Let’s create a folder for our new project (inside your home folder, or wherever you like to keep your coding projects) and add an <code>index.ts</code> file:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mkdir weather-app\ncd weather-app\ncode index.ts\n</code></pre> \n<p><em>Note: as I mentioned above, I’m using VS Code for this tutorial. If you’re using a different editor, replace the last line above.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"gettinguserinput\">Getting User Input</h2> \n<p>Our program is going to retrieve the weather forecast for a given city, so we’ll need to accept the city name as an argument when the program is run. Arguments supplied to a Deno script are available as <code>Deno.args</code>. Let’s log this variable out to the console to see how it works:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"ts language-ts\">console.log(Deno.args);\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now run the script, with the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">deno run index.ts --city London\n</code></pre> \n<p>You should see the following output:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">[ \"--city\", \"London\" ]\n</code></pre> \n<p>Although we could parse this argument array ourselves, <a href=\"https://deno.land/std\">Deno’s standard library</a> includes a module called <a href=\"https://deno.land/std/flags\">flags</a> that will take care of this for us. To use it, all we have to do is add an import statement to the top of our file:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"ts language-ts\">import { parse } from  \"https://deno.land/std@0.61.0/flags/mod.ts\";\n</code></pre> \n<p><em>Note: the examples in the docs for standard library modules will give you an unversioned URL (such as <code>https://deno.land/std/flags/mod.ts</code>), which will always point to the latest version of the code. It’s good practice to specify a version in your imports, to ensure your program isn’t broken by future updates.</em>*</p> \n<p>Let’s use the imported function to parse the arguments array into something more useful:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"ts language-ts\">const args = parse(Deno.args);\n</code></pre> \n<p>We’ll also change the script to log out our new <code>args</code> variable, to see what that looks like. So now your code should look like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"ts language-ts\">import { parse } from  \"https://deno.land/std@0.61.0/flags/mod.ts\";\n\nconst args = parse(Deno.args);\n\nconsole.log(args);\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now, if you run the script with the same argument as before, you should see the following output:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">Download https://deno.land/std@0.61.0/flags/mod.ts\nDownload https://deno.land/std@0.61.0/_util/assert.ts\nCheck file:///home/njacques/code/weather-app/index.ts\n{ _: [], city: \"London\" }\n</code></pre> \n<p>Whenever Deno runs a script, it checks for new import statements. Any remotely hosted imports are downloaded, compiled, and cached for future use. The <code>parse</code> function has provided us with an object, which has a <code>city</code> property containing our input.</p> \n<p><em>Note: if you need to re-download the imports for a script for any reason, you can run <code>deno cache --reload index.ts</code>.</em></p> \n<p>We should also add a check for the <code>city</code> argument, and quit the program with an error message if it’s not supplied:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"ts language-ts\">if (args.city === undefined) {\n    console.error(\"No city supplied\");\n    Deno.exit();\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-build-command-line-weather-app/?utm_source=rss\">Build a Command Line Weather App in Deno</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=klaI9EOzrnU:G0TeSY_ZqsY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=klaI9EOzrnU:G0TeSY_ZqsY:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=klaI9EOzrnU:G0TeSY_ZqsY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/klaI9EOzrnU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 09 Aug 2020 21:54:16 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597028804deno-runtime.png","linkMd5":"731bb5ef4f7a9811f29bb451f9511360","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn65@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-26-997_c9be10a526f5dc36.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":6618,"destBytes":6618,"author":"Nilson Jacques","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597028804deno-runtime.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn65@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-26-997_c9be10a526f5dc36.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=klaI9EOzrnU:G0TeSY_ZqsY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn80@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-40-704_eb14a5f70a4731ce.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/klaI9EOzrnU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-40-673_b0ef7706a9ea2703.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483247},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Use jQuery&#8217;s ajax() Function for Asynchronous HTTP Requests","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=88556","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/use-jquerys-ajax-function/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Use jQuery’s ajax() Function for Asynchronous HTTP Requests\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1588210620jquery-ajax.png\" alt=\"How to Use jQuery's $.ajax() for Asynchronous HTTP Requests\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1588210620jquery-ajax-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1588210620jquery-ajax.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Nowadays, developers tend to move away from <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://jquery.com/\">jQuery</a> and its handy methods for DOM manipulation and Ajax requests that made it hugely popular. Regarding the Ajax requests, the <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API\">Fetch API</a>, or alternatively, the <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://github.com/axios/axios\">Axios library</a>, are now more popular tools for performing asynchronous operations. That said, jQuery is still very much alive and <a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://trends.builtwith.com/javascript/jQuery\">powers almost 70,000 websites</a> worldwide. This means that knowing how to use jQuery is still valuable in the day-to-day work of developers, like supporting legacy codebases or maintaining projects that use jQuery as an important dependency.</strong></p> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/javascript/ajax-javascript/\">Ajax</a> is a technology that allows developers to make asynchronous HTTP requests without the need for a full page refresh. To make the process less cumbersome than it would be in pure JavaScript, devs have been using the jQuery library for years. In my article <a href=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/introduction-jquery-shorthand-ajax-methods\">An Introduction to jQuery’s Shorthand Ajax Methods</a>, I discussed some of jQuery’s most-used Ajax shorthand methods: <code>$.get()</code>, <code>$.post()</code>, and <code>$.load()</code>. They are convenient methods for making Ajax requests in a few lines of code.</p> \n<p>Sometimes, we need more control over the Ajax calls we want to make. For example, we want to specify what should happen in case an Ajax call fails or we need to perform an Ajax request but its result is only needed if retrieved within a certain amount of time. In such situations, we can rely on another function provided by jQuery, called <code>$.ajax()</code>, that is the topic of this tutorial.</p> \n<h2 id=\"thedajaxfunction\">The <code>$.ajax()</code> Function</h2> \n<p>The jQuery <a href=\"https://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajax/\"><code>$.ajax()</code></a> function is used to perform an asynchronous HTTP request. It was added to the library a long time ago, existing since version 1.0. The <code>$.ajax()</code> function is what every function discussed in the previously mentioned article calls behind the scene using a preset configuration. The signatures of this function are shown below:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">$.ajax(url[, settings])\n$.ajax([settings])\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <code>url</code> parameter is a string containing the URL you want to reach with the Ajax call, while <code>settings</code> is an object literal containing the configuration for the Ajax request.</p> \n<p>In its first form, this function performs an Ajax request using the <code>url</code> parameter and the options specified in <code>settings</code>. In the second form, the URL is specified in the <code>settings</code> parameter, or can be omitted, in which case the request is made to the current page.</p> \n<p>The list of the options accepted by this function, described in the next section, is very long, so I’ll keep their description short. In case you want to study their meaning in depth, you can refer to the official documentation of <code>$.ajax()</code>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"thesettingsparameter\">The <code>settings</code> Parameter</h3> \n<p>There are a lot of different options you can specify to bend <code>$.ajax()</code> to your needs. In the list below you can find their names and their description sorted in alphabetic order:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><code>accepts</code>: The content type sent in the request header that tells the server what kind of response it will accept in return.</li> \n <li><code>async</code>: Set this option to <code>false</code> to perform a synchronous request.</li> \n <li><code>beforeSend</code>: A pre-request callback function that can be used to modify the <code>jqXHR</code> object before it is sent.</li> \n <li><code>cache</code>: Set this option to <code>false</code> to force requested pages not to be cached by the browser.</li> \n <li><code>complete</code>: A function to be called when the request finishes (after <code>success</code> and <code>error</code> callbacks are executed).</li> \n <li><code>contents</code>: An object that determines how the library will parse the response.</li> \n <li><code>contentType</code>: The content type of the data sent to the server.</li> \n <li><code>context</code>: An object to use as the context (<code>this</code>) of all Ajax-related callbacks.</li> \n <li><code>converters</code>: An object containing dataType-to-dataType converters.</li> \n <li><code>crossDomain</code>: Set this property to <code>true</code> to force a cross-domain request (such as JSONP) on the same domain.</li> \n <li><code>data</code>: The data to send to the server when performing the Ajax request.</li> \n <li><code>dataFilter</code>: A function to be used to handle the raw response data of XMLHttpRequest.</li> \n <li><code>dataType</code>: The type of data expected back from the server.</li> \n <li><code>error</code>: A function to be called if the request fails.</li> \n <li><code>global</code>: Whether to trigger global Ajax event handlers for this request.</li> \n <li><code>headers</code>: An object of additional headers to send to the server.</li> \n <li><code>ifModified</code>: Set this option to <code>true</code> if you want to force the request to be successful only if the response has changed since the last request.</li> \n <li><code>isLocal</code>: Set this option to <code>true</code> if you want to force jQuery to recognize the current environment as “local”.</li> \n <li><code>jsonp</code>: A string to override the callback function name in a JSONP request.</li> \n <li><code>jsonpCallback</code>: Specifies the callback function name for a JSONP request.</li> \n <li><code>mimeType</code>: A string that specifies the mime type to override the XHR mime type.</li> \n <li><code>password</code>: A password to be used with XMLHttpRequest in response to an HTTP access authentication request.</li> \n <li><code>processData</code>: Set this option to <code>false</code> if you don’t want the data passed in to the <code>data</code> option (if not a string already) to be processed and transformed into a query string.</li> \n <li><code>scriptAttrs</code>: Defines an object with additional attributes to be used in a “script” or “jsonp” request.</li> \n <li><code>scriptCharset</code>: Sets the charset attribute on the script tag used in the request but only applies when the “script” transport is used.</li> \n <li><code>statusCode</code>: An object of numeric HTTP codes and functions to be called when the response has the corresponding code.</li> \n <li><code>success</code>: A function to be called if the request succeeds.</li> \n <li><code>timeout</code>: A number that specifies a timeout (in milliseconds) for the request.</li> \n <li><code>traditional</code>: Set this to <code>true</code> if you wish to use the traditional style of param serialization.</li> \n <li><code>type</code>: The type of request to make, which can be either “POST” or “GET”.</li> \n <li><code>url</code>: A string containing the URL to which the request is sent.</li> \n <li><code>username</code>: A username to be used with XMLHttpRequest in response to an HTTP access authentication request.</li> \n <li><code>xhr</code>: A callback for creating the XMLHttpRequest object.</li> \n <li><code>xhrFields</code>: An object to set on the native XHR object.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>That’s a pretty long list, isn’t it? Well, as a developer, you probably stopped reading this list at the fifth or sixth element I guess, but that’s fine. The next section will be more exciting, because we’ll put the <code>$.ajax()</code> function and some of these options into action.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/use-jquerys-ajax-function/?utm_source=rss\">How to Use jQuery’s ajax() Function for Asynchronous HTTP Requests</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=zHCvd46uyYo:ZOyVgxDbal8:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=zHCvd46uyYo:ZOyVgxDbal8:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img De Rosa","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1588210620jquery-ajax.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn26@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-26-615_d634d10b0e87dbb5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=zHCvd46uyYo:ZOyVgxDbal8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn70@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-36-654_c1738aeea59e0f83.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/zHCvd46uyYo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn82@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-35-184_3d9eeee7118a3c89.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483273},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Build and Structure a Node.js MVC Application","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=149088","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/node-js-mvc-application/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Build and Structure a Node.js MVC Application\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/1487098409MVC_app_B-01.png\" alt=\"Inside the monitor a puppet manipulates on-screen windows and popups\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/1487098409MVC_app_B-01-300x167.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/1487098409MVC_app_B-01-768x427.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/1487098409MVC_app_B-01.png 900w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>In a non-trivial application, the architecture is as important as the quality of the code itself. We can have well-written pieces of code, but if we don’t have good organization, we’ll have a hard time as the complexity increases. There’s no need to wait until the project is half-way done to start thinking about the architecture; the best time is before starting, using our goals as beacons for our choices.</strong></p> \n<p>Node.js doesn’t have a de facto framework with strong opinions on architecture and code organization in the same way that Ruby has the Rails framework, for example. As such, it can be difficult to get started with building full web applications with Node.</p> \n<p>In this tutorial, we’re going to build the basic functionality of a note-taking app using the MVC architecture. To accomplish this, we’re going to employ the <a href=\"https://hapi.dev/\">Hapi.js</a> framework for <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/\">Node.js</a> and <a href=\"http://www.sqlite.org/\">SQLite</a> as a database, using <a href=\"https://sequelize.org/v3/\">Sequelize.js</a>, plus other small utilities, to speed up our development. We’re going to build the views using <a href=\"https://pugjs.org/api/getting-started.html\">Pug</a>, the templating language.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatismvc\">What is MVC?</h2> \n<p>Model-View-Controller (or MVC) is probably one of the most popular architectures for applications. As with a lot of other <a href=\"https://youtu.be/NdSD07U5uBs?t=29m2s\">cool things in computer history</a>, the MVC model was conceived at <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PARC_(company)\">PARC</a> for the Smalltalk language as a solution to the problem of organizing applications with graphical user interfaces. It was created for desktop applications, but since then, the idea has been adapted to other mediums including the Web.</p> \n<p>We can describe the MVC architecture in simple terms:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Model</strong>: the part of our application that will deal with the database or any data-related functionality.</li> \n <li><strong>View</strong>: everything the user will see — basically, the pages that we’re going to send to the client.</li> \n <li><strong>Controller</strong>: the logic of our site, and the glue between models and views. Here we call our models to get the data, then we put that data on our views to be sent to the users.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Our application will allow us to create, view, edit and delete plain-text notes. It won’t have other functionality, but because we’ll have a solid architecture already defined we won’t have a lot of trouble adding things later.</p> \n<p>This tutorial assumes you have a recent version of Node installed on your machine. If this isn’t the case, please consult our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">tutorial on getting up and running with Node</a>.</p> \n<p>You can check out the final application in the <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/notes-board\">accompanying GitHub repository</a>, so you get a general overview of the application structure.</p> \n<h2 id=\"layingoutthefoundation\">Laying out the Foundation</h2> \n<p>The first step when building any Node.js application is to create a <code>package.json</code> file, which is going to contain all of our dependencies and scripts. Instead of creating this file manually, npm can do the job for us using the <code>init</code> command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">mkdir notes-board\ncd notes-board\nnpm init -y\n</code></pre> \n<p>After the process is complete, we’ll have a <code>package.json</code> file ready to use.</p> \n<p><em>Note: if you’re not familiar with these commands, checkout our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/beginners-guide-node-package-manager/\">Beginner’s Guide to npm</a>.</em></p> \n<p>We’re going to proceed to install Hapi.js — the framework of choice for this tutorial. It provides a good balance between simplicity, stability and features that will work well for our use case (although there are other options that would also work just fine).</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install @hapi/hapi@18.4.0\n</code></pre> \n<p>This command will download Hapi.js and add it to our <code>package.json</code> file as a dependency.</p> \n<p><em>Note: We’ve specified v18.4.0 of Hapi.js, as it’s compatible with Node versions 8, 10, and 12. If you’re using Node 12, you can opt to install the latest version (Hapi v19.1.0).</em></p> \n<p>Now we can create our entry file — the web server that will start everything. Go ahead and create a <code>server.js</code> file in your application directory and add the following code to it:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">\"use strict\";\n\nconst Hapi = require(\"@hapi/hapi\");\nconst Settings = require(\"./settings\");\n\nconst init = async () =&gt; {\n  const server = new Hapi.Server({ port: Settings.port });\n\n  server.route({\n    method: \"GET\",\n    path: \"/\",\n    handler: (request, h) =&gt; {\n      return \"Hello, world!\";\n    }\n  });\n\n  await server.start();\n  console.log(`Server running at: ${server.info.uri}`);\n};\n\nprocess.on(\"unhandledRejection\", err =&gt; {\n  console.log(err);\n  process.exit(1);\n});\n\ninit();\n</code></pre> \n<p>This is going to be the foundation of our application.</p> \n<p>First, we indicate that we’re going to use <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Strict_mode\">strict mode</a>, which is a <a href=\"https://hapi.dev/policies/styleguide/#strict-mode\">common practice</a> when using the Hapi.js framework.</p> \n<p>Next, we include our dependencies and instantiate a new server object where we set the connection port to <code>3000</code> (the port can be any number <a href=\"http://www.iana.org/assignments/service-names-port-numbers/service-names-port-numbers.xml\">above 1023 and below 65535</a>).</p> \n<p>Our first route for our server will work as a test to see if everything is working, so a “Hello, world!” message is enough for us. In each route, we have to define the HTTP method and path (URL) that it will respond to, and a handler, which is a function that will process the HTTP request. The handler function can take two arguments: <code>request</code> and <code>h</code>. The first one contains information about the HTTP call, and the second will provide us with methods to handle our response to that call.</p> \n<p>Finally, we start our server with the <code>server.start()</code> method.</p> \n<h2 id=\"storingoursettings\">Storing Our Settings</h2> \n<p>It’s good practice to store our configuration variables in a dedicated file. This file exports a JSON object containing our data, where each key is assigned from an environment variable — but without forgetting a fallback value.</p> \n<p>In this file, we can also have different settings depending on our environment (such as development or production). For example, we can have an in-memory instance of SQLite for development purposes, but a real SQLite database file on production.</p> \n<p>Selecting the settings depending on the current environment is quite simple. Since we also have an <code>env</code> variable in our file which will contain either <code>development</code> or <code>production</code>, we can do something like the following to get the database settings:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const dbSettings = Settings[Settings.env].db;\n</code></pre> \n<p>So <code>dbSettings</code> will contain the setting of an in-memory database when the <code>env</code> variable is <code>development</code>, or will contain the path of a database file when the <code>env</code> variable is <code>production</code>.</p> \n<p>Also, we can add support for a <code>.env</code> file, where we can store our environment variables locally for development purposes. This is accomplished using a package like <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/dotenv\">dotenv</a> for Node.js, which will read a <code>.env</code> file from the root of our project and automatically add the found values to the environment.</p> \n<p><em>Note: if you decide to also use a <code>.env</code> file, make sure you install the package with <code>npm install dotenv</code> and add it to <code>.gitignore</code> so you don’t publish any sensitive information.</em></p> \n<p>Our <code>settings.js</code> file will look like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// This will load our .env file and add the values to process.env,\n// IMPORTANT: Omit this line if you don't want to use this functionality\nrequire(\"dotenv\").config({ silent: true });\n\nmodule.exports = {\n  port: process.env.PORT || 3000,\n  env: process.env.NODE_ENV || \"development\",\n\n  // Environment-dependent settings\n  development: {\n    db: {\n      dialect: \"sqlite\",\n      storage: \":memory:\"\n    }\n  },\n  production: {\n    db: {\n      dialect: \"sqlite\",\n      storage: \"db/database.sqlite\"\n    }\n  }\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now we can start our application by executing the following command and navigating to <a href=\"http://localhost:3000\">http://localhost:3000</a> in our web browser:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">node server.js\n</code></pre> \n<p><em>Note: this project was tested on Node v12.15.0. If you get any errors, ensure you have an updated installation.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"definingtheroutes\">Defining the Routes</h2> \n<p>The definition of routes gives us an overview of the functionality supported by our application. To create our additional routes, we just have to replicate the structure of the route that we already have in our <code>server.js</code> file, changing the content of each one.</p> \n<p>Let’s start by creating a new directory called <code>lib</code> in our project. Here we’re going to include all the JS components.</p> \n<p>Inside <code>lib</code>, let’s create a <code>routes.js</code> file and add the following content:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">\"use strict\";\nconst Path = require(\"path\");\n\nmodule.exports = [\n  // we’re going to define our routes here\n];\n</code></pre> \n<p>In this file, we’ll export an array of objects that contain each route of our application. To define the first route, add the following object to the array:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  method: \"GET\",\n  path: \"/\",\n  handler: (request, h) =&gt; {\n    return \"All the notes will appear here\";\n  },\n  config: {\n    description: \"Gets all the notes available\"\n  }\n},\n</code></pre> \n<p>Our first route is for the home page (<code>/</code>), and since it will only return information, we assign it a <code>GET</code> method. For now, it will only give us the message “All the notes will appear here”, which we’re going to change later for a controller function. The <code>description</code> field in the <code>config</code> section is only for documentation purposes.</p> \n<p>Then, we create the four routes for our notes under the <code>/note/</code> path. Since we’re building a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Create,_read,_update_and_delete\">CRUD</a> application, we’ll need one route for each action with the corresponding <a href=\"http://www.w3schools.com/tags/ref_httpmethods.asp\">HTTP methods</a>.</p> \n<p>Add the following definitions next to the previous route:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  method: \"POST\",\n  path: \"/note\",\n  handler: (request, h) =&gt; {\n    return \"New note\";\n  },\n  config: {\n    description: \"Adds a new note\"\n  }\n},\n{\n  method: \"GET\",\n  path: \"/note/{slug}\",\n  handler: (request, h) =&gt; {\n    return \"This is a note\";\n  },\n  config: {\n    description: \"Gets the content of a note\"\n  }\n},\n{\n  method: \"PUT\",\n  path: \"/note/{slug}\",\n  handler: (request, h) =&gt; {\n    return \"Edit a note\";\n  },\n  config: {\n    description: \"Updates the selected note\"\n  }\n},\n{\n  method: \"GET\",\n  path: \"/note/{slug}/delete\",\n  handler: (request, h) =&gt; {\n    return \"This note no longer exists\";\n  },\n  config: {\n    description: \"Deletes the selected note\"\n  }\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>We’ve done the same as in the previous route definition, but this time we’ve changed the method to match the action we want to execute.</p> \n<p>The only exception is the delete route. In this case, we’re going to define it with the <code>GET</code> method rather than <code>DELETE</code> and add an extra <code>/delete</code> in the path. This way, we can call the delete action just by visiting the corresponding URL.</p> \n<p><em>Note: if you plan to implement a strict REST interface, then you would have to use the <code>DELETE</code> method and remove the <code>/delete</code> part of the path.</em></p> \n<p>We can name parameters in the path by surrounding the word in curly braces. Since we’re going to identify notes by a slug, we add <code>{slug}</code> to each path, with the exception of the <code>POST</code> route; we don’t need it there because we’re not going to interact with a specific note, but to create one.</p> \n<p>You can read more about Hapi.js routes on the <a href=\"https://hapi.dev/tutorials/routing/?lang=en_US\">official documentation</a>.</p> \n<p>Now, we have to add our new routes to the <code>server.js</code> file. Let’s import the routes file at the top of the file:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const Routes = require(\"./lib/routes\");\n</code></pre> \n<p>Then let’s replace our current test route with the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">server.route(Routes);\n</code></pre> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/node-js-mvc-application/?utm_source=rss\">How to Build and Structure a Node.js MVC Application</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VCo5yufWJg0:tE0xud6DDCA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VCo5yufWJg0:tE0xud6DDCA:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VCo5yufWJg0:tE0xud6DDCA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=VCo5yufWJg0:tE0xud6DDCA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/VCo5yufWJg0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 22 Mar 2020 13:30:30 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/1487098409MVC_app_B-01.png","linkMd5":"f9b35cedfa5c57876075f338a347cad8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn70@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-25-522_7cff6e860e4d64d2.webp","destWidth":900,"destHeight":500,"sourceBytes":10668,"destBytes":10668,"author":"James Kolce","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/1487098409MVC_app_B-01.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn70@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-25-522_7cff6e860e4d64d2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=VCo5yufWJg0:tE0xud6DDCA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn85@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-36-642_885fa5a0d46f0d91.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/VCo5yufWJg0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn11@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-39-328_d8a8f3f0381d95ea.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483289},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"20 Essential React Tools for 2020","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175472","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/essential-react-tools/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"20 Essential React Tools for 2020\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584060844react-tools.png\" alt=\"20 Essential React Tools for 2020\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584060844react-tools-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584060844react-tools.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>The React ecosystem has evolved into a growing list of dev tools and libraries. The plethora of tools is a true testament to its popularity. For devs, it can be a dizzying exercise to navigate this maze that changes at neck-breaking speed. To help navigate your course, below is a list of essential React tools for 2020.</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"hooks\">Hooks</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://reactjs.org/docs/hooks-intro.html\">reactjs.org/docs/hooks-intro.html</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/facebook/react/tree/v16.8.0\">github.com/facebook/react</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 140,000+</li> \n <li>developer: Facebook</li> \n <li>version: 16.8</li> \n <li>contributors: 1,300+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Hooks are a new addition to React as of version 16.8. They unlock useful features in classless components. With Hooks, React no longer needs lifecycle methods such as <code>componentDidMount</code> to manage state. This encourages separation of concerns because components are not managing their own state. Putting a lot of state management inside class components blows up complexity. This makes stateful components harder to maintain. Hooks attempt to alleviate this problem by providing key features.</p> \n<p>The following basic Hooks are available:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>useState: for mutating state in a classless component without lifecycle methods</li> \n <li>useEffect: for executing functions post-render, useful for firing Ajax requests</li> \n <li>useContext: for switching component context data, even outside component props</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>mitigates state management complexity</li> \n <li>supports functional components</li> \n <li>encourages separation of concerns</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>context data switching can exponentiate cognitive load</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"functionalcomponents\">Functional Components</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://reactjs.org\">reactjs.org</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/facebook/react/tree/v16.12.0\">github.com/facebook/react</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 140,000+</li> \n <li>developer: Facebook</li> \n <li>current version: 16.12</li> \n <li>contributors: 1,300+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Functional components are a declarative way to create JSX markup without class components. They embrace the functional paradigm because they don’t manage state in lifecycle methods. This emphasizes focus on the UI markup without much logic. Because the component relies on props it becomes easier to test. Props have a <em>one-to-one</em> relationship with the rendered output.</p> \n<p>This is what a functional component looks like in React:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const SimpleComponent = ({isInit, data}) =&gt;\n&lt;&gt;\n  {useEffect(() =&gt; {!isInt &amp;&amp; loadAjaxData()})}\n  {data}\n&lt;/&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>focuses on the UI only</li> \n <li>testable component</li> \n <li>less cognitive load when thinking about the component</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>no lifecycle methods</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"createreactapp\">Create React App</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://create-react-app.dev/\">create-react-app.dev</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app\">github.com/facebook/create-react-app</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 76,000+</li> \n <li>developer: Facebook</li> \n <li>current version: 3.4</li> \n <li>contributors: 700+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The quintessential tool to fire up a new React project. This manages all React dependencies via a single npm package. No more dealing with Babel, webpack, and whatnot. The entire dependency tool chain gets upgraded with <code>react-scripts</code> in <code>package.json</code>. There’s a way to integrate Create React App with any server-side rendering tool out there. The tool outputs <code>index.html</code> and static assets in the <code>public</code> folder. This public folder is the touch point where static assets are ready for integration.</p> \n<p>It’s easy to get started:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"shell language-shell\">npx create-react-app my-killer-app\n</code></pre> \n<p>And it’s even easier to upgrade later:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"shell language-shell\">npm i react-scripts@latest\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>easy to get started</li> \n <li>easy to upgrade</li> \n <li>single meta-dependency</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>no server-side rendering, but allows for integration</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"proxyserver\">Proxy Server</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://create-react-app.dev/docs/proxying-api-requests-in-development\">create-react-app.dev/docs/proxying-api-requests-in-development</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/tree/v0.2.3\">github.com/facebook/create-react-app</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 76,000+</li> \n <li>developer: Facebook</li> \n <li>version: 0.2.3</li> \n <li>contributors: 700+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Starting from version <code>react-scripts@0.2.3</code> or higher, it’s possible to proxy API requests. This allows the back-end API and local Create React App project to co-exist. From the client side, making a request to <code>/my-killer-api/get-data</code> routes the request through the proxy server. This seamless integration works both in local dev and post-build. If local dev runs on port <code>localhost:3000</code>, then API requests go through the proxy server. Once you deploy static assets, then it goes through whatever back end hosts these assets.</p> \n<p>To set a proxy server in <code>package.json</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">\"proxy\": \"http://localhost/my-killer-api-base-url\"\n</code></pre> \n<p>If the back-end API is hosted with a relative path, set the home page:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">\"homepage\": \"/relative-path\"\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>seamless integration with back-end API</li> \n <li>eliminates CORS issues</li> \n <li>easy set up</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Con</p> \n<ul> \n <li>might need a server-side proxy layer with multiple APIs</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"proptypes\">PropTypes</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/prop-types\">npmjs.com/package/prop-types</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/facebook/prop-types\">github.com/facebook/prop-types</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 3,000+</li> \n <li>developer: Facebook</li> \n <li>current version: 15.7.2</li> \n <li>contributors: 35+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Declares the type intended for the React component and documents its intent. This shows a warning in local dev if the types don’t match. It supports all JavaScript primitives such as <code>bool</code>, <code>number</code>, and <code>string</code>. It can document which props are required via <code>isRequired</code>.</p> \n<p>For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">import PropTypes;\n\nMyComponent.propTypes = {\n  boolProperty: PropTypes.bool,\n  numberProperty: PropTypes.number,\n  requiredProperty: PropTypes.string.isRequired\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>documents component’s intent</li> \n <li>shows warnings in local dev</li> \n <li>supports all JavaScript primitives</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>no compile type checking</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"typescript\">TypeScript</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://www.typescriptlang.org\">typescriptlang.org</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript\">github.com/facebook/prop-types</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 58,000+</li> \n <li>developer: Microsoft</li> \n <li>current version: 3.7.5</li> \n <li>contributors: 400+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>JavaScript that scales for React projects with compile type checking. This supports all React libraries and tools with type declarations. It’s a superset of JavaScript, so it’s possible to opt out of the type checker. This both documents intent and fails the build when it doesn’t match. In Create React App projects, turn it on by passing in <code>--template typescript</code>. TypeScript support is available starting from version <code>react-script@2.1.0</code>.</p> \n<p>To declare a prop type:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">interface MyComponentProps {\n  boolProp?: boolean; // optional\n  numberProp?: number; // optional\n  requiredProp: string;\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>compile type checking</li> \n <li>supports all React tools and libraries, including Create React App</li> \n <li>nice way to up your JavaScript skills</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>has a learning curve, but opt out is possible</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"redux\">Redux</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://www.redux.js.org\">redux.js.org</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/reduxjs/redux\">github.com/reduxjs/redux</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 52,000+</li> \n <li>developer: The Moon</li> \n <li>current version: 4.0.5</li> \n <li>contributors: 700+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Predictable state management container for JavaScript apps. This tool comes with a store that manages state data. State mutation is only possible via a dispatch message. The message object contains a type that signals to the reducer which mutation to fire. The recommendation is to keep everything in the app in a single store. Redux supports multiple reducers in a single store. Reducers have a one-to-one relationship between input parameters and output state. This makes reducers pure functions.</p> \n<p>A typical reducer that mutates state might look like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const simpleReducer = (state = {}, action) =&gt; {\n  switch (action.type) {\n    case 'SIMPLE_UPDATE_DATA':\n      return {...state, data: action.payload};\n\n    default:\n      return state;\n  }\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>predictable state management</li> \n <li>multiple reducers in a single store</li> \n <li>reducers are pure functions</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>set up from scratch can be a bit painful</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"reactredux\">React-Redux</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://www.react-redux.js.org\">react-redux.js.org</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/reduxjs/react-redux\">github.com/reduxjs/redux</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 18,500+</li> \n <li>developer: The Moon</li> \n <li>current version: 7.1.3</li> \n <li>contributors: 190+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Official React bindings for Redux, it comes in two main modules: <code>Provider</code> and <code>connect</code>. The Provider is a React component with a <code>store</code> prop. This prop is how a single store hooks up to the JSX markup. The connect function takes in two parameters: <code>mapStateToProps</code>, and <code>mapDispatchToProps</code>. This is where state management from Redux ties into component props. As state mutates, or dispatches fire, bindings take care of setting state in React.</p> \n<p>This is how a connect might look:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">import { bindActionCreators } from 'redux';\nimport { connect } from 'react-redux';\n\nconst mapStateToProps = (state) =&gt; state.simple;\nconst mapDispatchToProps = (dispatch) =&gt;\n  bindActionCreators({() =&gt; ({type: 'SIMPLE_UPDATE_DATA'})}, dispatch);\n\nconnect(mapStateToProps, mapDispatchToProps)(SimpleComponent);\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>official React bindings for Redux</li> \n <li>binds with JSX markup</li> \n <li>connects components to a single store</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>learning curve is somewhat steep</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"reduxthunk\">Redux-Thunk</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/redux-thunk\">npmjs.com/package/redux-thunk</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/reduxjs/redux-thunk\">github.com/reduxjs/redux-thunk</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 14,000+</li> \n <li>developer: The Moon</li> \n <li>current version: 2.3.0</li> \n <li>contributors: 40+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Thunk middleware for Redux to make asynchronous API calls. It defers execution behind a thunk to unlock asynchrony. A thunk is a function that defers evaluation. For example, <code>() =&gt; 1 + 1</code>, because it doesn’t have immediate execution. This comes with niceties, like access to store state, and dispatch. Optional parameters are also supported in the thunk.</p> \n<p>For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const loadData = () =&gt; async (dispatch, getState, optionalAsyncTool) =&gt; {\n  const state = getState();\n\n  const response = await optionalAsyncTool.get('/url/' + state.data);\n  dispatch({type: 'SIMPLE_LOAD_DATA', payload: response.data});\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>quintessential tool for asynchrony</li> \n <li>access to state, and dispatch</li> \n <li>configurable with optional parameter</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>at first, usefulness is not super clear</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"reduxlogger\">Redux-Logger</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>website: <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/redux-logger\">npmjs.com/package/redux-logger</a></li> \n <li>repository: <a href=\"https://github.com/LogRocket/redux-logger\">github.com/LogRocket/redux-logger</a></li> \n <li>GitHub stars: 5,000+</li> \n <li>developer: Log Rocket</li> \n <li>current version: 2.0.4</li> \n <li>contributors: 40+</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Logger for Redux that captures any dispatches going through the store. Each dispatch shows in the dev console in a log message. It allows drilling into prev, and next state. The action in the dispatch is also available for payload inspection. This logger is useful in local dev and can be ripped out post-build.</p> \n<p>The following is a potential setup in Redux middleware:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">import { createStore } from 'redux';\n\nlet middleware = [];\n\nif (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'development') { // rip out post-build\n  const {logger} = require('redux-logger');\n  middleware.push(logger);\n}\n\nexport default () =&gt; createStore({}, applyMiddleware(...middleware));\n</code></pre> \n<p>Pros:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>good Redux insight</li> \n <li>captures all dispatches in the store</li> \n <li>can run in local dev only</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Cons:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>tricky to filter out unwanted messages</li> \n</ul> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/essential-react-tools/?utm_source=rss\">20 Essential React Tools for 2020</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div 2020 22:00:08 Sponsors","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584427369Graphic-Designer.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn62@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-321_58d5e204ff42f342.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=3y4qoc6XcMM:i5vb9EYqg28:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn82@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-46-585_7343548c47cab41a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/3y4qoc6XcMM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn37@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-43-391_edcd9f9a7b315133.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483290},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"ADA Compliance Is Mandatory for Digital Agencies. Here&#8217;s How It&#8217;s Done","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175633","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-ultimate-ada-compliance-guide/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"ADA Compliance Is Mandatory for Digital Agencies. Here’s How It’s Done\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585099861web-accessibility.png\" alt=\"The Ultimate ADA Compliance Guide\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585099861web-accessibility-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585099861web-accessibility.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><em>This article was created in partnership with <a href=\"https://inboundjunction.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\">Inbound Junction</a>. Thank you for supporting the partners who make SitePoint possible.</em></p> \n<p><strong>Based on web accessibility data, the ADA compliance-related lawsuits reached over 2,000 cases in 2019. ADA Compliance is Mandatory for Digital Agencies. The challenge, however, is knowing <em>how</em> to build and design ADA-compliant websites. That’s the problem we’ll help you address in this post.</strong></p> \n<p>In this ultimate ADA compliance guide, we’ve laid out the things your web design agency needs to know to make accessible websites.</p> \n<p>The number of lawsuits will only keep growing if website owners, developers, and agencies continue to be non-compliant with the ADA.</p> \n<p>If you don’t want to be a part of that statistic, you’ll need to ensure that your agency and client websites offer accessibility to persons with disabilities and adhere to ADA standards.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatistheadaanyway\">What is the ADA, anyway?</h2> \n<p>The <em><a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://adata.org/learn-about-ada\">Americans with Disabilities Act</a></em> is a civil rights law that was enacted in 1990 to prohibit discrimination against persons with disabilities in every area of public life.</p> \n<p>This includes non-discrimination in schools, jobs, transportation, and all private and public places for general access — and those considered as “public accommodation.” </p> \n<p>For businesses, the required accommodations under the ADA include interface devices for the visually impaired, qualified interpreters or interpretive tools for the hearing impaired, ramp access for mobility devices like wheelchairs, and more.</p> \n<p>In the digital space, specifically websites, ADA compliance means providing web accessibility features and functionalities that allow persons with disabilities to use sites effectively.</p> \n<p>Originally, the ADA defined persons with disabilities as those with conditions that substantially limit major life activities — which somehow constricted what was considered as a disability.</p> \n<p>In the 2018 amendment, however, the ADA’s scope became broader, changing the meaning of “major life activity” to include daily life functions like performing manual operations.</p> \n<p>With this new definition, businesses will need to provide accessibility to a wide range of disabilities to adhere to ADA standards.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whyshouldwebdesignagenciesknowaboutit\">Why should web design agencies know about it?</h2> \n<p>If your web design agency creates websites that aren’t compliant with the ADA standards, you put your clients at risk of getting slapped with ADA-related lawsuits — and that’s not where you want to be.</p> \n<p>By providing non-compliant sites to your clients, not only will you get some flak from them due to the legal problems they’re bound to get in, but you’ll also wreck your agency’s credibility.</p> \n<p>It’s also worth pointing out that the ADA doesn’t specify the technical requirements for achieving compliance. Instead, it gives you the flexibility on how you can make your websites accessible.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, this doesn’t give you a lot to work with to comply with legislation fully.</p> \n<p>The Department of Justice (DOJ) and the US courts previously used the <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/\">Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1</a> Level AA success criteria as a standard for assessing the accessibility of websites.</p> \n<p>The WCAG 2.1 provides layers of standards to help you achieve web accessibility, including principles, basic guidelines, success criteria, and sufficient and advisory techniques.</p> \n<p>Although the WCAG 2.1 isn’t formally codified into US law, it’s currently the best and safest standard you can follow to comply with web accessibility requirements and the ADA.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-ultimate-ada-compliance-guide/?utm_source=rss\">ADA Compliance Is Mandatory for Digital Agencies. Here’s How It’s Done</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=WEdB9p-vJfk:ctdxhH77-f8:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=WEdB9p-vJfk:ctdxhH77-f8:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=WEdB9p-vJfk:ctdxhH77-f8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=WEdB9p-vJfk:ctdxhH77-f8:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/WEdB9p-vJfk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 25 Mar 2020 22:00:14 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585099861web-accessibility.png","linkMd5":"0a2ea1437d337d7224fa50351f3e7b19","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn10@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-24-685_e05ce13544d4229a.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":4500,"destBytes":4500,"author":"Gal Shachar","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1585099861web-accessibility.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn10@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-24-685_e05ce13544d4229a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=WEdB9p-vJfk:ctdxhH77-f8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn59@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-45-387_b9b005e4c09ee711.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/WEdB9p-vJfk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn99@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-39-026_0231d553a5f0980d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483282},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Set Up Basic jQuery Form Validation in Two Minutes","link":"http://www.jquery4u.com/?p=11819","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/basic-jquery-form-validation-tutorial/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Set Up Basic jQuery Form Validation in Two Minutes\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/1586403493jquery-validate.png\" alt=\"How to Set Up Basic jQuery Form Validation in Two Minutes\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/1586403493jquery-validate-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/1586403493jquery-validate.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>This tutorial shows you how to set up a basic form validation with jQuery, demonstrated by a registration form.</strong></p> \n<p>We’re going to use the <a href=\"https://jqueryvalidation.org/\">jQuery Validation Plugin</a> to validate our form. The basic principle of this plugin is to specify validation rules and error messages for HTML elements in JavaScript.</p> \n<p>\n <!-- \n\n<p>Here’s a live demo of what we’re going to build:\n\n\n<p>CodePen LINK GOES HERE</p>\n\n --></p> \n<h2 id=\"step1includejquery\">Step 1: Include jQuery</h2> \n<p>First, we need to include the jQuery library. The jQuery validation plugin has been tested up to jQuery version 3.1.1, but the demo in this article works perfectly with version 3.4.1, which is the latest one.</p> \n<p>You can use any of the following <a href=\"https://jquery.com/download/\">download options</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Download it from <a href=\"https://code.jquery.com/\">jquery.com</a></li> \n <li>Download it using Bower: <code>$ bower install jquery</code></li> \n <li>Download it using npm or Yarn: <code>$ npm install jquery</code> or <code>yarn add jquery</code></li> \n <li>Use a CDN: <code>https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.4.1/jquery.min.js</code></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Create a new HTML file named <code>index.html</code> and include jQuery before the closing <code>&lt;/body&gt;</code> tag:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;!-- Change the \"src\" attribute according to your installation path --&gt;\n&lt;script src=\"vendor/jquery/dist/jquery.min.js\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you’d like to use Bower or npm but aren’t familiar with them, you might be interested in these two articles:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/package-management-for-the-browser-with-bower/\">Package Management for the Browser with Bower</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/beginners-guide-node-package-manager/\">A Beginner’s Guide to npm — the Node Package Manager</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"step2includethejqueryvalidationplugin\">Step 2: Include the jQuery Validation Plugin</h2> \n<p>Choose between:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Download it from <a href=\"https://github.com/jquery-validation/jquery-validation/releases/tag/1.19.1\">the plugin’s github repo</a></li> \n <li>Download it using Bower: <code>$ bower install jquery-validation</code></li> \n <li>Download it using npm: <code>npm i jquery-validation</code></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.nuget.org/packages/jquery.validation\">NuGet</a>: <code>Install-Package jQuery.Validation</code></li> \n <li>Use a CDN: <code>https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery-validate/1.19.1/jquery.validate.min.js</code></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Include the plugin after jQuery:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;!-- Change the \"src\" attribute according to your installation path --&gt;\n&lt;script src=\"vendor/jquery-validation/dist/jquery.validate.min.js\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/basic-jquery-form-validation-tutorial/?utm_source=rss\">How to Set Up Basic jQuery Form Validation in Two Minutes</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\"
