/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158751965413-Unlayer-1024x542.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158751975014-XStore.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158751984015-Zentoshop-1024x525.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158751992416-Icons8-Design-Tools-1024x379.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158752003017-Content-Snare-1024x466.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=8qq0ADIWhAk:aLMYGmg7qU8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn80@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-43-016_32e94121eec2b0ac.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/8qq0ADIWhAk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-41-804_b93b8017ddba852d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483275},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Home Office Setup Essentials: 6 Principles to Improve Your Space","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176421","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/home-office-setup-essentials/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Home Office Setup Essentials: 6 Principles to Improve Your Space\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592788023ultimate-home-office.png\" alt=\"6 Essentials for the Ultimate Home Office Setup\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592788023ultimate-home-office-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592788023ultimate-home-office.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>A good home office setup is the sum of its parts. Great Wi-Fi isn’t going to offset the mounting frustration of a wobbly chair. Calming natural lighting won’t be able to shut those kids up from across the street. To create a space that cultivates productivity, everything has to work in harmony.</strong></p> \n<p>Although some specifics will likely differ depending on your job (software engineers are probably going to want a more powerful computer than copywriters), here are six essentials for building the ultimate home office setup imaginable.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1createadistinctspacetoworkin\">1. Create a Distinct Space to Work In</h2> \n<p>No matter how badly many of us loathe the morning commute, going from one’s home to a distinct secondary location helps create that thing we love to call a work/life balance. On one side of the scale is the office — aka work — and on the other side of the scale is your home — aka life. But if you work from home, work and life gets all crammed together on one side of the scale.</p> \n<p>To regain that balance, you have to create a distinct work space that’s either physically or psychologically separate from the space in which you relax and sleep. In other words, the place where you work can’t also be the place you don’t do work.</p> \n<p>If you have a home with extra rooms, this should be relatively easy. Designate one of those rooms as your office. Boom. We’re done.</p> \n<p>However, if you live in a home or apartment with no extra rooms, you’ll have to get a little creative. If you can’t put a door between your home and your work, put up a room divider or a curtain. Heck, make your own divider with <a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/search/pins/?rs=ac&amp;len=2&amp;q=plants%20as%20room%20dividers&amp;eq=plants%20as%20room&amp;etslf=4827\">plants</a>. These separators help tell your brain that it’s work time, not play time.</p> \n<p>Another way to trick your brain into separating your home office from your home is to leave the house before you start work. Get up and go for a walk, do a quick errand, or take out the garbage. Do something to tell your brain that you’re transitioning from one part of the day to another.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2preventdistractions\">2. Prevent Distractions</h2> \n<p>Unless you’re lucky enough to have a Faraday cage in your home, you’re bound to be met with some sort of distraction throughout your day. Some of these distractions may be auditory in nature. Perhaps the person living above you is an all-day stomper; maybe the park across your street attracts a lot of terrible street musicians. Here, sound is the enemy, and the solution is a white noise machine, sound canceling headphones, or even a loud fan.</p> \n<p>Other distractions may be digital. With no one looking over your shoulder, it’s tempting to futz around on the Internet instead of doing your work. This is where anti-procrastination apps come in handy. Here are some good ones:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/home-office-setup-essentials/?utm_source=rss\">Home Office Setup Essentials: 6 Principles to Improve Your Space</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=hXj-fAwwYSc:X0zjMeYYCiU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a 2020 17:03:48 Kraus","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592788023ultimate-home-office.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn53@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-25-138_fabc95b7a58d87ec.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=hXj-fAwwYSc:X0zjMeYYCiU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn25@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-38-535_d78014d6cae2fb3e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/hXj-fAwwYSc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-46-822_13abb9569ba8f15e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483261},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Finding the Perfect Remote Job Opportunity","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176025","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/finding-perfect-remote-job-opportunity/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Finding the Perfect Remote Job Opportunity\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587612049remote-work.png\" alt=\"Finding the Perfect Remote Job Opportunity\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587612049remote-work-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587612049remote-work.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>So, you’re considering making the switch to remote work, either because you’d like to work from home or maybe you’d like to lead a digital nomad lifestyle. But you’re wondering: “What should I be looking for in a remote job?” Or, if you’re “remote” already: “Is remote work overhyped, or do I just have a bad employer?”</strong></p> \n<p>If this sounds like you, keep reading as we take a deep dive into what remote workers should look for in a remote employer.</p> \n<h2 id=\"waitwhatsadigitalnomad\">Wait, what’s a digital nomad?</h2> \n<p>A <strong>digital nomad</strong> is anybody who’s referred to as “location-independent” as a result of them being able to work remotely, and leverages this unique opportunity to travel continuously.</p> \n<p>Considering the current of things (hello, COVID-19 👋), it’s worth noting that being a digital nomad doesn’t mean you need to travel between countries. Many digital nomads travel within their own countries, sometimes even via their own camper vans.</p> \n<p>It’s a thing; look it up. It’s really interesting!</p> \n<h2 id=\"whyareyouorwhydoyouwanttoberemote\">Why are you (or why do you want to be) remote?</h2> \n<p>First of all, there’s nothing wrong with wanting to work remotely (nomad or otherwise) simply because it’s the hot new thing and it sounds exciting. We only live once, so why not?</p> \n<p>This is especially true if you learn best by <em>doing</em>. If it turns out that it’s not for you, there’s no harm done really.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Who says you can’t go home? — Bon Jovi</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>However, the most likely scenario is that you’ve considered working remotely because your current lifestyle isn’t allowing you to be your best self. Perhaps you’d like to learn more about other cultures (or even yourself — that is, soul-searching), or maybe you’re looking to reinvent your lifestyle by embracing flexible hours or switching up your routine in the hope that it might improve your mental health or boost your level of work output.</p> \n<p>Also, there’s nothing wrong with craving a little wanderlust if international digital nomadism is what you’re thinking about.</p> \n<p>Some digital nomads simply enjoy the cheaper cost of living (which benefits <em>them</em>) while boosting the GDP (gross domestic product) of their host city/country (which benefits the <em>city/country</em>, assuming of course they’re contributing responsibly).</p> \n<p>However, with that being said, employers don’t always enable remote work as well as they could (even when they’re <em>supposed</em> to be a fully-remote company), so what exactly should one look for when searching for a digital nomad–friendly remote job?</p> \n<p>Let’s take a look.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1flexiblehours\">1. Flexible Hours</h2> \n<p>One thing that’s very synonymous with remote work is flexible hours, especially when team members are distributed (because of the multiple timezones). This appeals to digital nomads a lot because they typically would like to explore the city/country that they’re visiting.</p> \n<p>But “flexible hours” can be misleading. Sometimes, it means “as long as the work is completed” — which, in translation, actually means “we’ll keep sending you more work while trying to convince you that you’re mismanaging your time”.</p> \n<p>Many remote workers say that, although they <em>technically</em> have the freedom to work whenever they want, there’s so much work to do that they have literally no life in their work-life balance.</p> \n<p>A remote work contract <em>must</em> include the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>the amount of forced vacation</li> \n <li>the number of hours you must work</li> \n <li>a crystal-clear overtime agreement</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Hopefully, all of this should be evident from the job description, but if it isn’t, then enter the remote job interview with a bucket of questions. Trust your instincts.</p> \n<p>Speak to other remote employees if you can.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2productivitymentalhealth\">2. Productivity/Mental Health</h2> \n<p>As much as your remote employer should care about your work life, they should also care about your <em>life</em> life. Besides, how you feel outside of work deeply impacts the way you work anyway.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/finding-perfect-remote-job-opportunity/?utm_source=rss\">Finding the Perfect Remote Job Opportunity</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" Schwarz","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587612049remote-work.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn38@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-732_02fbd427a4a5fbc4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Da-FtOfNpm4:3JGPes_7H-s:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn83@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-42-971_bec9014ff9ba7df1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/Da-FtOfNpm4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn53@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-41-268_77f1474f7d9bb133.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483273},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"30 Life-saving Tools for Front-end Developers","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176261","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/life-saving-tools-for-front-end-developers/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"30 Life-saving Tools for Front-end Developers\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1591148465front-end-tools.png\" alt=\"30 Life-saving Tools for Front-end Developers\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1591148465front-end-tools-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1591148465front-end-tools.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>As the functionalities of web apps keep getting ever more sophisticated and complex, web developers need flexible tools to keep up with rising user expectations. The good news is, the web development ecosystem gives us plenty of choice, with both well-established companies and the open-source community racing to build more powerful libraries, frameworks and apps to help developers do their job and increase productivity and efficiency.</strong></p> \n<p>In this post, I’ve rounded up 30 top tools for front-end web developers ranging from code editors and code playgrounds to CSS generators, JS libraries, and more.</p> \n<p>Let’s dive right in!</p> \n<h2 id=\"codeeditors\">Code Editors</h2> \n<p>Front-end developers spend hours writing or editing code. Therefore, it’s only natural that their closest friend on the job is the code editor. In fact, getting to know their code editor of choice and all its capabilities and shortcuts gives any dev a great advantage in terms of productivity.</p> \n<h3 id=\"1visualstudiocodehttpscodevisualstudiocom\"><a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">1. Visual Studio Code</a></h3> \n<p>Visual Studio Code (VS Code) by Microsoft is a full-blown, free and open-source cross-platform integrated development environment (IDE) — that is, a complex piece of software that allows developers to create, test and deploy an entire project.</p> \n<p>Here are some of VS Code’s most popular features:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>IntelliSense, offering syntax highlighting and smart completions based on variable types, function definitions and imported modules</li> \n <li>debugging capabilities</li> \n <li>built-in Git commands</li> \n <li>flexibility and extensibility: you can easily add extensions relative to new languages, themes, etc.</li> \n <li>easy deployment capabilities</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You can download VS Code for Windows, MacOS, and Linux.</p> \n<h3 id=\"2atomhttpsatomio\"><a href=\"https://atom.io/\">2. Atom</a></h3> \n<p>Atom is a free, open-source and powerful cross-platform code editor that allows you to:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>collaborate with other developers using Teletype for Atom</li> \n <li>work with Git and GitHub with GitHub for Atom</li> \n <li>edit code on different platforms</li> \n <li>speed up coding with smart auto-completion</li> \n <li>search for, install and even create your own packages</li> \n <li>browse project files</li> \n <li>split the interface into multiple panes</li> \n <li>find and replace in a file or in multiple projects</li> \n <li>add new themes and customize the editor’s appearance and behavior by tweaking its code.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"3sublimetexthttpswwwsublimetextcom\"><a href=\"https://www.sublimetext.com/\">3. Sublime Text</a></h3> \n<p>Sublime Text introduces itself as “a sophisticated text editor for code, markup and prose”.</p> \n<p>It’s a paid, cross-platform code editing app with tons of features. These include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><em>Goto Anything</em> functionality: shortcuts that allow developers to search for bits of code in files and open files in projects</li> \n <li>multiple selections</li> \n <li>powerful API and package ecosystem to extend the built-in functionality</li> \n <li>split editing</li> \n <li>easy customization</li> \n <li>fast project switching</li> \n <li>high performance</li> \n <li>and more</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"packagemanagers\">Package Managers</h2> \n<p>Package managers are collections of tools for consistently automating processes like installing, upgrading, configuring and removing programs. Typing <code>npm install</code> or yarn install in a command-line interface has become one of the most ordinary parts of a developer’s day-to-day job.</p> \n<h3 id=\"4npmhttpswwwnpmjscom\"><a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/\">4. NPM</a></h3> \n<p>What is npm? Well, as it says on the company’s website, it’s many things. In particular:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>it’s the package manager for Node.js that helps JS devs to share packaged modules of code</li> \n <li>the npm registry is a public collection of packages of open-source code for Node.js, front-end web apps, and more</li> \n <li>npm is also the command-line client developers use to install and publish those packages</li> \n <li>npm, Inc. is the company responsible for hosting and maintaining all of the above</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"5yarnhttpsyarnpkgcom\"><a href=\"https://yarnpkg.com/\">5. Yarn</a></h3> \n<p>Yarn is a package manager for installing and sharing code and also a project manager. It’s extensible via plugins, stable, very well documented, free and open source.</p> \n<h2 id=\"bundlers\">Bundlers</h2> \n<p>Module bundlers are used to bundle several modules into one or more optimized bundles for the browser.</p> \n<h3 id=\"6webpackhttpswebpackjsorg\"><a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/\">6. Webpack</a></h3> \n<p>Here’s all the goodness you’ll find in webpack, as it’s detailed in the software’s website:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>At its core, <strong>webpack</strong> is a <em>static module bundler</em> for modern JavaScript applications. When webpack processes your application, it internally builds a <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/concepts/dependency-graph/\">dependency graph</a> which maps every module your project needs and generates one or more <em>bundles</em>. … Since version 4.0.0, <strong>webpack does not require a configuration file</strong> to bundle your project. Nevertheless, it is <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org/configuration\">incredibly configurable</a> to better fit your needs.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<h3 id=\"7parcelhttpsparceljsorg\"><a href=\"https://parceljs.org/\">7. Parcel</a></h3> \n<p>Parcel is a “blazing fast, zero configuration web application bundler”.</p> \n<p>Parcel</p> \n<ul> \n <li>is fast</li> \n <li>bundles all the project’s assets</li> \n <li>has zero-config code splitting</li> \n <li>and more.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"cssgenerators\">CSS Generators</h2> \n<p>Have you ever tried to memorize how to declare CSS properties for gradients, text shadows, Flexbox or Grid, to mention just a few? Not easy. Unless you use some CSS features and their properties over and over again, it’s hard to remember them all. But even those who master CSS sometimes need a refresher on some properties, especially if they haven’t used them in a while. </p> \n<p>If you need some quick help with the latest and greatest CSS, here are CSS generators to the rescue. Enter the values, preview the result, grab the generated code and run.</p> \n<h3 id=\"8css3generatorhttpscss3generatorcom\"><a href=\"https://css3generator.com/\">8. CSS3 Generator</a></h3> \n<p>The CSS3 Generator is a free online app that lets you quickly write code for a number of modern CSS features like Flexbox, gradients, transitions and transforms, and many more.</p> \n<p>Enter the required CSS values, preview the result in real time, copy and paste the generated code. Also, this app shows a list of browsers and their versions where your CSS code is supported.</p> \n<h3 id=\"9theultimatecssgeneratorhttpswebcodetoolscssgenerator\"><a href=\"https://webcode.tools/css-generator\">9. The Ultimate CSS Generator</a></h3> \n<p>The Ultimate CSS Generator is a free online app that lets you generate code for CSS animation, backgrounds, gradients, borders, filters, and more.</p> \n<p>The interface is user-friendly, the information about browser support for the CSS feature you’re interested in is clear and easy to spot, and the generated code is clean and accurate. </p> \n<h3 id=\"10thecssgridlayoutgeneratorbydmitriibykovhttpscssgridlayoutgeneratorpw\"><a href=\"https://css-grid-layout-generator.pw/\">10. The CSS Grid Layout Generator by Dmitrii Bykov</a></h3> \n<p>CSS Grid is awesome, and creating your grid in code gives you full control over the final result. However, it’s helpful to have a visual representation of the grid while you’re coding. Although some major browsers have implemented great tools to let you visualize your grid, some devs could do with some additional help. Here’s where a CSS Grid generator might come in handy.</p> \n<p>The CSS Grid Layout Generator by Dmitrii Bykov is free, accessible online, and extremely flexible. I took it for a spin and found that it gives me a lot of control both at the level of the grid container and that of the grid item while providing me with nice preview capabilities and clean code.</p> \n<p>If you need help, click on the <em>How to Use</em> button and watch the presentation video offered by the app’s author.</p> \n<p>To know more about which CSS Grid generators are available, I put some of the best ones through their paces on SitePoint in my article “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/css-grid-generators/\">5 Super CSS Grid Generators for Your Layouts</a>”.</p> \n<h2 id=\"librariesandframeworks\">Libraries and Frameworks</h2> \n<p>The demands on today’s web apps place great importance on speed in loading and updating page content. As powerful as modern JavaScript is, when packaged into a library or a framework, it becomes a fantastic tool for writing elegant and maintainable code and cutting back on repetitive and time-consuming typing efforts.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/life-saving-tools-for-front-end-developers/?utm_source=rss\">30 Life-saving Tools for Front-end Developers</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=qtKUf9_z9hU:gz9k9vRS5DU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a 2020 19:13:38 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How Aaron Osteraas Made the Content to Code Career Transition","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175540","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/content-code-career-transition/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How Aaron Osteraas Made the Content to Code Career Transition\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584488319developer-job.png\" alt=\"From Tinkering to Developing: A Programmer’s Journey\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584488319developer-job-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584488319developer-job.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>As Aaron Osteraas can tell you, the path between discovering what you want to do for a living and actually doing it is rarely linear.</strong></p> \n<p>Now a Software Engineer at Tigerspike, a digital services company headquartered in Sydney, Aaron’s journey toward becoming a developer began when he was in high school, yet it wasn’t until his early 30s that he obtained his first full-time development job. The years in between were filled with starts and stops, challenges and successes, and a whole lot of tinkering.</p> \n<p>“I was always tinkering with the family computer, which was mostly, ‘oh god I’ve broken it how do I fix it before I get in trouble,’” Aaron said of his technical beginnings. He had an appetite for building and modifying hardware, which he attributes to the joy that comes from doing something with your hands. He’d collect spare hardware, buy and sell parts, and at times resort to scrounging and trading. “There were computer parts strewn everywhere,” he said.</p> \n<p>But by the time he graduated high school, Aaron had checked out academically. He wasn’t confident his grades were good enough for university, so he enrolled in TAFE, Australia’s largest vocational training provider, and spent six months learning XML before realizing that “making mobile websites for 2004’s best mobile phones in XML was pretty damn far from my idea of a good time.”</p> \n<p>So he dropped out of TAFE and eventually found himself working in the world of content, where he stayed for seven years. Though he worked his way up to a managerial and editorial role for a handful of companies within the technical realm, Aaron found himself consistently unsatisfied.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>I had this itch to solve technical problems, and working in content, I wasn’t able to scratch it. That’s what a lot of programming is, problem-solving. And it’s not that this is unique to programming, it’s just the type of problems – and solutions to them – are more enjoyable to me.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<h2>Back to School</h2> \n<p>During his long stretch in content, Aaron maintained enough of an interest in tinkering and programming to eventually enroll in a Software Engineering degree program.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>I took one subject to start off, as I felt I needed to validate two things: one, that I could learn to study again, and two, that I would enjoy it.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Aaron found the validation he was after, but it wasn’t until a few years later, when he learned his company had been acquired and his job was on the line, that he decided to leave content behind and commit fully to becoming a developer. Knowing he could be let go in as little as a week, Aaron enrolled at RMIT University full-time to pursue a degree in Software Engineering.</p> \n<p>Aaron was finally where he belonged, but it wasn’t easy.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>There was a lot of frustration. I found certain languages, concepts, and themes difficult to grasp, and others came with remarkable ease. So when you’re going from, ‘How easy and fun is this!’ to swearing at the computer asking why something isn’t working, it can be emotionally turbulent.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>In conjunction with the difficult subject matter was the overwhelming amount of career paths to choose from.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>The world of programming is outrageously broad, there are innumerable paths you can take, and there’s temptation to try and take them all because everyone loves the new shiny thing.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>The more career paths he discovered, the less sure of himself he grew.</p> \n<p> 2020 09:40:24 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584488319developer-job.png","linkMd5":"7d8aa899128fe5a4cd09990e7e0e672f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn17@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-888_36eb321b13590b6f.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":7846,"destBytes":7846,"author":"Joshua Kraus","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584488319developer-job.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn17@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-888_36eb321b13590b6f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=jPn9TyDeBtQ:vMLaRyWHkTs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn17@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-42-715_de40123d2d031db2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/jPn9TyDeBtQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-41-879_7e03424d969533e9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483282},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"SVG 101: What Is SVG?","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=156582","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/svg-101-what-is-svg/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"SVG 101: What Is SVG?\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597254478svg-squashed.jpg\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597254478svg-squashed-300x158.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597254478svg-squashed-768x404.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1597254478svg-squashed-1024x539.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Though it was conceived back in the late 1990s, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalable_Vector_Graphics\">SVG</a> is in many ways the “ugly duckling” file format that grew up to become a swan. Poorly supported and largely ignored for most of the 2000s, since around 2017 all modern web browsers have been rendering SVG without serious issues, and most vector drawing programs have been offering the option to export SVG, which has unquestionably become a widely used graphic format on the Web.</strong></p> \n<p>This hasn’t happened by chance. Although traditional raster graphic file formats like JPGs and PNGs are perfect for photographs or very complex images, it turns out that SVG is the one graphic format that most closely meets current web development demands of scalability, responsiveness, interactivity, programmability, performance, and accessibility.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/1498798784svg101.svg\" alt=\"SVG 101 Header\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-156634\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"sowhatissvgandwhyshouldyouuseit\">So, What Is SVG and Why Should You Use It?</h2> \n<p>SVG is an <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XML\">eXtensible Markup Language (XML)</a>-based vector graphic format for the Web and other environments. XML uses tags like HTML, although it’s stricter. You cannot, for example, omit a closing tag since this will make the file invalid and the SVG will not be rendered.</p> \n<p>To give you a taste of what SVG code looks like, here’s how you would draw a white circle with a black border:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;circle cx=\"100\" cy=\"100\" r=\"50\" stroke-width=\"4\" stroke=\"#000\" fill=\"#fff\" /&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>As you can see, under the hood, SVG documents are nothing more than simple plain text files that describe lines, curves, shapes, colors, and text. As it’s human-readable, easily understandable and modifiable, when embedded in an HTML document as an <strong>inline SVG</strong>, SVG code can be manipulated via CSS or JavaScript. This gives SVG a flexibility and versatility that can’t ever be matched by traditional PNG, GIF or JPG graphic formats.</p> \n<p>SVG is a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web_Consortium\">W3C standard</a>, which means that it can inter-operate easily with other open standard languages and technologies including JavaScript, DOM, CSS, and HTML. As long as the W3C sets the global industry standards, it’s likely that SVG will continue to be the de facto standard for vector graphics in the browser.</p> \n<p>The awesomeness of SVG is that it can solve many of the most vexing problems in modern web development. Let’s breeze through some of them.</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><strong>Scalability and responsiveness</strong></p> <p>Under the hood, SVG uses shapes, numbers and coordinates rather than a pixel grid to render graphics in the browser, which makes it resolution-independent and infinitely scalable. If you think about it, the instructions for creating a circle are the same whether you’re using a pen or a skywriting plane. Only the scale changes.</p> <p>With SVG, you can combine different shapes, paths and text elements to create all kinds of visuals, and you’ll be sure they’ll look clear and crisp at any size.</p> <p>In contrast, raster-based formats like GIF, JPG, and PNG have fixed dimensions, which cause them to pixelate when they’re scaled. Although various responsive image techniques have proved valuable for pixel graphics, they’ll never be able to truly compete with SVG’s ability to scale indefinitely.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Programmability and interactivity</strong></p> <p>SVG is fully editable and scriptable. All kinds of animations and interactions can be added to an inline SVG graphic via CSS and/or JavaScript.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Accessibility</strong></p> <p>SVG files are text-based, so when embedded in a web page, they can be searched and indexed. This makes them accessible to screen readers, search engines and other devices.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><strong>Performance</strong></p> <p>One of the most important aspects impacting web performance is the size of the files used on a web page. SVG graphics are usually smaller in size compared to bitmap file formats.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/svg-101-what-is-svg/?utm_source=rss\">SVG 101: What Is SVG?</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=gVMAbWSfvEg:OKm27NddORk:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=gVMAbWSfvEg:OKm27NddORk:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=gVMAbWSfvEg:OKm27NddORk:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/gVMAbWSfvEg\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/replace-redux-react-hooks-context-api/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Replace Redux with React Hooks and the Context API\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/1584425271fishing-300x288.jpg 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/1584425271fishing-768x738.jpg 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/1584425271fishing-1024x985.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p>The most popular way to handle shared application state in React is using a framework such as Redux. Quite recently, the React team introduced several new features which include React Hooks and the Context API. These two features effectively eliminated a lot of challenges that developers of large React projects have been facing. One of the biggest problems was ‘prop drilling’ which was common with nested components. The solution was to use a state management library like Redux. This, unfortunately, came with the expense of writing boilerplate code — but now, it’s possible to replace Redux with React Hooks and the Context API.</p> \n<p>In this article, you are going to learn a new way of handling state in your React projects, without writing excessive code or installing a bunch of libraries — as is the case with Redux. React hooks allow you to use local state inside of function components, while the Context API allows you to share state with other components.</p> \n<h2 id=\"prerequisites\">Prerequisites</h2> \n<p>In order to follow along with this tutorial, you will need to have a good foundation in the following topics:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/getting-started-react-beginners-guide/\">Getting Started with React</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/your-first-week-with-react?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Your First Week with React</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/react-hooks/\">React Hooks</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/getting-started-redux/\">Foundation in Redux</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>The technique you will learn here is based on patterns that were introduced in Redux. This means you need to have a firm understanding of <code>reducers</code> and <code>actions</code> before proceeding. I am currently using <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">Visual Studio Code</a>, which seems to be the most popular code editor right now (especially for JavaScript developers). If you are on Windows, I would recommend you install <a href=\"https://gitforwindows.org/\">Git Bash</a>. Use the Git Bash terminal to perform all commands provided in this tutorial. <a href=\"https://cmder.net/\"><code>Cmder</code></a> is also a good terminal capable of executing most Linux commands on Windows.</p> \n<p>You can access the complete project used in this tutorial for this <a href=\"https://github.com/brandiqa/react-hooks-context-app\">GitHub Repository</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"aboutthenewstatemanagementtechnique\">About the New State Management Technique</h2> \n<p>There are two types of state that we need to deal with in React projects:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/replace-redux-react-hooks-context-api/?utm_source=rss\">How to Replace Redux with React Hooks and the Context API</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VozJdVWprgs:hNO5Omqgg0c:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VozJdVWprgs:hNO5Omqgg0c:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VozJdVWprgs:hNO5Omqgg0c:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=VozJdVWprgs:hNO5Omqgg0c:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/VozJdVWprgs\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 31 May 2020 23:00:54 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/1584425271fishing.jpg","linkMd5":"9fa367b85888d907da27fcea05858808","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn77@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-615_47bf4362874e41f4.webp","destWidth":2000,"destHeight":1923,"sourceBytes":50794,"destBytes":50794,"author":"Michael Wanyoike","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/1584425271fishing.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn77@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-615_47bf4362874e41f4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=VozJdVWprgs:hNO5Omqgg0c:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn85@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-35-374_90d0cfe9f2e82d3e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/VozJdVWprgs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn10@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-45-616_94003aacd7a54f56.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483269},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Visual Studio Code: A Power User&#8217;s Guide","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175823","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/visual-studio-code-power-user-guide/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Visual Studio Code: A Power User’s Guide\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586833239vs-code.png\" alt=\"A Visual Studio Code Power User's Guide\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586833239vs-code-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586833239vs-code.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>In this guide, you’ll learn how to take advantage of Visual Studio Code to supercharge your development workflow.</strong></p> \n<p>This article is written for beginners who may be using Visual Studio Code for the first time. VS Code, as it’s commonly known, is considered a “lightweight” code editor. In comparison with full integrated development environment (IDE) editors which occupy gigabytes of disk space, VS Code only uses less than 200MB when installed.</p> \n<p>Despite the “lightweight” term, VS Code offers a massive number of features which keep increasing and improving with every new update. For this guide, we’ll cover the most popularly used features. Every programmer has their own tool set which they keep updating whenever new workflows are discovered. If you want to learn every tool and feature VS Code has to offer, check out their <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs\">official documentation</a>. In addition, you may want to keep track of <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/updates\">updates</a> for new and improved features.</p> \n<h2 id=\"prerequisites\">Prerequisites</h2> \n<p>In order to follow along this guide, you need to be proficient in at least one programming language and framework. You also need to be conversant with versioning your project code with <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/git-for-beginners/\">git</a>. You’ll also need to have an account with a remote repository platform such as GitHub. I recommend you setup <a href=\"https://help.github.com/en/github/authenticating-to-github/connecting-to-github-with-ssh\">SSH Keys</a> to connect with your remote repo.</p> \n<p>We’ll use a minimal <a href=\"https://nextjs.org/\">Next.js</a> project to demonstrate VS Code features. If you’re new to this, don’t worry, as the framework and the language used are not the focus for this guide. The skills taught here can be transferred to any language and framework that you’re working with.</p> \n<h2 id=\"abitofhistory\">A Bit of History</h2> \n<p>If you’re new to programming, I recommend you start with a simple text editor such as Windows NotePad. It’s the most basic text editor and doesn’t offer any kind of help whatsoever. The main advantage of using it is that it forces you to memorize language syntax and do your own indentation. Once you get comfortable writing code, upgrading to a better text editor such as <a href=\"https://notepad-plus-plus.org/\">NotePad++</a> is the next logical step. It offers a bit of essential coding help with features like syntax colorization, auto indentation and basic autocomplete. It’s important when learning programming not to be overwhelmed with too much information and assistance.</p> \n<p>Once you’ve gotten used to having a better coding experience, it’s time to upgrade. Not so long ago, these were the fully integrated development environments on offer:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/\">Visual Studio IDE</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://netbeans.org/\">NetBeans</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.eclipse.org/\">Eclipse</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/\">IntelliJ IDEA</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>These platforms provide the complete development workflow, from coding to testing and deployment. They contain tons of useful features such as analyzing code and highlighting errors. They also contain a ton more features that many developers weren’t using, though they were essential for some teams. As a result, these platforms took a lot of disk space and were slow to start up. Many developers preferred using advance text editors such as <a href=\"https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/\">emacs</a> and <a href=\"https://www.vim.org/\">vim</a> to write their code in.</p> \n<p>Soon, a new crop of platform independent code editors started appearing. They were lightweight and provided many features that were mostly exclusive to IDEs. I’ve listed them below in the order they were released:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sublimetext.com/\">Sublime Text</a>: July 2013</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://atom.io/\">Atom.io</a>: June 2015</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">Visual Studio Code</a>: April 2016</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Mac developers had access to <a href=\"https://macromates.com/\">TextMate</a> which was released in October 2004. The snippets system used by all the above editors originated from TextMate. Having used all of them, I felt that the editor that came after was a significant improvement over the current one. According to a developer survey done by <a href=\"https://insights.stackoverflow.com/survey/2019#development-environments-and-tools\">Stack OverFlow</a> in 2019, Visual Studio Code is the most popular code development environment with 50.7% usage. Visual Studio IDE comes second and NotePad++ comes third.</p> \n<p>That’s enough history and stats for now. Let’s delve into how to use Visual Studio Code features.</p> \n<h2 id=\"setupandupdates\">Setup and Updates</h2> \n<p>Visual Studio Code package installer is less than 100MB and consumes less than 200MB when fully installed. When you visit the <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">download</a> page, your OS will automatically be detected and the correct download link will be highlighted.</p> \n<p>Updating VS Code is very easy. It displays a notification prompt whenever an update has been released. For Windows users, you’ll have to click on the notification to download and install the latest version. The download process occurs in the background while you’re working. When it’s ready to install, a restart prompt will appear. Clicking this will install the update for you and restart VS Code.</p> \n<p>For Ubuntu-based distributions, clicking on the <strong>update notification</strong> will simply open the website for you to download the latest installer. A much easier way is simply running <code>sudo apt update &amp;&amp; sudo apt upgrade -y</code>. This will update all installed Linux packages including VS Code. The reason this works is because VS Code added its repo to your package repo registry during the initial installation. You can find the repo information on this path: <code>/etc/apt/sources.list.d/vscode.list</code>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"userinterface\">User Interface</h2> \n<p>Let’s first get acquainted with the user interface:</p> \n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586831185hero.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"940\" height=\"645\" class=\"alignleft size-full wp-image-175827\" />\n <figcaption style=\"text-align:center; font-size:0.8em; margin: 12px 0 20px\">\n  <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/assets/docs/getstarted/userinterface/hero.png\">Image source</a> \n </figcaption>\n</figure> \n<p>VS Code’s user interface is divided into five main areas which you can easily adjust.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Activity Bar</strong>: allows you to switch between views: explorer, search, version control, debug and extensions.</li> \n <li><strong>Side Bar</strong>: contains the active view.</li> \n <li><strong>Editor</strong>: this is where you edit files and preview markdown files. You can arrange multiple open files side-by-side.</li> \n <li><strong>Panel</strong>: displays different panels: integrated terminal, output panels for debug information, errors and warnings.</li> \n <li><strong>Status</strong>: displays information about the currently opened project and file. Also contains buttons for executing version control actions, and enabling/disabling extension features.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>There’s also the top <strong>Menu Bar</strong> where you can access the editor’s menu system. For Linux users, the default integrated terminal will probably be the <strong>Bash</strong> shell. For Windows users, it’s <strong>PowerShell</strong>. Fortunately, there’s a shell selector located inside the terminal dropdown that will allow you to choose a different shell. If installed, you can choose any of the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Command Prompt</li> \n <li>PowerShell</li> \n <li>PowerShell Core</li> \n <li>Git Bash</li> \n <li>WSL Bash</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"workingwithprojects\">Working with Projects</h2> \n<p>Unlike full IDEs, VS Code doesn’t provide <strong>project creation</strong> or offer <strong>project templates</strong> in the traditional way. It simply works with folders. On my Linux development machine, I’m using the following folder pattern to store and manage my projects:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">/home/{username}/Projects/{company-name}/{repo-provider}/{project-name}\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <code>Projects</code> folder is what I refer to as to the <strong>workspace</strong>. As a freelance writer and developer, I separate projects based on which company I’m working for, and which repo I’m using. For personal projects, I store them under my own fictitious “company name”. For projects that I experiment with for learning purposes, and which I don’t intend to keep for long, I’ll just use a name such as <code>play</code> or <code>tuts</code> as a substitute for <code>{repo-provider}</code>.</p> \n<p>If you’d like to create a new project and open it in VS Code, you can use the following steps. Open a terminal and execute the following commands:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ mkdir vscode-demo\n$ cd vscode-demo\n# Launch Visual Studio Code\n$ code .\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can also do this in File Explorer. When you access the mouse context menu, you should be able to open any folder in VS Code.</p> \n<p>If you want to create a new project linked to a remote repo, it’s easier creating one on the repo site — for example, <a href=\"https://github.com/\">GitHub</a> or <a href=\"https://bitbucket.org/\">BitBucket</a>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610666602-github-create-project.png\" alt=\"GitHub create project\" /></p> \n<p>Take note of all the fields that have been filled in and selected. Next, go to the terminal and execute the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># Navigate to workspace/company/repo folder\n$ cd Projects/sitepoint/github/\n\n# Clone the project to your machine\n$ git clone git@github.com:{insert-username-here}/vscode-nextjs-demo.git\n\n# Open project in VS Code\n$ cd vscode-nextjs-demo\n$ code .\n</code></pre> \n<p>Once the editor is up and running, you can launch the integrated terminal using the keyboard shortcut <code>Ctrl+~</code> (tilde key). Use the following commands to generate <code>package.json</code> and install packages:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># Generate `package.json` file with default settings\n$ npm init -y\n\n# Install package dependencies\n$ npm install next react react-dom\n</code></pre> \n<p>Next, open <code>package.json</code> and replace the <code>scripts</code> section with this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">\"scripts\": {\n  \"dev\": \"next\",\n  \"build\": \"next build\",\n  \"start\": \"next start\"\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>The entire VS Code window should look like this:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610667503-vscode-project-setup.png\" alt=\"VS Code run script\" /></p> \n<p>Before we look at the next section, I’d like to mention that VS Code also supports the concept of <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/multi-root-workspaces\">multi-root workspaces</a>. If you’re working with related projects — front-end, back-end, docs etc. — you can manage them all in a single workspace inside one editor. This will make it easier to keep your source code and documentation in sync.</p> \n<h2 id=\"versioncontrolwithgit\">Version Control with Git</h2> \n<p>VS Code comes built-in with Git source control manager. It provides a UI interface where you can stage, commit, create new branches and switch to existing ones. Let’s commit the changes we just did in our project. On the <strong>Activity bar</strong>, open the <strong>Source Control Panel</strong> and locate the <strong>Stage All Changes</strong> plus button as shown below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610668504-vscode-source-control.png\" alt=\"VS Code source control\" /></p> \n<p>Click on it. Next, enter the commit message “Installed next.js dependencies”, then click the <strong>Commit</strong> button at the top. It has the checkmark icon. This will commit the new changes. If you look at the status located at the bottom, you’ll see various status icons at the left-hand corner. The <code>0 ↓</code> means there’s nothing to pull from the remote repo. The <code>1 ↑</code> means you’ve got one commit you need to push to your remote repo. Clicking on it will display a prompt on the action that will take place. Click <strong>OK</strong> to <code>pull</code> and <code>push</code> your code. This should sync up your local repo with the remote repo.</p> \n<p>To create a new branch or switch to an existing branch, just click the <strong>branch name</strong> <code>master</code> on the status bar, left bottom corner. This will pop up a <strong>branch panel</strong> for you to take an action.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610669105-vscode-branch-actions.png\" alt=\"VS Code branch actions\" /></p> \n<p>Do check out the following extensions for an even better experience with Git:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=eamodio.gitlens\">Git Lens</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=donjayamanne.githistory\">Git History</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Support for a different type of SCM, such as SVN, can be added via installing the relevant SCM extension from the marketplace.</p> \n<h2 id=\"creatingandrunningcode\">Creating and Running Code</h2> \n<p>On the <strong>Activity Bar</strong>, head back to the <strong>Explorer Panel</strong> and use the <strong>New Folder</strong> button to create the folder <code>pages</code> at the root of the project. Select this folder and use the <strong>New File</strong> button to create the file <strong>pages/index.js</strong>. Copy the following code:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">function HomePage() {\n  return &amp;lt;div&amp;gt;Welcome to Next.js!&amp;lt;/div&amp;gt;;\n}\n\nexport default HomePage;\n</code></pre> \n<p>With the <strong>Explorer Panel</strong>, you should see a section called <strong>NPM Scripts</strong>. Expand on this and hover over <code>dev</code>. A <code>run</code> button (play icon) will appear next to it. Click on it and this will launch a Next.js dev server inside the <strong>Integrated Terminal</strong>.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610669506-vscode-run-script.png\" alt=\"VS Code run script\" /></p> \n<p>It should take a few seconds to spin up. Use <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>Click</kbd> on the URL <code>http://localhost:3000</code> to open it in your browser. The page should open successfully displaying the “Welcome” message. In the next section, we’ll look at how we can change VS Code preferences.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/visual-studio-code-power-user-guide/?utm_source=rss\">Visual Studio Code: A Power User’s Guide</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=G9qC5ZM1SJI:XhHNLC3QefI:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=G9qC5ZM1SJI:XhHNLC3QefI:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=G9qC5ZM1SJI:XhHNLC3QefI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=G9qC5ZM1SJI:XhHNLC3QefI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/G9qC5ZM1SJI\"
