+0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586833239vs-code.png","linkMd5":"a7adfd12bda8bcc1541c8f6918433118","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn94@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-27-661_020d32b10582979e.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":9086,"destBytes":9086,"author":"Michael Wanyoike","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586833239vs-code.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn94@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-27-661_020d32b10582979e.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586831185hero.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn53@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-41-053_0e2451232a2c5bba.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610666602-github-create-project.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn36@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-46-771_7d8febe5dced6027.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610667503-vscode-project-setup.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-47-208_78e9070ef9f7fbec.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610668504-vscode-source-control.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn20@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-40-066_21cb4c73791e4796.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610669105-vscode-branch-actions.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn22@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-44-014_4826231e3fff5928.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/158610669506-vscode-run-script.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn18@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-35-184_f0e7b16641bb899a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=G9qC5ZM1SJI:XhHNLC3QefI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn26@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-44-298_75a2d85f15f741aa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/G9qC5ZM1SJI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn82@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-36-469_45fd1290fb1b9033.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483277},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"The Devastating Price Developers Pay for Working Hard","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175548","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-devastating-price-developers-pay-for-working-hard/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"The Devastating Price Developers Pay for Working Hard\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584577966working-hard.png\" alt=\"The Devastating Price Developers Pay for Working Hard\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584577966working-hard-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584577966working-hard.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>You’re a <em>wonderful</em> developer.</strong></p> \n<p>You come early, and you stay late. Your code is clear and well documented; you’re eager to help others, and you’re able to handle 3x the work your co-workers can handle.</p> \n<p><em>You’re an amazing developer, and that’s your problem.</em></p> \n<p>Your Boss and your co-workers all want your best work. It’s an unspoken expectation in the workplace. No one prepares you for the horrible consequences that come with doing your job well.</p> \n<h2 id=\"thedevastatingpriceyoupayforworkinghard\">The devastating price you pay for working hard</h2> \n<p>There are several unpleasant downsides that come with exceptional performance and hard work. There’s one reward in particular that acts as a demotivator that destroys job satisfaction.</p> \n<p>You’re probably already familiar with it.</p> \n<p>The reward for working hard and performing above expectations at your job is <em>more work</em>.</p> \n<p>This is devastating to developers in the long term, and here are a few reasons why …</p> \n<p><strong>1. Price’s Law becomes a dysfunctional cycle</strong> <br /> Information scientist and physicist <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_J._de_Solla_Price\">Derek de Solla Price</a> discovered that the square root of the number of people in any domain does 50 percent of the work. If there are ten developers on your team, 3 of them do half the work. Who are these employees? If you’re an A-player, you’re already doing far more than your co-workers.</p> \n<p>This is devastating because it creates a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtuous_circle_and_vicious_circle\">vicious cycle</a>. In many organizations, you’re rewarded with more and more work, but <em>your salary, titles or earning power remains unchanged</em>. When this happens, your employer steals from your future, minimizing your earning power and your ability to get a new job at an appropriate salary level with an appropriate title.</p> \n<p><strong>2. Mercenaries corrupt patriots</strong><br /> According to Gallup and Steve Rasmussen, former CEO of Nationwide, your co-workers are either <a href=\"https://news.gallup.com/businessjournal/157676/employees-either-patriots-mercenaries.aspx\"><em>Patriots or Mercenaries</em></a>.</p> \n<p>If you’re a <strong>Patriot</strong>, you’re engaged. You believe in your managers and co-workers, and they believe in you. You’re focused on taking care of your organization because you trust your co-workers to look out for you. If you’re a <strong>Mercenary</strong>, you’re focused primarily on yourself. You’re a job hopper or social climber. You’re focused on getting as much value as you can for yourself; forget the company!</p> \n<p>The employees who are willing to let others work for them? They’re usually mercenaries, people who are willing to do the bare minimum to collect a paycheck. Left unchecked, these mercenaries kill morale in the company, causing A-players to leave or become B- and C-players.</p> \n<p><strong>3. Crab mentality sends A-players to the bottom of the social hierarchy</strong><br /> Mediocre employees don’t like high achievers, and high achievers don’t like mediocre employees. If you’re an A-player who’s surrounded by mediocre B- and C-player employees, you’ll be punished for excellence.</p> \n<p>What does this mean specifically?</p> \n<p>Your co-workers will attempt to destroy the self-confidence of any employee (you) who achieves success or outperforms the rest of the group due to envy, spite, resentment, conspiracy or competitiveness. This isn’t mere speculation: the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tall_poppy_syndrome\">tall poppy syndrome</a>, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crab_mentality\">crab bucket mentality</a> and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_commons\">tragedy of the commons</a> are all examples of this kind of behavior in action. If you’re a great developer and you’re surrounded by mediocrity, you’ll be punished for it.</p> \n<p>“Yeah, well, I don’t care what anyone thinks anyway!”</p> \n<p>Here’s why you should care. No man is an island. At some point, you’re going to need help from others to do your job or complete a task. Want to find another job? You’ll need references from your manager and co-workers.</p> \n<p><strong>4. Mercenaries sabotage patriots</strong><br /> Their methods are simple. They get A-player patriots to do the work for them. Then they immediately take the credit for the A-player’s hard work. Mercenaries use a variety of strategies to accomplish this.</p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machiavellianism_(psychology)\">Machiavellianism</a></strong>, or interpersonal manipulation to shape alliances, is used to gain and maintain social status, regardless of their actual performance, to gain leverage against opponents or <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisoning_the_well\">poison the well</a>, turning managers against A-players they perceive as a threat.</p> \n<p><strong>Indirect aggression</strong> is characterized by bullying, slander, gossip, shaming or ostracizing others. It’s common in office settings and typically involves some reputation destruction. The thing with indirect aggression is that it’s incredibly difficult to prove and harder still to counteract unless you have a clear understanding of what it is and how it works.</p> \n<p><strong>Leverage.</strong> Malicious mercenaries will use anything as leverage: past mistakes, secrets shared in confidence, insecurities — anything that will get others (you) to do what they want when they want. For whatever reason, it’s important that they win and you lose.</p> \n<p>Successful patriots use their abilities and accomplishments as leverage to counter mercenary bad behavior. But they’ll also rely on strong relationships with others as a balm for scheming behavior. Unfortunately this is the exception, not the rule.</p> \n<p>See what I mean?</p> \n<p>Working hard comes with a devastating price. So what’s the alternative then? Doing the bare minimum? Working to keep my head down and collect a steady paycheck?</p> \n<p><em>Many employees do that already.</em></p> \n<p>Doing that is worse, because it comes with its own set of miserable problems. It’s difficult to find and keep a job. The mediocre aren’t paid all that well, and they’re the first to go if your company initiates layoffs or mass firings.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-devastating-price-developers-pay-for-working-hard/?utm_source=rss\">The Devastating Price Developers Pay for Working Hard</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=91D313f5p-E:kdO4Q9TPzEo:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=91D313f5p-E:kdO4Q9TPzEo:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=91D313f5p-E:kdO4Q9TPzEo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=91D313f5p-E:kdO4Q9TPzEo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/91D313f5p-E\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 31 Mar 2020 23:00:52 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584577966working-hard.png","linkMd5":"34d31f55c94b03682c404018d87762ce","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn17@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-26-601_b4d9a64e22f09468.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":340,"sourceBytes":8442,"destBytes":8442,"author":"Andrew McDermott","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1584577966working-hard.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn17@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-26-601_b4d9a64e22f09468.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=91D313f5p-E:kdO4Q9TPzEo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn62@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-35-435_f942f40beac0fc99.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/91D313f5p-E":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn74@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-41-338_08123ecaad75f5b7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483280},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Five Ways to Lazy Load Images for Better Website Performance","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=152544","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/five-techniques-lazy-load-images-website-performance/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Five Ways to Lazy Load Images for Better Website Performance\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1585618767lazy-load-images.png\" alt=\"Five Ways to Lazy Load Images for Better Website Performance\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1585618767lazy-load-images-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1585618767lazy-load-images.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>With images being among the most popular type of content on the web, page load time on websites can easily become an issue.</strong></p> \n<p>Even when <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/saving-bandwidth-by-using-images-the-smart-way/\">properly optimized</a>, images can weigh quite a bit. This can have a negative impact on the time visitors have to wait before they can access content on your website. Chances are, they get impatient and navigate somewhere else, unless you come up with a solution to image loading that doesn’t interfere with the perception of speed.</p> \n<p>In this article, you’ll learn about five approaches to lazy loading images that you can add to your web optimization toolkit to improve the user experience on your website.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatislazyloading\">What Is Lazy Loading?</h2> \n<p>Lazy loading images means loading images on websites asynchronously — that is, after the above-the-fold content is fully loaded, or even conditionally, only when they appear in the browser’s viewport. This means that if users don’t scroll all the way down, images placed at the bottom of the page won’t even be loaded.</p> \n<p>A number of websites use this approach, but it’s especially noticeable on image-heavy sites. Try browsing your favorite online hunting ground for high-res photos, and you’ll soon realize how the website loads just a limited number of images. As you scroll down the page, you’ll see placeholder images quickly filling up with real images for preview. For instance, notice the loader on <a href=\"https://unsplash.com/\">Unsplash.com</a>: scrolling that portion of the page into view triggers the replacement of a placeholder with a full-res photo:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492178800lazy-loading-unsplash.png\" alt=\"Lazy loading in action on Unsplash.com\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"whyshouldyoucareaboutlazyloadingimages\">Why Should You Care About Lazy Loading Images?</h2> \n<p>There are at least a couple of excellent reasons why you should consider lazy loading images for your website:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>If your website uses JavaScript to display content or provide some kind of functionality to users, loading the DOM quickly becomes critical. It’s common for scripts to wait until the DOM has completely loaded before they start running. On a site with a significant number of images, lazy loading — or loading images asynchronously — could make the difference between users staying or leaving your website.</li> \n <li>Since most lazy loading solutions work by loading images only if the user has scrolled to the location where images would be visible inside the viewport, those images will never be loaded if users never get to that point. This means considerable savings in bandwidth, for which most users, especially those accessing the Web on mobile devices and slow-connections, will be thanking you.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Well, lazy loading images helps with website performance, but what’s the best way to go about it?</p> \n<p>There’s no perfect way.</p> \n<p>If you live and breathe JavaScript, implementing your own lazy loading solution shouldn’t be an issue. Nothing gives you more control than coding something yourself.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, you can browse the Web for viable approaches and start experimenting with them. I did just that and came across these five interesting techniques.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1nativelazyloading\">#1 Native Lazy Loading</h2> \n<p>Native lazy loading of images and iframes is super cool. Nothing could be more straightforward than the markup below:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;img src=\"myimage.jpg\" loading=\"lazy\" alt=\"...\" /&gt;\n&lt;iframe src=\"content.html\" loading=\"lazy\"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>As you can see, no JavaScript, no dynamic swapping of the <code>src</code> attribute’s value, just plain old HTML.</p> \n<p>The <code>loading</code> attribute gives us the option to delay off-screen images and iframes until users scroll to their location on the page. <code>loading</code> can take any of these three values:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><code>lazy</code>: works great for lazy loading</li> \n <li><code>eager</code>: instructs the browser to load the specified content right away</li> \n <li><code>auto</code>: leaves the option to lazy load or not to lazy load up to the browser.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>This method has no rivals: it has zero overhead, it’s clean and simple. However, although at the time of writing most major browsers have <a href=\"https://caniuse.com/#feat=loading-lazy-attr\">good support for the <code>loading</code> attribute</a>, not all browsers are on board yet.</p> \n<p>For an in-depth article on this awesome feature for lazy-loading images, including browser support workarounds, don’t miss Addy Osmani’s “<a href=\"https://addyosmani.com/blog/lazy-loading/\">Native image lazy-loading for the web!</a>”.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2lazyloadingusingtheintersectionobserverapi\">#2 Lazy Loading Using the Intersection Observer API</h2> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Intersection_Observer_API\">Intersection Observer API</a> is a modern interface that you can leverage for lazy loading images and other content.</p> \n<p>Here’s how MDN introduces this API:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>The Intersection Observer API provides a way to asynchronously observe changes in the intersection of a target element with an ancestor element or with a top-level document’s viewport.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>In other words, what’s being asynchronously watched is the intersection of one element with another.</p> \n<p>Denys Mishunov has a great tutorial both on the Intersection Observer and on lazy loading images using it. Here’s what his solution looks like.</p> \n<p>Let’s say you’d like to lazy load an image gallery. The markup for each image would look like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;img data-src=\"image.jpg\" alt=\"test image\"&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Notice how the path to the image is contained inside a <code>data-src</code> attribute, not a <code>src</code> attribute. The reason is that using <code>src</code> means the image would load right away, which is not what you want.</p> \n<p>In the CSS, you give each image a <code>min-height</code> value, let’s say <code>100px</code>. This gives each image placeholder (the img element without the src attribute) a vertical dimension:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"css language-css\">img {\n  min-height: 100px;\n  /* more styles here */\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>In the JavaScript document, you then create a <code>config</code> object and register it with an <code>intersectionObserver</code> instance:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// create config object: rootMargin and threshold\n// are two properties exposed by the interface\nconst config = {\n  rootMargin: '0px 0px 50px 0px',\n  threshold: 0\n};\n\n// register the config object with an instance\n// of intersectionObserver\nlet observer = new intersectionObserver(function(entries, self) {\n  // iterate over each entry\n  entries.forEach(entry =&gt; {\n    // process just the images that are intersecting.\n    // isIntersecting is a property exposed by the interface\n    if(entry.isIntersecting) {\n      // custom function that copies the path to the img\n      // from data-src to src\n      preloadImage(entry.target);\n      // the image is now in place, stop watching\n      self.unobserve(entry.target);\n    }\n  });\n}, config);\n</code></pre> \n<p>Finally, you iterate over all of your images and add them to this <code>iterationObserver</code> instance:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const imgs = document.querySelectorAll('[data-src]');\nimgs.forEach(img =&gt; {\n  observer.observe(img);\n});\n</code></pre> \n<p>The merits of this solution: it’s a breeze to implement, it’s effective, and has the <code>intersectionObserver</code> do the heavy-lifting in terms of calculations.</p> \n<p>On the flip side, although the Intersection Observer API is supported by most browsers in their latest versions, it’s not <a href=\"https://caniuse.com/#feat=intersectionobserver\">consistently supported by all of them</a>. Fortunately, a <a href=\"https://github.com/w3c/IntersectionObserver/tree/master/polyfill\">polyfill is available</a>.</p> \n<p>You can learn more on the Intersection Observer API and the details of this implementation in <a href=\"https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2018/01/deferring-lazy-loading-intersection-observer-api/\">Denys’s article</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"3lozadjs\">#3 Lozad.js</h2> \n<p>A quick and easy alternative for implementing lazy loading of images is to let a JS library do most of the job for you.</p> \n<p>Lozad is a highly performant, light and configurable lazy loader in pure JavaScript with no dependencies. You can use it to lazy load images, videos, iframes and more, and it uses the Intersection Observer API.</p> \n<p>You can include Lozad with npm/Yarn and import it using your module bundler of choice:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install --save lozad\n\nyarn add lozad\n</code></pre> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">import lozad from 'lozad';\n</code></pre> \n<p>Alternatively, you can simply download the library using a CDN and add it to the bottom of the HTML page in a <code>&lt; script&gt;</code> tag:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;script src=\"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/lozad/dist/lozad.min.js\"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Next, for a basic implementation, add the class <em>lozad</em> to the asset in your markup:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"markup language-markup\">&lt;img class=\"lozad\" data-src=\"img.jpg\"&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Finally, instantiate Lozad in your JS document:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const observer = lozad();\nobserver.observe();\n</code></pre> \n<p>You’ll find all the details of how you can use the library on the <a href=\"https://github.com/ApoorvSaxena/lozad.js\">Lozad GitHub repository</a>.</p> \n<p>If you don’t want to dive into the workings of the Intersection Observer API or you’re simply looking for a fast implementation that applies to a variety of content types, Lozad is a great choice.</p> \n<p>Only, be mindful of browser support and eventually integrate this library with a polyfill for the Intersection Observer API.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/five-techniques-lazy-load-images-website-performance/?utm_source=rss\">Five Ways to Lazy Load Images for Better Website Performance</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=7GHJTfs8iVY:D3fQHaQBI98:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=7GHJTfs8iVY:D3fQHaQBI98:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/7GHJTfs8iVY\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Wed, 01 Apr 2020 13:00:29 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1585618767lazy-load-images.png","linkMd5":"348aae744f92b9d1c48ff3a07a411cb9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-162_43bf1f20344c0ee9.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":6930,"destBytes":6930,"author":"Maria Antonietta Perna","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/1585618767lazy-load-images.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-162_43bf1f20344c0ee9.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492178800lazy-loading-unsplash.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn20@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-41-634_da178a82a0a5c9d9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=7GHJTfs8iVY:D3fQHaQBI98:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn91@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-47-368_25296ac9b0b56ddc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/7GHJTfs8iVY":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn57@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-35-106_591f7b67101678a4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483280},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Why Flippa Is the Best Place to Sell Your Website","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176633","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/why-flippa-is-the-best-place-to-sell-your-website/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Why Flippa Is the Best Place to Sell Your Website\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594699498flippa.png\" alt=\"Why Flippa is the Best Place to Sell Your Website\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594699498flippa-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594699498flippa.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.flippa.com/\">Flippa</a> is a platform for buying and selling online businesses. In this article, we’ll look at how buying an online business through Flippa compares with buying one through a broker.</strong></p> \n<p>Digital real estate will become the next great commodity. Individuals and companies alike will buy and sell their assets as a means of investment, trading to scale up and continuing to invest for growth. The ability to buy and sell these commodities with ease has already become a battleground where a multitude of businesses are vying to win. Just as with real estate, cryptocurrency, stocks and bonds, or even precious metals, there is a need to trade these digital assets on the free market.</p> \n<p>Deciding between a peer-to-peer marketplace like Flippa.com versus a <a href=\"https://www.flippa.com/businesses/business-brokers\">website broker</a> is critical when looking for the right opportunity, accessing the largest base of buyers, speed of sale and price optimization. </p> \n<p>Now, <a href=\"https://thenextweb.com/growth-quarters/2020/01/30/digital-trends-2020-every-single-stat-you-need-to-know-about-the-internet/\">more than ever before</a>, there’s a new group entering the digital economy. Traditional industries have been upended and jobs that existed only months ago are no longer viable. Thanks to these fast-moving changes, a whole new group of people will find themselves in ownership positions, running digital real estate and extrapolating value out of a predominantly online world. Every generation is now aware of the opportunity: you can supplement your income, or completely replace your traditional income stream, from the comfort of your home.</p> \n<p>So what happens when there’s literally hundreds of millions of digital real estate assets in operation? They become tradable. As with traditional real estate, there’s a ready market of buyers clamoring over the best and a steady influx of owners looking to offload their assets as they move to grow their investments.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whataretheplatformspoweringthisneweconomy\">What are the platforms powering this new economy?</h2> \n<p>Before we jump into the platforms available to trade digital assets, we should consider the platforms that have led the way in creating this new economy. The number of tradable sites and other digital assets that are powering this growing economy is staggering, and the data behind the platforms that are powering this new asset class are equally enthralling. Whether we’re talking about “traditional” ecommerce sites focussed on selling branded product held in local warehouses, modern drop-shipping storefronts that essentially operate as middlemen between manufacturers and customers, or websites based on entertainment and information, driving revenue through advertising or affiliate marketing programs, there are a few platforms that are absolutely dominating this space and they are doing so in historical fashion.</p> \n<p>Let’s take a look at the four largest platforms that are leading the way for the traders of digital assets within the Flippa marketplace and through digital brokerage firms.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594698547amazon.jpg\" alt=\"stacked ecommerce icons\" width=\"1000\" height=\"507\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176644\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"amazon\">Amazon</h3> \n<p>All hail the king. The once-upon-a-time electronic book seller is not just the largest online retailer on the planet at this point, but dominates the booming digital asset economy as well.</p> \n<p>Did you know that half of all sales on Amazon come from third-party sellers? <a href=\"https://qz.com/1256651/amazon-marketplace-sold-more-stuff-than-amazon-itself-in-2017/\">It’s true</a>. There are actually more goods being sold through Amazon’s retail site by third-party vendors than Amazon is selling itself. If you take a look the next time you’re purchasing something through this behemoth, notice if it says the item is sold and/or shipped by Amazon or another party. It’s nearly impossible to survive as a consumer packaged goods brand these days without a presence on Amazon. And, once there, it’s all about competing through optimized listings and carefully positioned advertising to reach the number one space within your given niche.</p> \n<p>What many forward thinking entrepreneurs discovered through the Amazon platform was their Fulfilled by Amazon (FBA) system that essentially runs as a hands-off logistics integration. Today, there are over two million FBA sites live online, with 3,500 sellers joining that ecosystem daily. These businesses have found a way to move their product through Amazon’s system by providing the goods and marketing, but allowing Amazon to handle all of the fulfillment and customer service. In fact, these businesses have found so much success that it’s suggested the average turnover per FBA store is $115,000 annually.</p> \n<h3 id=\"shopify\">Shopify</h3> \n<p>Shopify has made a very strong name for itself over the past decade and is now the go-to answer for any business or individual looking to set up an independent ecommerce business with ease. It currently <a href=\"https://ecommerce-platforms.com/articles/best-shopify-stores\">boasts over 500,000 active sites</a> and the average revenue per business is noted at $50,000 per year. The added benefit that many users find when working with Shopify to build a successful digital business is the ability to readily integrate with several drop shipping service providers such as <a href=\"https://www.oberlo.com/\">Oberlo</a>. These plugins allow users to select items from overseas manufacturers and warehousers which they can sell on their site without the hassle, or upfront expenses, associated with purchasing, storing, and shipping inventory from their own location.</p> \n<h3 id=\"googleadsense\">Google AdSense</h3> \n<p>Not all digital businesses are selling products. Many, perhaps even most, are creating content, be it information or entertainment, and supplementing that content with advertisements in order to generate revenue. Google’s AdSense platform has made it incredibly easy for even the most amateur digital asset holders to monetize their websites. Opposed to a traditional newspaper or television stations that might be seeking out individual companies to sponsor their programming, AdSense simply plugs into your site using smart API integration and places appropriate ads on your website without any negotiation. At this point, over <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_AdSense#:~:text=Over%2011.1%20million%20websites%20use%20AdSense.\">11.1 million websites have integrated the AdSense platform</a>, each generating average revenue of $3,500 per year. Combined, AdSense has a value of $7billion in annual revenue. No wonder so many eager entrepreneurs are looking to trade these commodities.</p> \n<h3 id=\"wordpress\">WordPress</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://hostingtribunal.com/blog/wordpress-statistics/#gref\">Powering 35% of the Internet in 2020</a>, WordPress is one of (if not the) largest host of monetized, tradable digital assets in the world. Used for a variety of businesses from ecommerce companies to brick and mortar stores in need of a digital presence, WordPress truly serves the entire community. Bloggers certainly have a strong affinity with WordPress due to the ease of use, SEO practicalities, and thousands of helpful plugins. Of those bloggers, 65% have either a product or a service for sale, and 66% of them make money with their content. Professional bloggers have been reported to make an average of $185,000 per blog per year, while hobbyists are reporting an average of $16,000 per year.</p> \n<p>Many digital entrepreneurs use WordPress as a host for their ecommerce businesses, 28% of which are using the WordPress owned WooCommerce platform, which has similar integrations to Shopify as far as building a drop shipping business or managing warehoused inventory for online sale.</p> \n<p>All said and done, this was a lot of information just to let you know that digital entrepreneurship is big business and sees no signs of slowing down!</p> \n<p>If you already own and manage a content site or ecommerce business, or if you’re looking to enter the industry by acquiring an already successful online business, the question remains: what is the best way to go about it?</p> \n<p>Categorically, the best option for nearly all online businesses, websites, and investors is <a href=\"https://www.flippa.com/\">Flippa.com</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatarethedifferencesbetweenflippaandabroker\">What are the differences between Flippa and a broker?</h2> \n<p>The easiest way to understand the difference between Flippa and a broker is to draw an analogy. Let’s pretend that, rather than a digital asset, you’re in the market to either buy or sell a piece of art.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1594698574art.jpg\" alt=\"man viewing a wall of artworks\" width=\"1000\" height=\"568\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176645\" /></p> \n<p>As an art buyer, you want to see the widest selection of art available. You want to see paintings, drawings, sculptures, and maybe some modern art concepts that haven’t even crossed your mind. And beyond that, you want to be able to speak to the artists themselves. You want the opportunity to ask them about their work, what it means, why and how they created it. Then, you want the opportunity to negotiate with the artist for a price that works for your budget. Essentially, as a buyer, you want the largest selection, you want a great experience, and you want a fair price.</p> \n<p>As a seller, you want to showcase your artwork on a stage that gets the most attention. You know that you’ll likely only sell a few pieces of art each year, or maybe just one piece every couple of years, so you want the best chance of finding a buyer who’s excited about what you’ve created. More so, you realize that your art is unique, so you want the chance to explain to potential buyers why yours is worth the money. And, of course, you want to make as much as possible through the sale.</p> \n<p>Essentially, as a seller, you want the largest available field of buyers, a simple communication process, and you want to be able to make the most money possible.</p> \n<p>If these are your requirements as a buyer or a seller of digital assets, Flippa wins, hands down, when compared to a broker. As a peer to peer marketplace, Flippa provides the largest selection of assets, the most people searching to buy an asset, the most fluid communication experience, and the ability to negotiate for the best price possible on both sides of the deal.</p> \n<p>Don’t get us wrong. Brokers can also be great.</p> \n<p>Let’s look again at art as a parallel to digital assets. In this scenario, a broker will often have a very nice, yet much smaller selection of works. Many of their pieces are incredibly high in value, but their process for selling those pieces is much more closed. They work with a narrow range of creators and a small group of potential buyers who are all looking for something highly specific. In addition, the broker will take over the sales process, performing the burden of communications and negotiations as a middleman, which can certainly be a benefit to some, but this separates the seller from the buyer, removing the excitement from the potential sale.</p> \n<p>Selling with Flippa would be like selling at a popular gallery in the middle of a major city. People flow in and out, looking for all sorts of deals, from affordable to expensive, from paintings to sculptures, often looking to move quickly once they find what they like.</p> \n<p>Replace the paintings, sculptures, and drawings that an artist might sell with the ecommerce businesses, content sites, and SaaS products that a digital entrepreneur might sell, and you have the difference between Flippa and a digital assets broker. While brokers often have fantastic assets, it’s a relatively small collection, their pool of potential buyers is rather small, and there are hurdles within the acquisition process that must be conquered. A company like Flippa, on the other hand, has an extensive portfolio, an massive user base, and a platform that’s quite easy to join and navigate without any help.</p> \n<p>What’s more in our reasoning to choose Flippa in this equation is that <a href=\"https://www.flippa.com/businesses/business-brokers\">Flippa actually works in partnership with brokers</a> as well, should that be your preferred method of going about the process. Flippa’s network of brokers combines the best of both worlds. If you’re new to trading digital assets or you just don’t have the time or energy to work the sale yourself, choosing to work with one of the brokers recognized by Flippa will give you that hands-on treatment, but also gives you the advantage of the size of the Flippa community.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/why-flippa-is-the-best-place-to-sell-your-website/?utm_source=rss\">Why Flippa Is the Best Place to Sell Your Website</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=3IamY2L3UTw:WUo8Q8HckmU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"The Second Coming of the Productivity Tool","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=177042","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-second-coming-of-the-productivity-tool/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"The Second Coming of the Productivity Tool\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596790397robot.png\" alt=\"AI under construction\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596790397robot-300x158.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596790397robot-768x404.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596790397robot.png 876w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>I’ve been testing a range of information management and Second Brain tools this year, from&nbsp;<a href=\"https://bear.app/\">Bear</a>&nbsp;to&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.notion.so/\">Notion</a>&nbsp;to&nbsp;<a href=\"https://obsidian.md/\">Obsidian</a>.</strong></p> \n<p>In most of these cases, I’ve tried the apps before or used them for years. This year, I’ve endeavored to settle on my selections, commit, and get the workflows sorted out. I’ve been doing this with other mainstays in my system like&nbsp;<a href=\"https://textexpander.com/\">TextExpander</a>&nbsp;(a snippet manager) and&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.alfredapp.com/\">Alfred</a>&nbsp;(a powerful launcher) as well. Seven months into the year, I’m confident that this effort has been fruitful.</p> \n<p>Managing complexity without compromising it has always been interesting to me. My first gig with meaningful traffic was as a Lifehack writer in the mid-2000s. I’ve gorged myself on and become disillusioned by my quest for software holy grails more times than I can count. This quest is even a hereditary calling of sorts. As a kid, car conversations with my father compared the merits of Grandview and Lotus Agenda, or how much you could get done with an&nbsp;<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atari_Portfolio\">Atari Portfolio</a>&nbsp;on the train (an incredible amount, said with&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.macstories.net/stories/working-on-the-ipad-one-year-later-still-my-favorite-computer/\">Viticci</a>-esque passion). He taught me spreadsheets by having us log our jogging metrics on a Macintosh Portable. This is not a very portable device, for the record:</p> \n<p><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-177043\" src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596788866Macintosh_Portable-IMG_7541-9900000000079e3c.jpg\" alt=\"Macintosh Portable\" width=\"800\" height=\"533\" /></p> \n<p>I’m sure his heart still lies with an obscure 90s app called DayInfo — along with his data from that era, no doubt.</p> \n<p>This impossible but driving need to Reach Clarity has, for better or worse, entrenched itself within my own brain.</p> \n<p>Between then and now, information management and productivity software wandered in the wilderness. As a species, we have mastered the art of the list app. We have put more effort into this endeavour than the moon landing and the Large Hadron Collider combined. Nothing has impeded our ability to imagine new ways of being reminded about the things on the list.</p> \n<p>And yet the list has remained an unsatisfying — although not impotent — tool on its own. Lists are bad at context, yet we know that actions are meaningless without strategy. So, we’ve tried to brute force systems that provide context through lists. Folders of lists.&nbsp;<em>Areas of responsibilities</em>&nbsp;full of lists. The Today list, tomorrow’s list, Someday/Maybe,&nbsp;lists in kanban&nbsp;boards and listicles of list tips, tricks, and apps. Brain-dump into your big list and schedule a weekly review&nbsp;to sort that into your little lists. In this wilderness, lists have been our manna.</p> \n<p>For much of the last five years, I used a Bullet Journal-esque Markdown file to manage my tasks. It felt like a private stance of rejection against the pandering, posing performance art of productivity pornography.</p> \n<p>It felt good. It was a productive time.</p> \n<p>This isn’t an uncommon progression for the knowledge worker, whether you’re a developer, writer, or you sell a Memberful subscription to your clarinet lessons. Well ahead of the curve, Gina Trapani, founding editor of Lifehacker, became a&nbsp;<a href=\"http://todotxt.org/\">todo.txt</a>&nbsp;proponent. We’d all been let down by the failure of software to do what we had hoped it would do. We wanted it to connect the strategic and execution contexts for our lives, bridging the divide between the two so we could move forward with purpose. Instead, we had lists.</p> \n<p>Until the last few years, that is, when something broke loose and the fundamentalist rigidity around structure began to fall away. Notion created the momentum here. It cracked the tough UI problems of mixing free-form content tools with the power of the database.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://airtable.com/\">Airtable</a>&nbsp;pushed the spreadsheet into new territory. Its API is in the wild, giving us a glimpse at how much you can achieve when you can connect these engines to your data. A veritable horde stampedes over Notion’s social media manager every day, begging for an API timeline.</p> \n<p>I love the tools in this new wave of productivity software. I’ve used Notion personally for a few years and have been rebuilding SitePoint’s editorial workflow on it over the past month or two. For me, Notion&nbsp;<em>is</em>&nbsp;a holy grail.</p> [caption id=\"attachment_177044\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"273\"]\n<img class=\"size-full wp-image-177044\" src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596788927notion-views-9903cf06db028a3c.png\" alt=\"Notion\" width=\"273\" height=\"488\" />Freedom from lists: a mirage, 2020[/caption] \n<p>Sure, there are frequent moments of frustration. It’s so close to being unstoppably powerful – if only we had the API, or more powerful formulas and relational interactions. But these frustrations are borne of seeing the unfulfilled potential, rather than feeling stifled by inherent limitations. That’s an exciting shift.</p> \n<p>For all its anti-structure, Notion is best when you know how you want to structure your life, team, project, or data. It gives you all the tools you need to design workflows and dashboards that will be most useful for your use case. It is flexible to the extreme, but not the ideal free-wheeler.</p> \n<p>There’s another important side of information management. The ideal tool looks different when you want to build an organic body of knowledge. These tools should help you create context between discrete units of knowledge. They should help you do so rapidly without excessive structural overhead. The most valuable features are seamless interlinking, fast search, universal capture, and simplicity.</p> \n<p>In recent years, people like&nbsp;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/ctietze\">Christian Tietze</a>&nbsp;have shared how they build digital&nbsp;<a href=\"https://zettelkasten.de/posts/overview/\"><em>zettelkastens</em></a>&nbsp;with apps like&nbsp;<a href=\"https://brettterpstra.com/projects/nvalt/\">nvALT</a>. This concept has driven the wave of new apps built around these needs. In broad strokes, it’s an atomic database of all the information you acquire and deem worthy of saving. It grows and – this is the key – forms connections with the rest of your atomic notes over time. Similar thinking is at the root of the&nbsp;<a href=\"https://fortelabs.co/blog/basboverview/\">Second Brain</a>&nbsp;concept.</p> \n<p>There are a few apps bringing this style of information management into the future. The most famous is Roam Research, which I have not tried myself.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://obsidian.md/\">Obsidian</a>&nbsp;is another option that works well for developers. It’s also great for people who otherwise deal with a lot of code (like me – as an occasional developer, but primarily as an editor of content about code). Obsidian stores notes in local, plaintext Markdown, and you can use your preferred sync method.</p> [caption id=\"attachment_177045\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"800\"]\n<img class=\"size-full wp-image-177045\" src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596788985formatting-990000079e04513c.jpg\" alt=\"Obsidian's formatting options\" width=\"800\" height=\"919\" /> Obsidian’s formatting options[/caption] \n<p>It handles code blocks well, and offers features like Vim mode and a graph view of your note connections. For developers, the ideal tool should also be able to serve as a code snippet manager. Obsidian has what it takes, and you can extend it with plugins to make up for functionality you miss.</p> \n<p>My friend&nbsp;<a href=\"https://joeprevite.com/\">Joe Previte</a>&nbsp;recently posted a Twitter thread about these tools which introduced me to a new option,&nbsp;<a href=\"https://foambubble.github.io/foam/\">Foam</a>.</p> \n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"> \n <p dir=\"ltr\" lang=\"en\">I decided to experiment with Foam by <a href=\"https://twitter.com/jevakallio?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@jevakallio</a> today.</p> \n <p>Here is a thread with my notes 👇🏼</p> \n <p>— Joe Previte (@jsjoeio) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/jsjoeio/status/1278458385676021760?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">July 1, 2020</a></p>\n</blockquote> \n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p> \n<p>If the ideal knowledge manager should be able to replace your snippet manager, wouldn’t it be ideal if you could drive it from the app you write code in?</p> \n<p>Foam takes its cues from Roam Research — no surprise — but it’s built on Visual Studio Code and GitHub. Like Obsidian, it isn’t bound to the cloud, but unlike Obsidian it’s truly free and open source.</p> \n<p>The way in which it is extensible differs, too. As Joe notes, the ability to work with Code’s multitude of extensions gives Foam a powerful leg up. This is truer the more the use case applies to developers. Compare the options available in Code versus Obsidian’s built-in search, Vim mode, or GitHub integration. As with Obsidian, you can write your own extensions (if you’re a Premium member, you can access&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/visual-studio-code-end-to-end-editing-and-debugging-tools-for-web-developers/?utm_source=SitePoint&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=Versioning\">this VS Code&nbsp;book from Wiley</a>&nbsp;to learn how).</p> \n<p>Obsidian is the batteries-included option and it’s a good one. If you want absolute control at the expense of time, Foam offers it. Conversely, VS Code’s popularity means there are more off-the-shelf workflows to use with your other tools.</p> \n<p>While I manage my life in Notion, I manage my writing with Git. That happens beneath a layer of proprietary apps like Ulysses, and I’m uninterested in moving the writing process itself to Code. But it does make this approach appealing for my notes.</p> \n<p>We’ve gained so much power in our tools that you can almost replace a raft of apps with two. Are we far from seeing structured and unstructured information management apps collide? I don’t know, but for clarity’s sake it may be best that they don’t. Perhaps that’s how my brain works, and the app that does it all for you is taking shape in a repo somewhere.</p> \n<p>But for the first time in a long time, I’m enjoying the quest for the holy grail again.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596790200robot.jpg\" alt=\"AI under construction\" width=\"840\" height=\"250\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-177051\" /></p> \n<p><strong>This editorial was originally published in the <a href=\"http://go.sitepoint.com/t/y-A4F56872960D5149\">23 July 2020 issue of SitePoint Weekly</a>.</strong> To get the freshest resources, stories, and exclusive content for web developers, designers, and digital creators in your inbox each week, <a href=\"https://go.sitepoint.com/h/y/FF8A1E8197B86A00\">sign up here</a>.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-second-coming-of-the-productivity-tool/?utm_source=rss\">The Second Coming of the Productivity Tool</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a
