Falconer","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596790397robot.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn50@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-26-873_732e5f9b44333073.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596788866Macintosh_Portable-IMG_7541-9900000000079e3c.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn62@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-41-619_ca42b5d594441c43.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596788927notion-views-9903cf06db028a3c.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn65@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-41-145_2ed6c5a3d6745b3e.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596788985formatting-990000079e04513c.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn62@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-44-958_b0af6db2117f290b.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596790200robot.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn46@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-45-914_4381601be8a47162.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=zXID788nNN8:MNswIKy1AJA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn71@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-36-081_8bb2e97f8baaf695.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/zXID788nNN8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn21@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-45-655_609c40d3866a7d7f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483248},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"MEAN Stack: Build an App with Angular and the Angular CLI","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=158416","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/mean-stack-angular-angular-cli/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"MEAN Stack: Build an App with Angular and the Angular CLI\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/1584495070mean-stack-angular.png\" alt=\"MEAN Stack: Build an App with Angular and the Angular CLI\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/1584495070mean-stack-angular-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/1584495070mean-stack-angular.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>In this tutorial, we’re going to look at managing user authentication in the MEAN stack. We’ll use the most common MEAN architecture of having an Angular single-page app using a REST API built with Node, Express and MongoDB.</strong></p> \n<p>When thinking about user authentication, we need to tackle the following things:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>let a user register</li> \n <li>save user data, but never directly store passwords</li> \n <li>let a returning user log in</li> \n <li>keep a logged in user’s session alive between page visits</li> \n <li>have some pages that can only been seen by logged in users</li> \n <li>change output to the screen depending on logged in status (for example, a “login” button or a “my profile” button).</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Before we dive into the code, let’s take a few minutes for a high-level look at how authentication is going to work in the MEAN stack.</p> \n<h2 id=\"themeanstackauthenticationflow\">The MEAN Stack Authentication Flow</h2> \n<p>So what does authentication look like in the MEAN stack?</p> \n<p>Still keeping this at a high level, these are the components of the flow:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>user data is stored in MongoDB, with the passwords hashed</li> \n <li>CRUD functions are built in an Express API — Create (register), Read (login, get profile), Update, Delete</li> \n <li>an Angular application calls the API and deals with the responses</li> \n <li>the Express API generates a <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/using-json-web-tokens-node-js/\">JSON Web Token</a> (JWT, pronounced “Jot”) upon registration or login, and passes this to the Angular application</li> \n <li>the Angular application stores the JWT in order to maintain the user’s session</li> \n <li>the Angular application checks the validity of the JWT when displaying protected views</li> \n <li>the Angular application passes the JWT back to Express when calling protected API routes.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>JWTs are preferred over cookies for maintaining the session state in the browser. Cookies are better for maintaining state when using a server-side application.</p> \n<h2 id=\"theexampleapplication\">The Example Application</h2> \n<p>The code for this tutorial is available on <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/mean-authentication\">GitHub</a>. To run the application, you’ll need to have <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">Node.js installed</a>, along with <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/an-introduction-to-mongodb/\">MongoDB</a>. (For instructions on how to install, please refer to <a href=\"https://docs.mongodb.org/manual/administration/install-community/\">Mongo’s official documentation — Windows, Linux, macOS</a>).</p> \n<h3 id=\"theangularapp\">The Angular App</h3> \n<p>To keep the example in this tutorial simple, we’ll start with an Angular app with four pages:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>home page</li> \n <li>register page</li> \n <li>login page</li> \n <li>profile page</li> \n</ol> \n<p>The pages are pretty basic and look like this to start with:</p> \n<p><img src=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/1453465473CombinedScreenshots-1024x620.png\" alt=\"Screenshots of the app\" /></p> \n<p>The profile page will only be accessible to authenticated users. All the files for the Angular app are in a folder inside the Angular CLI app called <code>/client</code>.</p> \n<p>We’ll use the Angular CLI for building and running the local server. If you’re unfamiliar with the Angular CLI, refer to the <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/angular-2-tutorial/\">Building a Todo App with Angular CLI</a> tutorial to get started.</p> \n<h3 id=\"therestapi\">The REST API</h3> \n<p>We’ll also start off with the skeleton of a REST API built with Node, Express and MongoDB, using <a href=\"http://mongoosejs.com/\">Mongoose</a> to manage the schemas. This API should initially have three routes:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><code>/api/register</code> (POST), to handle new users registering</li> \n <li><code>/api/login</code> (POST), to handle returning users logging in</li> \n <li><code>/api/profile/USERID</code> (GET), to return profile details when given a <code>USERID</code></li> \n</ol> \n<p>Let’s set that up now. We can use the <a href=\"https://expressjs.com/en/starter/generator.html\">express-generator</a> tool to create a lot of the boiler plate for us. If this is new for you, we have a <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/create-new-express-js-apps-with-express-generator/\">tutorial on using it here</a>.</p> \n<p>Install it with <code>npm i -g express-generator</code>. Then, create a new Express app, choosing <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/a-beginners-guide-to-pug/\">Pug</a> as the view engine:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">express -v pug mean-authentication\n</code></pre> \n<p>When the generator has run, change into the project directory and install the dependencies:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">cd mean-authentication\nnpm i\n</code></pre> \n<p>At the time of writing, this pulls in an outdated version of Pug. Let’s fix that:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm i pug@latest\n</code></pre> \n<p>We can also install Mongoose while we’re at it:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm i mongoose\n</code></pre> \n<p>Next, we need to create our folder structure.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Remove the <code>public</code> folder: <code>rm -rf public</code>.</li> \n <li>Create an <code>api</code> directory: <code>mkdir api</code>.</li> \n <li>Create a <code>controllers</code>, a <code>models</code>, and a <code>routes</code> directory in the <code>api</code> directory: <code>mkdir -p api/{controllers,models,routes}</code>.</li> \n <li>Create a <code>authenication.js</code> file and a <code>profile.js</code> file in the <code>controllers</code> directory: <code>touch api/controllers/{authentication.js,profile.js}</code>.</li> \n <li>Create a <code>db.js</code> file and a <code>users.js</code> file in the <code>models</code> directory: <code>touch api/models/{db.js,users.js}</code>.</li> \n <li>Create an <code>index.js</code> file in the <code>routes</code> directory: <code>touch api/routes/index.js</code>.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>When you’re done, things should look like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">.\n└── api\n    ├── controllers\n    │   ├── authentication.js\n    │   └── profile.js\n    ├── models\n    │   ├── db.js\n    │   └── users.js\n    └── routes\n        └── index.js\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now let’s add the API functionality. Replace the code in <code>app.js</code> with the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">require('./api/models/db');\n\nconst cookieParser = require('cookie-parser');\nconst createError = require('http-errors');\nconst express = require('express');\nconst logger = require('morgan');\nconst path = require('path');\n\nconst routesApi = require('./api/routes/index');\n\nconst app = express();\n\n// view engine setup\napp.set('views', path.join(__dirname, 'views'));\napp.set('view engine', 'pug');\n\napp.use(logger('dev'));\napp.use(express.json());\napp.use(express.urlencoded({ extended: false }));\napp.use(cookieParser());\napp.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public')));\n\napp.use('/api', routesApi);\n\n// catch 404 and forward to error handler\napp.use((req, res, next) =&gt; {\n  next(createError(404));\n});\n\n// error handler\napp.use((err, req, res, next) =&gt; {\n  // set locals, only providing error in development\n  res.locals.message = err.message;\n  res.locals.error = req.app.get('env') === 'development' ? err : {};\n\n  // render the error page\n  res.status(err.status || 500);\n  res.render('error');\n});\n\nmodule.exports = app;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Add the following to <code>api/models/db.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">require('./users');\nconst mongoose = require('mongoose');\nconst dbURI = 'mongodb://localhost:27017/meanAuth';\n\nmongoose.set('useCreateIndex', true);\nmongoose.connect(dbURI, {\n  useNewUrlParser: true,\n  useUnifiedTopology: true\n});\n\nmongoose.connection.on('connected', () =&gt; {\n  console.log(`Mongoose connected to ${dbURI}`);\n});\nmongoose.connection.on('error', (err) =&gt; {\n  console.log(`Mongoose connection error: ${err}`);\n});\nmongoose.connection.on('disconnected', () =&gt; {\n  console.log('Mongoose disconnected');\n});\n</code></pre> \n<p>Add the following to <code>api/routes/index.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const ctrlAuth = require('../controllers/authentication');\nconst ctrlProfile = require('../controllers/profile');\n\nconst express = require('express');\nconst router = express.Router();\n\n// profile\nrouter.get('/profile/:userid', ctrlProfile.profileRead);\n\n// authentication\nrouter.post('/register', ctrlAuth.register);\nrouter.post('/login', ctrlAuth.login);\n\nmodule.exports = router;\n</code></pre> \n<p>Add the following to <code>api/controllers/profile.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">module.exports.profileRead = (req, res) =&gt; {\n  console.log(`Reading profile ID: ${req.params.userid}`);\n  res.status(200);\n  res.json({\n    message : `Profile read: ${req.params.userid}`\n  });\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>Add the following to <code>api/controllers/authentication.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">module.exports.register = (req, res) =&gt; {\n  console.log(`Registering user: ${req.body.email}`);\n  res.status(200);\n  res.json({\n    message : `User registered: ${req.body.email}`\n  });\n};\n\nmodule.exports.login = (req, res) =&gt; {\n  console.log(`Logging in user: ${req.body.email}`);\n  res.status(200);\n  res.json({\n    message : `User logged in: ${req.body.email}`\n  });\n};\n</code></pre> \n<p>Ensure that Mongo is running and then, finally, start the server with <code>npm run start</code>. If everything is configured properly, you should see a message in your terminal that Mongoose is connected to <code>mongodb://localhost:27017/meanAuth</code>, and you should now be able to make requests to, and get responses from, the API. You can test this with a tool such as <a href=\"https://www.postman.com/\">Postman</a>.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/mean-stack-angular-angular-cli/?utm_source=rss\">MEAN Stack: Build an App with Angular and the Angular CLI</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QH5kpKYX-gk:01GZgIlr7P0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QH5kpKYX-gk:01GZgIlr7P0:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=QH5kpKYX-gk:01GZgIlr7P0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=QH5kpKYX-gk:01GZgIlr7P0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/QH5kpKYX-gk\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 29 Mar 2020 13:00:13 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/1584495070mean-stack-angular.png","linkMd5":"f13dda5a88ab65fa5df6c1f5143d2854","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn37@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-24-673_b8488d10606c4836.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":7934,"destBytes":7934,"author":"Jurgen Van de Moere","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/1584495070mean-stack-angular.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn37@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-24-673_b8488d10606c4836.webp","http://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/1453465473CombinedScreenshots-1024x620.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn36@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-39-769_c5ea9d9ccfb34ea1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=QH5kpKYX-gk:01GZgIlr7P0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-40-955_46e73d48622d10c1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/QH5kpKYX-gk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn50@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-35-094_0994eb36f1b7c135.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483282},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Web Developer Workflow Tools: A Beginner&#8217;s Guide","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175773","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/web-developer-workflow-tools/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Web Developer Workflow Tools: A Beginner’s Guide\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1585885374workflow-tools.png\" alt=\"Workflow Tools Every Web Developer Should Know About\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1585885374workflow-tools-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1585885374workflow-tools.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Here’s a primer for the tools all web developers should get to know, from basic Bash commands to web browser add-ons that will debug your web apps and automate navigation tests, plus continuous integrations pipelines.</strong></p> \n<p>Keep in mind this article is intended to cover the tools that the largest number of web developers will share a need to learn, not a comprehensive listing. So don’t get too mad if your favorite tool isn’t here! (For example, I intentionally left out <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WYSIWYG\">WYSIWYG</a> <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Website_builder\">website builders</a> 😉.) </p> \n<h2 id=\"commandline\">Command Line</h2> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Command_language\">command line</a> is an interface that allows you to interact with the operating system through a console, and it can go a <em>very long</em> way to facilitate and even automate tedious and routine tasks.</p> \n<p>You shouldn’t be afraid of getting your hands dirty with the console. The time you’ll spend learning some basic scripting will most definitely pay off.</p> \n<h3 id=\"bashtoolslinuxmacos\">Bash Tools (Linux, macOS)</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Gnu-bash-logo.svg/180px-Gnu-bash-logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/\">Bash</a> is the most popular shell for the “<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix-like\">Unix-like</a>” operating systems such as Linux and macOS.</p> \n<p>Your mastery — or at the very minimum, a basic knowledge — of the Bash shell can save you <em>a lot</em> of time. Things like locating and renaming files, finding and replacing text strings, can literally take just a few seconds with commands like <code>locate</code> and <code>grep</code> with <code>sed</code>, respectively.</p> \n<p>Become proficient in Bash by reading the <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/bash-quick-start-guide?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Bash Quick Start Guide</a>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"powershellwindows\">PowerShell (Windows)</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/PowerShell_Core_6.0_icon.png/180px-PowerShell_Core_6.0_icon.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/\">PowerShell</a> is the “bash-like” task automation and configuration management framework from Microsoft. It comes with a command-line similar to that of the [Command Prompt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cmd.exe (CMD)), but it also includes <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/module/\">modules</a> and a proper <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/samples/sample-scripts-for-administration?view=powershell-7\">scripting language</a>. But keep in mind that <em>scripting is PowerShell in </em><em>nothing</em> like scripting in Bash. Except for a few exceptions, the commands have entirely different names, meaning that you’ll need to learn these separately.</p> \n<p>PowerShell 7 (under development) is intended as a successor to <a href=\"https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell\">PowerShell Core</a> 6, which was introduced as a successor to PowerShell 5. Who knows, folks at Microsoft might figure the naming thing out by version 8 or 9. 🤷‍♂️</p> \n<h3 id=\"cygwinalsowindows\">Cygwin (also Windows)</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://cygwin.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Cygwin_logo.svg/180px-Cygwin_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>You missed the Bash on Windows? Miss it no more! For those of you used to the power of the Bash shell but working regularly on a Windows environment, there’s an alternative.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://cygwin.com/\">Cygwin</a> is a POSIX-compatible environment that runs natively on Microsoft Windows, where the installation directory behaves like the root and follows a similar directory layout to that found in Unix-like systems.</p> \n<h2 id=\"codeeditors\">Code Editors</h2> \n<p>You almost certainly know what a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source-code_editor\">source-code editor</a> is, but you might not know about some of their <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_user\">power features</a>, such git integration.</p> \n<p>There are <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_development_environment\">integrated development environments</a> (IDEs) such as <a href=\"http://netbeans.apache.org/\">NetBeans</a> and <a href=\"https://www.eclipse.org/\">Eclipse</a> — but they’re bloated with features we mostly won’t care about anyway.</p> \n<p>As web developers, we’re more inclined towards <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-platform_software\">cross-platform tools</a>. Let’s take a look at a few of them.</p> \n<h3 id=\"atom\">Atom</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://atom.io/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Atom_icon.svg/180px-Atom_icon.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Not surprisingly, as it’s developed by GitHub, <a href=\"https://atom.io/\">Atom</a> has the finest embedded Git control of any text editor, specifically aimed for GitHub repositories.</p> \n<p>But that’s not all. The “hackable text editor for the 21st Century” is incredibly easy to customize (see the <a href=\"https://atom.io/docs\">docs</a>), and a rich <a href=\"https://atom.io/packages\">packages</a> and <a href=\"https://atom.io/themes\">themes</a> ecosystem has flourished around it. Be sure to check out the <a href=\"https://blog.atom.io/\">blog</a> and <a href=\"https://discuss.atom.io/\">discussion forums</a> to see what’s been cooking, as there are plenty of regular updates.</p> \n<h3 id=\"sublimetext\">Sublime Text</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sublimetext.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d2/Sublime_Text_3_logo.png/180px-Sublime_Text_3_logo.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sublimetext.com/\">Sublime Text</a> is the oldest product in this list (it’s been around since 2008), and the only one that’s not free. It’s still very popular, and was the first editor to introduce many of the features we considered a given today in any decent code editor, such as “goto anything”, “goto definition”, and “multiple selections”, among others.</p> \n<p>It also has a companion Git client with a very sleek interface, <a href=\"https://www.sublimemerge.com/\">Sublime Merge</a>, introduced in 2018.</p> \n<h3 id=\"visualstudiocode\">Visual Studio Code</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Visual_Studio_Code_1.35_icon.svg/180px-Visual_Studio_Code_1.35_icon.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">Visual Studio Code</a> (not to be confused with <a href=\"https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/\">Visual Studio</a> is another very popular code editor right now, which includes power features such as:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>IntelliSense</strong>, which provides smart completions based on variable types, function definitions, and imported modules.</li> \n <li><strong>Inline debugging</strong> to analyze coding issues right from within the editor.</li> \n <li><strong>Version control</strong> with Git commands built-in (learn <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/versioncontrol\">how to use version control</a>).</li> \n <li><strong>Extensions and customization</strong> which run in separate processes, ensuring they won’t slow down the editor (learn <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/extension-gallery\">more about extensions</a>).</li> \n <li><strong>Cloud integration</strong> with <a href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com\">Microsoft Azure</a> to deploy and host sites, store and query relational and document based data, and scale with serverless computing.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Read our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/visual-studio-code-power-user-guide/\">Visual Studio Code power user’s guide</a> to become a VS Code pro, and dive even deeper with the book <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/visual-studio-code-end-to-end-editing-and-debugging-tools-for-web-developers?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Visual Studio Code: End-to-End Editing and Debugging Tools for Web Developers</a>. </p> \n<h3 id=\"therunnersup\">The Runners Up</h3> \n<p>Although not so popular, <a href=\"http://brackets.io/\">Brackets</a> is worth mentioning, as it’s primarily focused on web development, with a very interesting feature called Live Preview, which gives real-time connection to your browser to <em>instantly visualize changes to CSS and HTML on screen</em>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://notepad-plus-plus.org/\">Notepad++</a> is a drop-in replacement for <a href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/p/windows-notepad/9msmlrh6lzf3?activetab=pivot:overviewtab\">Windows Notepad</a>, very minimalist and lacking some power features we mentioned such as Git integration, but it’s still a powerful, lightweight application to edit code.</p> \n<h4 id=\"commandlinebased\">Command Line–Based</h4> \n<p>As for commaind line–based editors, you’ve got <a href=\"https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/\">Emacs</a> and <a href=\"https://www.vim.org/\">Vim</a> … and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Editor_war\">endless flame wars about which one is better</a>!</p> \n<h2 id=\"browsertoolsdebuggingdebuggingdebugging\">Browser Tools — Debugging, Debugging, Debugging</h2> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_development_tools\">web development tools</a> shipped by some browsers aren’t quite website builders or IDEs, as they neither assist in the direct creation of a web page nor are a replacement for a code editor. Rather, they help to test the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface\">user interface</a> (UI) of the project you’re working on.</p> \n<p>Back in the day, you’d need a number of extensions to make for a decent debugging environment, but nowadays most browsers have great built-in tools to help web developers.</p> \n<p>Some tools you can expect to find:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>A <strong>DOM inspector</strong> to edit HTML and CSS code directly on the <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Document_Object_Model\">document object model</a> (DOM), view <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/EventListener\">event listeners</a>, and set <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Tools/Debugger/Break_on_DOM_mutation\">DOM mutation breakpoints</a>.</li> \n <li>A <strong>console</strong> to view and filter log messages, inspect JavaScript objects and <a href=\"https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_htmldom_nodes.asp\">DOM nodes</a>, and run JavaScript code in the context of the active window or frame.</li> \n <li>A <strong>debugger</strong> to control the execution flow stepping through code, and set <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Tools/Debugger/How_to/Examine,_modify,_and_watch_variables\">watches</a> and breakpoints.</li> \n <li>A <strong>network monitor</strong> to inspect requests and responses from the network and browser cache, including asynchronous <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XMLHttpRequest\">XMLHttpRequest</a> (XHR) — all of which can be very useful to identify bottlenecks.</li> \n <li>An <strong>accessibility inspector</strong> to access the page’s accessibility (a11y) tree, allowing you to check what’s missing or otherwise what needs attention to make your site available to as many people as possible.</li> \n <li><strong>Performance measurement</strong> to <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiling_(computer_programming)\">profile</a> execution time and system resources required by the site and walk <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Glossary/Call_stack\">JavaScript call stacks</a>.</li> \n <li><strong>Memory measurement</strong> to track memory consumption and compare <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools/memory-problems/heap-snapshots\">heap snapshots</a> at different stages of the code execution.</li> \n <li>A <strong>storage manager</strong> to handle cached data, cookies, <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Web_Storage_API\">web storage</a>, and even <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/IndexedDB_API\">IndexedDB</a> structured data.</li> \n <li>A <strong>service worker manager</strong> to handle and debug <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Service_Worker_API/Using_Service_Workers\">service workers</a> with updates, unregisters, and start/stop of individual workers.</li> \n <li>An <strong>emulator</strong> to test for different screen resolutions, and even different location coordinates.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"chromedevtools\">Chrome DevTools</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.google.com/chrome/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Google_Chrome_icon_%28September_2014%29.svg/180px-Google_Chrome_icon_%28September_2014%29.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.google.com/chrome/\">Google Chrome</a> comes with a comprehensive and incredibly well-documented set called <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools\">DevTools</a>.</p> \n<p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/VYyQv0CSZOE\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe></p> \n<p>In fact, it’s a good idea to visit Google’s <a href=\"https://developers.google.com/web/tools\">Tools for Web Developers</a>, as you’ll find plenty of useful resources.</p> \n<h3 id=\"firefoxdevelopertools\">Firefox Developer Tools</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.mozilla.org/firefox/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Firefox_logo%2C_2019.svg/180px-Firefox_logo%2C_2019.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.mozilla.org/firefox/\">Firefox</a> first introduced the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOM_Inspector\">DOM inspector</a> in version 3, and ever since then <strong>its <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Tools\">Developer Tools</a> are a state-of-the-art set that comes with extra goodies</strong> such as <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Tools/Eyedropper\">Eyedropper</a>, <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Tools/Taking_screenshots\">taking screenshots</a>, and <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Tools/Rulers\">rulers</a>, to name a few.</p> \n<p>Likewise, the <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/\">Mozilla Developer Network</a> (MDN) is a mandatory resource for web developers.</p> \n<h3 id=\"safaridevelopertools\">Safari Developer Tools</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.apple.com/safari/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Safari_browser_logo.svg/180px-Safari_browser_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Because of its lack of features and poor support to web developers, <a href=\"https://www.apple.com/safari/\">Apple Safari</a> is a pain to work with, and, like Internet Explorer back in the day, it would be nice not to have to deal with it. But you just have to.</p> \n<p>It does ship <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/safari/tools/\">Web Development Tools</a> that aren’t nearly as comprehensive as the aforementioned ones, and all the documentation you’ll get is what someone may have written over a lunch break. (Yes, that’s all there is.)</p> \n<h3 id=\"others\">Others</h3> \n<p>Even <a href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/edge\">Microsoft Edge</a>, the successor of infamous Internet Explorer, has a decent set of <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide\">Developer Tools</a>!</p> \n<p>And if you fancy good old <a href=\"https://www.opera.com/\">Opera</a>, check <a href=\"https://superuser.com/a/1323259\">this Stack Exchange answer</a> to see how you open its developer tools.</p> \n<p>Learn the Chrome and Firefox DevTools with <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/browser-devtool-secrets/?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Browser Devtool Secrets</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"javascripttools\">JavaScript Tools</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Node.js_logo.svg/180px-Node.js_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Since the arrival of <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/\">Node.js</a> (the runtime environment that executes JavaScript code outside the web browser), JavaScript has been used not only to enhance user interfaces but to write command-line tools and for <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Server-side_scripting\">server-side scripting</a> programs, effectively establishing the “JavaScript everywhere” paradigm.</p> \n<p>Consequently a whole ecosystem has emerged around it, and here are some tools you need to know.</p> \n<h3 id=\"npm\">npm</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Npm-logo.svg/180px-Npm-logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/\">Node package manager</a> (npm) claims to be “the world’s largest software registry”, and it’s an essential tool as it is <em>the main way to distribute JavaScript code these days</em>.</p> \n<p>As listed on its website, you can use npm to:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/web-developer-workflow-tools/?utm_source=rss\">Web Developer Workflow Tools: A Beginner’s Guide</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Aq3LwaT8YRA:VlHW15mYxDc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Aq3LwaT8YRA:VlHW15mYxDc:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=Aq3LwaT8YRA:VlHW15mYxDc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Aq3LwaT8YRA:VlHW15mYxDc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" imedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Safari_browser_logo.svg/180px-Safari_browser_logo.svg.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn50@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-45-268_0bfe284aabb6749f.webp","https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Node.js_logo.svg/180px-Node.js_logo.svg.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn33@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-35-169_593679a552bfb5f5.webp","https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Npm-logo.svg/180px-Npm-logo.svg.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn94@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-35-180_c468ab7b30d9d495.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=Aq3LwaT8YRA:VlHW15mYxDc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn53@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-35-430_935c4da9b7594d7e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/Aq3LwaT8YRA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn55@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-38-692_94f28f0b0f5ec2f5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483276},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"10 Git Techniques You Need to Know Before You Join a Team","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175377","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/git-techniques-to-know-before-you-join-a-team/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"10 Git Techniques You Need to Know Before You Join a Team\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583410943git-techniques.png\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583410943git-techniques-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583410943git-techniques.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Have you been using Git for some time but never in a team environment? Are you familiar with <a href=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/git-for-beginners/\">the basics of Git</a> but unsure how large teams use Git at work?</strong></p> \n<p>In this post, I’ll talk about the basic Git techniques that you must be familiar with before you join a team. I’ve listed them in an order that you’d logically follow to contribute to a repository, as the importance of each step is paramount. Let’s now jump into the list.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1cloninggettingstartedinateam\">1. Cloning: Getting Started in a Team</h2> \n<p>If you’ve used Git for personal projects, you may only have initialized a project from scratch and added to it over time. When you’re working on an existing codebase, the first step is to clone the codebase into your local system. This enables you to work on your copy of the repository without any interference from other changes.</p> \n<p>To clone a repository, run the <code>git clone</code> command, followed by the path to the repository:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git clone /path/to/repo\n</code></pre> \n<p>If your source doesn’t reside in the same system, you can SSH to a remote system and clone too:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git clone username@remote_system_ip:/path/to/repo/on/remote\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you’re cloning from a source on the Internet, you can simply add the URL:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git clone https://github.com/sdaityari/my_git_project.git\n</code></pre> \n<p>Whenever you’re cloning a repository, you’ve <a href=\"https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-on-the-Server-The-Protocols\">the choice of multiple protocols</a> to connect to the source. In the GitHub example above, I’ve used the <code>https</code> protocol.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2managingremotesingit\">2. Managing Remotes in Git</h2> \n<p>Once you’ve cloned your repository, it still maintains a pointer to the source. This pointer is an example of a remote in Git. A remote is a pointer to another copy of the same repository. When you clone a repository, a pointer <code>origin</code> is automatically created which points to the source.</p> \n<p>You can check a list of remotes in a repository by running the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git remove -v\n</code></pre> \n<p>To add a remote, you can use the <code>git remote add</code> command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git remote add remote_name remote_address\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can remove a remote using the <code>git remote remove</code> command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git remote remove remote_name\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you’d like to change the address of a remote, you can use the <code>set-url</code> command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git remote set-url remote_name new_remote_address\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"3branchingingit\">3. Branching in Git</h2> \n<p>The biggest advantage of Git over other version control systems is the power of its branches. Before I jump into the essentials of branching, you may be wondering <em>what a branch is</em>. A branch is a pointer to a commit in your repository, which in turn points to its predecessor. Therefore, a branch represents a list of commits in chronological order. When you create a branch, you effectively create only a new pointer to a commit. However, in essence, it represents a new, independent path of development.</p> \n<p>If you’ve been working on your own project, you may never have consciously used branches. By default, Git uses the <code>master</code> branch for development. Any new commits are added to this branch.</p> \n<p>Branching is necessary for Git to bifurcate lines of work in a project. At a single time, there may be many developers who are working on a variety of different problems. Ideally, these problems are worked on in different branches to ensure logical separation of new code until code review and merge.</p> \n<p>To check a list of branches and the current active branch, run the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git branch\n</code></pre> \n<p>To create a new branch, run the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git branch new_branch\n</code></pre> \n<p>Even though Git creates a new branch, notice that your active branch is still the old one. To start development in a new branch, run the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git checkout new_branch\n</code></pre> \n<p>To create a new branch and change the active branch, run the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git checkout -b new_branch\n</code></pre> \n<p>To rename the current branch, run the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git branch -m new_renamed_branch\n</code></pre> \n<p>Use the <code>-D</code> option to remove a branch:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git branch -D new_renamed_branch\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here’s a detailed guide on <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/git-branching/\">branching in Git</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"4updateyourlocalrepositorymerging\">4. Update your Local Repository: Merging</h2> \n<p>While we’ve checked the basics of branching in Git, the next logical step is to merge a branch into your base branch when you’ve finished working on a problem. To merge a branch, run the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git checkout base_branch\ngit merge new_branch\n</code></pre> \n<p>While it may sound like an easy process, merging is potentially the most time-consuming process in Git, as it can give rise to conflicts.</p> \n<h2 id=\"5handleconflicts\">5. Handle Conflicts</h2> \n<p>Imagine that you’re working on a file in a new branch. After you commit the changes, you request Git to merge your new branch with your base branch. However, the same part of the same file in the base branch has been updated since you created the new branch. How does Git decide which changes to keep and which changes to discard?</p> \n<p>Git always tries to not lose any data in the process of a merge. If the changes to the same file were done in different parts of the file, you could get away by keeping both sets of changes. However, if Git is unable to decide which changes to keep, it raises a conflict.</p> \n<p>When a conflict has been raised, running <code>git status</code> on your repository shows a list of files that were modified in both branches being merged. If you open any file with a conflict, you’d notice the following set of lines:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt; HEAD\n...\n...\n========\n...\n...\n&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; new_branch\n</code></pre> \n<p>The part of the file between <code>&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt; HEAD</code> and <code>========</code> contains that code which is present in the base branch. The lines of code between <code>========</code> and <code>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; new_branch</code> are present in the <code>new_branch</code> branch. The developer who’s merging the code has the responsibility to decide what part of the code (or a mix of both parts) should be included in the merge. Once edited, remove the three sets of lines shown, save the file, and commit the changes.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/git-techniques-to-know-before-you-join-a-team/?utm_source=rss\">10 Git Techniques You Need to Know Before You Join a Team</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=pWFYLfhHcjY:5UnbDbn2ylw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=pWFYLfhHcjY:5UnbDbn2ylw:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=pWFYLfhHcjY:5UnbDbn2ylw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=pWFYLfhHcjY:5UnbDbn2ylw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/pWFYLfhHcjY\" +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583410943git-techniques.png","linkMd5":"e3ad45f01fe6ef18575fd69d80b7b3d9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn53@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-042_719967dd0a4561db.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":7966,"destBytes":7966,"author":"Shaumik Daityari","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583410943git-techniques.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn53@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-042_719967dd0a4561db.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=pWFYLfhHcjY:5UnbDbn2ylw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn18@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-38-708_abc572af67a25446.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/pWFYLfhHcjY":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn58@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-43-636_3621cc2633f3ba77.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483295},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Deno Module System: A Beginner&#8217;s Guide","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176806","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-module-system-a-beginners-guide/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Deno Module System: A Beginner’s Guide\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596086356deno-modules.png\" alt=\"Deno Modules\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596086356deno-modules-300x158.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596086356deno-modules-768x404.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596086356deno-modules-1024x539.png 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Learn about the Deno module system – the biggest workflow change you’ll encounter if you’re coming from Node.js. Find out how it works and how to use it, how to make use of Node.js packages in Deno, and more.</strong></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/\">Node.js</a> is a JavaScript runtime based on Chrome’s V8 engine, developed by Ryan Dahl, and released in 2009.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://deno.land/\">Deno</a> is a JavaScript runtime based on Chrome’s V8 engine, developed by Ryan Dahl, and released in 2020. It was created with the benefit of a decade’s worth of hindsight. That doesn’t necessarily make it a sequel or superior to Node.js, but it deviates from that path.</p> \n<p>See also:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-introduction/\">Introduction to Deno: A Secure JavaScript &amp; TypeScript Runtime</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/node-vs-deno/\">Node.js vs Deno: What You Need to Know</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>The headline differences: Deno natively supports TypeScript, security, testing, and browser APIs. Module handling receives less attention, but it’s possibly the largest change to how you create JavaScript applications. Before discussing Deno, let me take you back to a simpler time…</p> \n<h2 id=\"nodejsmodules\">Node.js Modules</h2> \n<p>JavaScript didn’t have a standard module system in 2009. This was partly because of its browser heritage and ES6 / ES2015 was several years away.</p> \n<p>It would have been inconceivable for Node.js not to provide modules, so it adopted CommonJS from a choice of community workarounds. This led to the development of the Node Package Manager, or <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/\">npm</a>, which allowed developers to easily search, use, and publish their own JavaScript modules.</p> \n<p>npm usage grew exponentially. It’s become the most popular package manager ever devised and, by mid-2020, hosts almost 1.5 million modules with more than 800 new ones published every day (source: <a href=\"http://www.modulecounts.com/\">modulecounts.com</a>).</p> \n<h2 id=\"denomodules\">Deno Modules</h2> \n<p>Deno opts for <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/understanding-es6-modules/\">ES2015 Modules</a> which you <code>import</code> from an absolute or relative URL:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">import { something } from 'https://somewhere.com/somehow.js';\n</code></pre> \n<p>The script at that URL must <code>export</code> functions or other values accordingly, e.g.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">export function something() {\n  console.log('something was executed');\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Deno uses an identical module system to that implemented in modern web browsers.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html\">Node.js also supports ES2015 modules</a> … but it’s complicated and remains experimental. CommonJS and ES2015 modules look similar, but work in different ways:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deno-module-system-a-beginners-guide/?utm_source=rss\">Deno Module System: A Beginner’s Guide</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=xE0ZaBisScA:vNigKXyA-PM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img
