Buckler","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596086356deno-modules.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn46@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-24-665_e6b49b8f87181608.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=xE0ZaBisScA:vNigKXyA-PM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn14@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-47-062_db1a33beedf74c5d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/xE0ZaBisScA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn67@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-38-753_fb4da1c0870a9637.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483250},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How We Built a Serverless Web App for the Stax Console","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176929","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-we-built-a-serverless-web-app-for-the-stax-console/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How We Built a Serverless Web App for the Stax Console\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596594340Stax-Serverless-Web-App.png\" alt=\"How We Built a Serverless Web App for the Stax Console\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596594340Stax-Serverless-Web-App-300x223.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596594340Stax-Serverless-Web-App-768x572.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596594340Stax-Serverless-Web-App.png 998w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><em>This post was originally published on the <a href=\"https://www.stax.io/blog/2020-06-19-how-we-built-a-serverless-web-app-for-the-stax-console/?utm_source=sitepoint&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=sp-serv-ext&amp;utm_content=blog\">Stax website</a>.</em></p> \n<p><strong>Building a web console for a product as complex as Stax presented a number of challenges. Our API-first, serverless platform offers a diverse range of features for enterprises who want to manage and optimize their AWS ecosystem.</strong></p> \n<p>With such a developer-focused foundation, we needed to provide customers with a performant, reactive web app, with an intuitive user-experience that didn’t hide the power and functionality of our API. Data access through our console also needed to be built to the same high standard of security and compliance as the rest of our product.</p> \n<p>This post will cover what we set out to achieve when building the Stax Console, our experience building a serverless GraphQL API to power it, and the lessons we learned along the way.</p> \n<h2 id=\"serverlessbydesign\">Serverless By Design</h2> \n<p>We wanted to produce a solution that was serverless from the start, to match the architecture we use for the rest of the product. One of the biggest benefits we’ve seen from going all in on <a href=\"https://www.stax.io/how-it-works/?utm_source=sitepoint&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=sp-serv-ext&amp;utm_content=how\" rel=\"sponsored\">serverless architectures</a> at Stax is uptime and reliability. Avoiding relying on a server that can become a single point of failure allows us to meet our Service-Level Agreement, and ensure customers can access the platform during peak load times. Using <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/\" rel=\"sponsored\">AWS Lambda</a> means queries from our front-end scale out horizontally and there’s always enough compute resources to process requests.</p> \n<p>Using serverless products also improves security during development, as services like AWS Lambda provide baked-in compliance and service levels out of the box. Allowing Amazon to handle upgrades and patching of the infrastructure that our code runs on allows us to focus on building software instead of managing hardware.</p> \n<p>The minimal infrastructure overhead when going serverless has allowed our team to fully own the deployment and monitoring of our GraphQL API. For example, developers can add new <a href=\"https://www.stax.io/networks/?utm_source=sitepoint&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=sp-serv-ext&amp;utm_content=net\" rel=\"sponsored\">Networks</a> functionality using separate Lambda functions to those used to fetch account data, minimizing the blast radius from pushing a new change to production.</p> \n<h2 id=\"earlydays\">Early Days</h2> \n<p>The first iteration of our Console had a fairly traditional web architecture. A React single-page application (SPA) called the Stax REST API directly, which is a serverless solution using <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/api-gateway/\" rel=\"sponsored\">AWS API Gateway</a> and AWS Lambda in front of a relational database. <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/cognito/\" rel=\"sponsored\">AWS Cognito</a> handles user authentication and sign-on for both the Console and REST API.</p> \n<p>We ran into a few technical issues with this approach:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Tooling</strong>. Modern front-end frameworks evolve quickly. Consuming data from REST APIs with React was complex and it was difficult to manage state.</li> \n <li><strong>Stability</strong>. The tight coupling of our front-end SPA to back-end REST API was efficient, but the contract between systems was constantly changing as features developed which risked breaking our user interface.</li> \n <li><strong>Real-Time Updates</strong>. We would need to build our own WebSocket implementation to push data to our front-end SPA to provide real-time updates. This would have been complex to implement in both the front end and back end. </li> \n</ol> \n<p>It also became apparent that as Stax grew as a product, the Console needed to integrate with other back-end services than our REST API, such as Cost and Compliance data for accounts and our Customer Support Case service. Interfacing with multiple APIs and protocols, all with differing authentication mechanisms, led us to consider a <a href=\"https://samnewman.io/patterns/architectural/bff/\" rel=\"sponsored\">Back End for Front End</a> pattern with a single GraphQL API.</p> \n<h2 id=\"ourconsolearchitecturenow\">Our Console Architecture Now</h2> \n<p>The architecture centers on a <a href=\"https://graphql.org/\" rel=\"sponsored\">GraphQL</a> API layer that acts as a proxy between our front-end and back-end services. GraphQL is a query language for APIs; it allows developers to define the types of data in a system (the schema), and wire up functions to fetch data from different sources (resolvers). Relationships between data can be expanded in a single GraphQL query. For example, a single request can resolve a <a href=\"https://www.stax.io/workloads/?utm_source=sitepoint&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=sp-serv-ext&amp;utm_content=work\" rel=\"sponsored\">Stax Workload</a> and the user that deployed it in one go.</p> \n<p>A key reason GraphQL suited our needs is that data can be fetched from any source by a resolver and be presented to a front end as a single interface. This means that as Stax grows, we can refactor and optimize back-end services with minimal impact to our front-end developers and customers. Authentication is also massively simplified. The front-end authenticates to our GraphQL API in one place, which handles connections to various REST and GraphQL APIs and event sources behind the scenes.</p> \n<p>At Stax, we’re closely partnered with AWS, and try to use native AWS solutions where possible as part of our development philosophy. We opted to use <a href=\"https://docs.aws.amazon.com/appsync/index.html\" rel=\"sponsored\">AWS AppSync</a>, a fully managed serverless GraphQL implementation as the core of our service.</p> \n<p>AWS AppSync implements the main GraphQL directives, including GraphQL Subscriptions that manage WebSocket connections between clients and your GraphQL API. AWS Lambda fetches and transforms data in GraphQL resolver functions, <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/dynamodb/\" rel=\"sponsored\">AWS DynamoDB</a> is used for serverless data stores, and <a href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/eventbridge/\" rel=\"sponsored\">AWS EventBridge</a> triggers Lambda functions in response to system events.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596594179stax-console-graphql-layer-1024x675.png\" alt=\"Our current Stax Console architecture makes use of GraphQL, AWS AppSync, AWS Dynamo and AWS EventBridge\" width=\"1024\" height=\"675\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-176932\" /></p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-we-built-a-serverless-web-app-for-the-stax-console/?utm_source=rss\">How We Built a Serverless Web App for the Stax Console</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VPLn6N0LhYc:1IMOj1VtcSI:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VPLn6N0LhYc:1IMOj1VtcSI:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=VPLn6N0LhYc:1IMOj1VtcSI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=VPLn6N0LhYc:1IMOj1VtcSI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/VPLn6N0LhYc\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 04 Aug 2020 20:10:20 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596594340Stax-Serverless-Web-App.png","linkMd5":"006d50c34dca580ab1eddb69a37a0211","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn14@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-24-753_dcfe0513daff1b00.webp","destWidth":998,"destHeight":743,"sourceBytes":10560,"destBytes":10560,"author":"Adam Quigley","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596594340Stax-Serverless-Web-App.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn14@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-24-753_dcfe0513daff1b00.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1596594179stax-console-graphql-layer-1024x675.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn30@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-35-719_46170056cf1f22ef.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=VPLn6N0LhYc:1IMOj1VtcSI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn53@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-35-308_04b725b4325cefcb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/VPLn6N0LhYc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn31@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-41-100_49e754aec55d03b6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483249},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Build a Native Desktop GIF Searcher App Using NodeGui","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=174965","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-native-desktop-gif-searcher-app-using-nodegui/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Build a Native Desktop GIF Searcher App Using NodeGui\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1581383719nodegui.png\" alt=\"Build a Native Desktop GIF Searcher App Using NodeGui\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1581383719nodegui-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1581383719nodegui.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://docs.nodegui.org/\">NodeGui</a> is an open-source library for building cross-platform, native desktop apps with Node.js. NodeGui apps can run on macOS, Windows, and Linux. The apps built with NodeGui are written using JavaScript, styled with CSS and rendered as native desktop widgets using the <a href=\"https://doc.qt.io/\">Qt framework</a>.</strong></p> \n<p>Some of the features of NodeGui are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>native widgets with built-in support for dark mode</li> \n <li>low CPU and memory footprint</li> \n <li>styling with CSS including complete support for Flexbox layout</li> \n <li>complete Node.js API support and access to all Node.js compatible npm modules</li> \n <li>excellent debugging support using Chrome’s DevTools</li> \n <li>first-class TypeScript support</li> \n</ul> \n<p>NodeGui is powered by the Qt framework, which makes it CPU and memory efficient compared with other Chromium-based solutions such as Electron. This means that applications written using NodeGui <em>do not</em> open up a browser instance and render the UI in it. Instead, all the widgets are rendered natively.</p> \n<p>This tutorial will demonstrate how to install NodeGui and use it to build a meme searcher that lives in the system tray and communicates with the <a href=\"https://developers.giphy.com/\">GIPHY API</a>.</p> \n<p>The full source code for this tutorial is <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/memesearchapp-nodegui-tutorial\">available on GitHub</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"installationandbasicsetup\">Installation and Basic Setup</h2> \n<p>For this tutorial it’s assumed that you have <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/download/\">Node.js v12</a> or greater installed. You can confirm that both Node and npm are available by running:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># This command should print the version of Node.js\nnode -v\n\n# This command should print the version of npm\nnpm -v\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you need help with this step, check out our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">tutorial on installing Node</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"installcmakeandcompilationtools\">Install CMake and Compilation Tools</h2> \n<p>NodeGui requires CMake and C++ compilation tools for building the native C++ layer of the project. Make sure you install CMake &gt;= 3.1 along with a C++ compiler that supports C++11 and up. The detailed instructions are a bit different depending on your operating system.</p> \n<h3 id=\"macos\">macOS</h3> \n<p>It’s recommended to install CMake using Homebrew. Run the following commands in a terminal after installing Homebrew:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">brew install cmake\nbrew install make\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can confirm the installation by running:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># This command should print the version of CMake which should be higher than 3.1\ncmake --version\n\nmake --version\n</code></pre> \n<p>Lastly, you need GCC/Clang to compile C++ code. Verify that you have GCC installed using this command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">gcc --version\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you don’t have GCC installed, make sure you install <em>Command Line Tools for Xcode</em> or <em>XCode Developer tools</em> from <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/download/more/\">Apple’s developer page</a>.</p> \n<h3 id=\"windows\">Windows</h3> \n<p>You can install CMake on Windows by downloading the latest release from the <a href=\"https://cmake.org/download/\">CMake download page</a>.</p> \n<p>It’s strongly recommend you use Powershell as the preferred terminal in Windows.</p> \n<p>You can confirm the CMake installation by running:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># This command should print the version of CMake which should be higher than 3.1\ncmake --version\n</code></pre> \n<p>Lastly, you need a C++ compiler. One possibility would be to <a href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/install-visual-studio?view=vs-2017\">install Visual Studio 2017 or higher</a>. It’s recommended you choose the <strong>Desktop development with C++</strong> workload during the installation process.</p> \n<h3 id=\"linux\">Linux</h3> \n<p>We’ll focus on Ubuntu 18.04 for the purposes of this tutorial. It’s recommended to install CMake using the package manager. Run the following commands in a terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo apt-get install pkg-config build-essential\nsudo apt-get install cmake make\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can confirm the installation by running:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># This command should print the version of CMake which should be higher than 3.1\ncmake --version\n\nmake --version\n</code></pre> \n<p>Lastly, you need GCC to compile C++ code. Verify that you have GCC installed using the command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"># gcc version should be &gt;= v7\ngcc --version\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"helloworld\">Hello World</h2> \n<p>In order to get started with our NodeGui meme app, we’ll clone the starter project.</p> \n<p><em>Note: Running this requires Git and npm.</em></p> \n<p>Open a terminal and run:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">git clone https://github.com/nodegui/nodegui-starter memeapp\ncd memeapp\nnpm install\nnpm start\n</code></pre> \n<p>If everything goes well, you should see a working hello world NodeGui app on the screen.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/158038460101-hello-world.png\" alt=\"Hello World NodeGui example\" /></p> \n<p>By default, the <a href=\"https://github.com/nodegui/nodegui-starter\">nodegui-starter project</a> is a TypeScript project. However, in this tutorial we’ll be writing our application in JavaScript. In order to convert our starter to a JS project, we’ll make the following minor changes:</p> \n<ol> \n <li> <p>Delete the <code>index.ts</code> file in the <code>src</code> folder.</p> </li> \n <li> <p>Create a new file <code>index.js</code> in the <code>src</code> directory with the following contents:</p> <p><strong>src/index.js</strong></p> <pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const { QMainWindow, QLabel } = require('@nodegui/nodegui');\n\nconst win = new QMainWindow();\nwin.setWindowTitle('Meme Search');\n\nconst label = new QLabel();\nlabel.setText('Hello World');\n\nwin.setCentralWidget(label);\nwin.show();\n\nglobal.win = win;\n</code></pre> </li> \n</ol> \n<p>As far as development is concerned, a NodeGui application is essentially a Node.js application. All APIs and features found in NodeGui are accessible through the <code>@nodegui/nodegui</code> module, which can be required like any other Node.js module. Additionally, you have access to all Node.js APIs and Node modules. NodeGui uses native components instead of web-based components as building blocks.</p> \n<p>In the above example, we’ve imported <a href=\"https://docs.nodegui.org/docs/api/generated/classes/qmainwindow/\">QMainWindow</a> and <a href=\"https://docs.nodegui.org/docs/api/generated/classes/qlabel\">QLabel</a> to create a native window that displays the text “Hello World”.</p> \n<p>Now run the app again:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm start\n</code></pre> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/158038460202-js-hello-world.png\" alt=\"Hello World JavaScript version\" /></p> \n<p>Now that we have our basic setup ready, let’s start building our meme searcher 🥳.</p> \n<p><em>Note: If something doesn’t work while following this tutorial, check your <code>package.json</code> file to ensure that the starter project has pulled in the most up-to-date version of NodeGui.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"displayingananimatedgif\">Displaying an Animated GIF</h2> \n<p>Since memes are generally animated GIFs, we’ll start by creating a basic window that displays a GIF image from a URL.</p> \n<p>To do this, we’ll make use of <a href=\"https://docs.nodegui.org/docs/api/generated/classes/qmovie\">QMovie</a> along with QLabel. QMovie is not a widget but a container that can play simple animations. We’ll use it in combination with QLabel.</p> \n<p>An example usage of QMovie looks like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const movie = new QMovie();\nmovie.setFileName('/absolute/path/to/animated.gif');\nmovie.start();\n\nconst animatedLabel = new QLabel();\nanimatedLabel.setMovie(movie);\n</code></pre> \n<p>Since, we want to load an image from a URL, we can’t use <code>QMovie</code>‘s <a href=\"https://docs.nodegui.org/docs/api/generated/classes/qmovie#setfilename\">setFileName</a> method, which is reserved only for local files. Instead, we’ll download the GIF image using <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/axios\">axios</a> as a buffer and use the QMovie method <a href=\"https://docs.nodegui.org/docs/api/generated/classes/qmovie#loadfromdata\">loadFromData</a> instead.</p> \n<p>So let’s start with the axios installation:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm i axios\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now let’s create a function that will take a URL as a parameter and will return a configured <code>QMovie</code> instance for the GIF:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">async function getMovie(url) {\n  const { data } = await axios.get(url, { responseType: 'arraybuffer' });\n  const movie = new QMovie();\n  movie.loadFromData(data);\n  movie.start();\n  return movie;\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <code>getMovie</code> function takes in a URL, tells axios to download the GIF as a buffer, and then uses that buffer to create a <code>QMovie</code> instance.</p> \n<p>You can think of <code>QMovie</code> as a class that handles the inner logic of playing the GIF animation frame by frame. <code>QMovie</code> is not a widget, so it can’t be shown on the screen as it is. Instead, we’ll use a regular <code>QLabel</code> instance and set <code>QMovie</code> to it.</p> \n<p>Since <code>getMovie</code> returns a promise, we need to make some changes to the code. After some minor refactoring, we end up with the following.</p> \n<p><strong>src/index.js</strong></p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const { QMainWindow, QMovie, QLabel } = require('@nodegui/nodegui');\nconst axios = require('axios').default;\n\nasync function getMovie(url) {\n  const { data } = await axios.get(url, { responseType: 'arraybuffer' });\n  const movie = new QMovie();\n  movie.loadFromData(data);\n  movie.start();\n  return movie;\n}\n\nconst main = async () =&gt; {\n  const win = new QMainWindow();\n  win.setWindowTitle('Meme Search');\n\n  const label = new QLabel();\n  const gifMovie = await getMovie(\n    'https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e3/Animhorse.gif'\n  );\n  label.setMovie(gifMovie);\n\n  win.setCentralWidget(label);\n  win.show();\n  global.win = win;\n};\n\nmain().catch(console.error);\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <code>main</code> function is our entry point. Here we create a window and a label. We then instantiate a <code>QMovie</code> instance with the help of our <code>getMovie</code> function, and finally set the <code>QMovie</code> to a <code>QLabel</code>.</p> \n<p>Run the app with <code>npm start</code> and you should see something like this:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/158038460503-animation.gif\" alt=\"Basic animation example showing a galloping horse\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"fetchinggifsfromthegiphyapi\">Fetching GIFs from the GIPHY API</h2> \n<p>Giphy.com has a public API which anyone can use to build great apps that use animated GIFs. In order to use the GIPHY API, you should register at <a href=\"https://developers.giphy.com\">developers.giphy.com</a> and obtain an API key. You can find <a href=\"https://support.giphy.com/hc/en-us/articles/360020283431-Request-A-GIPHY-API-Key\">further instructions here</a>.</p> \n<p>We’ll be using the <a href=\"https://developers.giphy.com/docs/api/endpoint/#search\">search endpoint</a> feature for implementing our meme search.</p> \n<p>Let’s start by writing a <code>searchGifs</code> function that will take a <code>searchTerms</code> parameter as input and request GIFs using the above endpoint:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const GIPHY_API_KEY = 'Your API key here';\n\nasync function searchGifs(searchTerm) {\n  const url = 'https://api.giphy.com/v1/gifs/search';\n  const res = await axios.get(url, {\n    params: {\n      api_key: GIPHY_API_KEY,\n      limit: 25,\n      q: searchTerm,\n      lang: 'en',\n      offset: 0,\n      rating: 'pg-13'\n    }\n  });\n  return res.data.data;\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>The result of the function after execution will look something like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">[\n  {\n    \"type\": \"gif\",\n    \"id\": \"dzaUX7CAG0Ihi\",\n    \"url\": \"https://giphy.com/gifs/hello-hi-dzaUX7CAG0Ihi\",\n    \"images\": {\n      \"fixed_width_small\": {\n        \"height\": \"54\",\n        \"size\": \"53544\",\n        \"url\": \"https://media3.giphy.com/media/dzaUX7CAG0Ihi/100w.gif?cid=725ec7e0c00032f700929ce9f09f3f5fe5356af8c874ab12&amp;rid=100w.gif\",\n        \"width\": \"100\"\n      },\n      \"downsized_large\": {\n        \"height\": \"220\",\n        \"size\": \"807719\",\n        \"url\": \"https://media3.giphy.com/media/dzaUX7CAG0Ihi/giphy.gif?cid=725ec7e0c00032f700929ce9f09f3f5fe5356af8c874ab12&amp;rid=giphy.gif\",\n        \"width\": \"410\"\n      },\n      ...\n    },\n    \"slug\": \"hello-hi-dzaUX7CAG0Ihi\",\n    ...\n    \"import_datetime\": \"2016-01-07 15:40:35\",\n    \"trending_datetime\": \"1970-01-01 00:00:00\"\n  },\n  {\n    type: \"gif\",\n    ...\n  },\n  ...\n]\n</code></pre> \n<p>The result is essentially an array of objects that contain information about each GIF. We’re particularly interested in <code>returnValue[i].images.fixed_width_small.url</code> for each image, which contains the URL to the GIF.</p> \n<h2 id=\"showingalistofgifsusingtheapisresponse\">Showing a List of GIFs Using the API’s Response</h2> \n<p>In order to show a list of GIFs, we’ll create a <code>getGifViews</code> function that will:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>create a <a href=\"https://docs.nodegui.org/docs/api/generated/classes/qwidget\">QWidget</a> container</li> \n <li>create a <code>QMovie</code> widget for each GIF</li> \n <li>create a <code>QLabel</code> from each <code>QMovie</code> instance</li> \n <li>attach each <code>QLabel</code> as a child of the <code>QWidget</code> container</li> \n <li>return the <code>QWidget</code> container</li> \n</ol> \n<p>The code looks like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">async function getGifViews(listOfGifs) {\n  const container = new QWidget();\n  container.setLayout(new FlexLayout());\n\n  const promises = listOfGifs.map(async gif =&gt; {\n    const { url, width } = gif.images.fixed_width_small;\n    const movie = await getMovie(url);\n    const gifView = new QLabel();\n    gifView.setMovie(movie);\n    gifView.setInlineStyle(`width: ${width}`);\n    container.layout.addWidget(gifView);\n  });\n\n  await Promise.all(promises);\n\n  container.setInlineStyle(`\n      flex-direction: 'row';\n      flex-wrap: 'wrap';\n      justify-content: 'space-around';\n      width: 330px;\n      height: 300px;\n  `);\n\n  return container;\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Let’s break this down a bit.</p> \n<p>First, we create our container widget. <code>QWidget</code>s are essentially empty widgets that act as containers. They’re similar to <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> elements in the web world.</p> \n<p>Next, in order to assign child widgets to the <code>QWidget</code>, we need to give it a layout. A <strong>layout</strong> dictates how the child widgets should be arranged inside a parent. Here we choose <a href=\"https://docs.nodegui.org/docs/api/generated/classes/flexlayout\">FlexLayout</a>.</p> \n<p>Then, we use our <code>getMovie</code> function to create a <code>QMovie</code> instance for each GIF URL. We assign the <code>QMovie</code> instance to a <code>QLabel</code> (named <code>gifView</code>) and give it some basic styling using the <code>setInlineStyle</code> method. Finally, we add the <code>QLabel</code> widget to the container’s layout using the <code>layout.addWidget</code> method.</p> \n<p>Since this is all happening asynchronously, we wait for everything to resolve using <code>Promise.all</code>, before setting some container styles and returning the container widget.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-native-desktop-gif-searcher-app-using-nodegui/?utm_source=rss\">Build a Native Desktop GIF Searcher App Using NodeGui</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=z5djjDkCWV4:NqLSoIO_MqA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=z5djjDkCWV4:NqLSoIO_MqA:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=z5djjDkCWV4:NqLSoIO_MqA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=z5djjDkCWV4:NqLSoIO_MqA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/z5djjDkCWV4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 09 Mar 2020 14:49:31 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1581383719nodegui.png","linkMd5":"ab80d84012af1071dd45f961b13fedc5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn58@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-25-903_4ac613dcceed640a.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":12984,"destBytes":12984,"author":"Atul Ramachandran","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1581383719nodegui.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn58@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-25-903_4ac613dcceed640a.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/158038460101-hello-world.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn33@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-43-348_42c92310c9537316.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/158038460202-js-hello-world.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn12@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-36-211_99149a033b73c661.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/158038460503-animation.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn37@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-38-110_e912b8ed86f787ea.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=z5djjDkCWV4:NqLSoIO_MqA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn77@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-37-531_31ba78b4b6634a15.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/z5djjDkCWV4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn72@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-39-652_4a6a6ffca93e759a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483297},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Build Your First Discord Bot with Node.js","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=173997","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/discord-bot-node-js/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Build Your First Discord Bot with Node.js\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157247449972-Developing-Robot.png\" alt=\"\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157247449972-Developing-Robot-300x200.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157247449972-Developing-Robot-768x512.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157247449972-Developing-Robot-1024x683.png 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Nowadays, bots are being used for automating various tasks. Since the release of Amazon’s Alexa devices, the hype surrounding automation bots has only started to grow. Besides Alexa, other communication tools like Discord and Telegram offer APIs to develop custom bots.</strong></p> \n<p>This article will solely focus on creating your first bot with the exposed Discord API. Maybe the most well-known Discord bot is the Music Bot. The music bot lets you type a song name and the bot will attach a new user to your channel who plays the requested song. It’s a commonly used bot among younger people on gaming or streaming servers.</p> \n<p>Let’s get started with creating a custom Discord bot.</p> \n<p><em>By the way, you can join <a href=\"https://discord.gg/PyAM7tv\">SitePoint’s Discord community with this link</a>. Come talk tech with us and get notified about our new articles.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"prerequisites\">Prerequisites</h2> \n<ul> \n <li>Node.js v10 or higher installed (basic knowledge)</li> \n <li>a Discord account and Discord client</li> \n <li>basic knowledge of using a terminal</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"step1setuptestserver\">Step 1: Set Up Test Server</h2> \n<p>First of all, we need a test server on which we can later test our Discord bot. We can create a new server by clicking the plus icon on the left of the screen.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231152901-create-server.png\" alt=\"click create server\" width=\"1020\" height=\"510\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-173999\" /></p> \n<p>A pop-up will be displayed that asks you if you want to join a server or create a new one. Of course, we want to create a new server.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231157302-select-create-1024x823.png\" alt=\"select create server\" width=\"1024\" height=\"823\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-174000\" /></p> \n<p>Next, we need to input the name for our server. To keep things simple, I’ve named the server <code>discord_playground</code>. If you want, you can change the server location depending on where you’re located to get a better ping.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231237203-server-name-1024x823.png\" alt=\"server name\" width=\"1024\" height=\"823\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-174003\" /></p> \n<p>If everything went well, you should see your newly created server.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231241104-new-server-1024x494.png\" alt=\"new server\" width=\"1024\" height=\"494\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-174004\" /></p> \n<h2 id=\"step2generatingauthtoken\">Step 2: Generating Auth Token</h2> \n<p>When we want to control our bot via code, we need to register the bot first under our Discord account.</p> \n<p>To register the bot, go to the <a href=\"https://discordapp.com/developers/applications/\">Discord Developers Portal</a> and log in with your account.</p> \n<p>After logging in, you should be able to see the dashboard. Let’s create a new application by clicking the <em>New Application</em> button.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231247905-dev-dashboard-1024x420.png\" alt=\"developer dashboard\" width=\"1024\" height=\"420\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-174005\" /></p> \n<p>Next, you’ll see a pop-up that asks you to input a name for your application. Let’s call our bot <code>my-greeter-bot</code>. By clicking the <em>Create</em> button, Discord will create an API application.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231253706-create-app.png\" alt=\"create application\" width=\"956\" height=\"818\" class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-174006\" /></p> \n<p>When the application has been created, you’ll see the overview of the newly created <code>my-greeter-bot</code> application. You’ll see information like a client ID and client secret. This secret will be used later as the authorization token.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231283207-overview-greeter-1024x645.png\" alt=\"overview greeter bot\" width=\"1024\" height=\"645\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-174007\" /></p> \n<p>Now, click on the <em>Bot</em> menu option in the <em>Settings</em> menu. Discord will build our <code>my-greeter-bot</code> application and add a bot user to it.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231287808-add-bot-1024x284.png\" alt=\"add bot\" width=\"1024\" height=\"284\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-174009\" /></p> \n<p>When the bot has been built, you get an overview of your custom bot. Take a look at the <em>Token</em> section. Copy this authorization token and write it down somewhere, as we’ll need it later to connect to our bot user.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231293409-bot-tab-overview-1024x470.png\" alt=\"bot tab overview\" width=\"1024\" height=\"470\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-174012\" /></p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/discord-bot-node-js/?utm_source=rss\">How to Build Your First Discord Bot with Node.js</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=xCf062xlHtQ:UYjfYTPa_pE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=xCf062xlHtQ:UYjfYTPa_pE:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=xCf062xlHtQ:UYjfYTPa_pE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=xCf062xlHtQ:UYjfYTPa_pE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" 2020 14:00:56 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157247449972-Developing-Robot.png","linkMd5":"7134e5b97c8c3e7dfe90de2103a0c683","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn22@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-609_5bdd84a967a9b084.webp","destWidth":2340,"destHeight":1560,"sourceBytes":53636,"destBytes":53636,"author":"Michiel Mulders","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157247449972-Developing-Robot.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn22@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-26-609_5bdd84a967a9b084.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231152901-create-server.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-43-178_20a40593c123fa1e.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231157302-select-create-1024x823.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn87@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-40-471_1fad1e34da60e5c9.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231237203-server-name-1024x823.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-46-032_4b3166f542882685.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231241104-new-server-1024x494.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn60@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-43-286_d479db18c81dd6a7.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231247905-dev-dashboard-1024x420.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn81@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-41-438_121bbbb0ef1fe0c8.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231253706-create-app.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn69@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-40-356_afa23c30ebe0e9c1.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231283207-overview-greeter-1024x645.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn85@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-41-796_ff0ee95b3351f1fa.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231287808-add-bot-1024x284.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn59@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-46-064_97f69cf7efc1f5fb.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/157231293409-bot-tab-overview-1024x470.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn77@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-45-007_75831cc303a96b5c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=xCf062xlHtQ:UYjfYTPa_pE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn16@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-44-976_5e075d62f8bfdff1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/xCf062xlHtQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn92@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-42-271_b3596da9e712b6f2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483296},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Boost Your Developer Career with a Personal Brand","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175808","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/personal-brand-boost-developer-career/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Boost Your Developer Career with a Personal Brand\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586397781personal-branding.png\" alt=\"How to Boost your Developer Career with a Personal Brand\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586397781personal-branding-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1586397781personal-branding.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Personal branding is one the most (in)famous trends of the last decade.</strong></p> \n<p>In this article, I’ll talk about what a personal brand is and how building one can help boost your career. I’ll show you how to stake your claim in the online space as well as three paths you can follow to level up your brand. That’s plenty to talk about, so let’s get this started.</p> \n<h2 id=\"theargumentforapersonalbrandasadeveloper\">The argument for a personal brand as a developer</h2> \n<p>Our first stop is <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_branding\">Wikipedia</a>, where we can find the following definition:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Personal branding is the practice of marketing people and their careers as brands. It is an ongoing process of developing and maintaining a reputation and impression of an individual, group, or organization.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>That’s the part most of people have in mind when they think about personal branding. They think about the current diva of the day. About famous media celebrities. About publicity stunts that are meant to push you into the limelight. About presenting a fake facade in order to obtain undeserved rewards. And many other less-than-pleasant examples.</p> \n<p>However, there’s another aspect to personal branding — the other side of the coin, so to speak. Right after the definition above, the Wikipedia article has the following phrase:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>In <em>Be Your Own Brand</em>, first published in 1999, marketers David McNally and Karl Speak wrote: “Your brand is a perception or emotion, maintained by somebody other than you, that describes the total experience of having a relationship with you.”</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>In other words, your personal brand includes what other people say about you when you’re not there. It includes your reputation, your body of work, the testimonials other people give about you. Nowadays it includes your tweets and your posts on Facebook. To many people, your pictures on Instagram matter just as much (if not more) as your contributions to open-source software. Want to travel in the USA? Be prepared to let them know all your social media accounts for the last five years. (Sources: <a href=\"https://nakedsecurity.sophos.com/2019/06/04/us-visa-applicants-required-to-hand-over-social-media-info/\">Sophos</a> and <a href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-48486672\">BBC</a>). And the examples can continue.</p> \n<p>Everything you say and do affects your public image and your reputation. And that can have devastating impact on your career. Remember the Aria Richards case back in 2013? She was a developer taking part in a conference where she published a tweet about some male developers making sexual jokes behind her, including their picture. In the fallout, one of the guys was fired, but Aria lost her job as well, because her action was deemed to be damaging to the reputation of the company employing her. (Sources: <a href=\"https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/03/how-dongle-jokes-got-two-people-fired-and-led-to-ddos-attacks/\">ArsTechnica</a> and <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/techie-adria-richards-fired-after-tweeting-about-mens-comments/\">CBSNews</a>).</p> \n<p>Fortunately, it’s not just about mitigating possible damage. A great personal brand can increase your leverage at a level you wouldn’t dream about it. It can put you in a better light when applying to a new job, and you’ll have better negotiating power when discussing the salary and the perks of the position. If you have your own business, it can bring you more and better clients and projects. What’s not to like about it?</p> \n<p>But there’s one caveat in all this: be authentic. Don’t do it to project something you aren’t, or as a money-grabbing move or, worse, to cover negative aspects. That’s the main reason people react badly when hearing about personal branding.</p> \n<p>This subject alone (the pros and cons of personal branding) can fill a whole book and goes beyond the scope of this article. So, stop letting others write your story and take control of your narrative. All this being said, let’s push forward.</p> \n<h2 id=\"stakeyourclaimandestablishyourpresence\">Stake your claim and establish your presence</h2> \n<p>The first phase in building your personal brand is staking your claim in the online space and laying down the foundations for further expansion. It is, in my opinion, the most important part of the process. If you do nothing else from the other things we’ll talk about later, but you work on this part, I’m confident you’ll get a lot further than many other people.</p> \n<p>We’re currently living in the age of social media, so you might be surprised to hear that this foundation is actually your own website. Yes, a website. The old-fashioned kind, where you buy a domain name, arrange hosting and upload the files on the server for everyone else on the Internet to find.</p> \n<p>“That’s the dumbest idea I’ve heard,” you might say. “I don’t need a website. I have my CV on LinkedIn, my pictures on Facebook and Instagram, my articles on Medium, my code on GitHub and I keep in touch with everyone on Twitter. Why would I waste time and effort with a website that I have to promote as well?”</p> \n<p>From a certain point of view, all that sounds quite reasonable. But all those options have one thing in common: they’re all third-party platforms, and you’re actually renting the right to use them. You might not pay with money, but they are gathering data about you and your habits that’s either used to target ads your way or it’s passed to third parties for the same reasons. Remember, if you’re not paying for something, then you are the product being sold.</p> \n<p>It all comes down to a simple truth: you can’t build your home on rented land. You can lose access to social media at any moment. All these platforms have somewhere in their terms and conditions a clause that allows them to terminate their service to you at any time without having to provide an explanation. Or your account could get hacked or deleted. Your tens or hundreds of thousands of followers? All gone in a blink of an eye if you lose access to the platform.</p> \n<p>That’s why you need something you own completely — a place to present yourself without being beholden to a platform that only cares about their own interests. You need a way to gather contacts, followers, connections and clients and be able to keep them. Yes, websites and servers do get hacked. But in that case, all you need to do is install the latest backup and you’re up and running again.</p> \n<p>Let’s get down to the trinity of items needed to establish your online presence:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>A domain name</strong></li> \n</ol> \n<p>You need your own custom domain name for multiple reasons. It gives you more legitimacy and it opens the gates for further options down the road. <code>www.johnnydev.com</code> is a lot better than <code>johnnydev2335.github.io</code>, don’t you think? We can have a very long discussion over whether it’s better to choose a “brand name” or your own given name for the domain. However, that’s a conversation for another time and place.</p> \n<ol start=\"2\"> \n <li><strong>Hosting</strong></li> \n</ol> \n<p>There are plenty options of free hosting for developers: GitHub Pages, Netlify and many more. In many cases, that’s all you need to have a website up and running. For some of the more advanced options, though, it’s better to get some classic dedicated hosting.</p> \n<ol start=\"3\"> \n <li><strong>Custom email address</strong></li> \n</ol> \n<p>This is the same story as with the domain name above. I think we can agree that <code>johnny@johnnydev.com</code> is more professional than <code>johnnydev2335@gmail.com</code> or some other email address you created when you were 16 years old.</p> \n<p>Now all you have to do is upload your site and let everyone know about it. You can go from something as simple as a single static page to something complex like a WordPress blog or a static site generator like Gatsby or Hugo. Don’t despair if design isn’t your strong point. There are plenty of free themes and templates available.</p> \n<p>Remember, you don’t have to code the website yourself. You get extra brownie points and bragging rights for writing as much code as possible yourself, but that’s not a requirement. If time’s at a premium for you, just grab a free template or theme and get started. Be sure to check the code for any hidden, unpleasant surprises, though, or use trusted sources, like curated collections and communities. All major players, like WordPress, Gatsby or Hugo, come with curated themes that you can choose from.</p> \n<h3 id=\"onceyouhaveawebsite\">Once you have a website</h3> \n<p>Congratulations! You just became the proud owner of your own piece of online real estate. You how have a place where you can link all your social media profiles, upload your CV, write some blog posts or even articles. If you want to take it even further and remove further your dependency on other platforms, you can start your own email list. But that’s a topic for another time. For now, we’ll focus on three paths you can take to further increase your influence, your reputation and, ultimately, your personal brand. These are paths that other developers have taken before, and they got a lot of benefits out of that choice. They’re also not mutually exclusive. You can mix and match until you get the combination that works best for you.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/personal-brand-boost-developer-career/?utm_source=rss\">How to Boost Your Developer Career with a Personal Brand</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=1e1168l59rE:8ho_UKl_IHs:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Deliver Better Data-Informed UX Using Sisense Embedded Analytics","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176766","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deliver-better-data-informed-ux-using-sisense-embedded-analytics/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Deliver Better Data-Informed UX Using Sisense Embedded Analytics\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596008165Art-Director.jpg\" alt=\"\" https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596008165Art-Director-1024x683.jpg 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p class=\"wp-special\"><em>This article was created in partnership with <a href=\"https://www.sisense.com/\" rel=\"sponsored\">Sisense</a>. Thank you for supporting the partners who make SitePoint possible.</em></p> \n<p>Businesses across just about every industry are learning to prioritize collecting data along the customer journey. And to an increasing degree, data reporting and interactive visualizations are a big component of the value that apps have to offer users, whether these users are within your organization, external stakeholders or mass market end users.</p> \n<p>It doesn’t matter if your product is an executive dashboard that surfaces supply chain efficiency issues, a “quantifiable self” app that tracks biometrics for gamified fitness achievement or a business app that helps users keep track of project objectives – data storytelling is playing a bigger role in the interfaces of all digital products.</p> \n<p>At the same time, app churn continues to haunt product teams, as the marketplace gets more and more saturated with apps that have overlapping use cases and functionalities – all the more reason to make quantifiable accomplishment a core component to your app’s interface. There’s arguably no better way to ensure app loyalty than to give users the sense that it’s a key component in their ongoing triumphs.</p> \n<p>With this in mind, it’s easy to see why pretty much every mobile and web app today needs some sort of built-in analytics capabilities. Mobile app analytics can help you increase your product’s stickiness and <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/5-simple-ux-principles-guide-product-design/\">deliver better user experiences</a>. In turn, you’re able to create a high-value app for users that’s likely to be used more frequently.</p> \n<p>So, the question isn’t whether or not you should add analytics capabilities to your app. It’s whether you should build your own or use a third-party solution?</p> \n<p>The short answer is that it depends on a number of factors.</p> \n<p>If you choose to build these analytics capabilities on your own, you’ll have more control over the app’s functionality and branding. In addition, you’ll be able to ensure that it functions exactly how you want it to, even if you need to set aside a budget for ongoing development and compatibility updates.</p> \n<p>On the flip side, buying a third-party embedded analytics solution often makes for a far much less expensive option overall <em>and</em> you’ll be able to deploy the analytics capabilities in your app faster. Plus, you’ll get access to high-quality source components right off the bat, because you’ll be building on the experience of industry experts as opposed to an internal team that’s building out the capabilities from scratch on an as-needed basis.</p> \n<p>In this article, we’ll dig deeper into the build versus buy dilemma of adding analytics capabilities to apps and explain why it’s better to use embedded analytics than build your own app components. We’ll also share some best practices for using <a href=\"https://www.sisense.com/product/embedded-analytics/\" rel=\"sponsored\">Sisense’s embedded analytics solution.</a></p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/deliver-better-data-informed-ux-using-sisense-embedded-analytics/?utm_source=rss\">Deliver Better Data-Informed UX Using Sisense Embedded Analytics</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=c9i5fGUFpbQ:E98Mqvy-AeY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a 2020 21:00:37 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596008165Art-Director.jpg","linkMd5":"be6b9cb24d43a8cd3fbc71cdc7bdd673","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn94@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-630_c3b19b2f0aaca495.webp","destWidth":2340,"destHeight":1560,"sourceBytes":42912,"destBytes":42912,"author":"Gal Shachar","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/1596008165Art-Director.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn94@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-25-630_c3b19b2f0aaca495.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=c9i5fGUFpbQ:E98Mqvy-AeY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn81@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-918_4fd37c777afa6f1f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/c9i5fGUFpbQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn43@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-39-306_614ae3c5783fc8e4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483249},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"GitHub CLI: A Guide to GitHub from the Command Line","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176403","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/github-cli/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"GitHub CLI: A Guide to GitHub from the Command Line\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592442845github-cli.png\" alt=\"A Quickstart Guide to GitHub CLI\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592442845github-cli-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/1592442845github-cli.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>In this quickstart guide, you’ll learn <a href=\"https://cli.github.com/\">GitHub CLI</a>.</strong></p> \n<p>If you’re already familiar with <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/books/jump-start-git-2nd-edition/read/1/utm-preview/read/1/?preview=true&amp;utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">Git commands</a>, you’re obviously aware that you need to switch to the web browser in order to perform various actions on your GitHub repository. With the new GitHub CLI tool, you can execute many of these actions without leaving the command-line interface.</p> \n<h2 id=\"setup\">Setup</h2> \n<p>To get started, simply visit the <a href=\"https://cli.github.com/manual/installation\">installation page</a> and find instructions on how to install GitHub CLI for your operating system. For Windows and macOS, you can use package managers to install and keep GitHub CLI up to date. For Linux users, you’ll need to download the package from the <a href=\"http://github.com/cli/cli/releases/latest\">latest release</a> page. There are Signed MSI installers for Windows users too, but be aware you have to re-download and update the tool manually if you opt for this. The easiest way for Windows users is to use the <a href=\"https://scoop.sh/\">scoop</a> package manager.</p> \n<p>Below are snapshots of install instructions for each supported platform:</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p>Windows:</p> <pre><code class=\"powershell language-powershell\">scoop bucket add github-gh https://github.com/cli/scoop-gh.git\nscoop install gh\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>macOS:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">brew install github\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>Debian/Ubuntu Linux:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo apt install git &amp;amp;&amp;amp; sudo dpkg -i gh_*_linux_amd64.deb\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>Fedora/Centos Linux:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo yum localinstall gh_*_linux_amd64.rpm\n</code></pre> </li> \n <li> <p>Arch Linux:</p> <pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">yay -S github-cli\n</code></pre> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>On Windows, I would recommend the use of the <a href=\"https://gitforwindows.org/\">Git Bash</a> terminal. This interface will allow you to access common Linux commands and Bash features such as autocompletion. It’s also officially supported by Visual Studio Code via terminal integration.</p> \n<p>After installing GitHub CLI, you’ll need to authenticate your account. Running any command will trigger this authentication process. For example, try <code>gh repo view cli/cli</code>. For first-time users, you’ll be prompted with the following:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/159161888901-gh-authentication.png\" alt=\"GitHub authentication\" /></p> \n<p>Simply press the <kbd>Enter</kbd> key to start the process as illustrated below:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/159161889102-gh-authorize.png\" alt=\"Gitub authorization\" /></p> \n<p>Once you provide your password, you’ll get a “Successfully authenticated GitHub CLI” message. You’re now able to interact with the GitHub platform via the command-line terminal. The next step is to implement autocomplete, which is optional. Simply add this line to your <code>~/.bash_profile</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">eval \"$(gh completion -s bash)\"\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can also run the above command in your current terminal to get the autocomplete feature without restarting your terminal. To confirm it’s working, type <code>gh repo</code>, then press <kbd>tab</kbd> twice. It should show you four different commands you can append to the current <code>repo</code> command.</p> \n<h2 id=\"commandstructure\">Command Structure</h2> \n<p>The <code>gh</code> command structure is tree-like and easy to remember. There are basically two levels of commands. The first level only consists of six commands:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/github-cli/?utm_source=rss\">GitHub CLI: A Guide to GitHub from the Command Line</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"7 Collaborative Coding Tools for Remote Pair Programming","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=171845","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/collaborative-coding-tools-for-remote-pair-programming/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"7 Collaborative Coding Tools for Remote Pair Programming\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588917293THG_M78_02.jpg\" alt=\"Remote Pair Programming Tools\" 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p>Fifteen years ago, most online collaboration and remote work involved email threads, Skype calls, and endlessly re-zipping projects for sharing after each iteration.</p> \n<p>Things have changed a lot — many for the better (Google Docs!) and some things for worse (<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/the-real-future-of-remote-work-is-asynchronous/\">always-on messaging</a>). Either way, it’s fair to say that a lot of the friction has been removed from remote work.</p> \n<p>While other tools have moved ahead, real-time code collaboration has been a point of contention and viable solutions have only recently arrived on the scene. Developers working on the world’s top code editors have put forward their solutions, and they’re pretty good.</p> \n<p>You might <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/jobs/\">work on a distributed team</a> and need collaborative coding tools to serve you every day — a category that suddenly includes most of us, thanks to COVID-19. Or perhaps you just need something for the occasional problem-solving session with a friend. Either way, you’ll find something you can use here.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1visualstudioliveshare\">1. <a href=\"https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/services/live-share/\">Visual Studio Live Share</a></h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/services/live-share/\"><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/15889125551-vs-liveshare.jpg\" alt=\"Visual Studio Live Share\" width=\"1300\" height=\"497\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176145\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/services/live-share/\">Visual Studio Live Share</a> is Microsoft’s own real-time collaborative development solution for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code.</p> \n<p>Live Share allows teams to collaborate on a shared codebase, while maintaining the ability of each collaborator to navigate and work independently. While many code collaboration tools are bound to the host’s perspective, Microsoft’s entrant allows each person to navigate between files and make changes to code on their own terms.</p> \n<p>Live Share can share your workspace, terminal, and local servers, and you can communicate over voice from within the tool. This is a polished option with other useful touches, like group debugging and a focus-and-follow feature that allows you to draw the attention of your collaborators. With a price tag of free, this choice is a no-brainer — particularly if you’re already a Visual Studio Code user.</p> \n<p>While you’re at it, check out our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/visual-studio-code-power-user-guide/\">Visual Studio Code power user’s guide</a> and our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/vs-code-extensions-javascript-developers/\">VS Code extension recommendations for JavaScript developers</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2teletypeforatom\">2. <a href=\"https://teletype.atom.io/\">Teletype for Atom</a></h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://teletype.atom.io/\"><img src=\"https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/1588913548Teletype_for_Atom.jpg\" alt=\"Teletype for Atom\" width=\"1800\" height=\"1375\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-176147\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://teletype.atom.io/\">Teletype for Atom</a>, an early entrant among real-time code collaboration tools, allows <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/12-favorite-atom-tips-and-shortcuts-to-improve-your-workflow/\">Atom users</a> to share their workspace with team members.</p> \n<p>While Live Share users can move around a project freely, Teletype is a little more host-centric. After the host opens a “portal”, their active tab becomes a shared workspace, and collaborators follow the host as they move between files. Teletype is well-suited to the pair programming use-case — with its driver and navigator model — but not as robust for all purposes as Live Share’s open-ended collaborative development environment.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/collaborative-coding-tools-for-remote-pair-programming/?utm_source=rss\">7 Collaborative Coding Tools for Remote Pair Programming</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a
