href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=wnlzq4nSy30:gKcqt6VCU3Y:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=wnlzq4nSy30:gKcqt6VCU3Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=wnlzq4nSy30:gKcqt6VCU3Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/wnlzq4nSy30\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Thu, 07 May 2020 12:00:19 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588917293THG_M78_02.jpg","linkMd5":"98e312201674e8a948e55ae1978adfb5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn85@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-25-703_9428e459db6b4778.webp","destWidth":1800,"destHeight":1200,"sourceBytes":35640,"destBytes":35640,"author":"Joel Falconer","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/1588917293THG_M78_02.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn85@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-25-703_9428e459db6b4778.webp","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/15889125551-vs-liveshare.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://editor.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/1588913548Teletype_for_Atom.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=wnlzq4nSy30:gKcqt6VCU3Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-38-900_31d46030d4712cb3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/wnlzq4nSy30":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn39@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-40-239_b018c0a0cf90799e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483272},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"10 Must-have VS Code Extensions for JavaScript Developers","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=165453","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/vs-code-extensions-javascript-developers/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"10 Must-have VS Code Extensions for JavaScript Developers\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/1587003186vscode-extensions.png\" alt=\"10 Must-have VS Code Extensions for JavaScript Developers\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/1587003186vscode-extensions-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/1587003186vscode-extensions.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>In this article, I’ll focus on a list of must-have VS Code extensions for JavaScript developers.</strong></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">Visual Studio Code</a> (VS Code) is undoubtedly the most popular, lightweight code editor today. It does borrow heavily from other popular code editors, mostly Sublime Text and Atom. However, its success mainly comes from its ability to provide better performance and stability. In addition, it also provides much-needed features like IntelliSense, which were only available in full-sized IDEs like Eclipse or Visual Studio 2017.</p> \n<p>The power of VS Code no doubt comes from the <a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/vscode\">marketplace</a>. Thanks to the wonderful open-source community, the editor is now capable of supporting almost every programming language, framework and development technology. Support for a library or framework comes in various ways, which mainly includes snippets, syntax highlighting, <a href=\"https://emmet.io/\">Emmet</a> and IntelliSense features for that specific technology.</p> \n<h2 id=\"vscodeextensionsbycategory\">VS Code Extensions by Category</h2> \n<p>For this article, I’ll focus on VS Code extensions specifically targeting JavaScript developers. Currently, there are many VS Code extensions that fit this criterion, which of course means I won’t be able to mention all of them. Instead, I’ll highlight VS Code extensions that have gained popularity and those that are indispensable for JavaScript developers. For simplicity, I’ll group them into ten specific categories.</p> \n<h2 id=\"snippetextensions\">Snippet Extensions</h2> \n<p>When you first install VS Code, it comes with a several built-in snippets for JavaScript and Typescript. Snippets help you write repetitive code quickly. However, you may find these may not be enough. You can easily create your own, or you can simply install an extension that includes a bunch of new useful snippets. A quick tip if you want snippets to show on top of suggestions is to use this configuration:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  \"editor.snippetSuggestions\": \"top\"\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here are some of the most popular snippet extensions for JavaScript developers. However, I would recommend you install just one for simplicity’s sake.</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=xabikos.JavaScriptSnippets\">JavaScript (ES6) code snippets</a>, by Charalampos Karypidis. This is currently the most popular javaScript snippet extension with over 3+ million installs to date. This extension provides ES6 syntax for JavaScript, TypeScript, HTML, React and Vue. All snippets include a final semicolon.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=jmsv.JavaScriptSnippetsStandard\">JavaScript (ES6) code snippets in StandardJS style</a>, by James Vickery. This is basically a fork of the above extension for those who prefer <a href=\"https://standardjs.com/rules-en.html\">StandardJS style convention</a>—that is, the snippets don’t have semicolons.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=capaj.vscode-standardjs-snippets\">JavaScript standardjs styled snippets</a>, by capaj. Another StandardJS Styled snippets but this one is more popular with over 72k installs. Originally forked from <a href=\"https://github.com/gaboesquivel/atom-standardjs-snippets\">Atom StandardJS snippets</a>. Contains a huge collection of handy snippets and supports JavaScript, TypeScript and React.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=nathanchapman.JavaScriptSnippets\">JavaScript Snippets</a>, by Nathan Chapman. A collection of JavaScript snippets with about 33k+ installs to date. This snippet extension supports Node.js, BDD Testing frameworks such as Mocha and Jasmine.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=gluons.vscode-atom-javascript-snippet\">Atom JavaScript Snippet</a>, by Saran Tanpituckpong. With about 26k+ installs to date, the snippets in this extension were ported from <code>atom/language-javascript</code>. JavaScript snippets ported from the atom/language-javascript extension.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"syntaxhighlightingextensions\">Syntax Highlighting Extensions</h2> \n<p>The latest version of VS Code supports better syntax colorization and is now more in line with the standards set in Atom grammar. Hence, extensions such as <a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.js-atom-grammar\">JavaScript Atom Grammar</a> are no longer needed.</p> \n<p>However, we still have a few syntax highlighting extensions that are quite useful when it comes to certain types of projects and file extensions. Here’s a few:</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=mgmcdermott.vscode-language-babel\">Babel JavaScript</a>, by Michael McDermott. With over 550k+ installs to date, this extension provides syntax highlighting for ES201x JavaScript, React, FlowType and GraphQL code.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=mikestead.dotenv\">DotENV</a>, by 833,737. With over 833k installs to date, this extension supports syntax highlighting for environment settings — that is, <code>.env</code> files.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=CoenraadS.bracket-pair-colorizer-2\">Bracket Pair Colorizer 2</a>, by CoenraadS. With 730k+ installs, this extension highlights matching brackets with different colors, helping you identify which bracket belongs to which block.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"linterextensions\">Linter Extensions</h2> \n<p>Have you have ever gotten into a debate with your teammates over <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SsoOG6ZeyUI\">tabs vs spaces</a> or semicolons vs no semicolons? You’ll realize that people have strong opinions about which coding style to use. Nevertheless, everyone on the same team needs to use the same coding style regardless of their opinion.</p> \n<p>However, it’s quite common for programmers to forget which coding styling they agreed to work with. To enforce the rules, we need to use <strong>linters</strong> that compare your code with the rules you’ve established. You define your rules by picking a popular coding style such as <a href=\"https://standardjs.com\">Standard</a>, <a href=\"https://google.github.io/styleguide/jsguide.html\">Google</a>, and <a href=\"https://github.com/airbnb/javascript\">Airbnb</a>. You can use them as is or use a configuration file to customize the rules. VS Code doesn’t have a built-in JavaScript linter, so you’ll need to install an extension.</p> \n<p>Here are the extensions we have available:</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=dbaeumer.vscode-eslint\">ESLint</a>, by Dirk Baeumer. With over 8 million installs, this is the most popular extension providing support for the <a href=\"https://eslint.org/\">ESLint</a> library. In order for the extension to work, your project will need ESLint packages and plugins installed. You’ll also need to specify an <code>.eslintrc</code>, which will specify the rules the extension will use to lint your code .</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=dbaeumer.jshint\">JSHint</a>, by Dirk Baeumer. With 1.2M+ installs, this extension supports linting with the <a href=\"https://jshint.com/install/\">JSHint</a> library. A <code>.jshintrc</code> configuration file is required for the extension to lint your code.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=chenxsan.vscode-standardjs\">StandardJS – JavaScript Standard Style</a>, by Sam Chen. This extension (259k+ installs) simply integrates <a href=\"https://github.com/standard/standard\">JavaScript Standard Style</a> into VS Code. You’ll need to install <code>standard</code> or <code>semiStandard</code> as a dev dependency in your project. No configuration file is required. You’ll need to disable VS Code’s built-in validator for this extension to work.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ajhyndman.jslint\">JSLint</a>, by Andrew Hyndman. This extension provides linting with the <a href=\"http://jslint.com/help.html\">JSLint</a> library. You’ll need to install <code>jslint</code> locally or globally for the extension to work. It has 109k+ installs to date.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you’d like an overview of available linters and their pros and cons, check out our <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/comparison-javascript-linting-tools/\">comparison of JavaScript linting tools</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"nodepackagemanagementextensions\">Node Package Management Extensions</h2> \n<p>Every JavaScript project needs to at least one npm package, unless you’re someone who likes doing things the hard way. Here are a few VS Code extensions that will help you work with managing and working with npm packages more easily.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=eg2.vscode-npm-script\">npm</a>, by egamma. With over 2.3M+ installs, this extension uses <code>package.json</code> to validate installed packages. If anything is missing or versions are mismatched, the extension will provide you with clickable options to fix the issue. In addition, you can also run npm scripts defined in <code>package.json</code> right inside the editor.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>–<a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=christian-kohler.npm-intellisense\">npm IntelliSense</a>, by Christian Kohler. With 1.9M+ installs, this extension provides autocompleting npm modules in import statements.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://github.com/ChristianKohler/NpmIntellisense/raw/master/images/auto_complete.gif\" alt=\"npm IntelliSense demo\" /></p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=christian-kohler.path-intellisense\">Path IntelliSense</a>, by Christian Kohler. With 2.7M+ installs, this extension autocompletes filenames. It also works inside HTML and CSS files.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=miramac.vscode-exec-node\">Node exec</a>, by Miramac. With 168k+ installs, this extension allows you to execute the current file or your selected code with Node.js by pressing <kbd>F8</kbd> on your keyboard. You can also cancel a running process by pressing <kbd>F9</kbd>.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=dkundel.vscode-npm-source\">View Node Package</a> by Dominik Kundel. With 55k+ installs, this extension allows you to quickly view a Node package source and documentation while you’re working with your code.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=bengreenier.vscode-node-readme\">Node Readme</a>, by bengreenier. With 52k+ installs, this extension allows you to quickly open an npm package documentation right inside the VS Code editor as a separate tab.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=jasonnutter.search-node-modules\">Search node_modules</a>, by Jason Nutter. By default, the <code>node_modules</code> folder is excluded from VS Code’s built-in search. With over 470k installs, this extension allows you to quickly navigate and open files in <code>node_modules</code> by traversing the folder tree.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/1587001624demo.gif\" alt=\"Search Node modules\" />\n <figcaption style=\"text-align:center; font-size:0.8em; margin: 12px 0 20px\">\n  Source: \n  <a href=\"https://github.com/jasonnutter/vscode-search-node-modules\">vscode-search-node-modules</a>\n </figcaption>\n</figure> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=wix.vscode-import-cost\">Import Cost</a> by Wix. This displays how much disk space a package is using when you import it. The extension has 562K+ installs.</li> \n</ul> \n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://file-wkbcnlcvbn.now.sh/import-cost.gif\" alt=\"Import cost demo\" />\n <figcaption style=\"text-align:center; font-size:0.8em; margin: 12px 0 20px\">\n   Source: \n  <a href=\"https://github.com/wix/import-cost\">import-cost</a>\n </figcaption>\n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"formattingextensions\">Formatting Extensions</h2> \n<p>More often than not, we sometimes write code that’s out of alignment with the rest of the code. To fix this, we need to go back and fix the indentation in each line. In addition, we need to ensure braces and tags are properly formatted in a readable format. This process can quickly get tedious.</p> \n<p>Luckily, we have extensions that can do the work for us. Please note extensions such as <code>Prettier</code> and <code>Beautify</code> can’t both be active simultaneously.</p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=esbenp.prettier-vscode\">Prettier Code Formatter</a>, by Esben Petersen. This is the most popular extension that supports formatting of JavaScript, TypeScript and CSS using <a href=\"https://github.com/prettier/prettier\">Prettier</a>. It has over 5.7 million installs to date. It’s recommended you install <code>prettier</code> locally as a dev dependency.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=HookyQR.beautify\">Beautify</a>, by HookyQR. A <a href=\"http://jsbeautifier.org/\">jsBeautifier</a> extension that supports JavaScript, JSON, CSS and HTML. It can be customized via a <code>.jsbeautifyrc</code> file. It’s now the second most popular formatter, with 4.4 million installs to date.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=cmstead.jsrefactor\">JS Refactor</a>, by Chris Stead. This provides a number of utilities and actions for refactoring JavaScript code, such as extracting variables/methods, converting existing code to use arrow functions or template literals, and exporting functions. It has 140k+ installs to date.</p> </li> \n <li> <p><a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=sburg.vscode-javascript-booster\">JavaScript Booster</a>, by Stephan Burguchev. This is an amazing code refactoring tool. It features several coding actions such as converting <code>var</code> to <code>const</code> or <code>let</code>, removing redundant <code>else</code> statements, and merging declaration and initialization. Largely inspired by <a href=\"https://www.jetbrains.com/webstorm/\">WebStorm</a>, it has 74k+ installs to date.</p> </li> \n</ul> \n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/1587002116features.gif\" alt=\"JavaScript Booster Demo\" />\n <figcaption style=\"text-align:center; font-size:0.8em; margin: 12px 0 20px\">\n   Source: \n  <a href=\"https://github.com/xsburg/vscode-javascript-booster\">vscode-javascript-booster</a>\n </figcaption>\n</figure> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/vs-code-extensions-javascript-developers/?utm_source=rss\">10 Must-have VS Code Extensions for JavaScript Developers</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"React vs Angular: An In-depth Comparison","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=152707","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/react-vs-angular/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"React vs Angular: An In-depth Comparison\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492644427RvsA_B-01.png\" alt=\"Two knights jousting, with Angular and React logos on their shields\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492644427RvsA_B-01-300x167.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492644427RvsA_B-01-768x427.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492644427RvsA_B-01.png 900w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Should I choose Angular or React? Each framework has a lot to offer and it’s not easy to choose between them. Whether you’re a newcomer trying to figure out where to start, a freelancer picking a framework for your next project, or an enterprise-grade architect planning a strategic vision for your company, you’re likely to benefit from having an educated view on this topic.</strong></p> \n<p>To save you some time, let me tell you something up front: this article won’t give a clear answer on which framework is better. But neither will hundreds of other articles with similar titles. I can’t tell you that, because the answer depends on a wide range of factors which make a particular technology more or less suitable for your environment and use case.</p> \n<p>Since we can’t answer the question directly, we’ll attempt something else. We’ll compare Angular and React, to demonstrate how you can approach the problem of comparing any two frameworks in a structured manner on your own and tailor it to your environment. You know, the old “teach a man to fish” approach. That way, when both are replaced by a BetterFramework.js in a year’s time, you’ll be able to re-create the same train of thought once more.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492644427RvsA_B-01.png\" alt=\"Two knights jousting, with React and Angular logos on their shields\" /></p> \n<p><em>We’ve just overhauled this guide to reflect the state of React, Angular, and their respective advantages and disadvantages in 2020.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"wheretostart\">Where to Start?</h2> \n<p>Before you pick any tool, you need to answer two simple questions: “Is this a good tool per se?” and “Will it work well for my use case?” Neither of them mean anything on their own, so you always need to keep both of them in mind. All right, the questions might not be that simple, so we’ll try to break them down into smaller ones.</p> \n<p>Questions on the tool itself:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>How mature is it and who’s behind it?</li> \n <li>What kind of features does it have?</li> \n <li>What architecture, development paradigms, and patterns does it employ?</li> \n <li>What is the ecosystem around it?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Questions for self-reflection:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Will I and my colleagues be able to learn this tool with ease?</li> \n <li>Does it fit well with my project?</li> \n <li>What is the developer experience like?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Using this set of questions, you can start your assessment of any tool, and we’ll base our comparison of React and Angular on them as well.</p> \n<p>There’s another thing we need to take into account. Strictly speaking, it’s not exactly fair to compare Angular to React, since Angular is a full-blown, feature-rich framework, while React just a UI component library. To even the odds, we’ll talk about React in conjunction with some of the libraries often used with it.</p> \n<h2 id=\"maturity\">Maturity</h2> \n<p>An important part of being a skilled developer is being able to keep the balance between established, time-proven approaches and evaluating new bleeding-edge tech. As a general rule, you should be careful when adopting tools that haven’t yet matured due to certain risks:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>The tool may be buggy and unstable.</li> \n <li>It might be unexpectedly abandoned by the vendor.</li> \n <li>There might not be a large knowledge base or community available in case you need help.</li> \n <li>Both React and Angular come from good families, so it seems that we can be confident in this regard.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"react\">React</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://reactjs.org/\">React</a> is developed and maintained by Facebook and used in their products, including Instagram and WhatsApp. It has been around for around since 2013, so it’s not exactly new. It’s also one of the most popular projects on GitHub, with more than 150,000 stars at the time of writing. Some of the other notable companies using React are Airbnb, Uber, Netflix, Dropbox, and Atlassian. Sounds good to me.</p> \n<h3 id=\"angular\">Angular</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://angular.io/\">Angular</a> has been around since 2016, making it slightly younger than React, but it’s also not a new kid on the block. It’s maintained by Google and, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rbFLorQWlOQ&amp;feature=youtu.be&amp;t=358\">as mentioned by Igor Minar</a>, even in 2018 was used in more than 600 hundred applications in Google such as Firebase Console, Google Analytics, Google Express, Google Cloud Platform and more. Outside of Google, Angular is used by Forbes, Upwork, VMWare, and <a href=\"https://www.madewithangular.com/\">others</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"features\">Features</h2> \n<p>Like I mentioned earlier, Angular has more features out of the box than React. This can be both a good and a bad thing, depending on how you look at it.</p> \n<p>Both frameworks share some key features in common: components, data binding, and platform-agnostic rendering.</p> \n<h3 id=\"angular-1\">Angular</h3> \n<p>Angular provides a lot of the features required for a modern web application out of the box. Some of the standard features are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>dependency injection</li> \n <li>templates, based on an extended version of HTML</li> \n <li>class-based components with lifecycle hooks</li> \n <li>routing, provided by <code>@angular/router</code></li> \n <li>Ajax requests using <code>@angular/common/http</code></li> \n <li><code>@angular/forms</code> for building forms</li> \n <li>component CSS encapsulation</li> \n <li>XSS protection</li> \n <li>code splitting and lazy loading</li> \n <li>test runner, framework and utilities for unit-testing.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Some of these features are built into the core of the framework and you don’t have an option not to use them. This requires developers to be familiar with features such as dependency injection to build even a small Angular application. Other features such as the HTTP client or forms are completely optional and can be added on an as-needed basis.</p> \n<h3 id=\"react-1\">React</h3> \n<p>With React, you’re starting with a more minimalistic approach. If we’re looking at just React, here’s what we have:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>instead of classic templates, it has JSX, an XML-like language built on top of JavaScript</li> \n <li>class-based components with lifecycle hooks or simpler functional components</li> \n <li>state management using setState and hooks.</li> \n <li>XSS protection</li> \n <li>code splitting and lazy loading</li> \n <li>error handling boundaries</li> \n <li>utilities for unit-testing components</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Out of the box, React does not provide anything for dependency injection, routing, HTTP calls, or advanced form handling. You are expected to choose whatever additional libraries to add based on your needs which can be both a good and a bad thing depending on how experienced you are with these technologies. Some of the popular libraries that are often used together with React are:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://reactrouter.com\">React-router</a> for routing</li> \n <li>Fetch (or <a href=\"https://github.com/axios/axios\">axios</a>) for HTTP requests</li> \n <li>a wide variety of techniques for CSS encapsulation</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://enzymejs.github.io/enzyme/\">Enzyme</a> or <a href=\"https://testing-library.com/docs/react-testing-library/intro\">React Testing Library</a> for additional unit-testing utilities</li> \n</ul> \n<p>The teams I’ve worked with have found the freedom of choosing your libraries liberating. This gives us the ability to tailor our stack to particular requirements of each project, and we haven’t found the cost of learning new libraries that high.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/react-vs-angular/?utm_source=rss\">React vs Angular: An In-depth Comparison</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=DO5NliNasAw:AnaUnx8vTMU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=DO5NliNasAw:AnaUnx8vTMU:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=DO5NliNasAw:AnaUnx8vTMU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=DO5NliNasAw:AnaUnx8vTMU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/DO5NliNasAw\" +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492644427RvsA_B-01.png","linkMd5":"c9cdb92a528c588f5d31ca349750f3d2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn14@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-24-723_c9a73b83b05c84fc.webp","destWidth":900,"destHeight":500,"sourceBytes":21478,"destBytes":21478,"author":"Pavels Jelisejevs","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492644427RvsA_B-01.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn14@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-24-723_c9a73b83b05c84fc.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1492644427RvsA_B-01.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn23@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-45-202_29e48cc4e25b8b1e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=DO5NliNasAw:AnaUnx8vTMU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn9@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-35-383_4bb0816e569006e8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/DO5NliNasAw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn81@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-38-085_f41d600609d209a1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483244},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Prototype a Web App with Django and Vue.js","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175926","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/web-app-prototype-django-vue/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Prototype a Web App with Django and Vue.js\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587347568django-vue.png\" alt=\"Prototyping a Web App with Django and Vue.js\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587347568django-vue-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587347568django-vue.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Wouldn’t it be cool if you could prototype a custom web application that’s <a style=\"font-weight: bold;\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/build-responsive-bootstrap-website/\">responsive</a> (mobile-ready), <a style=\"font-weight: bold;\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/reactive-web-apps/\">reactive</a> (light-speed fast), with a full-featured&nbsp;<a style=\"font-weight: bold;\" href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/admin/\">admin interface</a>&nbsp;to manage the content — all in no time? Actually, using Django and Vue.js, you can!</strong> 😁</p> \n<h2 id=\"0introductionfullstackdevelopment101\">0. Introduction: Full Stack Development 101</h2> \n<p>I’ll cover how to prototype a custom web app, and to keep it as short and sweet as possible, the context information here will be rather brief. However, I will provide — hopefully — enough resources so that you know where to go should you need more information.</p> \n<p>To this end I’ll fully mash up data management, presentation, and routing between Django and Vue.js — so get ready!</p> \n<h3 id=\"aboutdjango\">About Django</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.djangoproject.com/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Django_logo.svg/100px-Django_logo.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>You may know of <a href=\"https://www.djangoproject.com/\">Django</a>, the Python-based <em>web framework for perfectionists with deadlines</em> that’s <strong>ridiculously fast, reassuringly secure, and exceedingly scalable</strong>. But if you don’t know much about it, this article will serve as an extremely fast hands-on introduction.</p> \n<h3 id=\"aboutvuejs\">About Vue.js</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://vuejs.org/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/100px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Same deal with <a href=\"https://vuejs.org/\">Vue.js</a>, <em>the progressive JavaScript framework</em> that’s <em>approachable, versatile, and performant</em>. If you aren’t familiar with it, here you’ll get a quick-and-dirty introduction.</p> \n<p>I’ll also cover two official Vue.js libraries:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://router.vuejs.org/\">Vue Router</a></strong> for route/view mapping</li> \n <li><strong><a href=\"https://vuex.vuejs.org/\">Vuex</a></strong> for state management</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"pythonjavascriptwin\">Python + JavaScript = WIN!</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.python.org/\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Python_logo_and_wordmark.svg/100px-Python_logo_and_wordmark.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>For this article, we’ll set a publishing project with a basic <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_schema\">database schema</a> to save <code>authors</code> and <code>articles</code>, and a minimal <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_interface\">user interface</a> (UI) to interact with them.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/javascript/\"><img src=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175926/ https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/JavaScript-logo.png/100px-JavaScript-logo.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Hopefully, this will serve as a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toy_program\">toy program</a> to understand <em>how to integrate Django using Python code on the back end with a JavaScript framework on the front end</em>, that you can adapt later to your own needs.</p> \n<h2 id=\"1settingupadjangoproject\">1. Setting Up a Django Project</h2> \n<p>Very quickly, we’ll set up a project from scratch. If you already know how to handle Django projects, you can skip this section. We’ll assume you already have <a href=\"https://realpython.com/installing-python/\">Python installed</a>.</p> \n<p>For a more in-depth guide, see <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/install/\">How to install Django</a> on the Django documentation site.</p> \n<h3 id=\"pythonvirtualenvironment\">Python Virtual Environment</h3> \n<p>Let’s open a console and create a virtual environment (see <a href=\"https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/venv.html\">Virtual Environments and Packages</a> for more info):</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ virtualenv myenvironment\n</code></pre> \n<pre><code class=\"text language-text\">Using base prefix 'c:\\\\users\\\\luzdealba\\\\appdata\\\\local\\\\programs\\\\python\\\\python37'\nNew python executable in C:\\Users\\luzdealba\\Development\\myenvironment\\Scripts\\python.exe\nInstalling setuptools, pip, wheel …\ndone\n</code></pre> \n<p>Don’t mind the paths, as these will change from system to system.</p> \n<p>Let’s access and activate the virtual environment.</p> \n<p>On Windows:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ cd myenvironment\n$ Scripts\\activate\n</code></pre> \n<p>On macOS and Linux:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ cd myenvironment\n$ source bin/activate\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"djangopackage\">Django Package</h3> \n<p>Let’s install Django:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">(myenvironment) $ pip install django\n</code></pre> \n<pre><code class=\"text language-text\">Collecting django\n  Downloading Django-3.0.3-py3-none-any.whl (7.5 MB)\nCollecting sqlparse&gt;=0.2.2\n  Downloading sqlparse-0.3.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl (40 kB)\nCollecting pytz\n  Using cached pytz-2019.3-py2.py3-none-any.whl (509 kB)\nCollecting asgiref~=3.2\n  Downloading asgiref-3.2.3-py2.py3-none-any.whl (18 kB)\nInstalling collected packages: sqlparse, pytz, asgiref, django\nSuccessfully installed asgiref-3.2.3 django-3.0.3 pytz-2019.3 sqlparse-0.3.1\n</code></pre> \n<p>One more time, don’t mind about program versions and file sizes as these will vary.</p> \n<h3 id=\"theproject\">The Project</h3> \n<p>Let’s start a project called <code>myproject</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">(myenvironment) $ django-admin startproject myproject\n</code></pre> \n<p>Let’s access the project:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">(myenvironment) $ cd myproject\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"theapp\">The App</h3> \n<p>Start an app called <code>myapp</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">(myenvironment) $ django-admin startapp myapp\n</code></pre> \n<p>And add <code>myapp.apps.MyappConfig</code> to the <code>INSTALLED_APPS</code> constant list in <code>myproject/settings.py</code> to enable the app.</p> \n<h2 id=\"2settingupthedatabasewithdjango\">2. Setting Up the Database with Django</h2> \n<p>Here we’ll define the back-end database with Django, which we’ll later integrate with a front-end storage with Vuex.</p> \n<h3 id=\"djangomodels\">Django Models</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/db/models/\">Models</a> are Django’s way to implement an <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-relational_database\">object-relational database management system</a> (ORDBMS). In other words, plain text files where you can define database tables and fields, and from where these will propagate to the application layer and the DB engine.</p> \n<p>Let’s code the following models for our app in <code>myapp/models.py</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"python language-python\">from django.db import models\n\nclass Article(models.Model):\n    \"\"\"Table schema to store articles.\"\"\"\n    name = models.CharField(max_length=64)\n    author = models.ForeignKey('myapp.Author', on_delete=models.CASCADE)\n    content = models.TextField()\n    slug = models.CharField(default='', max_length=64)\n\n    def __str__(self):\n        return '%s' % self.name\n\nclass Author(models.Model):\n    \"\"\"Table schema to store auhtors.\"\"\"\n    name = models.CharField(max_length=64)\n    slug = models.CharField(default='', max_length=64)\n\n    def __str__(self):\n        return '%s' % self.name\n</code></pre> \n<p>Notice that we implemented a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clean_URL#Slug\">URL slug</a> for both articles and authors.</p> \n<p>For more information, see <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/models/\">Model API reference</a> on the Django documentation site.</p> \n<h3 id=\"djangoadmin\">Django Admin</h3> \n<p>Before we can manage these models through the admin site, we’ll first need to <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/admin/#django.contrib.admin.AdminSite.register\"><code>register</code></a> them so that Django makes them available to us.</p> \n<p>Let’s simply edit <code>myapp/admin.py</code> so that it looks like this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"python language-python\">from django.contrib import admin\n\nfrom .models import Article\nfrom .models import Author\n\n# register models to use in admin site\nadmin.site.register(Article)\nadmin.site.register(Author)\n</code></pre> \n<p>Read more about the <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/admin/\">Django admin site</a> on the Django documentation site.</p> \n<h3 id=\"djangomigrations\">Django Migrations</h3> \n<p>From the Django’s <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/migrations/\">Migrations documentation</a>:</p> \n<blockquote>\n <p>Migrations are Django’s way of propagating changes you make to your models (adding a field, deleting a model, etc.) into your database schema.</p>\n</blockquote> \n<p>In short: migrations do <em>everything</em>; no SQL commands required.</p> \n<p>First, let’s create the migration files:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">(myenvironment) $ python manage.py makemigrations\n</code></pre> \n<pre><code class=\"text language-text\">Migrations for 'myapp':\n  myapp\\migrations\\0001_initial.py\n    - Create model Author\n    - Create model Article\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now let’s use that information to update the database:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">(myenvironment) $ python manage.py migrate\n</code></pre> \n<pre><code class=\"text language-text\">Operations to perform:\n  Apply all migrations: admin, auth, contenttypes, myapp, sessions\nRunning migrations:\n  Applying contenttypes.0001_initial... OK\n  Applying auth.0001_initial... OK\n  Applying admin.0001_initial... OK\n  Applying admin.0002_logentry_remove_auto_add... OK\n  Applying admin.0003_logentry_add_action_flag_choices... OK\n  Applying contenttypes.0002_remove_content_type_name... OK\n  Applying auth.0002_alter_permission_name_max_length... OK\n  Applying auth.0003_alter_user_email_max_length... OK\n  Applying auth.0004_alter_user_username_opts... OK\n  Applying auth.0005_alter_user_last_login_null... OK\n  Applying auth.0006_require_contenttypes_0002... OK\n  Applying auth.0007_alter_validators_add_error_messages... OK\n  Applying auth.0008_alter_user_username_max_length... OK\n  Applying auth.0009_alter_user_last_name_max_length... OK\n  Applying auth.0010_alter_group_name_max_length... OK\n  Applying auth.0011_update_proxy_permissions... OK\n  Applying myapp.0001_initial... OK\n  Applying sessions.0001_initial... OK\n</code></pre> \n<p>Don’t mind the long list. That’s because that was our first migration, so not only our <code>Author</code> and <code>Article</code> tables were created, but also all of Django’s default schemas.</p> \n<p>For more info, see <a href=\"https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/migration-operations/\">Migration operations</a> in the Django documentation site.</p> \n<h2 id=\"3abasicinterfacewithvuecomponentsinadjangotemplate\">3. A Basic Interface with Vue Components in a Django Template</h2> \n<p>Here’s one of the most interesting parts of the mashup, as we’ll mix closely related tools from different technologies.</p> \n<h3 id=\"djangoview\">Django View</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model%E2%80%93view%E2%80%93controller\"><img src=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/MVC-Process.svg/218px-MVC-Process.svg.png\" align=\"right\" /></a></p> \n<p>Django goes by the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model%E2%80%93view%E2%80%93controller\">model–view–controller</a> (MVC) software design pattern, which divides the related program logic into three interconnected elements.</p> \n<p>We’ll code the following view in <code>myapp/views.py</code>:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/web-app-prototype-django-vue/?utm_source=rss\">How to Prototype a Web App with Django and Vue.js</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=iv7vO0rcXMQ:YaGtFI0Cwkw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img del Alba","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1587347568django-vue.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn42@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-26-127_1853f6254aab1ed4.webp","https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Django_logo.svg/100px-Django_logo.svg.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn15@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-41-717_1d4e75f5fac3edab.webp","https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/100px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn6@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-36-129_9c6ea918f0627f80.webp","https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Python_logo_and_wordmark.svg/100px-Python_logo_and_wordmark.svg.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn26@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-36-653_8b6f86b71ec35af3.webp","https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=175926/ https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/JavaScript-logo.png/100px-JavaScript-logo.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn36@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-42-258_1ce72f020158ba98.jpg","https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/MVC-Process.svg/218px-MVC-Process.svg.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-36-916_266da3c5eaf2200a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=iv7vO0rcXMQ:YaGtFI0Cwkw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn59@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-46-901_2e48568050127b0c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/iv7vO0rcXMQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn47@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-41-830_cbfd36f7dea9376b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483272},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Use SSL/TLS with Node.js","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=115135","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-use-ssltls-with-node-js/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Use SSL/TLS with Node.js\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1585717345ssl-tls.png\" alt=\"How to Use SSL/TLS with Node.js\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1585717345ssl-tls-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1585717345ssl-tls.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>In 2020, there’s no reason for your website not to use HTTPS. Visitors expect it, Google uses it as a ranking factor and browser makers will happily name and shame those sites not using it.</strong></p> \n<p>In this tutorial, I’ll walk you through a practical example of how to add a <a href=\"https://letsencrypt.org/\">Let’s Encrypt</a>–generated certificate to your Express.js server.</p> \n<p>But protecting our sites and apps with HTTPS isn’t enough. We should also demand encrypted connections from the servers we’re talking to. We’ll see that possibilities exist to activate the SSL/TLS layer even when it’s not enabled by default.</p> \n<p><em>Note: if you’re looking for instructions on how to set up SSL with NGINX when configuring it to work as a reverse proxy for a Node app, check out our quick tip, “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/configuring-nginx-ssl-node-js/\">Configuring NGINX and SSL with Node.js</a>”.</em></p> \n<p>Let’s start with a short review of the current state of HTTPS.</p> \n<h2 id=\"httpseverywhere\">HTTPS Everywhere</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP/2\">The HTTP/2 specification</a> was published as RFC 7540 in May 2015, which means at this point it’s a part of the standard. This was a major milestone. Now we can all upgrade our servers to use HTTP/2. One of the most important aspects is the backwards compatibility with HTTP 1.1 and the negotiation mechanism to choose a different protocol. Although the standard doesn’t specify mandatory encryption, currently no browser supports HTTP/2 unencrypted. This gives HTTPS another boost. Finally we’ll get HTTPS everywhere!</p> \n<p>What does our stack actually look like? From the perspective of a website running in the browser (at the application level) we have to traverse the following layers to reach the IP level:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Client browser</li> \n <li>HTTP</li> \n <li>SSL/TLS</li> \n <li>TCP</li> \n <li>IP</li> \n</ol> \n<p>HTTPS is nothing more than the HTTP protocol on top of SSL/TLS. Hence all of HTTP’s rules still apply. What does this additional layer actually give us? There are multiple advantages: we get authentication by having keys and certificates; a certain kind of privacy and confidentiality is guaranteed, as the connection is encrypted in an asymmetric manner; and data integrity is also preserved, as transmitted data can’t be changed during transit.</p> \n<p>One of the most common myths is that using SSL/TLS is computationally expensive and slows the server down. This is certainly not true anymore. We also don’t need any specialized hardware with cryptography units. Even for Google, <a href=\"https://www.imperialviolet.org/2010/06/25/overclocking-ssl.html\">the SSL/TLS layer accounts for less than 1% of the CPU load and the the network overhead of HTTPS as compared to HTTP is below 2%</a>. All in all, it wouldn’t make sense to forgo HTTPS for the sake of a little overhead.</p> \n<p>As Ilya Grigorik puts it, there is but one performance problem:</p> \n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-lang=\"en\" data-dnt=\"true\" data-theme=\"light\"> \n <p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">TLS has exactly one performance problem: it is not used widely enough. Everything else can be optimized: <a href=\"https://t.co/1kH8qh89Eg\">https://t.co/1kH8qh89Eg</a></p> \n <p>— Ilya Grigorik (@igrigorik) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/igrigorik/status/436618170397646848?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">February 20, 2014</a></p>\n</blockquote> \n<p><script async=\"\" src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p> \n<p>The most recent version is TLS 1.3. TLS is the successor of SSL, which is available in its latest release SSL 3.0. The changes from SSL to TLS preclude interoperability, but the basic procedure is, however, unchanged. We have three different encrypted channels. The first is a public key infrastructure for certificate chains. The second provides public key cryptography for key exchanges. Finally, the third one is symmetric. Here we have cryptography for data transfers.</p> \n<p>TLS 1.3 uses hashing for some important operations. Theoretically, it’s possible to use any hashing algorithm, but it’s highly recommended to use SHA2 or a stronger algorithm. SHA1 has been a standard for a long time but has recently become obsolete.</p> \n<p>HTTPS is also gaining more attention for clients. Privacy and security concerns have always been around, but with the growing amount of online accessible data and services, people are getting more and more concerned. For those sites that don’t implement it, there is a useful browser extension — <a href=\"https://www.eff.org/https-everywhere\">HTTPS Everywhere from the EFF</a> — which encrypts our communications with most websites.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583329162https-everywhere.png\" alt=\"HTTPS-everywhere\" /></p> \n<p>The creators realized that many websites offer HTTPS only partially. The plugin allows us to rewrite requests for those sites that offer only partial HTTPS support. Alternatively, we can also block HTTP altogether (see the screenshot above).</p> \n<h2 id=\"basiccommunication\">Basic Communication</h2> \n<p>The certificate’s validation process involves validating the certificate signature and expiration. We also need to verify that it chains to a trusted root. Finally, we need to check to see if it’s been revoked. There are dedicated, trusted authorities in the world that grant certificates. In case one of these were to become compromised, all other certificates from the said authority would get revoked.</p> \n<p>The sequence diagram for an HTTPS handshake looks as follows. We start with the initialization from the client, which is followed by a message with the certificate and key exchange. After the server sends its completed package, the client can start the key exchange and cipher specification transmission. At this point, the client is finished. Finally the server confirms the cipher specification selection and closes the handshake.</p> \n<p><img src=\"http://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/1442392132sequence.png\" alt=\"HTTPS-sequence\" /></p> \n<p>The whole sequence is triggered independently of HTTP. If we decide to use HTTPS, only the socket handling is changed. The client is still issuing HTTP requests, but the socket will perform the previously described handshake and encrypt the content (header and body).</p> \n<p>So what do we need to make SSL/TLS work with an Express.js server?</p> \n<h2 id=\"https\">HTTPS</h2> \n<p>By default, Node.js serves content over HTTP. But there’s also an <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/https.html\">HTTPS module</a> that we have to use in order to communicate over a secure channel with the client. This is a built-in module, and the usage is very similar to how we use the HTTP module:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">const https = require(\"https\"),\n  fs = require(\"fs\");\n\nconst options = {\n  key: fs.readFileSync(\"/srv/www/keys/my-site-key.pem\"),\n  cert: fs.readFileSync(\"/srv/www/keys/chain.pem\")\n};\n\nconst app = express();\n\napp.use((req, res) =&gt; {\n  res.writeHead(200);\n  res.end(\"hello world\\n\");\n});\n\napp.listen(8000);\n\nhttps.createServer(options, app).listen(8080);\n</code></pre> \n<p>Ignore the <code>/srv/www/keys/my-site-key.pem</code> and and <code>/srv/www/keys/chain.pem</code> files for the moment. Those are the SSL certificates we need to generate, which we’ll do a bit later. This is the part that changed with Let’s Encrypt. Previously, we had to generate a private/public key pair, send it to a trusted authority, pay them and probably wait for a bit in order to get an SSL certificate. Nowadays, Let’s Encrypt instantly generates and validates your certificates for free!</p> \n<h2 id=\"generatingcertificates\">Generating Certificates</h2> \n<h3 id=\"certbot\">Certbot</h3> \n<p>The TLS specification demands a certificate, which is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA). The CA ensures that the certificate holder is really who they claim to be. So basically when you see the green lock icon (or any other greenish sign to the left side of the URL in your browser) it means that the server you’re communicating with is really who it claims to be. If you’re on facebook.com and you see a green lock, it’s almost certain you really are communicating with Facebook and no one else can see your communication — or rather, no one else can read it.</p> \n<p>It’s worth noting that this certificate doesn’t necessarily have to be verified by an authority such as Let’s Encrypt. There are other paid services as well. <a href=\"https://stackoverflow.com/q/10175812\">You can technically sign it yourself</a>, but then (as you’re not a trusted CA) the users visiting your site will likely see a large scary warning offering to get them back to safety.</p> \n<p>In the following example, we’ll use the <em>Certbot</em>, which is used to generate and manage certificates with Let’s Encrypt.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://certbot.eff.org/\">On the Certbot site</a> you can find instructions on how to install <em>Certbot</em> for almost any OS/server combination. You should choose the options that are applicable to you.</p> \n<p>A common combination for deploying Node apps is NGINX on the latest LTS Ubuntu and that’s what I’ll use here.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">sudo apt-get update\nsudo apt-get install software-properties-common\nsudo add-apt-repository universe\nsudo add-apt-repository ppa:certbot/certbot\nsudo apt-get update\n</code></pre> \n<h4 id=\"webroot\">Webroot</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://certbot.eff.org/docs/using.html#webroot\">Webroot is a Certbot plugin</a> that, in addition to the Certbot default functionality (which automatically generates your public/private key pair and generates an SSL certificate for those), also copies the certificates to your webroot folder and verifies your server by placing some verification code into a hidden temporary directory named <code>.well-known</code>. In order to skip doing some of these steps manually, we’ll use this plugin. The plugin is installed by default with <em>Certbot</em>. In order to generate and verify our certificates, we’ll run the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">certbot certonly --webroot -w /var/www/example/ -d www.example.com -d example.com\n</code></pre> \n<p>You may have to run this command as sudo, as it will try to write to <code>/var/log/letsencrypt</code>.</p> \n<p>You’ll also be asked for your email address. It’s a good idea to put in a real address you use often, as you’ll get a notification if your certificate is about to expire. The trade-off for Let’s Encrypt issuing a free certificate is that it expires every three months. Luckily, renewal is as easy as running one simple command, which we can <a href=\"https://www.howtogeek.com/101288/how-to-schedule-tasks-on-linux-an-introduction-to-crontab-files/\">assign to a cron job</a> and then not have to worry about expiration. Additionally, it’s a good security practice to renew SSL certificates, as it gives attackers less time to break the encryption. Sometimes developers even set up this cron to run daily, which is completely fine and even recommended.</p> \n<p>Keep in mind that you have to run this command on a server to which the domain specified under the <code>-d</code> (for domain) flag resolves — that is, your production server. Even if you have the DNS resolution in your local hosts file, this won’t work, as the domain will be verified from outside. So if you’re doing this locally, it will most likely fail, unless you opened up a port from your local machine to the outside world and have it running behind a domain name which resolves to your machine. This is a highly unlikely scenario.</p> \n<p>Last but not least, after running this command, the output will contain paths to your private key and certificate files. Copy these values into the previous code snippet — into the <code>cert</code> property for certificate, and the <code>key</code> property for the key:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">// ...\n\nconst options = {\n  key: fs.readFileSync(\"/var/www/example/sslcert/privkey.pem\"),\n  cert: fs.readFileSync(\"/var/www/example/sslcert/fullchain.pem\") // these paths might differ for you, make sure to copy from the certbot output\n};\n\n// ...\n</code></pre> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/how-to-use-ssltls-with-node-js/?utm_source=rss\">How to Use SSL/TLS with Node.js</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=d1amf2iSpyA:hVaO0YUOT1U:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=d1amf2iSpyA:hVaO0YUOT1U:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=d1amf2iSpyA:hVaO0YUOT1U:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=d1amf2iSpyA:hVaO0YUOT1U:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"
