Rappl","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/1585717345ssl-tls.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn25@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-24-742_63ec78a5e83081c5.webp","https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1583329162https-everywhere.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn89@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-43-108_e137658e4ef458d3.webp","http://www.sitepoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/1442392132sequence.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn77@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-38-796_18098b281188e923.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=d1amf2iSpyA:hVaO0YUOT1U:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn13@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-42-525_3fae321a3599e02f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/d1amf2iSpyA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_2/2020/08/24/22-51-43-459_a36c6be0ec5c40e0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483278},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Debug a Node.js Application: Tips, Tricks and Tools","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=151978","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/debug-node-app-tips-tricks-tools/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Debug a Node.js Application: Tips, Tricks and Tools\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1491329546nodebugsA-01.png\" alt=\"Two figures in protective suits with weapons, battling a giant spider-like bug\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1491329546nodebugsA-01-300x167.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1491329546nodebugsA-01-768x427.png 768w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1491329546nodebugsA-01.png 900w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Software development is complex and, at some point, your Node.js application will fail. If you’re <em>lucky</em>, your code will crash with an obvious error message. If you’re unlucky, your application will carry on regardless but not generate the results you expect. If you’re really unlucky, everything will work fine until the first user discovers a catastrophic disk-wiping bug.</strong></p> \n<h2 id=\"whatisdebugging\">What is Debugging?</h2> \n<p><strong>Debugging</strong> is the black art of fixing software defects. Fixing a bug is often easy — a corrected character or additional line of code solves the problem. Finding that bug is another matter, and developers can spend many unhappy hours trying to locate the source of an issue. Fortunately, Node.js has some great tools to help trace errors.</p> \n<h3 id=\"terminology\">Terminology</h3> \n<p>Debugging has its own selection of obscure jargon, including the following:</p> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th style=\"text-align:right;\">Term</th> \n   <th>Explanation</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">breakpoint</td> \n   <td>the point at which a debugger stops a program so its state can be inspected</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">debugger</td> \n   <td>a tool which offers debugging facilities such as running code line by line to inspect internal variable states</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">feature</td> \n   <td>as in the claim: “it’s not a bug, it’s a feature”. All developers say it at some point during their career</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">frequency</td> \n   <td>how often or under what conditions a bug will occur</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">it doesn’t work</td> \n   <td>the most-often made but least useful bug report</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">log point</td> \n   <td>an instruction to a debugger to show the value of a variable at a point during execution</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">logging</td> \n   <td>output of runtime information to the console or a file</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">logic error</td> \n   <td>the program works but doesn’t act as intended</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">priority</td> \n   <td>where a bug is allocated on a list of planned updates</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">race condition</td> \n   <td>hard-to-trace bugs dependent the sequence or timing of uncontrollable events</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">refactoring</td> \n   <td>rewriting code to help readability and maintenance</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">regression</td> \n   <td>re-emergence of a previously fixed bug perhaps owing to other updates</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">related</td> \n   <td>a bug which is similar or related to another</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">reproduce</td> \n   <td>the steps required to cause the error</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">RTFM error</td> \n   <td>user incompetence disguised as a bug report, typically followed by a response to “Read The <em>Flipping</em> Manual”</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">step into</td> \n   <td>when running code line by line in a debugger, step into the function being called</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">step out</td> \n   <td>when running line by line, complete execution of the current function and return to the calling code</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">step over</td> \n   <td>when running line by line, complete execution of a command without stepping into a function it calls</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">severity</td> \n   <td>the impact of a bug on system. For example, data loss would normally be considered more problematic than a UI issue unless the frequency of occurrence is very low</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">stack trace</td> \n   <td>the historical list of all functions called before the error occurred</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">syntax error</td> \n   <td>typographical errors, such as <code>console.lug()</code></td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">user error</td> \n   <td>an error caused by a user rather than the application, but may still incur an update depending on that person’s seniority</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">watch</td> \n   <td>a variable to examine during debugger execution</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\">watchpoint</td> \n   <td>similar to a breakpoint, except the program is stopped when a variable is set to a specific value</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<h2 id=\"howtoavoidbugs\">How to Avoid Bugs</h2> \n<p>Bugs can often be prevented before you test your application …</p> \n<h3 id=\"useagoodcodeeditor\">Use a Good Code Editor</h3> \n<p>A good code editor will offer numerous features including line numbering, auto-completion, color-coding, bracket matching, formatting, auto-indentation, variable renaming, snippet reuse, object inspection, function navigation, parameter prompts, refactoring, unreachable code detection, suggestions, type checking, and more.</p> \n<p>Node.js devs are spoiled for choice with free editors such as <a href=\"https://code.visualstudio.com/\">VS Code</a>, <a href=\"https://atom.io/\">Atom</a>, and <a href=\"http://brackets.io/\">Brackets</a>, as well as plenty of commercial alternatives.</p> \n<h3 id=\"useacodelinter\">Use a Code Linter</h3> \n<p>A linter can report code faults such as syntax errors, poor indentation, undeclared variables, and mismatching brackets before you save and test your code. The popular options for JavaScript and Node.js include <a href=\"https://eslint.org/\">ESLint</a>, <a href=\"https://www.jslint.com/\">JSLint</a>, and <a href=\"https://jshint.com/\">JSHint</a>.</p> \n<p>These are often installed as global Node.js modules so you can run checks from the command line:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">eslint myfile.js\n</code></pre> \n<p>However, most linters have code editor plugins, such as <a href=\"https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=dbaeumer.vscode-eslint\">ESLint for VS Code</a> and <a href=\"https://atom.io/packages/linter-eslint\">linter-eslint for Atom</a> which check your code as you type:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/1581435166eslint.png\" alt=\"ESLint for VS Code\" /></p> \n<h3 id=\"usesourcecontrol\">Use Source Control</h3> \n<p>A source control system such as <a href=\"https://git-scm.com/\">Git</a> can help safe-guard your code and manage revisions. It becomes easier to discover where and when a bug was introduced and who should receive the blame! Online repositories such as <a href=\"https://github.com/\">GitHub</a> and <a href=\"https://bitbucket.org/\">Bitbucket</a> offer free space and management tools.</p> \n<h3 id=\"adoptanissuetrackingsystem\">Adopt an Issue-tracking System</h3> \n<p><em>Does a bug exist if no one knows about it?</em> An issue-tracking system is used to report bugs, find duplicates, document reproduction steps, determine severity, calculate priorities, assign developers, record discussions, and track progress of any fixes.</p> \n<p>Online source repositories often offer basic issue tracking, but <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_issue-tracking_systems\">dedicated solutions</a> may be appropriate for larger teams and projects.</p> \n<h3 id=\"usetestdrivendevelopment\">Use Test-driven Development</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/learning-javascript-test-driven-development-by-example/\">Test-driven Development</a> (TDD) is a development process which encourages developers to write code which tests the operation of a function before it’s written — for example, <em>is X returned when function Y is passed input Z</em>.</p> \n<p>Tests can be run as the code is developed to prove a function works and spot any issues as further changes are made. That said, your tests could have bugs too …</p> \n<h3 id=\"stepaway\">Step Away</h3> \n<p>It’s tempting to stay up all night in a futile attempt to locate the source of a nasty bug. Don’t. Step away and do something else. Your brain will subconsciously work on the problem and wake you at 4am with a solution. Even if that doesn’t happen, fresh eyes will spot that obvious missing semicolon.</p> \n<h2 id=\"nodejsdebuggingenvironmentvariables\">Node.js Debugging: Environment Variables</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/cli.html#cli_environment_variables\">Environment variables</a> that are set within the host operating system can be used to control Node.js application settings. The most common is <code>NODE_ENV</code>, which is typically set to <code>development</code> when debugging.</p> \n<p>Environment variables can be set on Linux/macOS:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">NODE_ENV=development\n</code></pre> \n<p>Windows <code>cmd</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">set NODE_ENV=development\n</code></pre> \n<p>Or Windows Powershell:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$env:NODE_ENV=\"development\"\n</code></pre> \n<p>Internally, an application will enable further debugging features and messages. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">// is NODE_ENV set to \"development\"?\nconst DEVMODE = (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'development');\n\nif (DEVMODE) {\n  console.log('application started in development mode on port ${PORT}');\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p><code>NODE_DEBUG</code> enables debugging messages using the Node.js <code>util.debuglog</code> (see below), but also consult the documentation of your primary modules and frameworks to discover further options.</p> \n<p>Note that environment variables can also be saved to a <code>.env</code> file. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"env language-env\">NODE_ENV=development\nNODE_LOG=./log/debug.log\nSERVER_PORT=3000\nDB_HOST=localhost\nDB_NAME=mydatabase\n</code></pre> \n<p>Then loaded using the <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/dotenv\"><code>dotenv</code> module</a>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">require('dotenv').config();\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"nodejsdebuggingcommandlineoptions\">Node.js Debugging: Command Line Options</h2> \n<p>Various <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/cli.html\">command-line options</a> can be passed to the <code>node</code> runtime when launching an application. One of the most useful is <code>--trace-warnings</code>, which outputs stack traces for process warnings (including deprecations).</p> \n<p>Any number of options can be set, including:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><code>--enable-source-maps</code>: enable source maps (experimental)</li> \n <li><code>--throw-deprecation</code>: throw errors when deprecated features are used</li> \n <li><code>--inspect</code>: activate the V8 inspector (see below)</li> \n</ul> \n<p>By way of an example, let’s try to log <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/crypto.html#crypto_crypto_default_encoding\">the crypto module’s <code>DEFAULT_ENCODING</code> property</a>, which was deprecated in Node v10:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">const crypto = require('crypto');\n\nfunction bar() {\n  console.log(crypto.DEFAULT_ENCODING);\n}\n\nfunction foo(){\n  bar();\n}\n\nfoo();\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now run this with the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">node index.js\n</code></pre> \n<p>We’ll then see this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"text language-text\">buffer\n(node:7405) [DEP0091] DeprecationWarning: crypto.DEFAULT_ENCODING is deprecated.\n</code></pre> \n<p>However, we can also do this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">node --trace-warnings index.js\n</code></pre> \n<p>That produces the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"text language-text\">buffer\n(node:7502) [DEP0091] DeprecationWarning: crypto.DEFAULT_ENCODING is deprecated.\n    at bar (/home/Desktop/index.js:4:22)\n    at foo (/home/Desktop/index.js:8:3)\n    at Object.&lt;anonymous&gt; (/home/Desktop/index.js:11:1)\n    at Module._compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1151:30)\n    at Object.Module._extensions..js (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1171:10)\n    at Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1000:32)\n    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:899:14)\n    at Function.executeUserEntryPoint [as runMain] (internal/modules/run_main.js:71:12)\n    at internal/main/run_main_module.js:17:47\n</code></pre> \n<p>This tells us that the deprecation warning comes from the code in line 4 (the <code>console.log</code> statement), which was executed when the <code>bar</code> function ran. The <code>bar</code> function was called by the <code>foo</code> function on line 8 and the <code>foo</code> function was called on line 11 of our script.</p> \n<p>Note that the same options can also be passed to <a href=\"https://nodemon.io/\">nodemon</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"consoledebugging\">Console Debugging</h2> \n<p>One of the easiest ways to debug an application is to output values to the console during execution:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">console.log( myVariable );\n</code></pre> \n<p>Few developers delve beyond this humble debugging command, but they’re missing out on <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html\">many more possibilities</a>, including these:</p> \n<table> \n <thead> \n  <tr> \n   <th style=\"text-align:right;\"><code>console</code> method</th> \n   <th>description</th> \n  </tr> \n </thead> \n <tbody> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_log_data_args\"><code>.log(msg)</code></a></td> \n   <td>output a message to the console</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_dir_obj_options\"><code>.dir(obj,opt)</code></a></td> \n   <td>uses <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/util.html#util_util_inspect_object_options\"><code>util.inspect</code></a> to pretty-print objects and properties</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_table_tabulardata_properties\"><code>.table(obj)</code></a></td> \n   <td>outputs arrays of objects in tabular format</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_error_data_args\"><code>.error(msg)</code></a></td> \n   <td>output an error message</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_count_label\"><code>.count(label)</code></a></td> \n   <td>a named counter reporting the number of times the line has been executed</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_countreset_label\"><code>.countReset[label]</code></a></td> \n   <td>resets a named counter</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_group_label\"><code>.group(label)</code></a></td> \n   <td>indents a group of log messages</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_groupend\"><code>.groupEnd(label)</code></a></td> \n   <td>ends the indented group</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_time_label\"><code>.time(label)</code></a></td> \n   <td>starts a timer to calculate the duration of an operation</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_timelog_label_data\"><code>.timeLog([label]</code></a></td> \n   <td>reports the elapsed time since the timer started</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_timeend_label\"><code>.timeEnd(label)</code></a></td> \n   <td>stops the timer and reports the total duration</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_trace_message_args\"><code>.trace()</code></a></td> \n   <td>outputs a stack trace (a list of all calling functions)</td> \n  </tr> \n  <tr> \n   <td style=\"text-align:right;\"><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_console_clear\"><code>.clear()</code></a></td> \n   <td>clear the console</td> \n  </tr> \n </tbody> \n</table> \n<p><code>console.log()</code> accepts a list of comma-separated values. For example:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">let x = 123;\nconsole.log('x:', x);\n// x: 123\n</code></pre> \n<p>However, <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/es6-destructuring-assignment/\">ES6 destructuring</a> can offer similar output with less typing effort:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">console.log({x});\n// { x: 123 }\n</code></pre> \n<p>Larger objects can be output as a condensed string using this:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">console.log( JSON.stringify(obj) );\n</code></pre> \n<p><a href=\"https://nodejs.org/api/util.html#util_util_inspect_object_options\"><code>util.inspect</code></a> will format objects for easier reading, but <code>console.dir()</code> does the hard work for you.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/debug-node-app-tips-tricks-tools/?utm_source=rss\">How to Debug a Node.js Application: Tips, Tricks and Tools</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=qx00UQ79Vks:5ir6J6bxt1E:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"How to Contribute to Open Source TypeScript Projects","link":"https://editor.sitepoint.com/?p=176087","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/open-source-typescript/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"How to Contribute to Open Source TypeScript Projects\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588147117HL_M18_07.jpg\" 1024w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<blockquote> \n <p>If you think of the ideas of open source applied to information in an encyclopedia, you get to Wikipedia – lots and lots of small contributions that bubble up to something that’s meaningful. – <em>Matt Mullenweg</em></p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>One of my favorite aspects of open source is the fact that anyone can contribute! It’s like “productive volunteering” (if you’ll humor me). It’s a fantastic way to build something bigger than you, give back to the community, and level up your skills.</p> \n<p>In this article, we’re going to talk about practical ways for you to get involved in open source TypeScript projects. We’ll first cover assessing your level then jump into how you can find opportunities.</p> \n<h2 id=\"assessingyourlevel\">Assessing Your Level</h2> \n<p>Before you get started contributing to open source, you want to find your comfort level. Where are you at skill-wise? What level of complexity are you wanting to solve? How much time do you want to spend? These are important questions to consider before diving in. This information will guide us during the process of finding opportunities.</p> \n<p>To simplify things, we will create three levels:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Level 1</li> \n <li>Level 2</li> \n <li>Level 3</li> \n</ul> \n<p>In each level, we will provide a description and an example contribution for someone at that level. Let’s take a look.</p> \n<h3 id=\"level1newtotypescript\">Level 1: New to TypeScript</h3> \n<p>The first level in our three-level TypeScript skills assessment is for those who are “new to TypeScript.” You might find yourself here if any of this description resonates with you:</p> \n<p><em>You are new to TypeScript. You feel comfortable enough with JavaScript that you decided to give TypeScript a try. You have looked at the docs briefly. Maybe you’ve gone through a tutorial or two and. Maybe you’ve watched a video about TypeScript on YouTube. “Beginner” feels accurate when labeling your TypeScript skills.</em></p> \n<p>Below are a few examples of things you might contribute to while you are at this level:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>updates to documentation \n  <ul> \n   <li><a href=\"https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-loader/issues/1024\">open-source libraries</a></li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript-Handbook/pull/1115\">TypeScript Handbook</a> or website</li> \n   <li><a href=\"https://github.com/typescript-cheatsheets/react-typescript-cheatsheet/pull/155\">creating links to the TypeScript playground for examples</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"level2comfortablewithtypescript\">Level 2: Comfortable with TypeScript</h3> \n<p>The next level in our system is where I imagine most people self-categorize. Read the description and see if this relates to how you are currently feeling:</p> \n<p><em>You’ve used TypeScript in a few projects. You feel comfortable with TypeScript and understand how to fix general type errors. You’re not an expert when it comes to understanding issues, but you sure know how to find the answer. Maybe you’ve written a handful of interfaces or type aliases. You know a decent number of TypeScript tricks or tips. The compiler isn’t your bestie, but you consider yourselves acquaintances.</em> </p> \n<p>At this level, you might feel comfortable contributing in the following ways:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>fixing bugs \n  <ul> \n   <li>fixing a type error</li> \n   <li>making a switch statement exhaustive</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>adding small features \n  <ul> \n   <li>converting <code>any</code> to the correct type</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>updating docs with new examples, templates, etc. \n  <ul> \n   <li>contributing to a <a href=\"https://github.com/typescript-cheatsheets\">cheatsheet</a></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"level3readyfortypescriptchallenges\">Level 3: Ready for TypeScript Challenges</h3> \n<p>The last level we’ll have is for people who feel quite comfortable with TypeScript and are ready for a challenge! Take a glance at the description below and see if that’s how you would describe your level:</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/open-source-typescript/?utm_source=rss\">How to Contribute to Open Source TypeScript Projects</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=6JmyiJec4Tg:sWfR1L1vGtw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=6JmyiJec4Tg:sWfR1L1vGtw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/6JmyiJec4Tg\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Apr 2020 22:30:57 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588147117HL_M18_07.jpg","linkMd5":"8500970e79d41c05d9e8c452a9cb530a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn34@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-27-918_7aba5f35eff0f1e1.webp","destWidth":1800,"destHeight":1003,"sourceBytes":23766,"destBytes":23766,"author":"Joe Previte","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/1588147117HL_M18_07.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn34@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-27-918_7aba5f35eff0f1e1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=6JmyiJec4Tg:sWfR1L1vGtw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn21@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-43-010_3834c573d82e1660.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/6JmyiJec4Tg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn98@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-39-852_10e572eae005cc7d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483273},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"React Router v5: The Complete Guide","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=160204","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/react-router-complete-guide/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"React Router v5: The Complete Guide\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1587032757react-router.png\" alt=\"React Router v5: The Complete Guide\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1587032757react-router-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1587032757react-router.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong><a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://reacttraining.com/react-router/\">React Router</a> is the de facto standard routing library for React. When you need to navigate through a React application with multiple views, you’ll need a router to manage the URLs. React Router takes care of that, keeping your application UI and the URL in sync.</strong></p> \n<p>This tutorial introduces you to React Router v5 and a whole lot of things you can do with it.</p> \n<h2 id=\"introduction\">Introduction</h2> \n<p>React is a popular library for creating single-page applications (SPAs) that are rendered on the client side. An SPA might have multiple <strong>views</strong> (aka <strong>pages</strong>), and unlike the conventional multi-page apps, navigating through these views shouldn’t result in the entire page being reloaded. Instead, we want the views to be rendered inline within the current page. The end user, who’s accustomed to multi-page apps, expects the following features to be present in an SPA:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Each view in an application should have a URL that uniquely specifies that view. This is so that the user can bookmark the URL for reference at a later time. For example, <code>www.example.com/products</code>.</li> \n <li>The browser’s back and forward button should work as expected.</li> \n <li>The dynamically generated nested views should preferably have a URL of their own too. For example, <code>example.com/products/shoes/101</code>, where 101 is the product ID.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Routing</strong> is the process of keeping the browser URL in sync with what’s being rendered on the page. React Router lets you handle routing <em>declaratively</em>. The declarative routing approach allows you to control the data flow in your application, by saying “the route should look like this”:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">&lt;Route path=\"/about\" component={About} /&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>You can place your <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code> component anywhere you want your route to be rendered. Since <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;Link&gt;</code> and all the other React Router APIs that we’ll be dealing with are just components, you can easily get used to routing in React.</p> \n<p><em>A note before getting started. There’s a common misconception that React Router is an official routing solution developed by Facebook. In reality, it’s a third-party library that’s widely popular for its design and simplicity. If your requirements are limited to routers for navigation, you could implement a custom router from scratch without much hassle. However, understanding how the basics of React Router will give you better insights into how a router should work.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"overview\">Overview</h2> \n<p>This tutorial is divided into different sections. First, we’ll be setting up React and React Router using npm. Then we’ll jump right into React Router basics. You’ll find different code demonstrations of React Router in action. The examples covered in this tutorial include:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>basic navigational routing</li> \n <li>nested routing</li> \n <li>nested routing with path parameters</li> \n <li>protected routing</li> \n</ol> \n<p>All the concepts connected with building these routes will be discussed along the way. The entire code for the project is available on <a href=\"https://github.com/sitepoint-editors/react-router-demo\">this GitHub repo</a>. Once you’re inside a particular demo directory, run <code>npm install</code> to install the dependencies. To serve the application on a development server, run <code>npm start</code> and head over to <code>http://localhost:3000/</code> to see the demo in action.</p> \n<p>Let’s get started!</p> \n<h2 id=\"settingupreactrouter\">Setting up React Router</h2> \n<p>I assume you already have a development environment up and running. If not, head over to “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/getting-started-react-jsx/\">Getting Started with React and JSX</a>”. Alternatively, you can use <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/create-react-app/\">Create React App</a> to generate the files required for creating a basic React project. This is the default directory structure generated by Create React App:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\"> react-router-demo\n    ├── .gitignore\n    ├── package.json\n    ├── public\n    │   ├── favicon.ico\n    │   ├── index.html\n    │   └── manifest.json\n    ├── README.md\n    ├── src\n    │   ├── App.css\n    │   ├── App.js\n    │   ├── App.test.js\n    │   ├── index.css\n    │   ├── index.js\n    │   ├── logo.svg\n    │   └── registerServiceWorker.js\n    └── yarn.lock\n</code></pre> \n<p>The React Router library comprises three packages: <code>react-router</code>, <code>react-router-dom</code>, and <code>react-router-native</code>. <code>react-router</code> is the core package for the router, whereas the other two are environment specific. You should use <code>react-router-dom</code> if you’re building a website, and <code>react-router-native</code> if you’re on a mobile app development environment using React Native.</p> \n<p>Use npm to install <code>react-router-dom</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install --save react-router-dom\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"reactrouterbasics\">React Router Basics</h2> \n<p>Here’s an example of how our routes will look:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">&lt;Router&gt;/* App component */\nclass App extends React.Component {\n  render() {\n    return (\n      &lt;div&gt;\n        &lt;nav className=\"navbar navbar-light\"&gt;\n          &lt;ul className=\"nav navbar-nav\"&gt;\n            /* Link components are used for linking to other views */\n            &lt;li&gt;\n              &lt;Link to=\"/\"&gt;Homes&lt;/Link&gt;\n            &lt;/li&gt;\n            &lt;li&gt;\n              &lt;Link to=\"/category\"&gt;Category&lt;/Link&gt;\n            &lt;/li&gt;\n            &lt;li&gt;\n              &lt;Link to=\"/products\"&gt;Products&lt;/Link&gt;\n            &lt;/li&gt;\n          &lt;/ul&gt;\n        &lt;/nav&gt;\n        /* Route components are rendered if the path prop matches the current URL*/\n        &lt;Route path=\"/\" component={Home} /&gt;\n        &lt;Route path=\"/category\" component={Category} /&gt;\n        &lt;Route path=\"/products\" component={Products} /&gt;\n      &lt;/div&gt;\n    );\n  }\n}\n  &lt;Route exact path=\"/\" component={Home} /&gt;\n  &lt;Route path=\"/category\" component={Category} /&gt;\n  &lt;Route path=\"/login\" component={Login} /&gt;\n  &lt;Route path=\"/products\" component={Products} /&gt;\n&lt;/Router&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<h3 id=\"router\">Router</h3> \n<p>You need a router component and several route components to set up a basic route as exemplified above. Since we’re building a browser-based application, we can use two types of routers from the React Router API:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><code>&lt;BrowserRouter&gt;</code></li> \n <li><code>&lt;HashRouter&gt;</code></li> \n</ol> \n<p>The primary difference between them is evident in the URLs that they create:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">// &lt;BrowserRouter&gt;\nhttp://example.com/about\n\n// &lt;HashRouter&gt;\nhttp://example.com/#/about\n</code></pre> \n<p>The <code>&lt;BrowserRouter&gt;</code> is more popular amongst the two because it uses the HTML5 History API to keep track of your router history. The <code>&lt;HashRouter&gt;</code>, on the other hand, uses the hash portion of the URL (<code>window.location.hash</code>) to remember things. If you intend to support legacy browsers, you should stick with <code>&lt;HashRouter&gt;</code>.</p> \n<p>Wrap the <code>&lt;BrowserRouter&gt;</code> component around the App component.</p> \n<h4 id=\"indexjs\">index.js</h4> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">/* Import statements */\nimport React from \"react\";\nimport ReactDOM from \"react-dom\";\n\n/* App is the entry point to the React code.*/\nimport App from \"./App\";\n\n/* import BrowserRouter from 'react-router-dom' */\nimport { BrowserRouter } from \"react-router-dom\";\n\nReactDOM.render(\n  &lt;BrowserRouter&gt;\n    &lt;App /&gt;\n  &lt;/BrowserRouter&gt;,\n  document.getElementById(\"root\")\n);\n</code></pre> \n<p><em>Note: A router component can only have a single child element. The child element can be an HTML element — such as div — or a react component.</em></p> \n<p>For the React Router to work, you need to import the relevant API from the <code>react-router-dom</code> library. Here I’ve imported the <code>BrowserRouter</code> into <code>index.js</code>. I’ve also imported the <code>App</code> component from <code>App.js</code>. <code>App.js</code>, as you might have guessed, is the entry point to React components.</p> \n<p>The above code creates an instance of history for our entire App component. Let me formally introduce you to history.</p> \n<h3 id=\"history\">history</h3> \n<blockquote> \n <p><code>history</code> is a JavaScript library that lets you easily manage session history anywhere JavaScript runs. <code>history</code> provides a minimal API that lets you manage the history stack, navigate, confirm navigation, and persist state between sessions. — <a href=\"https://github.com/ReactTraining/history\">React Training docs</a></p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Each router component creates a history object that keeps track of the current location (<code>history.location</code>) and also the previous locations in a stack. When the current location changes, the view is re-rendered and you get a sense of navigation. How does the current location change? The history object has methods such as <code>history.push()</code> and <code>history.replace()</code> to take care of that. <code>history.push()</code> is invoked when you click on a <code>&lt;Link&gt;</code> component, and <code>history.replace()</code> is called when you use <code>&lt;Redirect&gt;</code>. Other methods — such as <code>history.goBack()</code> and <code>history.goForward()</code> — are used to navigate through the history stack by going back or forward a page.</p> \n<p>Moving on, we have Links and Routes.</p> \n<h3 id=\"linksandroutes\">Links and Routes</h3> \n<p>The <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code> component is the most important component in React router. It renders some UI if the current location matches the route’s path. Ideally, a <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code> component should have a prop named <code>path</code>, and if the pathname is matched with the current location, it gets rendered.</p> \n<p>The <code>&lt;Link&gt;</code> component, on the other hand, is used to navigate between pages. It’s comparable to the HTML anchor element. However, using anchor links would result in a browser refresh, which we don’t want. So instead, we can use <code>&lt;Link&gt;</code> to navigate to a particular URL and have the view re-rendered without a browser refresh.</p> \n<p>We’ve covered everything you need to know to create a basic router. Let’s build one.</p> \n<h3 id=\"demo1basicrouting\">Demo 1: Basic Routing</h3> \n<h4 id=\"srcappjs\">src/App.js</h4> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">/* Import statements */\nimport React, { Component } from \"react\";\nimport { Link, Route, Switch } from \"react-router-dom\";\n\n/* Home component */\nconst Home = () =&gt; (\n  &lt;div&gt;\n    &lt;h2&gt;Home&lt;/h2&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;\n);\n\n/* Category component */\nconst Category = () =&gt; (\n  &lt;div&gt;\n    &lt;h2&gt;Category&lt;/h2&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;\n);\n\n/* Products component */\nconst Products = () =&gt; (\n  &lt;div&gt;\n    &lt;h2&gt;Products&lt;/h2&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;\n);\n\nexport default function App() {\n  return (\n    &lt;div&gt;\n      &lt;nav className=\"navbar navbar-light\"&gt;\n        &lt;ul className=\"nav navbar-nav\"&gt;\n          &lt;li&gt;\n            &lt;Link to=\"/\"&gt;Homes&lt;/Link&gt;\n          &lt;/li&gt;\n          &lt;li&gt;\n            &lt;Link to=\"/category\"&gt;Category&lt;/Link&gt;\n          &lt;/li&gt;\n          &lt;li&gt;\n            &lt;Link to=\"/products\"&gt;Products&lt;/Link&gt;\n          &lt;/li&gt;\n        &lt;/ul&gt;\n      &lt;/nav&gt;\n      /* Route components are rendered if the path prop matches the current URL */\n      &lt;Route path=\"/\" component={Home} /&gt;\n      &lt;Route path=\"/category\" component={Category} /&gt;\n      &lt;Route path=\"/products\" component={Products} /&gt;\n    &lt;/div&gt;\n  );\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p>We’ve declared the components for Home, Category and Products inside <code>App.js</code>. Although this is okay for now, when the component starts to grow bigger, it’s better to have a separate file for each component. As a rule of thumb, I usually create a new file for a component if it occupies more than 10 lines of code. Starting from the second demo, I’ll be creating a separate file for components that have grown too big to fit inside the <code>App.js</code> file.</p> \n<p>Inside the App component, we’ve written the logic for routing. The <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code>‘s path is matched with the current location and a component gets rendered. The component that should be rendered is passed in as a second prop.</p> \n<p>Here <code>/</code> matches both <code>/</code> and <code>/category</code>. Therefore, both the routes are matched and rendered. How do we avoid that? You should pass the <code>exact= {true}</code> props to the router with <code>path='/'</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">&lt;Route exact={true} path=\"/\" component={Home} /&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you want a route to be rendered only if the paths are exactly the same, you should use the exact props.</p> \n<h2 id=\"nestedrouting\">Nested Routing</h2> \n<p>To create nested routes, we need to have a better understanding of how <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code> works. Let’s do that.</p> \n<p><code>&lt;Route&gt;</code> has three props that you can you use to define what gets rendered:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>component</strong>. We’ve already seen this in action. When the URL is matched, the router creates a React element from the given component using <code>React.createElement</code>.</li> \n <li><strong>render</strong>. This is handy for inline rendering. The render prop expects a function that returns an element when the location matches the route’s path.</li> \n <li><strong>children</strong>. The children prop is similar to render in that it expects a function that returns a React element. However, children gets rendered regardless of whether the path is matched with the location or not.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3 id=\"pathandmatch\">Path and match</h3> \n<p>The <strong>path</strong> is used to identify the portion of the URL that the router should match. It uses the Path-to-RegExp library to turn a path string into a regular expression. It will then be matched against the current location.</p> \n<p>If the router’s path and the location are successfully matched, an object is created and we call it the <strong>match</strong> object. The match object carries more information about the URL and the path. This information is accessible through its properties, listed below:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><code>match.url</code>. A string that returns the matched portion of the URL. This is particularly useful for building nested <code>&lt;Link&gt;</code>s</li> \n <li><code>match.path</code>. A string that returns the route’s path string — that is, <code>&lt;Route path=\"\"&gt;</code>. We’ll be using this to build nested <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code>s.</li> \n <li><code>match.isExact</code>. A boolean that returns true if the match was exact (without any trailing characters).</li> \n <li><code>match.params</code>. An object containing key/value pairs from the URL parsed by the Path-to-RegExp package.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Now that we know all about <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code>s, let’s build a router with nested routes.</p> \n<h3 id=\"switchcomponent\">Switch Component</h3> \n<p>Before we head for the demo code, I want to introduce you to the <code>&lt;Switch&gt;</code> component. When multiple <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code>s are used together, all the routes that match are rendered inclusively. Consider this code from demo 1. I’ve added a new route to demonstrate why <code>&lt;Switch&gt;</code> is useful:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"jsx language-jsx\">&lt;Route exact path=\"/\" component={Home}/&gt;\n&lt;Route path=\"/products\" component={Products}/&gt;\n&lt;Route path=\"/category\" component={Category}/&gt;\n&lt;Route path=\"/:id\" render = {()=&gt; (&lt;p&gt; I want this text to show up for all routes other than '/', '/products' and '/category' &lt;/p&gt;)}/&gt;\n</code></pre> \n<p>If the URL is <code>/products</code>, all the routes that match the location <code>/products</code> are rendered. So, the <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code> with path <code>:id</code> gets rendered along with the <code>Products</code> component. This is by design. However, if this is not the behavior you’re expecting, you should add the <code>&lt;Switch&gt;</code> component to your routes. With <code>&lt;Switch&gt;</code>, only the first child <code>&lt;Route&gt;</code> that matches the location gets rendered.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/react-router-complete-guide/?utm_source=rss\">React Router v5: The Complete Guide</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=eqdQC0khaAU:Q70g63dFBww:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=eqdQC0khaAU:Q70g63dFBww:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=eqdQC0khaAU:Q70g63dFBww:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=eqdQC0khaAU:Q70g63dFBww:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/eqdQC0khaAU\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Apr 2020 15:00:02 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1587032757react-router.png","linkMd5":"595809fd463ed102037385921c0e386f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn53@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-24-743_a295f55ad6dbe0eb.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":9920,"destBytes":9920,"author":"Manjunath M","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/1587032757react-router.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn53@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-24-743_a295f55ad6dbe0eb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=eqdQC0khaAU:Q70g63dFBww:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn34@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-35-373_8a68467b65b6cf8a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/eqdQC0khaAU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn5@2020_4/2020/08/24/22-51-43-829_961ea48a93bdaf85.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483289},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"Create New Express.js Apps in Minutes with Express Generator","link":"https://www.sitepoint.com/?p=163399","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/create-new-express-js-apps-with-express-generator/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"Create New Express.js Apps in Minutes with Express Generator\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1585291419express-generator.png\" alt=\"Create New Express.js Apps in Minutes with Express Generator\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1585291419express-generator-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1585291419express-generator.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong><a style=\"font-weight:bold\" href=\"https://expressjs.com/\">Express.js</a> is a Node.js web framework that has gained immense popularity due to its simplicity. It has easy-to-use routing and simple support for view engines, putting it far ahead of the basic Node HTTP server.</strong></p> \n<p>However, starting a new Express application requires a certain amount of boilerplate code: starting a new server instance, configuring a view engine, and setting up error handling.</p> \n<p>Although there are various starter projects and boilerplates available, Express has its own command-line tool that makes it easy to start new apps, called the <a href=\"https://expressjs.com/en/starter/generator.html\">express-generator</a>.</p> \n<h2 id=\"whatisexpress\">What is Express?</h2> \n<p>Express has a lot of features built in, and a lot more features you can get from other packages that integrate seamlessly, but there are three main things it does for you out of the box:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong>Routing</strong>. This is how <code>/home</code> <code>/blog</code> and <code>/about</code> all give you different pages. Express makes it easy for you to modularize this code by allowing you to put different routes in different files.</li> \n <li><strong>Middleware</strong>. If you’re new to the term, basically middleware is “software glue”. It accesses requests before your routes get them, allowing them to handle hard-to-do stuff like cookie parsing, file uploads, errors, and more.</li> \n <li><strong>Views</strong>. Views are how HTML pages are rendered with custom content. You pass in the data you want to be rendered and Express will render it with your given view engine.</li> \n</ol> \n<h2 id=\"gettingstarted\">Getting Started</h2> \n<p>The first thing you’ll need is to get Node and npm installed on your machine. To do this, either head to <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/download/\">the official Node download page</a> and grab the correct binaries for your system, or use a version manager such as nvm. We cover installing Node using a version manager in our quick tip, “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">Install Multiple Versions of Node.js Using nvm</a>”.</p> \n<p>Starting a new project with the Express generator is as simple as running a few commands:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install express-generator -g\n</code></pre> \n<p>This installs the Express generator as a global package, allowing you to run the <code>express</code> command in your terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">express myapp\n</code></pre> \n<p>This creates a new Express project called <code>myapp</code>, which is then placed inside of the <code>myapp</code> directory:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">cd myapp\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you’re unfamiliar with terminal commands, this one puts you inside of the <code>myapp</code> directory:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install\n</code></pre> \n<p>If you’re unfamiliar with npm, it’s the <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/beginners-guide-node-package-manager/\">default Node.js package manager</a>. Running <code>npm install</code> installs all dependencies for the project. By default, the <code>express-generator</code> includes several packages that are commonly used with an Express server.</p> \n<h3 id=\"options\">Options</h3> \n<p>The generator CLI takes half a dozen <a href=\"https://expressjs.com/en/starter/generator.html\">arguments</a>, but the two most useful ones are the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>-v \n   <ejs |hbs|hjs|jade|pug|twig|vash=\"\"></ejs></strong>. This lets you select a view engine to install. The default is <code>jade</code>. Although this still works, it has been deprecated and you should always specify an alternative engine.</li> \n <li><strong>-c \n   <less |stylus|compass|sass=\"\"></less></strong>. By default, the generator creates a very basic CSS file for you, but selecting a CSS engine will configure your new app with middleware to compile any of the above options.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Now that we’ve got our project set up and dependencies installed, we can start the new server by running the following:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm start\n</code></pre> \n<p>Then browse to <a href=\"http://localhost:3000\">http://localhost:3000</a> in your browser.</p> \n<h2 id=\"applicationstructure\">Application Structure</h2> \n<p>The generated Express application starts off with four folders.</p> \n<h3 id=\"bin\"><code>bin</code></h3> \n<p>The <code>bin</code> folder contains the executable file that starts your app. It starts the server (on port 3000, if no alternative is supplied) and sets up some basic error handling. You don’t really need to worry about this file, because <code>npm start</code> will run it for you.</p> \n<h3 id=\"public\"><code>public</code></h3> \n<p>The <code>public</code> folder is one of the important ones: ​<em>everything​</em> in this folder is accessible to people connecting to your application. In this folder, you’ll put JavaScript, CSS, images, and other assets that people need when they load your website.</p> \n<h3 id=\"routes\"><code>routes</code></h3> \n<p>The <code>routes</code> folder is where you’ll put your router files. The generator creates two files, <code>index.js</code> and <code>users.js</code>, which serve as examples of how to separate out your application’s route configuration.</p> \n<p>Usually, you’ll have a different file here for each major route on your website. So you might have files called <code>blog.js</code>, <code>home.js</code>, and/or <code>about.js</code> in this folder.</p> \n<h3 id=\"views\"><code>views</code></h3> \n<p>The <code>views</code> folder is where you have the files used by your templating engine. The generator will configure Express to look in here for a matching view when you call the <code>render</code> method.</p> \n<p>Outside of these folders, there’s one file that you should know well.</p> \n<h2 id=\"appjs\"><code>app.js</code></h2> \n<p>The <code>app.js</code> file is special, because it sets up your Express application and glues all of the different parts together. Let’s walk through what it does. Here’s how the file starts:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">var createError = require('http-errors');\nvar express = require('express');\nvar path = require('path');\nvar cookieParser = require('cookie-parser');\nvar logger = require('morgan');\n</code></pre> \n<p>These first six lines of the file are required. If you’re new to Node, be sure to read “<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/understanding-module-exports-exports-node-js/\">Understanding module.exports and exports in Node.js</a>”.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">var indexRouter = require('./routes/index');\nvar usersRouter = require('./routes/users');\n</code></pre> \n<p>The next two lines of code <code>require</code> the different route files that the Express generator sets up by default: <code>routes</code> and <code>users</code>.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">var app = express();\n</code></pre> \n<p>After that, we create a new app by calling <code>express()</code>. The app variable contains all of the settings and routes for your application. This object glues together your application.</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">app.set('views', path.join(__dirname, 'views'));\napp.set('view engine', 'jade');\n</code></pre> \n<p>Once the app instance is created, the templating engine is set up for rendering views. This is where you’d change the path to your view files if necessary.</p> \n<p>After this, you’ll see Express being configured to use middleware. The generator installs several common pieces of middleware that you’re likely to use in a web application:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">app.use(logger('dev'));\napp.use(express.json());\napp.use(express.urlencoded({ extended: false }));\napp.use(cookieParser());\napp.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public')));\n</code></pre> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>logger</strong>. When you run your app, you might notice that all the routes that are requested are logged to the console. If you want to disable this, you can just comment out this middleware.</li> \n <li><strong>express.json</strong>. You might notice that there are two lines for parsing the body of incoming HTTP requests. The first line handles when JSON is sent via a POST request and it puts this data in <code>request.body</code>.</li> \n <li><strong>express.urlencoded</strong>. The second line parses query string data in the URL (e.g. <code>/profile?id=5</code>) and puts this in <code>request.query</code>.</li> \n <li><strong>cookieParser</strong>. This takes all the cookies the client sends and puts them in <code>request.cookies</code>. It also allows you to modify them before sending them back to the client, by changing <code>response.cookies</code>.</li> \n <li><strong>express.static</strong>. This middleware serves static assets from your <code>public</code> folder. If you wanted to rename or move the public folder, you can change the path here.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Next up is the routing:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">app.use('/', indexRouter);\napp.use('/users', usersRouter);\n</code></pre> \n<p>Here, the example route files that were required are attached to our app. If you need to add additional routes, you’d do it here.</p> \n<p>All the code after this is used for error handling. You usually won’t have to modify this code unless you want to change the way Express handles errors. By default, it’s set up to show the error that occurred in the route when you’re in development mode.</p> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/create-new-express-js-apps-with-express-generator/?utm_source=rss\">Create New Express.js Apps in Minutes with Express Generator</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=M75lmchKk9Q:eBFYJRzvgSE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=M75lmchKk9Q:eBFYJRzvgSE:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=M75lmchKk9Q:eBFYJRzvgSE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=M75lmchKk9Q:eBFYJRzvgSE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/M75lmchKk9Q\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Sun, 05 Apr 2020 15:00:28 +0000","feedId":6128,"bgimg":"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1585291419express-generator.png","linkMd5":"bf62aa6aaf7f5be5fa684d89620521cc","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn61@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-26-072_2ee2a3de91c32ecb.webp","destWidth":600,"destHeight":339,"sourceBytes":7592,"destBytes":7592,"author":"Paul Sauve","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/1585291419express-generator.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn61@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-26-072_2ee2a3de91c32ecb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_1/2020/08/24/22-51-39-311_6409ebad5acff93a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/22-51-47-113_bf83e999bebef320.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=M75lmchKk9Q:eBFYJRzvgSE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn62@2020_6/2020/08/24/22-51-40-345_e682b5d42405a788.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/M75lmchKk9Q":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn2@2020_3/2020/08/24/22-51-35-177_ff658ac89f60fb85.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598309483280},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 06:51:23","title":"A Beginner’s Guide to npm, the Node Package Manager","link":"http://www.sitepoint.com/?p=126537","description":"<a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/beginners-guide-node-package-manager/?utm_source=rss\" title=\"A Beginner’s Guide to npm, the Node Package Manager\" rel=\"nofollow\"> <img class=\"webfeedsFeaturedVisual\" style=\"display: block; margin: auto; margin-bottom: 5px;max-width: 100%;\" link_thumbnail=\"1\" src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/1583709471npm.png\" alt=\"A Beginner’s Guide to npm\" srcset=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/1583709471npm-300x170.png 300w, https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/1583709471npm.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /> </a> \n<p><strong>Node.js makes it possible to write applications in JavaScript on the server. It’s built on the <a href=\"https://v8.dev/\">V8 JavaScript runtime</a> and written in C++ — so it’s fast. Originally, it was intended as a server environment for applications, but developers started using it to create tools to aid them in local task automation. Since then, a whole new ecosystem of Node-based tools (such as <a href=\"http://gruntjs.com/\">Grunt</a>, <a href=\"http://gulpjs.com/\">Gulp</a> and <a href=\"https://webpack.js.org\">webpack</a>) has evolved to transform the face of front-end development.</strong></p> \n<p>To make use of these tools (or packages) in Node.js, we need to be able to install and manage them in a useful way. This is where npm, the Node package manager, comes in. It installs the packages you want to use and provides a useful interface to work with them.</p> \n<p>In this guide, we’re going to look at the basics of working with npm. We’ll show you how to install packages in local and global mode, as well as delete, update and install a certain version of a package. We’ll also show you how to work with <code>package.json</code> to manage a project’s dependencies. If you’re more of a video person, why not sign up for SitePoint Premium and watch our free screencast: <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/premium/screencasts/what-is-npm-and-how-can-i-use-it?utm_source=blog&amp;utm_medium=articles\">What is npm and How Can I Use It?</a></p> \n<p>But before we can start using npm, we first have to install Node.js on our system. Let’s do that now.</p> \n<h2 id=\"installingnodejs\">Installing Node.js</h2> \n<p>Head to the Node.js <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/download/\">download page</a> and grab the version you need. There are Windows and Mac installers available, as well as pre-compiled Linux binaries and source code. For Linux, you can also install Node via the package manager, <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/download/package-manager/\">as outlined here</a>.</p> \n<p>For this tutorial, we’re going to use v12.15.0. At the time of writing, this is the current <a href=\"https://github.com/nodejs/Release#release-schedule\">Long Term Support (LTS) version of Node</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Tip: You might also consider <a href=\"http://sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm\">installing Node using a version manager</a>. This negates the permissions issue raised in the next section.</em></p> \n<p>Let’s see where node was installed and check the version:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ which node\n/usr/bin/node\n$ node --version\nv12.15.0\n</code></pre> \n<p>To verify that your installation was successful, let’s give Node’s REPL a try:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ node\n&gt; console.log('Node is running');\nNode is running\n&gt; .help\n.break    Sometimes you get stuck, this gets you out\n.clear    Alias for .break\n.editor   Enter editor mode\n.exit     Exit the repl\n.help     Print this help message\n.load     Load JS from a file into the REPL session\n.save     Save all evaluated commands in this REPL session to a file\n\nPress ^C to abort current expression, ^D to exit the repl\n</code></pre> \n<p>The Node.js installation worked, so we can now focus our attention on npm, which was included in the install:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ which npm\n/usr/bin/npm\n$ npm --version\n6.13.7\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"updatingnpm\">Updating npm</h2> \n<p>npm, which originally stood for Node Package Manager, is a separate project from Node.js. It tends to be updated more frequently. You can check the latest available npm version on this <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/npm\">page</a>. If you realize you have an older version, you can update as follows.</p> \n<p>For Linux and Mac users, use the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install -g npm@latest\n</code></pre> \n<p>For Windows users, the process might be slightly more complicated. This is what it says on the <a href=\"https://github.com/npm/cli/#windows-install-or-upgrade\">project’s home page</a>:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Many improvements for Windows users have been made in npm 3 – you will have a better experience if you run a recent version of npm. To upgrade, either use <a href=\"https://github.com/felixrieseberg/npm-windows-upgrade\">Microsoft’s upgrade tool</a>, <a href=\"https://nodejs.org/en/download/\">download a new version of Node</a>, or follow the Windows upgrade instructions in the <a href=\"https://npm.community/t/installing-upgrading-npm/251/2\">Installing/upgrading npm</a> post.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>For most users, the upgrade tool will be the best bet. To use it, you’ll need to open PowerShell as administrator and execute the following command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted -Scope CurrentUser -Force\n</code></pre> \n<p>This will ensure you can execute scripts on your system. Next, you’ll need to install the <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/npm-windows-upgrade\">npm-windows-upgrade</a> tool. After you’ve installed the tool, you need to run it so that it can update npm for you. Do all this within the elevated PowerShell console:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install --global --production npm-windows-upgrade\nnpm-windows-upgrade --npm-version latest\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"nodepackagedmodules\">Node Packaged Modules</h2> \n<p>npm can install packages in local or global mode. In local mode, it installs the package in a <code>node_modules</code> folder in your parent working directory. This location is owned by the current user.</p> \n<p>If you’re not using a <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">version manager</a> (which you probably should be), global packages are installed in <code>{prefix}/lib/node_modules/</code>, which is owned by root (where <code>{prefix}</code> is usually <code>/usr/</code> or <code>/usr/local</code>). This means you would have to use <code>sudo</code> to install packages globally, which could cause permission errors when resolving third-party dependencies, as well as being a security concern.</p> \n<p>Let’s change that!</p> \n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://dab1nmslvvntp.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/1426064914package_manager-1024x682.jpg\" alt=\"Parcel delivery company\" />\n <figcaption \"=\"\">\n  Time to manage those packages\n </figcaption>\n</figure> \n<h2 id=\"changingthelocationofglobalpackages\">Changing the Location of Global Packages</h2> \n<p>Let’s see what output <code>npm config</code> gives us:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ npm config list\n; cli configs\nmetrics-registry = \"https://registry.npmjs.org/\"\nscope = \"\"\nuser-agent = \"npm/6.13.7 node/v12.15.0 linux x64\"\n\n; node bin location = /usr/bin/nodejs\n; cwd = /home/sitepoint\n; HOME = /home/sitepoint\n; \"npm config ls -l\" to show all defaults.\n</code></pre> \n<p>This gives us information about our install. For now, it’s important to get the current global location:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ npm config get prefix\n/usr\n</code></pre> \n<p>This is the prefix we want to change, in order to install global packages in our home directory. To do that create a new directory in your home folder:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ cd ~ &amp;&amp; mkdir .node_modules_global\n$ npm config set prefix=$HOME/.node_modules_global\n</code></pre> \n<p>With this simple configuration change, we’ve altered the location to which global Node packages are installed. This also creates a <code>.npmrc</code> file in our home directory:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ npm config get prefix\n/home/sitepoint/.node_modules_global\n$ cat .npmrc\nprefix=/home/sitepoint/.node_modules_global\n</code></pre> \n<p>We still have npm installed in a location owned by root. But because we changed our global package location, we can take advantage of that. We need to install npm again, but this time in the new, user-owned location. This will also install the latest version of npm:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">npm install npm@latest -g\n</code></pre> \n<p>Finally, we need to add <code>.node_modules_global/bin</code> to our <code>$PATH</code> environment variable, so that we can run global packages from the command line. Do this by appending the following line to your <code>.profile</code>, <code>.bash_profile</code>or <code>.bashrc</code> and restarting your terminal:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">export PATH=\"$HOME/.node_modules_global/bin:$PATH\"\n</code></pre> \n<p>Now our <code>.node_modules_global/bin</code> will be found first and the correct version of npm will be used:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ which npm\n/home/sitepoint/.node_modules_global/bin/npm\n$ npm --version\n6.13.7\n</code></pre> \n<p><em>Tip: you can avoid all of this if you use a Node version manager. Check out this tutorial to find out how: <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/quick-tip-multiple-versions-node-nvm/\">Installing Multiple Versions of Node.js Using nvm</a>.</em></p> \n<h2 id=\"installingpackagesinglobalmode\">Installing Packages in Global Mode</h2> \n<p>At the moment, we only have one package installed globally — the npm package itself. So let’s change that and install <a href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/uglify-js\">UglifyJS</a> (a JavaScript minification tool). We use the <code>--global</code> flag, but this can be abbreviated to <code>-g</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ npm install uglify-js --global\n/home/sitepoint/.node_modules_global/bin/uglifyjs -&gt; /home/sitepoint/.node_modules_global/lib/node_modules/uglify-js/bin/uglifyjs\n+ uglify-js@3.7.7\nadded 3 packages from 38 contributors in 0.259s\n</code></pre> \n<p>As you can see from the output, additional packages are installed. These are UglifyJS’s dependencies.</p> \n<h2 id=\"listingglobalpackages\">Listing Global Packages</h2> \n<p>We can list the global packages we’ve installed with the <code>npm list</code> command:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ npm list --global\nhome/sitepoint/.node_modules_global/lib\n├─┬ npm@6.9.0\n│ ├── abbrev@1.1.1\n│ ├── ansicolors@0.3.2\n│ ├── ansistyles@0.1.3\n│ ├── aproba@2.0.0\n│ ├── archy@1.0.0\n....................\n└─┬ uglify-js@3.5.3\n  ├── commander@2.19.0\n  └── source-map@0.6.1\n</code></pre> \n<p>The output, however, is rather verbose. We can change that with the <code>--depth=0</code> option:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ npm list -g --depth=0\n/home/sitepoint/.node_modules_global/lib\n├── npm@6.13.7\n└── uglify-js@3.7.7\n</code></pre> \n<p>That’s better; now we see just the packages we’ve installed along with their version numbers.</p> \n<p>Any packages installed globally will become available from the command line. For example, here’s how you would use the Uglify package to minify <code>example.js</code> into <code>example.min.js</code>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ uglifyjs example.js -o example.min.js\n</code></pre> \n<h2 id=\"installingpackagesinlocalmode\">Installing Packages in Local Mode</h2> \n<p>When you install packages locally, you normally do so using a <code>package.json</code> file. Let’s go ahead and create one:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ mkdir project &amp;&amp; cd project\n\n$ npm init\npackage name: (project)\nversion: (1.0.0)\ndescription: Demo of package.json\nentry point: (index.js)\ntest command:\ngit repository:\nkeywords:\nauthor:\nlicense: (ISC)\n</code></pre> \n<p>Press <kbd>Return</kbd> to accept the defaults, then press it again to confirm your choices. This will create a <code>package.json</code> file at the root of the project:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  \"name\": \"project\",\n  \"version\": \"1.0.0\",\n  \"description\": \"\",\n  \"main\": \"index.js\",\n  \"scripts\": {\n    \"test\": \"echo \\\"Error: no test specified\\\" &amp;&amp; exit 1\"\n  },\n  \"author\": \"\",\n  \"license\": \"ISC\"\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p><em>Tip: If you want a quicker way to generate a <code>package.json</code> file use <code>npm init --y</code>.</em></p> \n<p>The fields are hopefully pretty self-explanatory, with the exception of <code>main</code> and <code>scripts</code>. The <code>main</code> field is the primary entry point to your program, and the <code>scripts</code> field lets you specify script commands that are run at various times in the life cycle of your package. We can leave these as they are for now, but if you’d like to find out more, see the <a href=\"https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json\">package.json documentation on npm</a> and this article on <a href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/guide-to-npm-as-a-build-tool/\">using npm as a build tool</a>.</p> \n<p>Now let’s try and install <a href=\"http://underscorejs.org/\">Underscore</a>:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"bash language-bash\">$ npm install underscore\nnpm notice created a lockfile as package-lock.json. You should commit this file.\nnpm WARN project@1.0.0 No repository field.\n\n+ underscore@1.9.2\nadded 1 package from 1 contributor and audited 1 package in 0.412s\nfound 0 vulnerabilities\n</code></pre> \n<p><em>Note that a lockfile is created. We’ll be coming back to this later.</em></p> \n<p>Now if we have a look in <code>package.json</code>, we’ll see that a <code>dependencies</code> field has been added:</p> \n<pre><code class=\"javascript language-javascript\">{\n  ...\n  \"dependencies\": {\n    \"underscore\": \"^1.9.2\"\n  }\n}\n</code></pre> \n<p> Continue reading <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com/beginners-guide-node-package-manager/?utm_source=rss\">A Beginner’s Guide to npm, the Node Package Manager</a> on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sitepoint.com\">SitePoint</a>. </p>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=tb6a7jv_MiY:WoxI1ddprjI:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?a=tb6a7jv_MiY:WoxI1ddprjI:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/SitepointFeed?i=tb6a7jv_MiY:WoxI1ddprjI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/SitepointFeed/~4/tb6a7jv_MiY\"
